article_title: ... And St. Louis Loves Dem Filipinos

photos.desc: Dulaang UP’s …And St. Louis Loves Dem Filipinos, UP Diliman, 1992 (Nilo Odiaman, Dulaang UP Collection)
Dulaang UP’s St. Louis Loves Dem Filipinos UP Diliman, 2005 (Erik Liongoren, Dulaang UP Collection)

text:
1992. Three-act play in Filipino. Direction, Tony Mabesa. Script, Floy Quintos. Cast: Joel Lamangan/Ronnie Lazaro (Bulan), Ogie Juliano (Dean Worcester), Amiel Leonardia (Prof Gustavo Niederlein), Cesar Xerez Burgos (Clarence Edwards), Mario O’Hara/Crispin Pineda (Bontoc Chief Antonio), Rolando Tinio/Joel Saracho (Pedro Paterno), Ishmael Bernal/Abdel Langit/Lu Decenteceo (Dr Leon Ma. Guerrero), Eduardo Guzman (Fred Tinawid), Lani Sumalinog, Eugene Domingo, Margarita Yulo Gomez, Alya Honasan, Marissa Sanchez, and Sonny Damask. First staged by Dulaang Unibersidad ng Pilipinas (DUP) at the Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero Theater in UP Diliman, it was restaged in 1998 under the direction of Quintos. The play was also featured in Cultural Center of the Philippines National Theater Festival and was toured in universities of Southern Philippines. The script was published in The Likhaan Book of Philippine Drama 1991-1996: From Page to Stage, 2000.

Quintos later wrote the libretto for its musical version, titled St. Louis Loves Dem Filipinos, 2005; direction, Alexander Cortez; production design, Tuxqs Rutaquio; lighting design, Voltaire de Jesus; sound design, Jethro Joaquin; original score, Antonio Africa; additional ethnic music, Kontemporaryong Gamelan Pilipino; choral direction, Joel Aquino; choreography, Dexter Santos; ethnic dance choreography, Jhordan Cruz; martial arts choreography, Nathan Dominguez; vocal coach, Leslie Diaz; accent coach, Richard Cunanan; video, Winter David; research, Sir Anril Tiatco; production management, Rosario Mae Quinto; stage management, Mia Bautista; technical direction, John Carlo Pagunaling. Cast: Miguel Castro/Arnold Reyes (Bulan), Jake Macapagal/Irra Cenina (Fred Tinawid), Raffy Tejada/Donato G. Karingal (Antonio), Katrina Saporsantos/Agnes Barredo (Maude), Mae Ann Valentin (Momayon), Leo Rialp (Niederlein), James Gregory Paolelli (Edwards), Richard Cunanan (Worcester), Ronan Capinding (Gramps Alfredo), Leslie Diaz (Guerrero), Bong Embile Jr (Paterno), Bon Vibar, Kenneth Cataylo, and Christopher Alvero

 

The play chronicles the journey of Bulan, a Bagobo magani (chief warrior), from the mountains of Davao to America. His story is retold by Filipino-American Fred Tinawid through the memory of his grandfather, Gramps Alfredo, a migrant worker in the United States (US) from Ilocos. In act 1, Dean Worcester and Gen Clarence Edwards are introduced as representatives of the US Philippine Commission looking for “specimens” for the 1904 Saint Louis Exposition of US colonies. German scientist Prof Gustavo Niederlein shows he has a pure heart for the natives while members of the Philippine Exhibit Committee, Dr Leon Ma. Guerrero and Pedro Paterno, express their opposition to sending tribal folks to Missouri. Christianized Bontoc chief Antonio accepts America’s offer to the Igorot community to show off their dog-eating tradition for a fee of 380 dollars per month. More than the promise of wealth, Bulan is enticed to “do something great” by reaching a faraway land. On board the boat going to America, Bulan quickly learns English, and meets Antonio and the kind Prof Niederlein. During their travel by sea, Bulan’s wife, Momayon, dies of smallpox.

Act 2 presents the events in the June fair that features the Philippine Exposition. Pres Theodore Roosevelt declares that America loves Filipinos, yet does not recognize Bulan as a leader. Paterno resigns from his post in protest against the discrimination toward the natives, while Worcester lectures that self-reconstruction is the key to acceptance in the imperial land. As seasons pass, Antonio and his tribe become popular as the “savages” who need to be civilized. Observing the growing disillusionment of Bulan, Fred shares his thoughts about the Filipino natives’ loss of identity. In one show, Bulan trades off his Magani dress and head scarf for Salvation Army rags. Meanwhile, he develops a close friendship with Maude, the fat lady of the circus. By December, the fair closes and the colonial natives are told to head home. However, Bulan jumps ship to pursue his love for Maude and his dream in America.

 

In act 3, the exploits of Worcester in the Cordilleras are exposed in the editorial “Aves de Rapiña” (Birds of Prey) in El Renacimiento, 1908. Without documents chronicling what happens to Bulan thereafter, Fred imagines Bulan’s life post-fair, including his acceptance to the circus as Madam Maude’s prop in the act “Madam Maude and Her Apeman.” Later, she dumps him when the show is no longer popular and as racism heightens. For 10 years, Bulan bravely travels across the foreign land alone; reduced from a chief to a pauper. Alfredo feels Bulan’s hardship as he shares his own story as a young migrant laborer. Alfredo would also encounter the old Niederlein who confesses that it was a great mistake to uproot the natives. Niederlein hands him Bulan’s head scarf in hopes that it will be returned to the chief for his “reconstruction.” By 1935, Quezon’s Repatriation Act mandates the “free” return of Filipino natives to their homeland. Alfredo, who now heads the labor union in Seattle, convinces the crowd of Filipinos to take advantage of the act. But they fear the possibility of being forbidden to reenter the United States. On the other hand, Bulan, who is in the crowd, looks up to the horizon hoping to be repatriated. Alfredo recognizes him as the Bagobo chief whom Niederlein was searching for. He then hands him his head scarf, symbol of nobility and bravery.

The play reexamines the American “benevolence” to the Philippines. While it presents a tragic experience of a native chief who genuinely desires greatness for his people during the American occupation, it also shows the people’s resiliency and strong determination to create their identity as a self-reliant homeland. The play provides insights into the prevailing Filipino diaspora, as well as the Filipino nationalism amidst colonial/slave mentality. While the straight play was, for Quintos, “political, issue-oriented, even didactic,” the musical, according to Cortez, takes on a more “intimate, more human approach.  Written by Joanna Lerio and Carlo Pacolor Garcia

text:
(Abadeja: Our Own Cinderella). 1977. Puppet play in Filipino. Script and direction, Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio; original music, Felipe M. de Leon Jr; puppet design, Rafael del Casal and Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio; set design, Rafael del Casal; lighting design, Edgardo Avila, Ruth Pambid, Audie San Juan, and Nona Unas; puppeteers, Noel Alejandro, Susan Princesa, Victor Antonio, Susanna Querubin, Angelito Muñoz, Rosario Rodrigo, Cristina Gosalvez, Alex Ocampo, Pia Bediones, Rene Agbayani, Fe Corazon Ramos, Dominador Obligacion Jr, Nacefera Jarales, Francis Quimpo, Leonila Marcelina, and Armando Sta. Ana; vocal cast, Cristina Gosalvez, Alexander Cortez, Antonio Mabesa, Monnette E. Alfon, Antonio Santos, Fe Corazon Ramos, Susanna Querubin, Ma. Lourdes Cayabyab, Edgardo Crisol, Douglas Nierras, Esperanza Tinio, Herman Escueta, Lou Veloso, Joy Sababan, Victor Antonio, Jorge Hernandez, Noel Alejandro, Jun Farin, Bien Fernandez, and Victor Antonio. First staged by Dulaang Unibersidad ng Pilipinas (DUP) on 12 Dec 1977 at the Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero Theater in UP Diliman.

 

This puppet play derives its story from a Leyte folktale. Abadeja is an orphan whose father, Abac, married the wicked Concha, who has two daughters, Conchinita and Conchiching. Envious of her beauty, Abadeja’s stepfamily make life difficult for her, giving her impossible tasks and threatening her with banishment. However, with the help of a magical fish-friend, she performs wondrous feats. The stepsisters capture the magical fish and cook it. When Abadeja sadly buries its remains, a magical lady appears and gives her a colorful cock, which soon suffers the fate of the fish. The lady assures Abadeja that if she buries the cock’s feathers and feet, and waters the spot on the third day, a wonderful gift awaits her. At this point she meets a handsome man, who introduces himself as Itoy, but is actually Principe Destrito (Prince Destrito) of the royal family. They fall in love. The buried remains of the cock bloom into a jewel-bearing tree. Only Abadeja can pluck the jewels, and only to help the poor or needy. When she impulsively picks a ring and gives it to Itoy, he suffers from a painful swollen finger, because the ring was meant for other purposes. Hari Destro (King Destro) and Reyna Destra (Queen Destra) are told by a herbolaryo (native healer) that only a lady with a pure, loving heart can get the ring off. The royal family visits every household, seeking that woman, and finally come to Abac’s house. Concha presents her daughters, who cannot remove the ring. When Abadeja is presented, she and Itoy recognize each other. Abadeja removes the ring, curing the prince’s finger instantly. The king and queen ordain that they should be married, and rule the kingdom. The magical lady scolds Abac for having neglected his daughter and given her to the abuse of his wife. Abac turns on his wife and daughters, who beg forgiveness.

The play, which now forms part of the repertoire of the Teatrong Mulat ng Pilipinas, is one of the first in the country to tell a folktale through puppets. It inspired the movement to reorient the values of Filipino children through the use of folklore as theater.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis

 

Source

Dulaang UP (Unibersidad ng Pilipinas). 1977. Abadeja: Ang Ating Sinderela. Souvenir program.

photos.desc: Villa de Bacolor Cultural, Literary and Civic Foundation’s Alang Dios!, 1975 (Lino Sanchez, photo courtesy of Carmen Cochon)

text:
(There Is No God!). 1902. Sarsuwela in two acts, in Kapampangan. Libretto: Juan Crisostomo Soto aka Crissot. Music: Pablo Palma • Cast: Catalina Carreon, Carlos Perez, Pedro Punsalan, Ignacio Navarro, Carmen Alfaro, and Mariana Munkal. First performed on 16 Nov 1902 at Teatro Sabina in Bacolor, Pampanga. It has been staged many times since then, once at the Teatro Zorrilla in Manila where it was reported to have been given a standing ovation. It was revived on 31 May 1975 by the Villa de Bacolor Cultural, Literary and Civic Foundation at the Cultural Center of the Philippines.

 

Enrique, a poor painter, is released from prison for the alleged theft of a diamond crucifix belonging to his sweetheart Maria Luz, the daughter of wealthy Don Andres. Upon his return to his hometown, he learns of the impending marriage between Maria Luz and Ramon, the son of a wealthy family. Angered by the apparent unfaithfulness of Maria Luz, he decides to leave town. A tearful Maria Luz pleads with him, saying that she consented to the marriage only under pressure from Doña Cucang, her ambitious stepmother. Enrique refuses to believe her and Maria Luz is forced to proceed with the wedding. Bothered by her conscience, Clara, Maria Luz’s maid, confesses the truth to Enrique. On the night of the alleged theft, she had seen Enrique leaving the house after a secret rendezvous with Maria Luz. Wishing to protect the reputation of her mistress, she had stolen the diamond crucifix to make it appear that Enrique was there as a thief rather than as a lover. Clara’s confession, however, comes too late to prevent the marriage of Maria Luz and Ramon. A family friend, Don Monico, succeeds in preventing Enrique and Ramon from fighting by revealing to them that they are really half-brothers. Now reconciled, they return home to find that Maria Luz has died. They exclaim, “There is no God!” but are reproved by Don Monico. Repentant, they affirm that there is after all a God who rewards the good and punishes the bad.

While critics have nominated other plays of Crissot as his masterpiece, Alang Dios! remains popular because of its grandiloquence. There are lines in the play whose sheer eloquence has remained unsurpassed in Pampango drama. The beauty of the lyrics is complemented by the music score. The memorable songs in the sarsuwela have proven to be so popular that they have virtually assumed the status of folk songs among the Pampango.  Written by Edna Z. Manlapaz

 

Sources

Aguas, Juan S. 1963. Juan Crisostomo Soto and Pampangan Drama. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press

Manlapaz, Edna Zapanta, ed. 1975. Aurelio Tolentino: Selected Writings. Quezon City: University of the Philippines.
———. 1981. Kapampangan Literature, A Historical Survey and Anthology. Quezon City: Ateneo University Press.

photos.desc: UP Anak Tibawan’s Alipato, featuring Pacita Gavino and Bernardo Bernardo, 1975 (CCP Collection)

text:
(Spark). 1975. Three-act play in Filipino. Direction, Jonas Sebastian; script, Nonilon Queaño; set design, Ma. Corazon Alejo; costume design, Lea A. Igaya; lighting design, Jun Gomez. Cast: Obet Lumba, Pacita Gavino, Jess Calixto, Myrna Soriente, Alex Gonzales, Rene Arambulo, Egai Alcantara, Diana Libunao, Lourdes Delingon, Rosette Buenaventura, Vicky Magno, Boyet Subida, Rene Sison, Bopeep Bonus, Benjie Somera, Danny Jocson, Gerard Borrero, and Donna Borrero. As one of the plays that won in the Palihang Aurelio Tolentino Playwriting Workshop, it was first staged by the University of the Philippines (UP) Anak-Tibawan on 24 Aug 1975 at the Abelardo Hall, UP Diliman. It was restaged by Anak-Tibawan in Feb 1976 at Pius XII Auditorium, and again in Apr 1976 at the UP College Baguio, with Bernardo C. Bernardo taking over as lead actor and set designer. During rehearsals in 1975, it underwent several revisions in consultation with the director. Then in 1976, the play garnered first prize in the three-act play category at the Palanca Memorial Literary Contest, and was published in The Literary Apprentice, 1976-77.

 

Alipato depicts urban poverty at its worst as it dramatizes the travails of a community living beside mountains of garbage in a dump site in Tondo. Bino, Mana, and their son Sinto are the play’s central family. Their neighbors are forced to beg and steal in order to survive. Lukas, Bino’s older brother who is jobless because he is unskilled, drowns his misery in alcohol. Lala, the prostitute, searches for love but finds it too late. When two landless peasants who migrated to the city resort to suicide in desperation, their children are hauled off to orphanages, except for Karda who finds employment as a waitress but is subsequently raped. Iling-Iling, a 45-year-old retardate of unknown background, wanders around as mute witness to suffering and tragedy in a setting made more ominous by the intermittent hooting of an unseen owl. A gang of extortionists calling themselves the pederasyon (federation) continually harasses with impunity the helpless beggars and sidewalk vendors. Refusing to die in defeat or cower in subservience, Bino forsakes family and home, and secretly joins a band that steals from the rich to give to the poor as a solution to the miseries of his community. His death at play’s end serves as the alipato, the spark that starts a fire of indignant revolutionary fervor at Barrio Labak.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis, updated by Ronel O. Laranjo

When two landless peasants who migrated to the city resort to suicide in desperation, their children are hauled off to orphanages, except for Karda who finds employment as a waitress but is subsequently raped. Iling-Iling, a 45-year-old retardate of unknown background, wanders around as mute witness to suffering and tragedy in a setting made more ominous by the intermittent hooting of an unseen owl. A gang of extortionists calling themselves the pederasyon (federation) continually harasses with impunity the helpless beggars and sidewalk vendors. Refusing to die in defeat or cower in subservience, Bino forsakes family and home, and secretly joins a band that steals from the rich to give to the poor as a solution to the miseries of his community. His death at play’s end serves as the alipato, the spark that starts a fire of indignant revolutionary fervor at Barrio Labak.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis, updated by Ronel O. Laranjo

article_title: Anak ng Dagat, Silay ng Liwanag

photos.desc: (Courtesy of Nicanor G. Tiongson)

text:
(Child of the Sea, Ray of Light). 1921. Sarsuwela in three acts with prologue, in Filipino. Libretto, Patricio Mariano; music, Bonifacio Abdon. First staged on 14 Dec 1921 at the Teatro Zorrilla, Manila, and published in Manila by Roberto Martinez and Sons, 1951.

The “Pasimula” (Prologue) opens on a beach buffeted by strong waves. Mang Berong comes out of the stormy sea, from which he has saved a four-year-old child.

Act 1 opens with fishers singing about their life and work. Among them is Nene, Mang Berong’s ward, now a young girl selling kakanin (native cakes). She is being courted by Carlos, a poet, and surrounded by friends: Sipa, Kosme, Tonyo, and Kolodyo. Don Mariano enters, looking for Nene, the daughter he has been seeking for 13 years and whom he identifies by a mark. Nene tearfully welcomes her long-lost father.

 

In act 2, Nene is taken by Don Mariano to his home in the city, and her friends talk of its marvels: thick carpets and a bath of marble in which a gadget brings indoor rain. Nene arrives, dries Mang Berong’s tears, and lovingly remembers her childhood with him. There is a comic interlude between Kolodyo and Carriton, the son of her father’s friend Fernando and to whom Don Mariano has promised Nene’s hand in marriage. Carriton, who has the arrogance and accent of a Spanish friar, meets his match in Kolodyo.

In act 3, which is set in Don Mariano’s luxurious house, Nene overhears Carlos telling Kolodyo why he has stayed away: he does not want people to think that he is attracted to Nene because of her wealth. She confronts Carlos and asks him to take her back to the barrio by the sea. Berong meanwhile makes Don Mariano understand that it is Nene’s happiness that matters. Don Mariano terminates his agreement with Fernando. He announces that in order that Nene would always remain technically poor, he is leaving his wealth to Carlos for their children to inherit.

Probably the most famous of Mariano’s plays, Anak ng Dagat is a rare sarsuwela because it is written in verse. Moreover, its verse is one of the most lyrically romantic in Philippine theater.   Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

text:
(Anatomy of Corruption). 1992. Three-act play in Filipino. Direction, Dennis Marasigan; script, Malou Leviste Jacob; set design, Ricardo Cruz; lighting design, Shax Siasoco. Cast: Irma Adlawan-Marasigan (Cely Martinez), John Arcilla (Ric), Madeleine Nicolas (Charing), Herbie Go (Loret), RJ Leyran (Bok), Tito Tesoro (Judge), Peaches Gallegos, Olga Natividad, Garry Lim, Len Ag Santos, and Ony de Leon. First staged on 6-22 Nov 1992 by Tanghalang Pilipino as part of the company’s sixth season offering at the Tanghalang Huseng Batute of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). For a few times, the production was played in actual government offices. Tanghalang Pilipino restaged the play at the CCP in 1998 and 2002. In 2003, the outreach program of the CCP commissioned translations of the play into several regional languages—such as Ilocano, Cebuano, and Hiligaynon—and mounted productions in major cities in the regions for regional theater groups. The production inspired a CCP radio program, and was turned to a film with the same title in 2011, with Dennis Marasigan also as director. The script is included in Jacob’s collection of plays, titled Teatro Pulitikal (Political Theater), 1994.

Set in a government office in the 1980s, act 1 begins on Cely Martinez’s first day in her new job as a hearing officer in a family court. She is hopeful that this will finally become her permanent job. Before this, she had floated from one office to another because she could not accept the crooked practices in the workplace.

 

The janitor Loret is having problems opening the lock of the door, a portent of things to come. Led by senior lawyer Ric, the rest of the staff and the attorneys arrive, including Bok, the court stenographer who masterly executes under the table deals and maneuvers. The judge enters using the back entrance. The last to enter is Cely who is late because she got stuck in the elevator of the building. That same day, Cely’s remarkable speed, skill, and acumen in handling two cases—an extrajudicial case of child support and a pretrial case of dissolution of conjugal property—mark her as a force that would cut the “extra income” of the office. Bok, who has been spying on her, explodes because the family court’s new hearing officer refuses to accept “envelopes.”

Act 2 opens with a confrontation scene between Bok and Cely. Bok deliberately misplaces Cely’s decision papers on the Claveria adoption case. With its location unknown, the messenger timely arrives to pick up the papers. The conflict escalates when the senior lawyer Ric strongly advises Cely to approve a marriage annulment case. Ric had already accepted three goats and a promise of bigger rewards should the annulment be granted by the court. Cely declares she cannot circumvent the law in this case. With tensions reaching the boiling point and the Claveria decision papers still missing, an internal meeting of the office staff with the judge is called. Cely thinks Charing and May would testify to the irregularities and anomalies going on in the office, but in the meeting the employees remain silent. The judge requests Ric to take over and Cely to take the afternoon off. Cely is hysterical. The phone rings and she learns her sick mother just suffered a stroke.

Act 3 is set in the office right before the Christmas party. Ric gives Cely an ultimatum: play the game of justice by their rules or leave. In the epilogue, during the Christmas party, Cely is seen isolated from everybody else. Toward the end, she delivers a short monologue about her career, and about how difficult it is to fight the system by herself. Nobody is interested in joining her. Taking a last look at everybody else enjoying the party, she addresses the memory of her beloved father, and sees only a dead end. Nobody notices her leaving.

Realist in conception, worldview, and execution, the play dramatizes the clash between an honest and principled lawyer and the prevalent system of lagay (bribes) and commissions entrenched in a dilapidated, cramped, and outdated government office.  Written by Apolonio B. Chua

 

Sources

Guerrero, Amadis Ma. 2012. Tanghalang Pilipino: Celebrating 25 Years of Philippine Theater. Pasay City: Artpostasia and Tanghalang Pilipino.

Jacob, Malou L. 1978. 1992. Anatomiya ng Korupsyon Production Book. Tanghalang Pilipino Special Collection. Cultural Center of the Philippines.
———. 1994. Teatro Pulitikal. Manila: De La Salle University Press.

article_title: Andres Bonifacio, Ang Dakilang Anakpawis (see Music Volume.)
text:
(Andres Bonifacio, The Great Plebeian). 1979. Music and musical direction, Jerry A. Dadap; libretto, Jerry A. Dadap, Paulino Capitulo, Rogelio Mangahas, and Dionisio Salazar; stage direction, Tony Espejo; choreography, Gener Caringal; set design, Salvador Bernal; costume design, Warto Torrevillas; lighting design, Monino Duque.

Commissioned by the Manila Bankers Life Insurance Corporation and the Loyola Group of Companies. First performed on 16 Nov 1979 at the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, Cultural Center of the Philippines. Cast: Elmo Makil, Jay Valencia-Glorioso, Tommy Abuel, and 200 other performers.

Based on Teodoro Agoncillo’s Revolt of the Masses, the three-hour, five-act opera closely follows the life of Andres Bonifacio from his early days as the breadwinner for his orphaned brothers and sisters, to his marriage to Gregoria de Jesus, his involvement with La Liga Filipina, and his leadership of the Katipunan. He leads several successful battles against the Spanish army. However, two factions develop within the movement: the Magdiwang faction of Andres Bonifacio based in Manila, and the Magdalo faction of General Emilio Aguinaldo based in Cavite. In the climactic Tejeros Convention in Cavite, Bonifacio is grilled by the Magdalo faction who finds him “unworthy” of a position in the movement. Appalled, he leaves the convention with his followers. They are later arrested by Aguinaldo’s soldiers. After a mock trial, Bonifacio and his brother Procopio are brought to Mount Buntis where they face their execution with dignity.

Dadap used period music such as the danza and marcha. Indigenous instruments, like the kalatong, a pair of sticks which warns people of an impending attack, was also employed.

Between 1979 to 1992, the piece was staged around 150 times, from Lagaue, Mountain Province, to Zamboanga City. It was restaged at the University of the Philippines College of Music (UPCM) Abelardo Hall Auditorium in Sep 2013 in celebration of Abelardo Hall’s 50th anniversary and Andres Bonifacio’s 150th birth anniversary. The 2013 production was directed by Alegria O. Ferrer and featured UP College of Music alumni and students with Jerry Dadap’s Andres Bonifacio Concert Choir (ABCC). ABCC performed it again with the conductor himself directing at the Saint Scholastica’s College Manila in Nov 2013 and at the GSIS Theater, CCP Complex, Pasay City with the Manila Symphony Orchestra (MSO) conducted by Arturo Molina in Nov 2014. Another GSIS Theater version with the MSO and RTU Tunog Rizalia Rondalla was performed in 2015.  Written by Antonio C. Hila, updated by Josephine Cecilia L. Baradas

text:
(Anti-Christ). 1976. One-act play in Bikol. Script, Justino Nuyda. Written in 1910, it was first staged in 1976 at the University Theater of the University of the Philippines (UP) in Diliman, Quezon City, during UP’s first Folk Drama Festival with Meriem Rodriguez-Palacio in the lead role. It was published in the Bikol original with an English translation in Maria Lilia F. Realubit’s The Bicol Dramatic Tradition, Philippine Social Sciences and Humanities Review, 1976, and in Philippine Drama: Twelve Plays in Six Philippine Languages, 1987.

 

Written in Camalig, Albay, this short, seriocomic play is set in the convento or parish house of the cura (parish priest), Fray Agusting. The friar sits beside Felixberta, the daughter of Bernabela, on the pretext of teaching her the catechism. When he tries to take advantage of her, the girl becomes apprehensive. “Marry someone rich and good-looking like me,” the priest says, “and not that coarse and stupid Kalatiyo who does not even know how to pray.” Felixberta answers: “What good shall money and wealth bring if I become enslaved to them? I shall be happier with a poor man who can give me peace.” The priest is furious. He gives her 10 minutes to decide. Felixberta refuses him and he threatens to kill her. The priest forces her to submit. A scuffle ensues and the girl stabs him in the chest. The assistant comes in, sees the dead priest and runs out. Bernabela rushes in, and asks: “My child, why have you tampered with God’s emissary?” Felixberta, fearless and composed, replies: “It is not his priesthood that I avenged, but his iniquity … For his profligacy on our Filipino women, he has proved himself to be the antithesis of Christ—the Anti-Cristo!”

The play was probably not staged at the time it was written, for its performance would have cost Nuyda his life and property. Albay was then still under the power and influence of the Spanish frailes (friars). The play was discovered only when research was conducted by the UP System Integrated Research Program on Philippine Drama: Twelve Plays in Six Philippine Languages, 1987. It has been staged at UP and in Naga City several times.  Written by Maria Lilia F. Realubit

text:
(The Art of Poetry). 2005. One-act play in Filipino. Direction, set design, and sound design, Robert Arlo de Guzman; script, Chris Martinez and Eugene Y. Evasco. Cast: Soliman Cruz (Amador Sta. Romana) and Cris Pasturan (Lloyd Bobadilla).First staged on 9 Jun 2005 at the Tanghalang Huseng Batute of the Cultural Center of the Philippines. It was part of the Virgin Labfest 1 presented by The Writer’s Bloc and the Tanghalang Pilipino Actors Company. The play was restaged in 2006 as one of the two plays from Virgin Labfest 1.

The play takes place in the room of Amador Sta. Romana, a creative writing professor and seasoned poet.Lloyd Bobadilla, Amador’s student, is tied securely to a seat, except for his arms, allowing him to freely employ his hands on a typewriter. Amador threatens Lloyd with a gun to create a poem. Lloyd negotiates that for each stanza he finishes, he gets a cup of coffee, a cigarette, or music in return. Every time Lloyd finishes a line in his poem, Amador comments on how amateur Lloyd’s writing style is. Lloyd answers back, commenting on Amador’s old writing style. Before long, envy and their dislike for each other consume both writers. Amador recounts his literary history, pointing out every achievement he has earned. Lloyd recalls how he has won five literary competitions, beating his professor. The professor and the protégé compare how they search for their muses. Together, they pin down elusive words on the typewriter, still competing for literary superiority. Finally, Lloyd finishes his poem. Amador reads each stanza, tears the paper, and feeds it to Lloyd until the latter chokes to death. Amador begins to type on the machine and writes his own poem.

 

Ars Poetica exploresthe writers’ strugglebetween the traditional and the modern as if they are exclusive and contradictory. The all-white production design and the music played during the reading of poems are used toexpress the fusion between tradition, as a practical evolution that suggests fresh truths, and modernity, as an acceptance of new ideas. Together, tradition and modernity arebalancedand benefit each other. In 2001,the script won the grand prize in the National Commission for Culture and the Arts’ Timpalak Teatro Bulawan. Written by Olivia Nieto

text:
2008. Two-act play with music, in Filipino. Direction, Alexander Cortez ; script, Floy Quintos; scenic and costume design, Tuxqs Rutaquio; costume design, Eric Pineda and Tuxqs Rutaquio; lights design, Luther Gumia; original score and arrangement, Von de Guzman; dramaturg, Sir Anril Tiatco; choreographer, Dexter M. Santos; choral master, Cholo C. Gino; video design, Winter David; sound design, Arkel Mendoza; photography, Jojit Lorenzo; musicians, Renato Lucas, Michelle Nicolasura, Noel de la Rosa, and Marz Taylan. Cast: Shamaine Centenera-Buencamino/Frances Makil-Ignacio (Atang de la Rama), Ayen Munji-Laurel/Kalila Aguilos (Gia Almonte), Mitoy Sta. Ana (Pres Manuel L. Quezon), Bituin Escalante/Jacinta Remulla (Katy de la Cruz), Teroy Guzman/Greg de Guzman (Gen Artemio Ricarte and Amado Hernandez), RJ Camangon (Jose Corazon de Jesus), Jerson Guiwa (Deogracias Rosario), Gelo Pascual/Arkel Mendoza (Rene), Paola Muñoz (Pastora), Ricky Ibe (Leon Ignacio), Hazel Maranan/Martha Sta. Barbara (Eveng), JC Santos, William Manzano, and Meynard Peñalosa. First staged on 26 Nov 2008 by Dulaang Unibersidad ng Pilipinas (DUP) at the Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero Theater in UP Diliman, it was restaged as part of UP’s Sarsuwela Festival in 2009 in line with the university’s centennial festivities. It was also published in Floy Quintos: Collected Plays Volume 2, 2011.

In act 1, Gia Almonte, a movie star, arrives at the de la Rama residence in Gagalangin, Tondo, and is welcomed by Rene and Eveng. text:
2002. One-act play in Filipino. Direction, Alexander C. Cortez; script, Chris Martinez. Cast: Mon Confiado (David), Melvin Lee (Naomi), and Jethro Patalinghug (Jonathan). First staged by the University of the Philippines (UP) Playwrights’ Theater in May 2002 at the Teatro Hermogenes Ylagan of UP Diliman, Quezon City. The script was anthologized in Ang Aklat Likhaan ng Dula 1997-2003: Kapangahasan bilang Kaligtasan (The Likhaan Book of Plays 1997-2003: Boldness as Redemption), 2006.

Baclofen comes from the name of a generic muscle relaxant and sedative, and also sounds similar to the term “bakla,” the Filipino term for “gay.”

 

The play begins a few minutes before midnight, inside the Femme Fatale Beauty Box. The owner of the gay parlor, Naomi, and lover David are playing cards as the TV blasts away the final notes of the Philippine National Anthem. Jonathan, Naomi’s houseboy and parlor assistant, enters, carrying bottles of beer. Their exchange reveals that David provides companionship for Naomi in exchange for money and things like tricycle parts and a Swiss Army knife. After a few exchanges of unfriendly banter, Naomi instructs Jonathan to buy isaw (grilled chicken or pork intestines) to go with the beer. Jonathan reluctantly exits. Naomi reveals that Jonathan has agreed to work for him to pay for the family’s debt. Jonathan returns with the food. Naomi leaves to take a bath, recalling that David prefers “women-smelling” partners. During Naomi’s absence, David starts seducing Jonathan. The seduction ends abruptly when Naomi returns. Naomi drinks his beer and asks for the newspaper that Jonathan is holding. Jonathan proceeds to stack towels, while Naomi reads to David a news article about an old man whose penis has been cut off. Before he finishes reading the article, Naomi collapses. From there, it is revealed that David and Jonathan are lovers, and that they have planned to drug Naomi with a strong dose of Baclofen and steal all of the parlor-owner’s money. As they recount the specific details of their plan, Jonathan confronts David about the latter’s fear of being identified as gay, as well as his inability to stand up for himself and their relationship. Naomi suddenly wakes up and, to his surprise, David pulls out his Swiss Army knife and stabs Naomi to death. David and Jonathan resume their argument. Jonathan insists on sticking to the initial plan that he would leave first to get Naomi’s money. Vehemently rejecting this suggestion, David soon realizes that Jonathan actually intends to leave him for good after they have split the money. The argument escalates into a brawl, knocking over the parlor’s manicure set. The much bigger David overpowers Jonathan. David pulls out his Swiss Army knife and is about to stab Jonathan, but he hesitates and cries, saying that he cannot kill him. David hugs Jonathan, crying. Jonathan comforts him, but slowly pulls out a nail pusher that he has picked up from the manicure set and repeatedly stabs David’s nape until he dies. Jonathan moves away from David’s dead body. Jonathan sits in front of the mirror, puts on heavy makeup and finishes off with a vibrant red lipstick. As the lights dim, Jonathan rehearses his high-pitched shrieks.

The staging of Baclofen, twin-billed with Rene O. Villanueva’s Dobol (Double), utilized a minimalist set which allowed the audience to focus on the play’s characters and dialogue. The play displayed an abundance of witty banter, dark humor, unexpected plot shifts, intertextual insertions from Filipino pop culture, and well-rounded Filipino characters with a strong local urban flavor. Cortez’s staging was faithful to Martinez’s detailed stage directions—from Jonathan’s tie-dye shirt to his transformation into the screaming victim. The intimate space of the Teatro Hermogenes Ylagan drew the audience closer to the fast-changing emotions of the play—from apathy to laughter, terror to desperation, madness to resignation. The play suggests a possible reading on the slippages of homosexual identity—the struggle to break free from labels and to desire beyond the oppressive confines of signification.  Written by Vladimeir B. Gonzales

text:
(The New Christ). 1907. Three-act play in Filipino. Script, Aurelio V. Tolentino. The script was published in Edna Z. Manlapaz’s Aurelio Tolentino: Selected Writings, 1975. The play was staged by the Dulaang Babaylan in 1977 at the San Sebastian College Auditorium, Manila, under the direction of Anton Juan Jr.

The author called the three-act play a drama socialista (socialist drama) and revista teatral (theatrical revue). The wealthy Magdangal asks why Jesus Gatbiaya has been invited to speak before a crowd. Cabesang Andoy (Cabeza Andoy) explains that when he had almost been expelled from his land, a few words from Jesus had won it back for him. He had pacified and converted many, which is why he had come to be called “Bagong Cristo.” Jesus is then shown speaking about the evils of gambling, inalienable rights, the sacred duties of citizens, the danger of fanaticism, the need for mercy and compassion, and just wages to workers. As a result, he arouses the anger of the landed Magdangal and Berto, and the abusive Frayle, who sells salvation through alms and candles. But he wins followers among the workers; the just, like Justo and Dimaliwat; the enlightened, like Doña Salud who devotes her wealth to helping workers on strike; the compassionate, like Neneng; and the oppressed, like Biheng. As a result, Bagong Cristo is mocked, slapped, then kidnapped by Limbas at the command of Magdangal, tortured and made to carry a post on which he would be crucified. At some point, his mother, Dolores, is made to bear the post. Jesus is almost killed. The play closes on a large Labor Day meeting, which the workers attend bearing banners saying “Mabuhay ang Bayang Obrero” (Long Live the Working Class), “Samahang Artes y Oficios” (Association of Arts and Trades), and others. Jesus Gatbiaya speaks about the unity of purpose among workers around the world, and is stabbed in the back by two men.

Bagong Kristo is one of the early attempts to reinterpret the Christ story according to contemporary conditions—a truly significant achievement at a time when no one dared to touch, let alone contemporize, the image of Christ as created by the dogmas of the Catholic Church. It is also significant because it is one of the very first proletarian plays written by a Filipino.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

 

Source

Manlapaz, Edna Zapanta, ed. 1975. Aurelio Tolentino: Selected Writings. Quezon City: University of the Philippines.

text:
1988. Monologue in Filipino. Direction, Grace Budac; script, Enrico Santos. Cast: Jon Santos. First produced in 1988 along with two other set pieces—namely, Reuel Aguila’s Alimuom (Steam of the Earth) and Chris Millado’s Babaing Itawis (Itawis Woman) from his full-length play Buwan at Baril sa E-flat Major (Moon and Gun in E-flat Major), comprising the trilogy staged by the Third World Theater Company for its first season’s offering. In the first quarter of 1988, the play had a total run of 54 performances.

The hilarious meeting of a nun, a young man, and a young woman happens in a seedy motel room in 1988 Manila. Sister Maria enters the room and comes upon Clement and Grace making love. Sister Maria thinks she is seeing an apparition until Clement recognizes her as his former catechism teacher in a Catholic school. The characters then talk about their life stories, which constitute a series of witty and outrageous scenes. Sister Maria as a young girl mistook her first menstruation as a form of stigmata. Grace the prostitute describes her life as an endless cycle of servicing customers, eating, and sleeping. Clement passes off his machismo as “that’s what balls are for.” The story comes to a close when Grace confesses she may have contracted AIDS from an American customer, which prompts Clement to wring her neck. But his murderous intention is foiled by a nail file Grace grabs to protect herself from the attack. Sister Maria intervenes and everyone tries to get hold of the nail file. In the end, they all vow to change their ways, and express their desire to go to Antipolo to bathe and cleanse themselves to prepare for a new life.

Bang-bang-alu is a hybrid theatrical piece, being a short stand-up comic act that can also be considered a one-act play. The concept and staging of the play are influenced by the popular doble-kara (two-face) performance style where male and female roles are acted out by a single actor, complete with appropriate lateral half-body costumes and makeup. Except that here the actor must also play a third character.

The Sister Maria character is inspired by a little-known off-Broadway play Sister Mary Ignatius Explains It All for You by Christopher Durang, but Bang-bang-alu ’s narrative structure and message remain original, showing how the Filipino psyche has been fragmented into three manifestations: the convent moralist (the nun), the innocent forced to face pragmatic realities (the young man), and the tainted sinner (the prostitute). Only by colliding can these fragments hope to be integrated. Despite the seemingly meandering banter of the plotless narrative and the repartees and monologues filled with ad-libs, double entendre, and non sequiturs, the play successfully delivers its satiric social commentaries on the lives of politicians, religious people, and common folk who are in the grip of dogma, bigotry, and colonial mentality.  Written by Romulo P. Baquiran Jr

text:
(Basilia of Malolos). 2007. Sarsuwela in two acts, in Filipino. Direction, Jose Estrella; script, Nicanor G. Tiongson; costume design, John Abul; set design, Ludendorffo Decenteceo; lighting design, John Ilao Batalla; music and musical direction, Joy Marfil; choreography, Dexter Santos; video, Melie Yamomo; sounds, Jon Lazam. Cast: Jenny Jamora/Natasha Garrucha (Basilia Tantoco), Nathasia Garrucha (Alberta Uitangcoy), Nikki Ventosa (Mercedes Tiongson), Felix Rivera (Miguel Maglaya), Leon Lorenzo Tuells (Lex Marcos), Diana Alferez (Ikang), Neil Ryan Sese (Teodoro Sandico), Belen Calingacion (Andeng Tantoco), Red Concepcion, Judith Javier, Rito Asilo, Carissa Cortez, Hazel Gutierrez, Hazel Grace Maranan, Papan Fetalvero, Maria Nieves Reyes, Mary Indalecio, Coreen Angelica Chan, William Manzano, Dax Carnay, and Adel Monteverde. This is the revised version with new music of the author’s earlier sarsuwela titled Las Malolenas (The Young Women of Malolos), which was staged by Armand Sta. Ana for the Barasoain Kalinangan Ensemble in 2005. This new version was staged by the University of the Philippines (UP) Playwrights’ Theater from 14 Feb to 11 Mar 2007 at the Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero Theater, UP Diliman.

 

From the last decades of the 19th century to the first decades of the 20th, Basilia Tantoco and the other women of Malolos struggle to assert themselves against two patriarchal overlords: the panginoong puti (white overlord) and the panginoong kayumanggi (brown overlord). Politicized by the reformists of Malolos, Basilia and her barkada (friendly gang) of female relatives successfully push for the opening of a school where they could learn Spanish, and in secret meet to discuss political ideas and actions. Gov-Gen Valeriano Weyler favors the school, but the friars of Malolos and Basilia’s arrogant Spanish suitor Leon Lorenzo Tuells—representing the religious and secular authorities of the colony and the patriarchy—do all they can to suppress what they correctly read as an antifriar move. However, the women get support from the reformists of Malolos, Basilia’s maid Ikang (a battered wife), the maestro de Latinidad Teodoro Sandico, and the latter’s friend and townmate Miguel Maglaya. Basilia and Miguel fall in love. But the crafty Leon manages to have Miguel put in jail while the friars close down the womens’s school after Sandico narrowly escapes arrest. text:
(The Children! The Children!). 2013. One-act play in Filipino. Script, Erick Dasig Aguilar; dramaturgy, Jose Jay Cruz; production management, Frances Santos; stage management, Jihad Mambuay; assistance in stage management, Ron Billete. Cast: Joan Bugcat, Alison Segarra/Frances Santos (Ningning), Terrie Martinez/Nex Agustin (Aya), Eric dela Cruz/Ian Lomongo (Roemart Randolph Deocareza), Joshua Lim So, Ron Billete, and Jihad Mambuay. First staged by Destiyero Theater Commune (DTC) on 17-20 Oct 2013 at the Fo Guang Shang Mabuhay Temple in Manila. The play was also mounted by DTC in the Karnabal: A Def. Defying Festival at the National Commission for Culture and the Arts lobby in Intramuros, Manila, on 23 Nov 2013, and in the MNL X: Festival of New Performances at the Tanghalang Huseng Batute of the Cultural Center of the Philippines on 23 Feb 2014.

For three days since the landslide brought about by a typhoon, Ningning and Aya have been roaming the muddy grounds as ghosts. They play around while searching for the body of Ningning, which Ningning herself claims to be buried right beneath them. While they are sad, they playfully converse about their memory of the typhoon, their families, and how they ended up as ethereal beings. From afar, they see a group of living people looking for bodies. They comment that the search team, which includes the soldiers, are searching in the wrong places and that their long rifles are inutile. They see survivors who are obviously in a state of shock and starvation, yet there is no food relief. They wonder what might have happened to their family members and relatives as they do not see them among the living and among them as ghosts. Ningning thinks that some may have gone with the crows, guardians of death, or have been blown away by the wind to a place of no return. They wonder whether other towns are also submerged in mud. As they continue to play and converse, a boy emerges from the ground. As in a Mr Pogi pageant competition, he rehearses and introduces himself as Roemart Randolph Deocareza. He is waiting for his father, as they are going to the dance in the plaza. He wonders why he cannot see the plaza anymore or their house. Roemart accuses Aya and Ningning of stealing his house and the plaza. Aya and Ningning try to console him. They make him understand that he is already dead, a fact which does not really surprise Roemart, who was buried alive for three days in a distorted position below ground surface. Ningning then reveals that her father was a logger who was accidentally killed by a falling tree. Aya comments that Roemart is just a sad child playfully inventing stories. Ningning responds that they, too, invent stories so they must be just as sad as Roemart. Aya says it is better to invent stories because it keeps them from despair. Roemart asks if the search team is going to where their bodies are located. Ningning comments that maybe their bodies need to really smell to be noticed. Roemart, fearing his body might not be found, goes to where the search team is. Ningning follows. Aya is left alone calling the names of her ghost friends.

 

The play was staged by DTC based on collective devising, improvisation, and site-specificity. The two main characters are alternately portrayed based on the available actors. The first staging utilized a pile of clothes in place of mud onstage. It also utilized sound bites from actual typhoon and news coverage. While the play is set in an anonymous local town, it tackles an experience of national impact as natural and man-made disasters have worsened and raised questions on accountability and resiliency.  Written by Joanna Lerio

text:
(Child Prostitute). 1985. Play in eight scenes, in Filipino. Direction and script, Bienvenido M. Noriega Jr; production design, Ray Albano; assistant production design, Rolly de Leon; music, Sonny Angeles; lights, Jun Gomez; sounds, Jun Austria; production manager, Ed Murillo; stage management, Lito Casaje; assistant stage manager, Dorothy Hope Matriano; theme song and lyrics, Sonny Angeles; singer, Joy Soler de Castro; producer, Lou Gaite and Oggie Gomez. Cast: Soliman Cruz/Jonic Magno (Nado), Dennis Contemplacion/Joseph Maluyao (Ricky), and Shamaine Centenera/Yvette Ocampo (Milet). First staged at the Bulwagang Gantimpala of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) on 27-30 Jun and 4-7 Jul 1985. Since its first staging up until the publication of the script, the play already had more than 40 performances at the CCP and other venues. It came to print in Noriega’s third collection of plays, titled Bongbong at Kris/Batang Pro (Bongbong and Kris/Child Prostitute), 1987. The play was adapted to film by Lito Casaje, co-written with Noriega, in 1999 with the following cast: Gerald Madrid, Marcus Madrigal, and Ana Capri.

The play encompasses the three years of friendship between three child prostitutes: Nado, a battered child sold by his father to a Mr Gelber, a German pedophile and clubhouse owner; Ricky, a slum dweller who serves as a pimp; and Milet, a victim of sexual abuse by her stepfather. The play starts as Nado and Ricky watch a blazing fire engulf a nearby building. They wait for Milet, who went out with Nado’s guardian. Nado narrates how he became Mr Gelber’s ward. Milet arrives, tells them her harrowing first experience, and is about to break down but Ricky tells her to just chew it all up with a bubble gum. The next time they meet, Milet is dressed as a schoolgirl. Nado makes fun of her look, while they wait for Ricky, who went inside a building to blackmail an office manager who is fond of Milet. Ricky enters saying that he was given only a few bucks. Nado narrates the abuses he suffers in the hands of Mr Gelber. He says that whenever he does something “wrong,” Mr Gelber would beat him and make him sleep inside the cage of his dog named Rizal. Ricky wants to study electronics and plans to go to Saudi so he could help his mother and siblings. But Ricky’s mother dies from an abortion. His money is all spent. Nado arrives and tells them that he has run away from Mr Gelber. He tells Ricky and Milet that he has also killed Rizal and taken money from Mr Gelber. He needs a place to stay. Ricky refuses him at first but gives in on the condition that Nado should contribute his share of the expenses.

 

After a time, Nado and Ricky celebrate the former’s birthday. They hear news that Mr Gelber is now based in Cebu and decide to tip the police on him. Milet returns and narrates her experiences in Japan as the three of them wait for the Manila Zoo gates to open. Nado and Ricky talk about their escapades as prostitutes. Milet leaves for a while and returns after learning that her elephant friend already died of cold. Months after, Milet becomes pregnant. Ricky tells her how shameful it is for her to continue prostituting herself while she is pregnant. She accuses Ricky of impregnating her. Nado decides to return to Quezon upon hearing news of Mr Gelber’s release from jail. Milet expresses her desire to go with Nado as they talk of their waning career as prostitutes. Ricky decides to go back to school.

After a year, Nado and Milet talk on how they were able to kill Mr Gelber. Milet, after musing on her wasted life, asks Nado to stab her with the knife she used to kill Mr Gelber. Nado, at first refuses, but in the end stabs Milet and throws her body into the waves of Manila Bay. In the end, Ricky boasts that he started a fire at the school he enrolled at and from where he learned nothing. Ricky and Nado admire the blazing fires and call for stronger winds to come. They comment on how Milet’s death did not even come close to reaching the tabloid newspapers. Their lives mean nothing to society. Nado decides to burn himself in the fires Ricky started. Nado says farewell and runs into the fire. Ricky, alone now, cheers Nado on.

This searing play on the lives of three child prostitutes of Manila and their no-holds-barred dialogue is an eye opener. The play was awarded second prize in the full-length play in Filipino category of the Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature in 1983.  Written by Erick Dasig Aguilar

text:
(The Young Rizal). 2007. Musical in three acts with music, in Filipino. Direction, Dudz Teraña; script, Christine S. Bellen; music and musical direction, Vince de Jesus; production design, Bobot Lota; costume design, Ron Alfonso; lights/technical design, Amor Guanao; animation, Don Salubayba and Anino Shadowplay Collective. Cast: JK Anicoche, Ian Segarra, Abner Delina Jr, Mark Norella, Nex Agustin, Ron Ryan Alfonso, Norberto Portales, Glecy C. Atienza, Bernah Bernardo, Willy Casero, Joan Bugcat, Mary Ann Espinosa, Kitchie Pagaspas, Neomi Gonzales, Marie Gold Villar, JV Katipunan, Patricia Liwanag, She Maala, and Carlon Matobato. First staged by the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) on 20 Jul 2007 at the PETA Theater Center.

In celebration of the Linggo ng Wika (National Language Week), the grade school students of Rizal Elementary School are presenting a scene from Rizal’s life. For this occasion, Mayor Rapcu donates a statue of the young Rizal to the school. But Pepito accidentally damages it when Manuel and the bullies push him against the statue, causing it to fall. The statue’s face is a wreck and Pepito has to have it repaired in a week’s time or he and his siblings will be kicked out of school and his father will lose his job at the town hall.

 

Confused, Pepito opens the book on Rizal that he has been reading and is transported to the young Rizal’s house in Calamba in the 1870s. He is mistaken by Rizal’s sisters for Pepe. To cover up, Pepito delights the sisters with his shadow play rendition of the monkey and turtle story in rap. After Doña Lolay tells Pepe the story of the moth, Pepito gets to meet Pepe Rizal himself and becomes witness to events in Pepe’s life, like the incarceration of Doña Lolay on false charges and the execution of the three priests and the involvement of Pepe’s brother Paciano. Finally, Pepe, who likes to sculpt, agrees to go with Pepito to the present so he can help repair the statue that Pepito broke.

At first Pepito’s classmates cannot believe Pepe is Jose Rizal but are later convinced. Pepe gets to like the present, including Kaye, but turns sad when he is told that he became a hero because he was killed during his time. As the deadline draws near, Pepito desperately asks Pepe to repair the statue. This is hijacked by Manuel and the other bullies, who hate Pepito because he is Manuel’s rival for Kaye’s attention. Manuel and his gangmates are about to smash the statue with hammers but suddenly stop when Pepito reveals that the mayor will close the whole school if the statue is not repaired. Now everyone is in a panic to get the statue repaired in time. They also talk and come up with an alternative plan.

On the day of the statue’s unveiling, the mayor pulls the curtain open and is surprised to see Pepito and his classmates standing together in place of the statue. Each of the students admit to having destroyed the statue because they could not move in the cramped spaces of the school, so they all appeal to the mayor to give their school a bigger space and budget. In the end, Pepito bids goodbye to Pepe and the two part ways with a deeper understanding that the conditions and challenges of each other’s time and place are the same—both are in search of freedom.

This is the first play on the young Rizal, showing him as a normal, albeit very talented child. In 2008, the Philippine Legitimate Stage Artists Group Gawad Buhay! cited the work as Outstanding Play for Original Script, Stage Direction, Ensemble Performance, Set Design, and Costume Design.  Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

text:
(Little Country). 1975. Three-act play in Filipino. Direction, Rolando S. Tinio; script, Bienvenido M. Noriega Jr; music, Lucrecia R. Kasilag; set and costume design, Salvador Bernal; lighting design, Teddy L. Hilado. Cast: Edmundo Farolan, Ella Luansing, Ward Luarca, Georgia Lee Kangas, Leticia Guzman, Emmanuel B. Gregorio, Rey Malte-Cruz (Ricky), Rustica Carpio, Aurelio Estanislao, and Antonio Mabesa. First staged by Teatro Pilipino on 14 Nov 1975 at the Little Theater, later Tanghalang Aurelio V. Tolentino, of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). It has been restaged various times at the CCP by Teatro Pilipino, Bulwagang Gantimpala, and Tanghalang Pilipino, and at the University of the Philippines and the Manila Metropolitan Theater. It was anthologized in Bayan-Bayanan at Iba Pang Dula (Little Country and Other Plays), 1982.

 

This play is set in Geneva, where a microcosmic Filipino community gathers at the home of Manang, a motherly woman who is an excellent cook; her husband Manong, employed as driver at the Philippine embassy; and their only son Ricky. Among them are Pol, a sojourner and wanderer who longs to go home to the Philippines but cannot do so without a measure of success as well as pasalubong (presents) for his family; Tessie, a nurse who works abroad to earn some money, and who has fallen in love with an Italian; Dino, a student on his first European trip; Anna Marie, a Filipino-American, whose father has remarried, and who is not quite sure where she belongs; Ginoong del Castillo, who is an official at the Philippine Embassy; his wife, Ginang del Castillo, who considers her shopping loot the trophies of living abroad; Connie, a model; and Ginoong Luz, a homesick Filipino on temporary detail to Geneva. Their lives interweave and interrelate, and in the process reveal the different Filipino perceptions of home and country—thus bayan-bayanan, the homelike arrangements made in an alien land—and the various motives that make Filipinos leave home and their prospects for return. Pol, who dies without going home, and Manong, Manang, and Ricky, who know where the home and heart are, represent opposite ends of the spectrum, with all the others ranged between.

Bayan-bayanan is Noriega’s most famous play, winning the grand prize in the CCP Literary Contest for the years 1974-75.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

text:
1967. Play in five scenes, in Tagalog. Direction, Cecile Guidote; script, Virgina Moreno; translation, Wilfredo Pascua Sanchez; music, Bayani M. de Leon; set design, Leandro Locsin; production design, Cecile Guidote. Cast: Vic Silayan, Lolita Rodriguez, Robert Arevalo, Nick Lizaso, Lily Gamboa, Michael Parsons, Aurelio Estrada, Allan Cosio, the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) Kalinangan Ensemble, with the University of the Philippines Madrigal Singers. First staged by PETA in commemoration of Rizal Day (29-30 Dec 1967) at the Dulaang Rajah Sulayman in Manila. Straw Patriot is a tragedy originally written by Moreno in English in 1956 and translated into Tagalog by Sanchez as Bayaning Huwad in 1967. It was first published in The Literary Apprentice in 1956. Both English and Tagalog scripts were published in a limited edition of 1,000 copies in 1967.

 

Straw Patriot is the story of Caciqueng Bruno, a Nueva Ecija rice land owner. As the play opens, his entire warehouse has been laid waste, his rice stocks commandeered by the American lieutenant who knows he gives rice to the insurrectos (rebels). He prepares the hungry townspeople for a siege upon his own rice fields, over which the lieutenant and his sentries keep guard. On the day of the siege, a journeying merchant entices the cacique to sell him the rice his men are stealing back for the people, and urges the cacique to offer his goddaughter Concha to the lieutenant, who fancies her. During the raid, the rice thieves cower; the tenant chief Tano returns with news of their meager loot. Meanwhile, Concha has gone to see the lieutenant, having been asked by the cacique to plead with him for rice for the children, for the hungry, and for the people. She is afraid, but he vows to protect her. She returns, broken, but with a release for the cacique’s rice lands under strict conditions. Concha disappears, and is later found hanging from the rimas (breadfruit) tree. The cacique’s tenants realize that he had intended to sell the rice that Concha had bought back for him with her self-sacrifice. They stage a midnight raid, climaxed by the arrival of an insurrecto, who arrests Caciqueng Bruno for trial.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis

text:
(White Veil). 2007. Three-act play in Filipino. Script, adaptation, and direction, Nonon Padilla; set and costume design, Salvador Bernal; lighting design, Shoko Matsumoto; music design, Dodjie Fernandez. Cast: Mario O’Hara (Rondolf Mauricio and Sister Clemencia), CB Garrucho (Annella Mauricio and Sister Vitalis), Lou Veloso (Roland, Annella’s Mother, and Doctor Britanico), Sherry Lara (Mother Superior), Sherlyn Mae Cuare (Marita), Miles Pasamanero (Liliana and Yolanda), Vicenta Ello-Alaban, Upeng Galang-Fernandez, Joan Orendain, Carme Sanchez, and Sonia Valenciano. First staged on 9 Feb 2007 by the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) at the PETA Theater Center, Quezon City.

Rondolf Mauricio is a playwright. He begins to stage scenes in his mind as he lies on his deathbed at the mansion where he lives. A party is taking place in honor of his wife Annella Mauricio. She arrives with a white veil on her face, which she takes off, revealing the face of a woman in her early 20s. Their daughter Liliana and her boyfriend Roland arrive, and Annella flirts with Roland. Annella then insults Marita, a guest from the squatter’s area. Rondolf acts in the role of Sister Clemencia, who arrives and reprimands Annella for her behavior toward Marita. It starts to rain heavily, and Annella is upset that her party is ruined.

 

A few days later, Annella discovers she has breast cancer. Annella vents her anger on her mother, who later reveals that she is adopted. Annella seduces Roland into giving her a massage and is caught by Liliana. Sister Clemencia arrives to offer Annella’s mother refuge and Liliana leaves with them. Rondolf beats up Annella’s face in anger. She goes for treatment from Doctor Britanico, who injects her with a serum and hypnotizes her to watch a scene created by Rondolf: in a convent, the Mother Superior wants to expel the student Yolanda. Rondolf makes Annella act in the role of Sister Vitalis. Yolanda asks Sister Vitalis for help in appealing to Mother Superior. Sister Vitalis urges the Mother Superior to reconsider, but Yolanda is still expelled and commits suicide. It is at this point that Rondolf realizes he is in despair and is unable to give Annella a story with a proper ending. Annella comforts him and he makes Yolanda the mother of Annella. Rondolf dies and Annella honors him with a concerto.

The play does not strictly follow a linear and chronological plot as Padilla adapted Ony de Leon’s Filipino translation of Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero’s previously unproduced The Woman with a White Veil. Padilla, a nephew of Guerrero, used the heavily edited text of acts 1 and 2 while substituting act 3 with an excerpted version of Guerrero’s first one-act play Half an Hour in a Convent. The play’s themes can be used as a reference for both personal introspection as well as a meditation on the struggles of Filipino artists. The play won the Best Non-Musical Production and Best Stage Director awards in the 2007 Aliw Awards.  Written by Walter Ang

text:
(Trip to the South). 1984. Two-act play in Filipino. Direction and production design, Nonon Padilla; script, Tony Perez; lighting design, Katsch SJ Catoy; music, Jun Austria. Cast: Pio de Castro III, Joy Soler-de Castro, Tito Tesoro, Noemi Manikan-Gomez, Susan Valdez, Ricky Davao, Reggie Mababang-loob, Allan Bautista, Susan Africa, and Peng Olaguera. First staged by Bulwagang Gantimpala in Nov 1984 at the Bulwagang Gantimpala, later Tanghalang Huseng Batute, of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). Padilla also directed A Small Matter of Sacrifice, Perez’s English translation of the play, at the Royal Park Theater in New York in May 1986, and as Trip to the South in Singapore with the Black Box Theater Company in 1991. Biyaheng Timog is the second of Perez’s critically acclaimed dramatic trilogy titled Tatlong Paglalakbay (Three Journeys). The other two are Bombita, 1981, and Sa North Diversion Road (On the North Diversion Road), 1985.

This play is divided into two parts, which roughly correspond to the “death” and the “resurrection” of the characters.

The five Valles—brothers and sisters—are traveling with their families in four vehicles: a sports car, a luxurious sedan, a motorcycle, and a small truck. They are headed south to Bicol to attend the funeral of their father, an authoritarian patriarch of an old landed family. They stop several times and remount the vehicles, in different groupings, revealing the many relationships and background of each character. Clarita Valle, the eldest, travels with her husband Tito Razon, whom she married only because of her father’s wishes. The man she really loved committed suicide on the day of her wedding, and she has not forgiven herself or Tito since. Geoffrey Valle is a well-meaning but spineless character, brutalized by his father, henpecked by his wife Nona, and largely ignored by his son Andre. Paul Valle, the only gentle, kind, and understanding member of the family, has remained that way because he managed to escape from his father into a seminary. Sylvia Valle is still unmarried, and often insults her suitor, Nona’s brother, Cyril, because she cannot get over the trauma of almost being raped by her own father, and because she has fallen in love with her brother-in-law, Tito. Brenold Valle tried to prevent the rape of Sylvia, and since then he has not been able to relate to women normally, but instead would take care of younger men whom he often hurt physically and emotionally.

Upon arrival at the ancestral house, and at the funeral, each of the Valles finally confronts the principal nightmare of their lives, and buries with their father the traumas, prejudices, the constraints that had warped or destroyed their lives.

 

As they travel back to Manila, and as they watch a fire caused by a vehicular accident, each of them is resurrected as a person, now able to fully shape his or her own life. Clarita decides to separate from Tito, whom she has never loved, and whom she now hates after he maneuvered to buy off all the lands that the father left Geoffrey. Geoffrey has inherited only the old santos to Nona’s chagrin but now has money to go to the States. Paul forgives his girlfriend Cherry, whose insecurity had made her seduce Brenold. Sylvia now despises Tito for what he has done and decides to try a relationship with Cyril, on condition that there would be no physical contact between them. Brenold has decided to stop taking in strangers into his life and consents to take care of his nephew Andre, when Geoffrey and Nona leave for the United States.

Biyaheng Timog is one of the best examples of realism in Philippine theater. It won the grand prize in the full-length play category in the 1984 CCP Playwriting Contest.  Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

text:
(Bombs Away, Sir!). 1925. Sarsuwela in two acts, in Cebuano. Script, Buenaventura Rodriguez . It was published in Wilhelmina Q. Ramas’s Sugbuanon Theater from Sotto to Rodriguez and Kabahar, 1982.

This play is set in Cebu, during elections for the presidente municipal (mayor) and councilors. “Bomba Nyor!”—literally “Bombs away, Sir!” or “Let ’em have it!”—is what voters shout at campaigning politicians, challenging or encouraging them to castigate their opponents during rallies. The play weaves election practices and malpractices around the story of Peping and Loling.

The customs of local elections are exposed: paying for the cedulas of voters as a form of indirect bribery, holding small meetings and larger rallies, feeding and housing voters, renting trucks to convey voters to precincts, slandering candidates or revealing their shady secrets, spending family funds for the campaign and leaving families penniless, paying rival candidates to withdraw, switching sides, and using “tickets” (sample ballots).

The personal dimension is provided by Peping and Loling: they are secretly married, but Peping has rejected her because he heard that she had an affair with someone else. “Why didn’t you tell me?” he asks. “Because you didn’t ask,” she answers. During the elections, Loling, although grieving because of the rejection, loyally helps Peping. She asks Paking, who loves her, to switch his votes to Peping, implying that if Peping wins she will love him back. When he does, she reveals to him her being secretly married, and he is impressed by her courage and loyalty. She also gives all her money and a ring to some voters, so that they will vote for Peping. When Peping wins by just five votes, he is triumphant and rejects her outright. Paking goes to see him and reveals that the crucial votes that gained him his narrow margin were all to be credited to Loling. Peping finally thanks her, and acknowledges her to her father: “I waited for the moment when I could worthily claim her, before telling you.” The downtrodden but grateful Loling forgives all, and is happy: “Life is heaven to me now!  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

 

Source

Ramas, Wilhelmina Q. 1982. Sugbuanon Theater from Sotto to Rodriguez to Kabahar: An Introduction to Pre-War Sugbuanon Drama. Quezon City: Asian Center, University of the Philippines.

text:
1981.Three-act play in Filipino. Direction, Tony Espejo; script, Tony Perez. Cast: Tommy Abuel, Ray Ventura, Edgar Mortiz, Spanky Manikan, Dindo Angeles, Soxy Topacio, Tita Pambid, and Jonathan Romulo. First staged by Bulwagang Gantimpala in Sep 1981 at the Bulwagang Gantimpala, later Tanghalang Huseng Batute, of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). It was published in the English translation by Doreen G. Fernandez in Tenggara 23, 1989. Restaged by the Philippine Educational Theater Association in 1990 at the Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Fort Santiago, Manila. It is the first of Perez’s “road play” trilogy titled Tatlong Paglalakbay. The two other plays are Biyaheng Timog (Journey South), 1984, and Sa North Diversion Road (On the North Diversion Road), 1985.

 

This play is about the irony of military discipline and obedience to a corrupt and unthinking leadership. It revolves around Corporal Salvador Bombita, a low-ranking and obedient soldier and one of a group of trainees who are hazed by upperclassmen. They are ordered to deliver a box containing top-secret information to Kalibo, Aklan, and warned of efforts by upperclassmen to divert, delay, or defeat them. text:
1988.Two-act play with prologue in Filipino. Direction, Jonas Sebastian; script, Rene O. Villanueva. Cast: Nanding Josef (Botong), Sherry Lara (Musa, Nene, Dalaga), Lou Veloso (Ebo, Genghis Khan, and Juan Tamad), Danny Deopante (San Clemente, Kababata, Higante, Kababaryo, Apostoles), Dante Balois (Higante, Kababata, Kababaryo, Apostoles), and Arthur Barba (Kababata and Kababaryo). The play was commissioned by the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Coordinating Center for Dramatic Arts in 1988 and was first staged by Tanghalang Filipino on 14-25 Nov at the Tanghalang Huseng Batute of the CCP. The script was published as Botong: Alay at Alaala (Botong: Offering and Memory), 1989, and was included in Villanueva’s collected plays titled Apat na Dula (Four Plays), 1998.

In the prologue, Botong and Angono’s patron saint San Clemente meet on the clouds over the mountains of Angono. San Clemente reveals that Botong is one of the dead. Botong, unwilling to accept his fate, asks for a one-day reprieve so he could create his last masterpiece. San Clemente grants this.

In the mountains of Angono, overlooking the town, act 1 opens with Botong meeting his childhood friend and a public school teacher Ebo in the afterlife. Ebo worries about his unfinished duties as a teacher. Botong tells Ebo about a portal near one of the caves where every soul in the afterlife would eventually pass through. Botong reveals he could only go through the portal in peace if his Musa (muse) inspires him to finish another mural. Ebo decides to pass through the portal only after Botong does so. Then, Botong meets his Musa and asks why she chose him, and taught him to love art. Instead of a direct response, Musa lets him interact with his three kababata (childhood friend), thus recreating the time when his passion for art took root. Botong resents Musa’s interference with the pace and direction of his life. Then, Genghis Khan materializes and challenges Botong, saying that he can leave the mountain and the afterlife, and proceed to Hollywood to make another film. As Genghis Khan tries to convince Botong to leave with him, two higantes (giants) appear. Countering Genghis Khan’s appeal for Botong to leave, they tell Botong that he does not need the attractions of Tinseltown because he is fated to become a National Artist. Botong maintains that he must finish his last work first. He asks the two higantes if they could bring him to the town so he could see his family once more, but they do not have the power to get him out of the mountain. While Botong sulks, Nene, his real muse and wife, comes to him. Nene blurts out her deepest hurts to Botong—that art stole away her love and chance at happiness. Botong defends art as a passion that he cannot do without. With no common ground between them, Nene leaves him.

Act 2 opens with Ebo confiding to Botong of his decision to pass through after realizing that he has lived a full life. Botong and Ebo are joined by three of their kababaryo (town mates). Botong’s deep appreciation for the ordinary and the folk, as well as the value of artifacts and heritage, is revealed in their exchange. Saddened by Ebo’s departure, Botong then meets two Apostoles (Apostles) in the sinakulo. Later, the Dalaga (single woman) enters and narrates how she died of pneumonia and of love at a young age. With the thought of being unloved, she decides to pass through. Botong marvels at her unwavering decision. After Botong asks for the Apostoles’ company, they reveal that he cannot leave the mountain. Juan Tamad, the last character he encounters, inspires him to recognize the virtue of patience through his “aral ng bayabas” (lesson of the guava). Juan is not just a lazy fool after all. The play ends with Ebo and Botong meeting each other again in another realm, the so-called paradise.

Botong is a tribute to a cultural icon, renowned muralist, and National Artist for painting Carlos “Botong” Francisco from Angono, Rizal. The play is memorable because it lives up to the artistic challenge of portraying an artist’s life. Villanueva incorporates the discourse of culture—the ordinary folk as bearers of art, artifact, and history—through Botong’s interaction with his town mates who were fishermen and farmers. Through the appearance of various characters, Villanueva was able to articulate the power of art as counter-memory to much of history and art’s excesses. The play won third prize in the full-length play category, Filipino division, of the Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature in 1989.  Written by Luna Sicat-Cleto

text:
(Batilyo Life, We Will Not Surrender). 1976. Play in 17 scenes with epilogue, in Filipino. Direction, Mario Ignacio; script, Manny D. Pambid. Cast: Members of a community theater in Quezon City. First staged in Jan 1976 at the Luneta Open Air Theater. The play script was first published in two issues of the Philippine Collegian, 10 and 18 Dec 1975. It was also published in Pambid’s Canuplin at Iba Pang Akda ng Isang Manggagawang Pangkultura (Canuplin and Other Works of a Cultural Worker), 2015.

The play opens with a slide presentation on the lives and work of the batilyo (fish stevedore) inside the pondohan (fish port). Kardo, the engkargado or officer-in-charge of fish broker Marina, abuses a batilyo. Other batilyo witness the incident but can do nothing about it. Later, they are instructed to meet at Marina’s house where they have to work extra hours without the assurance of being paid after. Led by Mando and Ramon, the batilyo meet to organize themselves against the abuses of engkargado and fish brokers. One batilyo who works for Marina meets with an accident at the fishing port. The other batilyo demands financial help from Marina for their fellow batilyo. Their demands are refused and one of their leaders gets suspended. The batilyo execute the plan of not working after the day’s break. Crisis erupts inside the pondohan. Kardo makes a promise to the batilyo: their leader’s suspension is to be lifted, salary adjustments are to be made, and health benefits are to be worked out. The batilyo are victorious in proving their importance to the fishing port. The workers’ union is formed. Upon learning of the existence of the formation, Marina and Kardo plan their maneuvers to break the union. The fish brokers implement an ID system where IDs are not issued to union members. Inside the pondohan, verbal and physical abuses toward the batilyo continue. The union decides to seek the help of the Fisheries Commission. Mando is invited by Marina’s bodyguards for a “small talk” while Marina meets and offers Ramon a deal for him to leave and sell out the union. Ramon refuses the offer and leaves. Marina orders her body guards to “secure” Ramon. Mando, likewise, refuses the bodyguards’ offer for him to distance himself from the union. The batilyo arrive and help Mando out of the situation. One batilyo reports that Ramon is found dead in a canal. Revolted, they decide to fight for their rights.

The play is based on a feature article by Fanny A. Garcia, which gives a history of the existence of batilyo in the Navotas fishing port by Armando Cedro Sr, and on Pambid’s immersion in the fishing port in the 1970s. The play initially won the Palihang Aurelio V. Tolentino award in 1975. Likewise, the shortened play was given a Special Citation in the one-act play category by the Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature.  Written by Erick Dasig Aguilar
