text:
(Gold). 1986. Poem-play in Cebuano. Direction, Arnel Mardoquio; script, Arnel Mardoquio, Tony Apat, and Mario Castillo. Cast: Antonio Apat (Kaloy) and Mario Castillo (Poloy). First staged in 1986 by the Mindanao Council for People’s Culture.

Bulawan tackles the EDSA Revolt aftermath through the adventures of two friends, Kaloy and Poloy. Emerging from an underground cave, Kaloy finds Poloy fishing for a meal while taking a break from his gold-hunting mission in the mountains of Mindanao. Soon, Poloy catches a kasili (cod) that has swallowed a big piece of gold. Soon after, they come across a balutan (pack) containing documents, which Kaloy tries to share with Poloy. The documents encourage them to listen to a radio station, DXBB. Kaloy tries to convince Poloy to give up his search for gold and join him in finding out the importance of the documents. They uncover stories from the Bible, militarization and internal refugees, and the Aquino government’s low-intensity conflict program. The two friends then encounter the military elements that lose no time in persuading them to surrender. Kaloy flees to the countryside after he entrusts the documents with Poloy. Poloy promises to search for the true meaning of bulawan and spread it to the cities and the countryside.

Inspired by the African play Woza Albert, Bulawan was the first among the series of two-man shows performed by the Mindanao Council for People’s Culture as part of their anti-Dekopyu (Dekadente, Kolonyal, Pyudal) campaigns. The play was performed in conferences, seminars, and rallies in Davao City. The play’s satirical treatment of militarization and the actors’ comic antics effectively presented new insights into the post-EDSA national situation. Being a two-man performance, it can be presented anywhere, using available furniture or any space where people can have a good view of a performance. The actors, garbed in their multicolored malong (traditional tube skirt of the Maranao), make use of their bodies and voices as props and sound effects to take on various roles during the performance—as military men, displaced Lumad, radio announcers, helicopters, and ordinary townspeople. Bulawan exemplifies political theater, which can be critical, engaging, and entertaining as it pokes fun and comments on social concerns delivered through fine acting and satire.  Written by Glecy C. Atienza

text:
(The Mountain). 1976. Sarsuwela in three acts, in Filipino. Direction, Behn Cervantes; libretto, Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio; music, Fabian V. Obispo Jr and Rodolfo de Leon; musical arrangement, Francis Dandan; set design, Antonio Mabesa; costume design, Mayeng Paguio. Cast: Robert Arevalo, Toti Cruz, Fons Deza, Cizel Planta, Belen Perez, Cris Gosalvez, Marian Saenz, Teza Mendoza, Celina Cristobal, Luis Gregorio, Boots Pascual, Candida Malferrari, Alexander Cortez, Raul Recio, Kiko Santos, Rey Ramirez, Kats Sarraon, Dennis Estrada, Raul Dealino, Tony Nierras, and the University of the Philippines (UP) Repertory and Dulaang UP actors. First staged on 16 Sep 1976 to open the College of Arts and Sciences Little Theater, later renovated and renamed Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero Theater, of UP Diliman.

This modern sarsuwela depicts the struggle of a tribal community to protect their ancestral land from foreign aggressors and man-made destruction. The play is set in the Mountain Province, the whole mountainous area that is found to be rich in gold. On the spot of the Ifugao village lies the mother lode. Foreign-owned mining companies have designs on the land. Leading the struggle to prevent miners from carrying out their plans is Paran, an elder, who dies defending the land. He is succeeded by his son Umangal, who was to have been married to Gayan, but the latter elopes with another lover. He is then married to Bugan, Gayan’s young and impish sister, who volunteers to marry Umangal in order to save the family from disgrace. The relationship develops into love, and after some time, Bugan carries his child. The two decide to be married according to the rites of the Ifugao, officiated by the priestess Indunan. When the mining companies send bulldozers up the sides of the mountain, the men and women of the tribe link arms and block the path, singing: “This is our country!”

 

This “modernized” sarsuwela uses the conventional love story as the center of the plot, but sets it in the context of a real problem faced by indigenous communities: preservation of ancestral lands. Unlike the traditional sarsuwela, the lovers’ happiness is not the central concern, but the villagers’ realization that the solution to their problem lies in the unity of the community.

Ang Bundok won third prize in the 1971-72 First National Zarzuela Writing Competition of the Zarzuela Foundation of the Philippines Inc.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis

article_title: Buwan at Baril sa E-flat Major

photos.desc: Nanding Josef and Connie Lauigan-Chua in PETA’s Buwan at Baril sa E-flat Major, Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Manila, 1985 (PETA Library and Archives)

text:
(Moon and Gun in E-flat Major). 1985. Play in five scenes with prologue and epilogue, in Filipino. Direction and production design, Apo Chua; script, Chris Millado; lighting design, Rollie Navarro; music, Louie Pascasio and Ronnie Quesada; musical arrangement, Chino Toledo. Cast: Crispin Pineda, Dante Balois, Connie Lauigan-Chua, Nanding Josef, Ditchay Roxas, Bal Bernardo, Joel Lamangan, and Cecilia B. Garrucho. A commissioned play, Buwan at Baril sa E-flat Major was first staged by the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) Kalinangan Ensemble in Apr 1985 at the Dulaang Rajah Sulayman in Fort Santiago, Intramuros, Manila. The same year, it was staged by the University of the Philippines (UP) Department of Filipino and Philippine Literature in UP Diliman. In 1989, the play was staged by Tanghalang Pilipino at the Cultural Center of the Philippines, and the May-i Theater Ensemble in New York, USA. It was presented twice by Ateneo de Manila University’s ENTABLADO, 2007 and 2013, under the direction of Allan Forte and Jethro Tenorio, respectively. The play is anthologized in Kamao: Mga Dula ng Protesta 1970-1986 (Fist: Plays of Protest 1970-1986), 1987, and Linangan: Mga Babasahin sa Humanidades I (Field: Readings in the Humanities I), 1992.

The title is from a child’s rhyme: “Buwan, buwan, hulugan mo ako ng sundang” (Moon, moon, drop me a bolo). The author saw the moon as hope and the weapon—which transmutes from a sundang (bolo) to a gun—as reality. The play unfolds in five scenes.

 

Scene 1 is set in the Lakbayan (People’s March) of May 1984. Two brothers meet after many years: one a farmer, the other a laborer-organizer. They share memories and experiences, and realize that they had trod different paths toward the same commitment. Scene 2 has a priest receiving journalists who wish to interview evacuees who trekked for two days to escape the military. He interrogates an Itawis woman for them. Her father had been found dead, and she had been tortured and raped; her suffering and eloquence break through the Itawis language she uses. Scene 3 features a socialite’s monologue as she dresses and prepares to leave for a street demonstration in which she expects to confront the military; it reveals the factors that awakened the elite in 1983 and led them to march in the streets. Scene 4 is another monologue: a wife goes to identify and claim the corpse of her husband, an NPA leader. In the final scene, a university student is picked up at a street corner and interrogated by a policeman who was a former student activist himself. In the conversation, a common humanity is revealed and shared, and the policeman releases the student, only to find out that he was the student leader for whom an arrest order had long been out. The epilogue closes the characters’ stories.

Buwan at Baril was written during the political ferment of the 1970s and 1980s, but it avoids the clichés of protest theater; it highlights the human dimension while delineating the political, thus singing humanity while speaking politics.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez, updated by Athena Angela Aquino

text:
(Canuplin: An Improvisation on the Life and Shows of a Filipino Comedian). 1980. Four-act play with music, in Filipino. Direction, Soxie Topacio; script, Manuel Pambid; musical direction, Louie Pascasio; production design, Weni Gamboa; costume design, Joven Velasco, Annie Nisce, Len Santos, Evelyn Vargas, Estrella Antonio, Vicky Anastacio, Nanette Venturanza, George Calma, Arlene Abuid, Ben Villamin, and Aba Kuaman; lighting design, Jonathan Romulo. Cast: Joonee Gamboa/Bodgie Pascua (Canuplin), Anita Linda, Cecilia B. Garrucho, Nanding Josef, Cesar Xeres-Burgos III, Spanky Manikan, Thea Cleofe-Salvador, Joe Gruta, Jack Benny Azarcon, Annie Nisce, Vicky Anastacio, and the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) Kalinangan Ensemble. First staged by PETA in Apr 1980 at the Dulaang Rajah Sulayman in Fort Santiago, Manila. It was restaged by the Araw Theater Ensemble Inc and the University of the East (UE) Drama Company from Jun 2006 to Mar 2007 under the direction of Frederick R. Castro. Pambid’s version of the script was published in his collection titled Canuplin at Iba Pang Akda ng Isang Manggagawang Pangkultura (Canuplin and Other Works of a Cultural Worker), 2015.

The play depicts the rise and fall of Canuto Francia, better known as Canuplin, the once famous Chaplinesque comedian-magician of bodabil. Characters shift roles and improvise in the tula-dula (poem-play); the koro (chorus) serves as storyteller and commentator. The play opens with Canuplin’s birth, and then shows him as a child of about 11, regaling his mother with jokes and offering to work to help alleviate their poverty. His mother dies, his father remarries, poverty remains. The boy joins carnival contests and wins by impersonating Charlie Chaplin. He starts work in the carnival, his career managed by Lou Borromeo. He meets and marries Isabel, a Chinese mestiza. By this time, he is one of the highest paid comedians in the country, winning against other comedians in contests.

 

Bodabil and stage shows flourish during World War II, but peace changes the public taste: Canuplin’s stage acts are no longer as popular, comedians like him have to wait at the Plaza Cafe for contracts, and the audience begins to find his tricks and comedy outdated. The aging comedian sinks deeper into poverty as he tries to raise a family in Tondo. The last scenes show the disheartened comedian stripped of popularity. His mother appears to him, asking if he is ready to join her, as do the deceased Isabel and their son Jun. As the three recite a litany of Canuplin’s sacrifices and memories, and of forgiveness, he dies. A funeral procession follows, and the play ends with scenes from a film documentary about Canuplin.

The play is one of very few stage biographies on important theater personalities. It produced the famous song “Sa Hirap at sa Ginhawa” (In Bad Times and Good Times) aka “Awit ni Canuplin” (The Song of Canuplin).  Written by Malou L. Maniquis, updated by Erick Dasig Aguilar

 

Source

Atienza, Glecy C. 1990. “Subersyon sa Dula sa Ilalilm ng Batas Militar: Mga Dula ng PETA 1975-1981.” MA thesis, College of Arts and Letters, University of the Philippines Diliman.

text:
(The Captain). 1903. Sarsuwela in one act and one scene, in Hiligaynon. Script, Valente Cristobal; music, Juan Paterno. Cast: Ciriaca Izar, Maria Zolayvar, Antonina de los Santos, Jose Ma.Nava, Jose Ma. Ingalla, Salvador del Rosario, Salvador Magno, Miguel Lavente, Cornelio Lavente, Romulo Cabales, and Epifanio Solis. First staged on 3 Mar 1903 at the Teatro Filipino in Iloilo, it was later staged at Teatro Oriental.

This play revolves around Magdalena, daughter of Tomas and Serapia, who is courted by a capitan and a Chinese. Tomas favors the capitan for the prestige the union would give him; Serapia is inclined toward Tiama, the Chinese, who offers gifts. The two quarrel and argue about the suitors, about the plans of Tomas to join the forces of the revolution, as well as Serapia’s slavish belief in what the friars teach. Without their knowledge, the capitan is able to send Magdalena a letter (on the tip of a bayonet). The pair elopes and gets married that night. When they return, they are forgiven, but told to ask an audience for forgiveness.

A pasillo lirico (lyrical playlet) in one act and one cuadro (scene), it was first performed as a sainete (one-act comedy). It is the first Ilonggo sarsuwela on record and the first dramatic work by Valente Cristobal.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez.

 

Source

Fernandez, Doreen G. 1978. The Iloilo Zarzuela: 1903-1930. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

text:
2011. Musical in two acts, in Filipino. Direction, Maribel Legarda; libretto and script, Liza Magtoto; musical direction, Vince de Jesus; choreography, Carlon Matobato; set design, Leo Abaya; lights design, Jonjon Villareal. Cast: Melvin Lee/Roeder Camañag (Chelsea), Vince de Jesus (Shai), Jerald Napoles/Ricci Chan (Kayla), Dudz Teraña/Jason Barcial (Thalia), Phil Noble/Buddy Caramat (Jonee), Paul Holme (Isaac), Miguel Hidalgo (Israeli Faraj), and Angeli Bayani (Nona). First staged by the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) in Feb-Mar 2011 at the PHINMA-PETA Theater Center, with encore shows in April and December. In 2012, PETA and Repertory Philippines co-produced the musical at the Onstage Greenbelt in Makati City.

Five gay overseas Filipino workers (OFW) work in Tel Aviv, Israel, as caregivers by day and drag queen performers by night. Chelsea is caregiver to Isaac whom she regards as a father. He is kind enough to teach her Hebrew and treat her as a daughter. Chelsea is the levelheaded and would-be leader, trying to keep the group of conflicting personalities together. Kayla is a nurse who suffers under the watchful eye of her patient’s daughter, one who cannot be pleased. Shai, the leader of the group, is also a caregiver who lives with the voice of her mother in her head, scolding her about being gay. The group of five is completed by Jonee, the confident and assertive one, and Thalia, the naive and the most innocent, who has kleptomaniac tendencies. They all live in a flat with Nona.

The play begins with all five being given the opportunity to perform in a club. But this seems to come at a bad time. The voice of Shai’s mother seems to grow louder and louder in her head, straining Shai’s relations with everyone else. Kayla loses her job and her status as legal migrant. Chelsea meets and falls in love with the Israeli Faraj whose identity is shrouded in mystery. Eventually, Kayla is deported and no one can do anything lest their own statuses as migrant workers be put into question. Shai leaves for New York, a strange and ineffectual escape from her mother who will continue to haunt her. Chelsea finds love but becomes the victim of an improvised explosive device, which leads to her death. Jonee and Thalia are left behind in Israel.

Care Divas presents facets of the complex relationships between OFWs in the context of Jewish culture. The play is also layered with issues of gender and sexuality, as well as language and religious differences. The play won six awards in the 2011 Philippine Legitimate Stage Artists Group Gawad Buhay!: Outstanding Musical Production, Outstanding Ensemble Performance for a Musical, Outstanding Original Libretto, Outstanding Musical Direction, Outstanding Choreography, and Male Lead Performance in a Musical (Lee).  Written by Katrina Stuart Santiagos

text:
(Municipal Code). 1908. Sarsuwela in one act, in Ilocano. Libretto and music, Mena Pecson Crisologo. Cast: L. Paredes, A. Filart, S. Alviar, S. Averia, R. Favis, F. Viloria, and Agcaoili. First staged on 25 Jan 1908 on an open-air stage in Vigan, Ilocos Sur. It was published in Alejandrino G. Hufana’s Mena Pecson Crisologo and Iloko Drama, 1963.

This play opens with the presidente municipal (mayor) and councilors discussing the need for a main event in the coming town fiesta. The choice lies between a komedya and a sarsuwela. The presidente’s personal choice is the komedya, which is here associated with the old authoritarian order, while the former presidente, Capitan Tinong, sides with the council which voted for the more realistic and liberal sarsuwela and speaks for the people it represents by virtue of the Municipal Code. To help them come to a common decision, the komedyante (komedya performers) and the sarsuwelista (sarsuwela performers) are asked to render samples of their performances. The komedyante march grandly; the leader recounts favorite komedya stories, and the troupe presents a colorful sample. The sarsuwela troupe performs a scene from an Ilocano sarsuwela about love where men are deceivers and women are believers. Another scene features dancing, which entices the presidente to join in. Capitan Tinong reminds him of the dignity of his office but the presidente cannot keep his feet still, and the sarsuwela wins the day.

Codigo Municipal is believed to be Crisologo’s first sarsuwela, and perhaps the first in Ilocano. The battle between the komedya and the sarsuwela marked a transition of theater from fantasy to early realism. It is probably the first major criticism of the komedya in the Ilocano theater.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis

article_title: Comedia ni Hadeng Grimaldo sa Reinong Irlanda

photos.desc: A komedya performance in Bicol in the 1880s (Le Tour du Monde by Jose Montano. Librairie Hachette & Cie., 1884.)

text:
(Comedia of King Grimaldo in the Kingdom of Ireland). 1917. Komedya in Bikol. Script, Sabas Armenta. Staged in Albay.

This verse play opens with King Grimaldo setting up a tournament to find a husband for daughter Criselda. Three princes, the usual number, vie for her hand in marriage: Reinaldo of Aragon, Majometo of Turkey, and Lizardo of Babylon, who is disguised as a farmer. When the king favors wealthy Reinaldo to poor Lizardo, who won in the battle, the troubles begin. Lizardo, who is now secretly engaged to Criselda, complains of the maltreatment but gets locked up in jail instead. Worse, Reinaldo takes advantage of his position as mantenedor (referee) of the tournament and pronounces Lizardo’s death penalty amid the protest of the councilors. Desperate, Criselda begs her father to pardon Lizardo, but she is punished similarly.

The Moros, in a reversal of stereotype roles, free Lizardo and Criselda and throw Grimaldo behind bars instead. Consequently, Lizardo becomes king upon the insistence of both Criselda and the Moros. As king, Lizardo’s first act is to release Grimaldo to enable him to attend the coronation and wedding ceremonies. But Lizardo finds later that he is powerless because Grimaldo, desirous of regaining power, manipulates matters and puts up a case against Reinaldo, who he claims slighted the new king. However, Lizardo objects to Reinaldo’s execution on the basis of that one mistake. But the execution has been prearranged by Grimaldo and his men, and son-in-law Lizardo finds it futile to disobey Grimaldo.

 

Lizardo achieves success but cannot enjoy it. Grimaldo, who is supposed to make a gracious exit, is a tyrant once again. The councilors are no better; they connive and are jealous of one another. The Moros are bloodthirsty just the same. Reinaldo is executed, and the play ends in a funeral procession.

Although it was highly popular, the play was not written to entertain but to expose the problems that attend unlimited authority and overweening ambition. The story is not religious but retains the form of the komedya. Dissatisfied with the irrelevance of the old komedya to the lives of the people, Armenta deviated from the standard patterns of Moros presented as villains and persecutors, Christians fighting and converting them, and sword fights and magical tricks. This komedya focuses on social and political problems, and emphasizes character study.  Written by Maria Lilia F. Realubit

 

Source

Realubit, Maria Lilia F. 1976b. The Bicol Dramatic Tradition. Quezon City: University of the Philippines.

article.value: Lizardo achieves success but cannot enjoy it. Grimaldo, who is supposed to make a gracious exit, is a tyrant once again. The councilors are no better; they connive and are jealous of one another. The Moros are bloodthirsty just the same. Reinaldo is executed, and the play ends in a funeral procession.

Although it was highly popular, the play was not written to entertain but to expose the problems that attend unlimited authority and overweening ambition. The story is not religious but retains the form of the komedya. Dissatisfied with the irrelevance of the old komedya to the lives of the people, Armenta deviated from the standard patterns of Moros presented as villains and persecutors, Christians fighting and converting them, and sword fights and magical tricks. This komedya focuses on social and political problems, and emphasizes character study.  Written by Maria Lilia F. Realubit
Source

text:
(The Council of the Gods). Allegorical play in Spanish. Script, Jose Rizal. Written in 1879, it was first published in the Revista del Liceo Artistico-Literario de Manila in Apr 1880, and subsequently in the La Solidaridad. It was translated into Tagalog in Dec 1900. This version was published in El Comercio de Filipinas and was adapted into a zarzuela by Pascual H. Poblete. In 1915, Hucapte made arrangements for its staging. Later, it was edited with a prologue by Astrana Maria in El Cervantismo del Heroe Filipino Rizal, 1961. It was published in the original Spanish and with English translation in Nick Joaquin’s The Complete Poems and Plays of Jose Rizal, 1976. A Filipino translation of the play, together with Junto al Pasig (Beside the Pasig), 1880, was commissioned by the Komisyon sa Wikang Filipino.

The play opens with the gods of Olympus in council: Jupiter on a throne of gold; Juno to his right with diadem and peacock; Minerva on the left in helmet and shield; Saturn squatting; Venus reclining on a bed of roses and caressing Cupid; Apollo strumming his lyre and dallying with eight muses; also Mars, Bellona, Alcides, Momus, Hebe, and Ganymede. On the right sits Justice on a throne. Terpsichore and her nymphs dance, and Mercury enters to announce that Neptune, Vulcan, and Pluto cannot come.

Jupiter declares his intention to celebrate the feast of his victory against the “proud sons of earth” with a literary contest, and asks the gods to name the mortal deemed worthy of the prizes. Juno names Homer, Venus Virgil, and Minerva Cervantes, which is seconded by Apollo and disputed by Mars. The discussion of their merits is heated and eloquent. Justice weighs the Iliad, the Aeneid, and Don Quixote on her impartial scales and finds them equal. Jupiter then awards the trumpet to Homer, the lyre to Virgil, and the laurel crown to Cervantes.

The play won first prize in an 1880-81 literary contest commemorating the death of Cervantes sponsored by the Liceo Artistico Literario de Manila. For the award, Rizal, who was then 18 years old, gave the epigraph: “I enter the future remembering the past.” The play is considered the most sensuous of Rizal’s writings. It reveals his Hispanist and classicist side.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez, with notes from from Nicanor G. Tiongson

text:
(Philippine Scenes). 1882. Sainete in Spanish. Script, Francisco de P. Entrala. Cast: Elisea Raguer, Praxedes Fernandez, Jose Carvajal, Patrocinio Tagaroma, and Nemesio Ratia. First staged by the Compañia Lirico Dramatica in 1882 at the Teatro Filipino, Manila.

The first scene is set in the market, where “la babel Manileña” (Manila’s Babel)—food and wine vendors, cooks, transients, Chinese barbers, musicians, actors, and so forth—move and meet. Here Don Juancho pays court to Fuensanta, a cigar maker by day, komedya princess by night. He promises her gifts of clothing, gold, and diamonds. Her mother is fierce, says Fuensanta, and therefore he can only see her at the theater—onstage. The second scene takes place in a theater with a komedya in full swing, Fuensanta appearing as the princess, and Don Juancho as “moro improvisado” (improvised Moro), who is recognized by his wife, Doña Nicolasa, from her box seat.

The play, in two scenes and in verse, was staged only two or three times. Although the Spanish press saw it as a comic parody of the Tagalog komedya, the Filipino audience saw it as a mockery and an insult to local customs. They whistled at the author and practically stoned him.

Entrala was a Spanish novelist and journalist who arrived in Manila in 1837. Cuadros Filipinos was the first locally written play in Spanish to have local characters and settings. It was published by La Oceania Española in 1882.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

 

Source

Retana, Wenceslao E. 1909. Noticias Historico-Bibliograficas de el Teatro en Filipinas desde Sus Origines hasta 1899. Madrid: Libreria General de Victoriano Suarez.

text:
(Rice Leaves/Snake). 1983. Full-length play in Filipino. Direction, adaptation, and stage design, Chris Millado; script, Marina Feleo-Gonzalez; artistic advising, Amiel Leonardia; music, Inang Laya; libretto, Jess Santiago, Chyn San Juan, and Lina Cabero; lights, Hobart Solmerano and Jimmy Villanueva; costume, Ruby Ruth Azanza. Cast: Lito Peña, Crispin Pineda, Bart Bartolome, Marivic Teodosio, Nena Andaya, Ruby Ruth Azanza, Jeanne de Leon, Joel Cruz, Bong Medina, German Asuncion, Anchet Yu, Sonny Lardizabal, Hobart Solmerano, Bong Bringas Jr, Chito Gregorio, Bernie Belen, Lia Moran, Ponce de Leon, Jimmy Villanueva, Apollo Abraham, Pinky Isidoro, Anthony Buyco, Joi Barrios, Teroy Guzman, Starr Dimayuga, and Shamaine Centenera-Buencamino. First staged by the University of the Philippines (UP) Tropang Bodabil from 24 Feb to 13 Mar 1983 at the Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero Theater, UP Diliman.

The play was a stage adaptation of Feleo-Gonzalez’s screenplay and was presented for the UP Diamond Jubilee. A musical based on Dahong Palay titled Pangako ng Binhi (Promise of the Seedlings) was written by Robbie Guevarra and was produced in 1988 as part of Philippine Educational Theater Association’s (PETA) Peasant Theater Program, headed then by Manny Pambid. The adaptation’s direction was done by Khryss Adalia, music composition by Vincent de Jesus, and choreography by Jojo Atienza (Samson et al. 2008, 558-59).

 

The play is set in the province of Nueva Ecija during the early decades of the 20th century, a time when the centuries-old feudal system of the landlords led to the abuse and misery of the farmers. This system is embodied by the character of Don Hilario Baraseda, a corrupt and dishonest landlord who deceives his farmers into entering a contract that puts them in eternal debt to the landlord. The story revolves around David and Julian, sons of farmers, who both went through very trying experiences since childhood. Their complicated background is gradually revealed: David’s real father is a mestizo priest, who raped his mother. David’s foster father involved himself in a peasant movement against the landlord, which eventually led to his demise. Likewise, Julian, at an early age, lost his father who was abducted, tortured, and killed because of participation in the movement. Despite their painful childhood, the two push through life as teenagers and meet Celia, a captain’s daughter who later on will become David’s wife. Many years pass, the peasant movement continues to gain force. David and Julian eventually choose their own paths: the former becomes an Aglipayan priest, and the latter enlists in the peasant movement. In the movement, Julian meets and marries Luningning. During World War II, the movement teams up with the American forces to fight the Japanese. The Japanese are defeated, but little do the peasants know that the Americans will betray them, confiscating their arms and executing them in the process. The play ends with David receiving the news about the death of Julian and Luningning.

Dahong Palay presents the impoverished and exploited state of Filipino farmers from 1920 until after World War II. The play is noteworthy as it tackles the tragic fate of the Filipino farmers by vividly depicting the abusive feudal system and the betrayal of the Filipinos by the Americans whom they considered their allies.  Written by Tyron Judes de la Calsada Casumpang

 

Source

Samson, Laura, Brenda V. Fajardo, Cecilia B. Garrucho, Lutgardo L. Labad, and Ma. Gloriosa Santos-Cabangon. 2008. A Continuing Narrative on Philippine Theater: The Story of PETA (1967-2007). Quezon City: Philippine Educational Theater Association.

Tanghalang Pilipino’s Dalagang Bukid, featuring Noemi Manikan-Gomez, center, CCP, Manila, 1987 (Tanghalang Pilipino Collection)

text:
(Country Maiden). 1917. Sarsuwela in three acts, in Filipino. Libretto, Hermogenes Ilagan; music, Leon Ignacio; musical arrangement, Florentino Ballecer and Ben Buenaventura. First staged by the Compañia de Zarzuela Ilagan in 1917 at the Teatro Zorrilla, Manila, with Honorata “Atang”de la Rama in the title role. Restaged in 1940 at the Manila Grand Opera House as a benefit show for Hermogenes Ilagan; then in 1952 by Florentino Ballecer at the Far Eastern University Auditorium, with Conching Rosal (Angelita) and Atang de la Rama (Kobang); and in 1987 by Nonon Padilla at the Tanghalang Aurelio V. Tolentino, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), with Noemi Manikan-Gomez (Angelita) and Cynthia Patag (Kobang), to honor Atang de la Rama on the occasion of her being named National Artist for music and theater. It was published in the original Tagalog and in English translation by Marcela Zamora in Philippine Drama: Twelve Plays in Six Philippine Languages, 1987. Around 1989, the CCP Sarsuwela Series came out with a kit on Dalagang Bukid, containing the printed script of the 1987 production of Tanghalang Pilipino and, in two cassette tapes, the songs from the sarsuwela and the minus one to encourage groups to stage the sarsuwela.

This play is the story of Angelita, who brings a whiff of country freshness and maidenhood into the cabaret, where she sells flowers. Her wit, charm, and humor all conjure up a mysterious fragrance among the men in the dance hall, where dances and female company are sold by tickets. She is courted by Don Silvestre, a usurer who lends money to her parents for their gambling, and thus gains their consent for his suit. Her true love, however, is Cipriano, a law student at the end of his studies. The couple Kobang and Parlong, married and unfaithful, provide foil to the romance of Angelita and Cipriano. The path of true love is complicated by Don Silvestre spending money to have Angelita win a beauty contest so that he can be her escort at the coronation. But, as in most plays of the period, true love wins out, as Angelita not only has Cipriano as escort, but marries him—to everyone’s surprise and with their (even Don Silvestre’s) eventual blessing.

 

Dalagang Bukid was the most popular Tagalog sarsuwela of the period, having been performed about a thousand times in Manila and in the provinces before World War II. It also became the first full-length Filipino feature film when made into a silent movie by Jose Nepomuceno in 1919, also starring Atang de la Rama, who was often asked to sing the songs and recite the dialogue with the rest of the cast behind the screen while the film was being shown. The play features the song “Nabasag ang Banga” (The Clay Pot Broke), which, with its innocent sexual innuendo, became the hit song of the time. It also featured the social and artistic mores of the era: gambling and cabaret, tap dancing and “modern” social dances, and the conflict between country values and city manners.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

 

Sources

CCP (Cultural Center of the Philippines). 1990. Dalagang Bukid. Souvenir program.

Tanghalang Pilipino. 1987. Atang de la Rama: Una’t Huling Bituin. Manila: Cultural Center of the Philippines.

text:
(Women of the Night). 1991. Three-act play in Filipino. Direction, Brenda Fajardo; script, Joi Barrios; musical direction, Maria Carunungan; production design, Sarri Tapales; choreographer, Mary Joan Fajardo, Chie Concepcion, and Jojo Atienza. Cast: Angie Cantero (Magdalena), Avic Ilagan (Clara), Connie Lauigan-Chua (Maria), Glecy Atienza (Juanita), Chie Concepcion (Leonarda), Wylie Casero (Guwardiya, Miguel, Artista, and Stephen), and Suyin Chua (Mang-aawit).

The Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) planned to produce plays on women and other gender issues each year, and in 1991, it commissioned Joi Barrios to write a play about prostitution during the last years of the Spanish colonization. The play was based on the report on 19th-century prostitutes written by Efren Isorena in a graduate class of Milagros Guerrero, as well as research on the same topic during the American period by Luis Dery. The play was presented together with a Rody Vera work in a twin bill titled Baligtaran: Dalawang Dula ukol sa Kasarian (Two-sided: Two Gender Plays), which was the initial offering of PETA Kalinangan Ensemble’s 25th major season. The twin bill opened on 22 Nov 1991 and had a continuous staging until 15 Dec 1991. Damas de Noche was published in Bailaya: Mga Dula para sa Kababaihan (Bailaya: Plays for Women), 1997.

 

As the mock battle of Manila Bay takes place at the turn of the century, five women are imprisoned because they are accused of being prostitutes. Magdalena, a prostitute with a golden heart, serves as the narrator of the play and comments on the stories of the other characters. Clara, the secondary narrator, is used to washing clothes for a living until she is pimped by a Chinese named Sytuco. She pretends to be a mute. Maria, a former cigarrera (cigar factory worker), works in acasa(brothel) after meeting Ramon, an official. She has been imprisoned a number of times. Juanita dreams of becoming a sarsuwelista (sarsuwela actress), but instead, becomes a kept woman of a rich and powerful man, Don Pedro. She is imprisoned when Don Pedro’s jealous wife learns about the infidelity. Leonarda is a criada (servant) charged with being a prostitute when she is caught late one night wandering the streets in search of Miguel, her lover, who is a Katipunero. The characters narrate their varied stories with common experiences of oppression and suggest how they are constrained by social constructs—mujer publica (public woman), indocumentada (undocumented), prostituta (prostitute), vagamunda (vagabond), dama de noche (woman of the night), prostitute, call girl, puta (bitch), and even their opposite, virgen (virgin)—and other labels used by society to evaluate and judge women. The play is not just about the individual narratives of the victimized women nor is it just about prostitution; rather, it is a reexamination of the misogynist language that permits and perpetuates the oppression of women. The play ends with a ritual that celebrates women’s capacity to define their own destiny.

The play weaves into the narrative various intertexts to highlight the myriad forms and contexts of women’s subjugation. For example, the work plays around with the names Maria and Clara to draw into the narrative Rizal’s famous character, Maria Clara, who has been a symbol of women particularly in the 19th century—timid, submissive, prayerful, frail—while stressing that these images were true only for the privileged and not among the lower class. Leonarda’s character who was mistaken for a prostitute for just wandering the streets calls to mind Modesto de Castro’s Urbana at Feliza (Urbana and Feliza), which discourages women to leave their homes without chaperones.

Damas de Noche goes from the Spanish period to the American period but also traverses within various times and spaces—the presence of American military bases in the country, the time when Ermita replaced Binondo as the “red-light district,” and the indefinite period of women’s rituals—thereby highlighting women’s continuous struggles throughout Philippine history. Each historical period is defined by the sound and music, as well as dance and movements using indigenous, traditional, and modern idioms and styles.

This play contributes to the increasing body of feminist plays, and specifically calls attention to the centrality of language in women’s struggle for freedom. The play won first prize in the full-length play category of the Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature in 1992.  Written by Galileo S. Zafra

 

Sources

Barrios, Joi. 1997. Bailaya: Mga Dula para sa Kababaihan. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

article.value: As the mock battle of Manila Bay takes place at the turn of the century, five women are imprisoned because they are accused of being prostitutes. Magdalena, a prostitute with a golden heart, serves as the narrator of the play and comments on the stories of the other characters. Clara, the secondary narrator, is used to washing clothes for a living until she is pimped by a Chinese named Sytuco. She pretends to be a mute. Maria, a former cigarrera (cigar factory worker), works in acasa(brothel) after meeting Ramon, an official. She has been imprisoned a number of times. Juanita dreams of becoming a sarsuwelista (sarsuwela actress), but instead, becomes a kept woman of a rich and powerful man, Don Pedro. She is imprisoned when Don Pedro’s jealous wife learns about the infidelity. Leonarda is a criada (servant) charged with being a prostitute when she is caught late one night wandering the streets in search of Miguel, her lover, who is a Katipunero. The characters narrate their varied stories with common experiences of oppression and suggest how they are constrained by social constructs—mujer publica (public woman), indocumentada (undocumented), prostituta (prostitute), vagamunda (vagabond), dama de noche (woman of the night), prostitute, call girl, puta (bitch), and even their opposite, virgen (virgin)—and other labels used by society to evaluate and judge women. The play is not just about the individual narratives of the victimized women nor is it just about prostitution; rather, it is a reexamination of the misogynist language that permits and perpetuates the oppression of women. The play ends with a ritual that celebrates women’s capacity to define their own destiny.

The play weaves into the narrative various intertexts to highlight the myriad forms and contexts of women’s subjugation. For example, the work plays around with the names Maria and Clara to draw into the narrative Rizal’s famous character, Maria Clara, who has been a symbol of women particularly in the 19th century—timid, submissive, prayerful, frail—while stressing that these images were true only for the privileged and not among the lower class. Leonarda’s character who was mistaken for a prostitute for just wandering the streets calls to mind Modesto de Castro’s Urbana at Feliza (Urbana and Feliza), which discourages women to leave their homes without chaperones.

Damas de Noche goes from the Spanish period to the American period but also traverses within various times and spaces—the presence of American military bases in the country, the time when Ermita replaced Binondo as the “red-light district,” and the indefinite period of women’s rituals—thereby highlighting women’s continuous struggles throughout Philippine history. Each historical period is defined by the sound and music, as well as dance and movements using indigenous, traditional, and modern idioms and styles.

This play contributes to the increasing body of feminist plays, and specifically calls attention to the centrality of language in women’s struggle for freedom. The play won first prize in the full-length play category of the Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature in 1992.  Written by Galileo S. Zafra

article_title: Death in the Form of a Rose
text:
1991.Script and direction, Anton Juan Jr; set sculpture and masks, Agnes Arellano; props, Ada Bautista; lighting design and technical direction, Shax Siasoco. Cast: Anton Juan Jr/Ishmael Bernal (Director), Noel Lopez (Teenager), Ogie Juliano, Len Ag. Santos, Jaime Yambao, Lawrence Espinosa, Edward Baluyut, Rico Gutierrez, Arjay Avisado, Gines Enriquez, Aristotle Bancale, Cora Lopez, Dante Bantatua, and Alex Parane. First staged by the UP Playwrights’ Theatre on 17 Sep 1991 at the Faculty Center Studio, University of the Philippines Diliman.

The prologue shows the Director lying dead on the beach, his genitals cut off by unknown killers. In Act 1, a ballet de court uses clashing music and stylized movements to depict a chessgame between the white forces on stage and the red forces offstage (supposedly the audience itself). The white forces are led by the power brokers of the social hierarchy composed of pope, bishop, baron, general, and queen and their respective pawns who execute their orders to protect and strengthen the hierarchy. But one white pawn transforms into a red knight, and then into a red queen. The Director shouts “Cut.” The Director is happy with the rehearsal of the dance that will be filmed and intercut with realistic scenes of his new anti-establishment film. The Director is a communist who rails against the abuses of capitalists and believes the church is a fascist institution. He is also a gay man who pays for sex from male prostitutes or strangers.

Act 2 opens with the Director and the Teenager, a male prostitute, conversing while drinking wine on the beach. The young man left his father, a fisherman, and family to become an actor. Strangely, because both the Director and the Teenager are rebels against the establishment, a bond is formed between them. This bond, however, is exploited by the power brokers of church and government, who now lure the Teenager into their circle with promises of material riches and a place in heaven. They convince the young man to execute their plan to end the Director’s life and art.

In Act 3, the Director and the Teenager engage in sex on the beach, but begin to quarrel when the Director accuses the boy of selling not only his body but his soul to the very people he earlier denounced as evil. In a fit of anger, the Teenager attacks the Director and kills him. In the final tableau, the power brokers dismember the Director’s corpse and cut off his testicles and penis, which promptly transform into two seashells and a beautiful rose.

The play won second prize in the full-length play in English category at the 1993 Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature. It is considered as one of Juan’s most controversial works because of its use of nudity and realistic depiction of sexual acts. However, it has also been hailed by many critics for its avant-garde style which effectively combines realistic with highly expressionistic scenes and for its bold exposition of homosexual love and sex and its brave affirmation that the power brokers of the Catholic church and the Italian government connived to have the rebel Italian director Pier Paolo Pasolini murdered for his irreverence and belligerence against the establishment. In 1991, the play was also read as a statement against the suppression of the freedom of speech by the government censors and the return of the old social hierarchy after the restoration of “democracy” in 1986.  Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

photos.desc: Teatro Kolehiyo ng Miriam’s Despedida de Soltera, UP Diliman, 2004 (Photo courtesy of Liza Magtoto)

text:
(Bridal Shower). 1999. Two-act play in Filipino. Direction, Mae Quesada; script, Liza Magtoto; music, Ronnie Quesada. Cast: Mhalouh Crisologo (Barbs), Tanya Cordero (Diane Marie), Bernah Bernardo (Auntie Mayang), Rain Santos (Tiyo), Loui Montilla, Gabo Oliveros, Ron Alfonso, and Dudz Teraña. First staged by the Philippine Educational Theater Association’s (PETA) Dulaang Laboratoryo on 26 Mar 1999 at the Dulaang Rajah Sulayman in Fort Santiago, Intramuros, Manila.The production was featured at the Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature Awards Night on 1 Sep 1999 at the Rigodon Ballroom, Peninsula Hotel, Makati City, under the direction of Uro de la Cruz.

Despedida de Soltera follows the story of Barbs, a dressmaker. In the receiving room of her dress shop, she is fitting a wedding gown and talking to herself while awaiting the arrival of her relatives who have been invited to her bridal shower. The play flashes back to the wedding of Diane Marie, Barbs’s goddaughter. During the wedding, Diane Marie, Auntie Mayang, and Tiyo are interrogating Barbs. They are pressuring Barbs to get married to avoid being an old maid. Barbs replies by comparing life to a big factory where each person has a job in the life’s assembly line: those who get married, those who become nuns, and those who remain single. She enumerates all her past boyfriends and recounts the complicated relationships she had with men who wanted to trim women down to their liking. Barbs ends by announcing her bridal shower the following week. The play then goes back to Barbs’s dress shop. It is the day of her bridal shower, with her relatives now sitting around a large box. A male erotic dancer pops out of the box as part of the usual ritual for the despedida de soltera. After this, Barbs announces that her guests will witness a special celebration—of Barbs marrying herself. First, she burns a bundle of romance novels. Then, she makes a vow never to let her happiness depend on another person, assuring herself that being single is not a lonely journey. And finally, she throws away her bouquet of flowers.

 

The play sends an empowering message to single women by questioning the conventional path of marriage as dictated by one’s family and society. The script won second prize in the full-length play in Filipino category in the 1999 Don Carlos Palanca Foundation Memorial Awards for Literature.  Written by Olivia Nieto

text:
(Double: A Short Play of Farewell). 1998. One-act play in Filipino. Script, Rene O. Villanueva. The play’s first laboratory theater staging was in 1998 by the Philippine Educational Theater Association Writers’ Bloc; and the first nonlaboratory theater staging was in May 2001 under the direction of Alexander Cortez. In 2001, the play was twin-billed with Chris Martinez’s Baclofen for the UP Playwrights’ Theatre where Mario Magallona performed the role of the unnamed stunt double. The revised version of the script dated 18 Sep 2004 is included in Villanueva’s collection Bedtime Stories: Mga Dula sa Relasyong Sexual (Bedtime Stories: Plays on Sexual Relationships), 2005.

A play on voices and concealed identities, Dobol begins with the unnamed stunt double standing in the middle of Quezon Bridge, approaching midnight, waiting for the movie director’s cue to jump. As he waits, he recalls his experiences as a closeted gay through a series of flashbacks and monologues. His recollections are textured by the story and music of Walt Disney’s animated film The Little Mermaid. The unnamed stunt double draws parallels between his stories and the tale of the movie’s protagonist Ariel, the mermaid who surrendered her voice to the sea witch Ursula in exchange for a pair of human legs.

Through reenactments, the double narrates his stories of brief sexual encounters and his one great love story involving Ding, a criminology student whom he meets in a one-night stand. Their initial encounter progresses into a five-year domestic partnership. While the double and his partner Ding bicker about issues like financial dependence and emotional intimacy, the double describes their relationship as a relatively peaceful one. The relationship crumbles the moment Ding expresses that he wants to have a “normal” family life with a wife and children—a desire that he believes the double will not understand as the latter is not a straight man. The double’s reminiscences end with the couple’s separation.

Returning from his memories, the double waits for his cue to perform what he believes is his greatest stunt—the performance that nevertheless calls for him to remain nameless, hidden in the shadow of the movie star. The play ends with the double leaping from the bridge, his fate ambiguously marked by symbolic death and potential rebirth—a departure, an act of moving on from the failed romantic affair, the drowning of his hidden gay self, a possible reemergence from the traumatic dark waters of his closeted existence.

Dobol foregrounds the difficulty of asserting queer identity as akin to having one’s true voice drowned in a river of dominant and permissible voices. As the double’s existence is muted, so is the homosexual within the society condemned to return to the waters as froth, bubbles devoid of any meaning, purpose, or value. The play received third prize in the one-act play category of the Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards in 1999.  Written by Vladimeir B. Gonzales

text:
(Doc Resureccion: Will Heal the Nation). 2009. One-act play in Filipino. Direction, Tuxqs Rutaquio; script, Layeta Bucoy. Cast: Riki Benedicto (Jess), Jonathan Tadioan (Boy Pogi), Rayna Reyes (Elsa), Paulo Cabañero (Boy Pogi’s father), and Sherry Lara (Mang). The play was first staged as part of the Virgin Labfest 5 in Jun 2009 at the Tanghalang Huseng Batute of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). It was restaged as one of three revisited plays for Virgin Labfest 6 in 2010, and was drafted to be part of Tanghalang Pilipino’s 25th theater season titled Eyeball: New Visions in Philippine Theater in 2012, a selection of plays from the Virgin Labfest at the CCP Tanghalang Aurelio Tolentino.

The play is set in Boy Pogi’s house, which is found in the slums beside a polluted river. Jess, a doctor, has come to speak to his cousin Boy Pogi about the coming elections. Jess tries to convince Boy Pogi not to run against him, promising to institute changes when he becomes mayor and to employ Boy Pogi himself. Jess invokes their childhood memories to get Boy Pogi to decide in his favor. Boy Pogi responds with bitterness, reminding Jess of how the latter had abandoned Boy Pogi and the community as a whole. Jess gives Boy Pogi a new fishing line and hook, because he remembers how they both used to fish there as kids. Boy Pogi refers to the river in front of them, now dirty and unproductive.

 

As they talk and reminisce, they are interrupted every so often by Boy Pogi’s family members. Boy Pogi’s father is revealed to have been sleeping in one of the boats docked to the side of the house. Boy Pogi’s wife Elsa enters to bring them drinks, asks Jess to stay for lunch then disappears to take a bath. Boy Pogi’s mother, Mang, arrives from selling fish sauce in the market, and reminds Jess of how he had ignored her once, but all has been forgiven. These interruptions remind Boy Pogi of Jess’s other sins against his family and community. Boy Pogi’s anger escalates. He shifts between being bullied by Jess to being the bully himself. It then dawns on Jess that Boy Pogi is just a nuisance candidate. Jess offers Boy Pogi cash to drop his candidacy. Boy Pogi says Jess need not pay him off and asks instead that Jess bring his wife and kids to spend a day with Boy Pogi’s family. Jess makes excuses saying his wife Margaret is busy with work and his kids need to go with him on the campaign trail. Boy Pogi turns glum, accusing Jess of thinking so little of him. He then takes his old fishing hook and gouges out Jess’s eye. Jess tries to fight back but is overpowered by Boy Pogi. Jess pleads for his life. Boy Pogi sneers and says Margaret won’t even look at him now. Jess screams. Boy Pogi says no one will bother about the screams of a stranger in this corner of his community. Boy Pogi then strangles Jess with the fishing line. Once Jess is dead, Boy Pogi’s family starts stepping out from the shadows, all in on the planned murder. It is revealed that the mastermind is the mayor, Jess’s political rival. The mayor was certain that Jess would be forced to seek out Boy Pogi the moment the latter’s name popped up as a candidate. Pang, Mang, and Elsa all give the dead Jess a kick to get back at him for his sins to them as family.

The play creates a world of wretchedness which de-romanticizes poverty by showing its filth not only in the set design but in the language the play utilizes, full of cuss words that characterize the everyday conversation of Boy Pogi’s social class. The play won first prize in the one-act play in Filipino category of the Don Carlos Palanca Awards for Literature in 2009.  Written by Katrina Stuart Santiago

text:
(People’s Poetic Joust). 1976. Dramatized duplo in Filipino. Direction, Lutgardo Labad with Brenda Fajardo; script, Domingo Landicho, Socrates Topacio aka Soxie Topacio, Cecilia B. Garrucho, and Jose Purisima; music, Cynthia Zayas and Fe Prudente. Cast: Joel Lamangan, Melvi Pacubas, Eddie Pagayon, Estrella Antonio, Socrates Topacio, Rudy Hermano, Jerry O’Hara, and Myrna de la Paz. First staged by the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) on 15 Jan 1976 at the Dulaang Rajah Sulayman in Fort Santiago, Manila. It was staged by Teatro Umalohokan under the direction of Rey Pimentel and Louie Sevilla in Laguna in 1978. It was published in Domingo G. Landicho’s Dupluhang Bayan at Dalawa Pang Dula (People’s Poetic Joust and Two Other Plays), 1991.

The play takes the form of the duplo, the verbal jousting traditionally done at funeral wakes between young men and women. It differs in that instead of being a mere battle of wit and verse, the play has the debaters come together in mutual resolve. Dupluhang Bayan substitutes workers and peasants for the bilyako (male participants) and bilyaka (female participants), but has the tagapagsalita (speaker) present the usual opening question: who is responsible for the loss of the king’s beloved kulasisi (Philippine hanging parrot)? The Magsasaka (peasant) and Manggagawa (worker) begin the battle; the workers react, but the peasants passively follow the king’s orders. The king emphasizes his power: “Pagkat nasa setro ang pangako’t buhay … Ang hari’y siyang kalahatan …” (The sceptre holds all promise and life … thus the king is all …).

 

Dramatized alamat (legend) and tales intersperse the verse debates. “Alamat I” is about the Creation; “Alamat II” about Baltog, Indarapatra, and Lam-ang; “Alamat III,” about two little birds, the tukmo (zebra dove) and the larger tikling (rice bird); “Alamat IV,” about the tsonggo (monkey) and the pagong (turtle); and “Alamat V,” about the arrival of the Spaniards. The stories reveal and illustrate the contending ideologies of service to the kingdom against service to the people, and the powerful against the powerless. The story of creation makes the Manggagawa and Magsasaka realize that after the world was created, it is they who go on creating, planting, working, and fighting. The stories of the mythic heroes raise arguments about power and enslavement: Is use of might right? Is slavery brought upon themselves by the enslaved? The parable of the tukmo shows the triumph of the strong over the weak, and so the duplero (duplo performers) go on to examine the story of the monkey and the turtle, in which each side sees the other in the monkey (the clever) or the turtle (the duped). The king complains that the duplo has gone on long enough. The last scene, a pageant from history, shows how colonization treated the katutubo or the native. The Manggagawa and Magsasaka see how they were both enslaved and victimized, first by the Spanish hari (king) and reyna (queen), and then by the ilustrado (educated). They realize that “Tangi ninyong dalit ay pamamanginoon/At kami ang bayan na ibinabaon/Sa dustang libingan ng dusa’t linggatong” (You only speak of rulership/While we the folk are doomed to grief/In the grave of pain without relief),” and end with:

 

Ang ating alamat

Ay ang lakas natin

Na siyang tutubos

Sa laya ng bayan.

 

(Our own story

Is our strength

Which will win

The nation’s freedom.)  Written by Malou L. Maniquis

article.value: (People’s Poetic Joust). 1976. Dramatized duplo in Filipino. Direction, Lutgardo Labad with Brenda Fajardo; script, Domingo Landicho, Socrates Topacio aka Soxie Topacio, Cecilia B. Garrucho, and Jose Purisima; music, Cynthia Zayas and Fe Prudente. Cast: Joel Lamangan, Melvi Pacubas, Eddie Pagayon, Estrella Antonio, Socrates Topacio, Rudy Hermano, Jerry O’Hara, and Myrna de la Paz. First staged by the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) on 15 Jan 1976 at the Dulaang Rajah Sulayman in Fort Santiago, Manila. It was staged by Teatro Umalohokan under the direction of Rey Pimentel and Louie Sevilla in Laguna in 1978. It was published in Domingo G. Landicho’s Dupluhang Bayan at Dalawa Pang Dula (People’s Poetic Joust and Two Other Plays), 1991.

The play takes the form of the duplo, the verbal jousting traditionally done at funeral wakes between young men and women. It differs in that instead of being a mere battle of wit and verse, the play has the debaters come together in mutual resolve. Dupluhang Bayan substitutes workers and peasants for the bilyako (male participants) and bilyaka (female participants), but has the tagapagsalita (speaker) present the usual opening question: who is responsible for the loss of the king’s beloved kulasisi (Philippine hanging parrot)? The Magsasaka (peasant) and Manggagawa (worker) begin the battle; the workers react, but the peasants passively follow the king’s orders. The king emphasizes his power: “Pagkat nasa setro ang pangako’t buhay … Ang hari’y siyang kalahatan …” (The sceptre holds all promise and life … thus the king is all …).

article.value: Dramatized alamat (legend) and tales intersperse the verse debates. “Alamat I” is about the Creation; “Alamat II” about Baltog, Indarapatra, and Lam-ang; “Alamat III,” about two little birds, the tukmo (zebra dove) and the larger tikling (rice bird); “Alamat IV,” about the tsonggo (monkey) and the pagong (turtle); and “Alamat V,” about the arrival of the Spaniards. The stories reveal and illustrate the contending ideologies of service to the kingdom against service to the people, and the powerful against the powerless. The story of creation makes the Manggagawa and Magsasaka realize that after the world was created, it is they who go on creating, planting, working, and fighting. The stories of the mythic heroes raise arguments about power and enslavement: Is use of might right? Is slavery brought upon themselves by the enslaved? The parable of the tukmo shows the triumph of the strong over the weak, and so the duplero (duplo performers) go on to examine the story of the monkey and the turtle, in which each side sees the other in the monkey (the clever) or the turtle (the duped). text:
(Scene from Prison). 1989. Playlet in Filipino. Direction, Dante; script, an organizer known only as Dante and Tanghalang Silangan; music, Mar Laguna and Tanghalang Silangan. Cast: Tanghalang Silangan and Kairos. It is a collaboration among Tanghalang Silangan of the then Bisig-Pagkakaisa, National Federation of Labor Unions, a religious group Kairos, and some members of Panday Sining. It was originally part of a longer piece, Paraisong Rehas (Chained Paradise), staged at Our Lady of Angels Seminary in 1989. The Eksena ng Kulungan is the core of the longer opus and its centerpiece scene. It was eventually repeatedly mounted as a separate playlet after the Haranang Bayan (People’s Serenade) concert-play at Folk Arts Theater in 1991, where it was performed with other Teatro Pabrika texts. The play’s script appeared in the University of the Philippines (UP) literature textbook Linangan (Field), 1999, and in Simulain: Dulambayan ng Manggagawa sa Konteksto ng Militanteng Kilusang Unyonismo,1980-1994 (Guiding Principle: Workers’ Dulambayan in the Context of the Militant Unionism Movement, 1980-1994), 2009.

Eksena ng Kulungan starts as a group stages a rally in front of the United States Embassy. With police officers at bay, an angel suddenly shows up. As the police apprehend him, the scene freezes and Lukayo, who serves as the narrator, enters to reveal that the play is about one of Saint Peter’s angels sent to earth to retrieve one of Saint Peter’s missing cocks. The angel ends up somewhere near the rally, and gets picked up by the police. Once in jail, the police officers complain about how the prisons are perpetually packed despite some criminals being set free and others being salvaged. Their sergeant tells the police officers not to worry about it. The angel is then thrown into a prison cell, which he shares with a thief, a drug addict, a street vendor, and a student. The angel learns each of his cell members’ reasons for being jailed: the thief steals to feed his family, the street vendor bribes the police for selling on the streets, the addict reasons family problems for taking drugs, and the student protests the increase in tuition fees. Upon hearing this, the angel reflects on how difficult it is to be human. A labor leader comes in and speaks of their protest against inhumane labor conditions and other social issues, such as the opening of the controversial Bataan Nuclear Power Plant. He reiterates a point the student made earlier: anyone who challenges those in power ends up dead or imprisoned. In order to be human, one must live with courage and integrity; one must make a stand.

The angel realizes that Saint Peter sent him to earth precisely to discover the conditions here and to learn to be human. Lukayo then interpolates that the heavens were deaf to the pleas of the angel, and that the angel is sent to several other places such as a cabaret, the countryside, and the factories. As the Lukayo continues to talk about the dangers of the power plant the angel is going to visit, the police blow their whistles at him and arrest him too.

Eksena ng Kulungan asserts the leadership of the working class as proletariat and ideal protagonist amid a society in crisis. Despite the consequences of imprisonment or death, they fight for what they believe in. The characters’ back stories are sung through a string of lapat-awit where new lyrics are fitted unto existing popular tunes touching on social and national issues. The Lukayo directly addresses the audience and cast by making commentary about the play such as:“Teka sandali, teka, siguro nagtataka kayo kung bakit nagkaroon ng anghel sa aming palabas, huwag kayong ma-shock!!!” (Wait, wait, wait, maybe you’re all wondering why there’s an angel in the play. Don’t be shocked!!!).  Written by Ma. Clara Rosario C. Palma, with notes from Apolonio B. Chua

 

Sources

Chua, Apolonio B. et al. 1999. Linangan. 3rd ed. Quezon City: Office of the Vice Chancellor for Research and Development, Office of the Vice Chancellor for Academic Affairs, and Departamento ng Filipino at Panitikan ng Pilipinas, University of the Philippines

text:
(Innocent Girls). 2007. One-act play in Filipino. Direction, set design, and costume design, Tuxqs Rutaquio; script, Layeta Bucoy. Cast: Lovely Balili (Ana) and Ness Roque (Mica). First staged on 1 Jul 2007 as part of Virgin Labfest 3 at the Tanghalang Huseng Batute, Cultural Center of the Philippines. It was part of the Revisited Set in the following year’s Virgin Labfest. In 2010, it was restaged by Maskara Theater Ensemble of the De La Salle University–Bacolod. The play is anthologized in Mga Piling Dula Mula sa Virgin Labfest 2005-2008: Unang Antolohiya (Selected Plays from the Virgin Labfest, 2005-2008: First Anthology), 2009.

After playing their favorite “game,” sisters Ana, eight years old, and Mica, six years old, are beaten and locked up by their spinster aunt and their married uncle. Into two bedrooms they go, separated by a wooden divider, in the house once owned by the girls’ dead father. The aunt tells the girls to wait for her when she returns with their grandmother who will decide what to do with them. Their uncle warns them that if they “play” again, they will be sent back to their mother’s house.

 

Left by themselves, the two girls communicate with each other by knocking at the wooden divider. They have to decide if they will wait for the return of their relatives or escape from the house. Mica insists that they leave the house. Jealous of their cousin RJ, with whom Ana played their favorite game, Mica challenges Ana to choose between her and RJ. Ana assures Mica that she is the better playmate and promises her that she will only play with her. Ana wants to stay in their father’s house because if they escape, they will be forced to go back to their mother’s house.

Mica tries to convince Ana that they are better-off in their mother’s house. Ana doubts Mica’s intentions and accuses her of wanting to go back to their mother’s house so she can play with their half-sister Matet. Mica assures Ana that she will only play with her. She then reminds Ana that although they may have enough food, clothes, and toys in their mother’s house, their mother never hits them and allows them to play whenever they want. Their mother even allows them to watch her play with their “godfathers.”

They eventually decide to escape but all their attempts fail. They then recall their uncle’s warning. As they hear the house’s front door open, they start to play their favorite game—fingering themselves and humping on their pillows as they call out the names of their “godfathers” in imitation of their mother.

Ellas Inocentes presents a disturbing portrait of children losing their innocence because of psychological abuse and the moral depravity of the adults around them. The play is most remembered for its gripping and sensitive staging as well as the harrowing revelations of the characters towards the grim finale. The script won third prize in the one-act play in Filipino category of the Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature in 2007.  Written by Walter Ang

text:
2011.One-act play in English. Direction, Jomari Jose; script, Floy Quintos; set design, Eric Cruz. Cast: Ana Abad Santos (Miranda Beloto), Frances Makil-Ignacio (Mamang), and Jonathan Tadioan (Gov Bingo Beloto). First staged as part of the Virgin Labfest 7 in Jul 2011, it was chosen as one of Virgin Labfest 8’s Revisited plays for 2012. It was published in Floy Quintos: Collected Plays Volume 1, 2014.

In the master bedroom of the governor’s mansion, Miranda Beloto prepares for the premiere night of an Italian opera to be staged at the provincial kapitolyo (capitol). As she awaits the arrival of her husband, incumbent governor Bingo Beloto, she converses with her mother Mamang, who is already dead but is still present as a ghost. Mamang advises Miranda to fulfill her role as a dutiful wife to a governor and as a good daughter to their political clan. Mamang disappears when Bingo walks into the room. Already late for the opera, Bingo makes excuses and asks Miranda to help him decide what to wear. Miranda picks up a suit and a barong but Bingo rejects them both, and even threatens not to come with her to the opera. After a while, Miranda asks where he has been—if he was with Eva. To her surprise, he denies the truth. She reveals that she already knows about Eva and his other women, and that she is on good terms with all of them. Miranda even advised Eva to accept the condominium unit that Bingo offered her. Bingo curses upon knowing that he has been found out.

 

Suddenly he changes the subject and asks whether they should be going to the opera or not. He does not understand how the masses will be able to understand an opera in Italian and suggests that she should have done more popular shows like a sports event or a beauty contest. Mamang, who has been eavesdropping on the conversation, agrees with what Bingo is saying. Then Miranda declares that it is her birthday. Mamang and Bingo make excuses for forgetting Miranda’s birthday. Bingo apologizes for not buying her a gift. Miranda tells him that he has already given her what she wants for her birthday—the funding for the staging of Mascagni’s Cavalleria Rusticana (Rustic Chivalry) in their province. She says it is not necessary to know Italian to connect with this opera. Bingo concedes and now invites her to go. Miranda does not move but instead asks him again where he has been. He reasons that he had a meeting with his Beloto Youth Association on how to “eradicate the leftist threat.” With this lie, Miranda demands that as a dutiful wife, she has the right to know everything. After all, it is she who gives him legitimacy and “class.” With Miranda’s continuous tirade, Bingo then grabs and pins her to the bed, almost suffocating her. Bingo leaves after apologizing for his hostility. Miranda composes herself. It is her birthday after all, and it is the evening of the opera. Mamang tries to talk to her daughter, but Miranda slaps her and stomps out of the room.

The play exemplifies marriages of convenience in local politics, conjugal corruption, as well as the machismo that it cradles. The play also portrays the tenuous balance between the public and private lives of local politicians and how often the personal is sacrificed in favor of the public’s expectations. The script won first prize in the one-act play in English category of the 2011 Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature.  Written by Katrina Stuart Santiago and Erick Dasig Aguilar

text:
2011.Two-act play in English. Direction, Tony Mabesa; script, Floy Quintos; production design, Dante Nico Garcia. Cast: Joel Lamangan/Leo Rialp (Jose Marco), Paul Holme (William Henry Scott), Shamaine Centenera-Buencamino (Sister Emily), Olive Nieto (Sister Emily and Concepcion), Alya Honasan/Ces Quesada (Concepcion), Richard Cunanan (George), Bojong Fernandez/Jerald Napoles (Lobo and Code of Kalantiao), Gerard Pizarras/Brian Tibayan (Miguel), Karen Gaerlan (La Loba Negra), and Ross Pesigan (young Miguel). First staged by the University of the Philippines (UP) Playwrights’ Theater on 4 May 2011 at the Teatro Hermogenes Ylagan of UP Diliman, the play was restaged in Aug 2011 as part of Dulaang UP’s 36th theater season. It was published in Floy Quintos: Collected Plays Volume 2, 2014.

Act 1 begins with Miguel arriving at the Mountain of Revelations, accompanied by Lobo. Miguel is looking for Sister Emily, a miracle woman known to be a medium of the Virgin Mary. Miguel shares his doubts about Sister Emily’s miracles and his desire to reveal the woman as a hoax. Lobo reminisces about his life as a poster boy for the fake Tasaday tribe. They encounter a group of disappointed pilgrims because Sister Emily could not make the Virgin appear. Just as another group of pilgrims pass, Miguel calls out to Lobo who vanishes within the forest. Miguel sees George, a foreigner with a gout-like affliction who is looking for Sister Emily, the miracle worker featured in the documentary. Lobo returns and leads Miguel and George to Sister Emily. She reveals that the Virgin has stopped talking to her and will never come back. The group argues about Sister Emily being a fraud and the country being a “country of fakes.” Then, just as the air smells of roses, petals start to rain. George’s affliction is healed. A rosebud materializes from Sister Emily’s chest and she faints. George takes the rosebud and hands it to Miguel who rejects it and leaves. Sister Emily asks Lobo and George to pray for Miguel so that he may find something that he believes in.

 

In act 2, Miguel visits the home of Jose Marco, a historian and antiquarian, residing in Pontevedra, Negros. Miguel is led inside the house by Concepcion, Jose Marco’s wife. As Concepcion asks Miguel about how the outside world talks about her husband and his work, a young Miguel enters. This glimpse of the past, shows how Jose Marco filled the young Miguel’s head with fiction passed off as historical facts—the Code of Kalantiao, an indigenous Filipino penal code; and La Loba Negra or the Black She-Wolf, a governor-general’s lady-turned-rebel who kills Spanish friars. In exchange for the stories and some historical trinkets, the young Miguel would give Jose Marco old paper and rubber stamp imprints he gets from his family’s baul (vault). Jose Marco and young Miguel enjoy this bond, as they call themselves “mambubulok” or collectors of old useless things—seekers of lost treasures. This bond is put to the test with the arrival of William Henry Scott, an American professor from the University of Santo Tomas. Scott, under the guise of doing a dissertation, interviews Jose Marco on the Code of Kalantiao. The young Miguel arrives in the middle of Jose Marco’s interrogation and realizes that all of his stories were fakes. Jose Marco pleads with Scott not to expose his fraud and insists that what he did was for the good of his country, providing hope and a sense of pride. Before leaving, Scott stresses the importance of exposing truth, especially for historians. Jose Marco justifies that he did everything so that Miguel could have something to believe in. The play ends with the young Miguel exiting as the present Miguel enters. They pause and stand back-to-back as the older Miguel stares at Jose Marco.

Fake demonstrates humanity’s never-ending quest for truth. A fictional narrative that is influenced by nonfictional characters and events, the play emphasizes the importance of always interrogating the stories behind and beneath the “facts.” The business of truth, as Quintos mentions in his notes, will forever be a vague endeavor, a perpetual work in progress.

In his anthology, Quintos clarifies that in the 2009 draft of the play, Jose Marco’s story came first, followed by Sister Emily’s. For the production, the director Mabesa recommended not only interchanging the two acts but also performing the work as two separate one-act plays. Fake won third prize in the full-length play category of the 2009 Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature.   Written by Vladimeir B. Gonzales

article.value: 2011.Two-act play in English. Direction, Tony Mabesa; script, Floy Quintos; production design, Dante Nico Garcia. Cast: Joel Lamangan/Leo Rialp (Jose Marco), Paul Holme (William Henry Scott), Shamaine Centenera-Buencamino (Sister Emily), Olive Nieto (Sister Emily and Concepcion), Alya Honasan/Ces Quesada (Concepcion), Richard Cunanan (George), Bojong Fernandez/Jerald Napoles (Lobo and Code of Kalantiao), Gerard Pizarras/Brian Tibayan (Miguel), Karen Gaerlan (La Loba Negra), and Ross Pesigan (young Miguel). First staged by the University of the Philippines (UP) Playwrights’ Theater on 4 May 2011 at the Teatro Hermogenes Ylagan of UP Diliman, the play was restaged in Aug 2011 as part of Dulaang UP’s 36th theater season. It was published in Floy Quintos: Collected Plays Volume 2, 2014.

Act 1 begins with Miguel arriving at the Mountain of Revelations, accompanied by Lobo. Miguel is looking for Sister Emily, a miracle woman known to be a medium of the Virgin Mary. Miguel shares his doubts about Sister Emily’s miracles and his desire to reveal the woman as a hoax. Lobo reminisces about his life as a poster boy for the fake Tasaday tribe. They encounter a group of disappointed pilgrims because Sister Emily could not make the Virgin appear. Just as another group of pilgrims pass, Miguel calls out to Lobo who vanishes within the forest. Miguel sees George, a foreigner with a gout-like affliction who is looking for Sister Emily, the miracle worker featured in the documentary. Lobo returns and leads Miguel and George to Sister Emily. She reveals that the Virgin has stopped talking to her and will never come back. The group argues about Sister Emily being a fraud and the country being a “country of fakes.” Then, just as the air smells of roses, petals start to rain. George’s affliction is healed. A rosebud materializes from Sister Emily’s chest and she faints. George takes the rosebud and hands it to Miguel who rejects it and leaves. Sister Emily asks Lobo and George to pray for Miguel so that he may find something that he believes in.

value.desc: UP Playwrights’ Theatre’s Fake, starring Joel Lamangan and Ross Pesigan, UP Diliman, 2011 (Dino Dimar, Dulaang UP Collection)

article.value: In act 2, Miguel visits the home of Jose Marco, a historian and antiquarian, residing in Pontevedra, Negros. Miguel is led inside the house by Concepcion, Jose Marco’s wife. As Concepcion asks Miguel about how the outside world talks about her husband and his work, a young Miguel enters. This glimpse of the past, shows how Jose Marco filled the young Miguel’s head with fiction passed off as historical facts—the Code of Kalantiao, an indigenous Filipino penal code; and La Loba Negra or the Black She-Wolf, a governor-general’s lady-turned-rebel who kills Spanish friars. In exchange for the stories and some historical trinkets, the young Miguel would give Jose Marco old paper and rubber stamp imprints he gets from his family’s baul (vault). Jose Marco and young Miguel enjoy this bond, as they call themselves “mambubulok” or collectors of old useless things—seekers of lost treasures. This bond is put to the test with the arrival of William Henry Scott, an American professor from the University of Santo Tomas. Scott, under the guise of doing a dissertation, interviews Jose Marco on the Code of Kalantiao. The young Miguel arrives in the middle of Jose Marco’s interrogation and realizes that all of his stories were fakes. Jose Marco pleads with Scott not to expose his fraud and insists that what he did was for the good of his country, providing hope and a sense of pride. Before leaving, Scott stresses the importance of exposing truth, especially for historians. Jose Marco justifies that he did everything so that Miguel could have something to believe in. The play ends with the young Miguel exiting as the present Miguel enters. They pause and stand back-to-back as the older Miguel stares at Jose Marco.

Fake demonstrates humanity’s never-ending quest for truth. A fictional narrative that is influenced by nonfictional characters and events, the play emphasizes the importance of always interrogating the stories behind and beneath the “facts.” The business of truth, as Quintos mentions in his notes, will forever be a vague endeavor, a perpetual work in progress.

In his anthology, Quintos clarifies that in the 2009 draft of the play, Jose Marco’s story came first, followed by Sister Emily’s. For the production, the director Mabesa recommended not only interchanging the two acts but also performing the work as two separate one-act plays. Fake won third prize in the full-length play category of the 2009 Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature.   Written by Vladimeir B. Gonzales
