text:
2004.Two-act play in English. Direction, Alexander Cortez; script, Floy Quintos. Cast: Ana Abad Santos (Mira), Ebong Joson (Amir), Stella Cañete/Camilla Kim (Simone), Jomari Jose (Jom), Lex Marcos (Alben), and Frances Makil-Ignacio (Renata). First staged on 26 Apr 2004 at the Teatro Hermogenes Ylagan of the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman as part of the UP Playwrights Theater’s (UPPT) 17th season. The following UPPT season saw its restaging as Fluid … Flows Again, 2014. It was published in Floy Quintos: Collected Plays Volume 1, 2014.

In act 1, Mira, an art collector returning from a recent trip, enters the studio of Amir. Mira offers to finance Amir’s next exhibition on the condition that the latter abandon his social realist approach and paint only for the rich and famous. Amir hesitates at first but later concedes. The lovers Alben and Jom, both stage actors, constantly argue about the theater. Alben believes in theater’s social responsibility, while Jom sees theater as a stepping stone to fame. With Jom’s prodding, Alben auditions for a big-budget production but comes out shamed for mispronouncing some English words. The lovers decide to part ways. In a wedding ceremony, events coordinator Simone and coordinator for the Philharmonic Orchestra Renata argue over which musical piece is more apt to be played at different stages of the wedding reception. Simone prefers popular romantic songs, while Renata insists on classical masterpieces. Renata always gets her way, so Simone retaliates by tearing up Renata’s check.

 

The characters all meet in act 2 during Amir’s exhibition opening. Mira attends to the guests and sells the paintings. Simone, still an events coordinator, is now contracted by Mira. Simone insists that an events coordinator is also an artist. Jom has become a famous matinee idol while Alben serves as a waiter. Renata, now an art critic, remembers Alben as the actor who portrayed Alceste in a production, while altogether dismissing Jom’s presence. At that moment, Renata’s comment was all that mattered for Alben. Renata discerns the “shallowness and the emptiness” that Amir tries to cover up in his works. Embarrassed, Amir gets drunk and makes a scene. Mira decides to leave him. In the end, self-proclaimed artist Simone goes out to obey Mira’s order for her to get the chauffer.

In act 1, the scenes alternate between the three couples who seemingly have nothing to do with each other. At times, a character takes the stage and talks to the audience to reveal his or her views on art and life. These alternating scenes generate tension between the characters who take on opposing views regarding “art, life, compromise.” The quick shifts in the scenes in act 1 are contrasted with the direct and uninterrupted encounters between characters who compromise (Mira, Jom, and Simone) and those who don’t (Amir, Alben, and Renata) in act 2.

Fluid won second prize in the Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature in 2003.  Written by Carlo Pacolor Garcia

text:
1940. Three-act play in English. Direction and script, Wilfrido Ma.Guerrero; production, Maria Ansaldo. Cast: Raymundo Lorenzana, Nati Valentin, Emma Benitez, Virginia Mata, Rosalinda Guidote, Angelo Castro, Johnny Setzer, Francisco A. Garcia, Celestino Carlos, Aurora Diño, Pacita Santiago, Ricardo Puno, Philip Buencamino III, Gonzalo Misa, and Mariano Villarin. First staged on 27 Feb 1940 at the Manila Grand Opera House. Staged in Jan 1944 at the Metropolitan Theater in Manila by Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero in the Juan C. Laya Tagalog translation, Ulilang Tahanan, with Angelo Castro, Cory Ylagan, Corazon Ma. Garcia, Nelly Ordoñez, Nelly Javalera, Fred Montilla, Jesus Pimentel, Rene Antonio, Luciano Tapia, Carmen Bernardino, Pacita Francisco, Oscare Frazenda, Bert Zamora, Morris Costello, Josefina Tando, and Ruben Saplala. The film version, under the direction of Gerardo de Leon, was shown in Jun 1944 at the Capitol Theater under the title House for Sale. It was first published in The Herald Magazine in 1940, and in Spanish in La Vanguardia in 1941.

 

This play dramatizes the tragic story of a family torn apart by the tension between old and new, and differences in ways and moral standards. Don Ramon imposes upon his children the rigid treatment under which he had been brought up. As master of the house, his word is law and obeyed by his wife, Doña Encarna, and his children who, although showered with material comforts, fall apart one by one. Flavio is knifed in a nightclub brawl. Clemencia succumbs to illness. Adeling marries to find escape, but is trapped in an immature relationship. Gonzalo, the dearest and the youngest, seeks to assuage loneliness in the company of women, but contracts a sexual disease. Jorge is found to have gambled away his classmates’ money, and chooses to leave home and face life on his own. The sensible Teresita seeks permission to enter the convent. To everything, Don Ramon responds negatively, blaming his children for their failures and weaknesses and becoming more strict with each perceived fault. Doña Encarna sympathizes with the children, but defers to her husband completely. Carlos, Ramon’s brother, serves as friend and confidant to the children, and reminds his brother that “youth has an excess of energy which must find a natural outlet.” Ramon hurries to save the last of his children, Gonzalo, by giving him time, affection, and freedom to be himself.

The significance of this play derives from its being one of the first examples of psychological realism.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

text:
2013. Two-act play in English. Direction and production design, Ed Lacson Jr; script, Glenn Sevilla Mas; original music and sound design, Teresa Barrozo; light execution, Ninya Bedruz. Cast: Kalil Almonte (Diego), Thea Yrastorza (Luna), and Abner Delina Jr (Julio). First staged as a dramatic reading by Tanghalang Pilipino for Virgin Labfest 3 on 29 Jun 2007 at the Tanghalang Aurelio Tolentino of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). The play had its first full staging on 16 Oct 2013 as Lacson’s thesis production at the Teatro Hermogenes Ylagan, University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman. The play was restaged on 24 Nov 2013 as part of Sipat Lawin Ensemble’s Karnabal: Def. Defying Festival at the National Commission for Culture and the Arts, Intramuros, Manila; on 22-23 Feb 2014 as part of MNL X: Festival of New Performances at the Tanghalang Huseng Batute, CCP; and on 26 Feb to 6 Mar and 22-26 Apr 2014 as part of the Ateneo Fine Arts Program’s production at the Ateneo Black Box Theater, Ateneo de Manila University.

Set in a village in Panay Island, the play revolves around three characters who gradually reveal and confront their inner “monsters” through the games they play with each other, from their childhood to teenage years. Julio is an effeminate boy who cannot come to terms with his gayness because this is not accepted by his family. Luna is a plain and trusting girl who tries to free herself from the lustful dreams haunting her by entering the convent. The dreams were of her parents making love, an act she had watched live. Diego is a boy filled with confusion, being a fatherless boy and son to a negligent mother. He grows to be more confused than before, and gets intimate with Julio.

 

The play begins with the three characters grimly reciting familiar yet twisted lines from fairy tales, foreshadowing the dark tone of the play. The three friends then proceed to play their favorite games—pitik-bulag (guessing game), bahay-bahayan (playing house), marbles—which serve as outlets to express their repressed desires, their deep-seated “monsters.” While playing bahay-bahayan, Diego and Luna clash over whether they should make love, as husband and wife do at night. In playing pitik-bulag, Julio challenges Diego to lower his pants if the latter loses. Diego agrees and the two start to be intimate with each other. With each game, they are able to understand why they are the way they are. They get to know themselves deeper, even the monsters they fear themselves to be. As they age, their relationships get strained and they eventually separate ways. Years pass and the three meet once again, updating each other about their lives in the most awkward manner. The scars of their childhood have remained with them in adulthood, so they are still unable to face the monsters they fear themselves to be.

The play depicted the complex inner struggles of people resulting from their childhood experiences. Although written in English, the locality of the material was established by the use of Karay-A and/or Hiligaynon-laced English. The stark minimalism of the production contrasted with the material’s complexity. Cardboard box cutouts resembling a castle, a chapel, and a forest created the main characters’ individual spaces. The actors were clad in black, over which were worn pieces—a teddy bear, a rosary, and a shawl—to identify character and scene shift.

Games People Play won second prize in the full-length play in English category of the Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature in 2007. It was awarded Best Non-musical Production, Best Director, and Best Ensemble Acting in the 2014 Aliw Awards.  Written by Tyron Judes de la Calsada Casumpang

article_title: Gonzalo De Cordoba/Comedia Heroica De La Conquistada De Granada O Sea Vida De Don Gonzalo De Cordoba Llamado El Gran Capitan

photos.desc: Illustration of a komedya performance (Philippine Saga: A Pictorial History of the Archipelago Since Time Began by Henry Otley Beyer and Jaime C. de Veyra. The Evening News, 1947)

text:
(Heroic Comedia on the Conquest of Granada or the Life of Don Gonzalo de Cordoba Known as the Great Captain). 1831. Three-part komedya in Kapampangan. Script, Anselmo Jorge de Fajardo. First staged in Feb 1831 in Bacolor, Pampanga. It was the only time it is known to have been staged. It was printed by Cornelio Pabalan Byron, 1912.

This verse play was inspired by the historical Gonzalo de Cordoba (1453-1515) who was a general in the service of Reyna Isabela and was among those responsible for recovering Granada from the Moors who had occupied it for three centuries. Gonzalo’s military exploits appeared tailor-made for the komedya, but Fajardo made alterations on his amorous conquests by including a fictional romance with Zulema, a beautiful Moorish princess. This interweaving of historical and fictional threads spun the tapestry of Gonzalo de Cordoba’s fame as folk hero.

Like other komedya, Gonzalo de Cordoba has an extremely intricate plot. During the invasion of a Muslim city, Gonzalo falls in love at first sight with Zulema. Nothing comes out of that first encounter because Gonzalo is sent on another mission, this time to Africa. During Gonzalo’s absence from the Christian camp, a letter arrives. It is addressed to Gonzalo by Zulema and her sister-in-law, Reyna Zoraida. The latter, who has been falsely accused of plotting the murder of her husband, the despotic Boabdil, begs Gonzalo to come to her defense. On behalf of the absent Gonzalo, Conde de Lara goes to Granada and saves the queen’s life as well as her honor. Meanwhile, Zulema is abducted by Almanzor and taken prisoner on a ship bound for Africa. Gonzalo, who is on his way back to Spain disguised as a Moor, rescues Zulema. They anchor at Malaga, where Zulema nurses the wounded Gonzalo—only known to her as the African knight. Learning of his daughter’s rescue, Muley Hassem promises Zulema’s hand to any one of her four suitors (one of whom is the African knight) who can capture Gonzalo. When Gonzalo reveals his true identity to Zulema, the Moorish princess nevertheless assures him of her love. Gonzalo surprises his rivals by revealing his identity to them, and easily defeats them in combat. Meantime, the news of Gonzalo’s impending arrival in Granada causes panic among the inhabitants. Almanzor, the brother of Zulema, challenges Gonzalo to personal combat. Without Gonzalo’s knowledge, Reyna Isabela accepts the challenge. Gonzalo thus finds himself caught between his loyalty to the queen and his love for Zulema. When Gonzalo fails to arrive on time, Conde de Lara puts on Gonzalo’s armor and kills Almanzor. Gonzalo then rushes to Zulema to explain what had happened, but he is captured by Boabdil’s men and is sentenced to death. The wounded Lara hears this and he confesses that it was he who killed Almanzor. Refusing to have his friend sacrifice his life for him, Gonzalo insists that he is guilty. The matter is settled when Lara exhibits the wounds he received during that fateful combat. Muley Hassem is so moved by the friendship between the two men that he releases them both. Angered, Boabdil imprisons his father and his sister. In response to Zulema’s plea for help, Gonzalo invades Granada. On behalf of Spain, he claims the city of Granada and, on his own behalf, claims the hand of Zulema.

 

This Kapampangan kumidya is only one of many similarly romanticized accounts of Gonzalo de Cordoba’s life. What distinguishes Fajardo’s version from the others is its epic proportions. Possibly the longest work in Philippine literature, it consists of three volumes of 832 pages and 31,000 lines. The three volumes correspond to its formal division into three jornadas (day’s journeys). When it was staged, the performance took seven nights. Its scope appears to run the entire gamut of human experience because the poet-priest Fajardo took the opportunity to moralize on all aspects of human experience. The work became a veritable treasury of maxims, both spiritual and secular.

The work was most appealing to the ears of its Kapampangan audience because of its lyrical manipulation of the Kapampangan language: the richness of its vocabulary, the refinement of its rhetoric, and the intricate turns of phrasing. The most famous Kapampangan kumidya, it is regarded as a regional masterpiece. What Florante at Laura is to the Tagalog, Gonzalo de Cordoba is to the Kapampangan.  Written by Edna Z. Manlapaz

 

Source

Manlapaz, Edna Zapanta. 1981. Kapampangan Literature, A Historical Survey and Anthology. Quezon City: Ateneo University Press.

Almanzor, the brother of Zulema, challenges Gonzalo to personal combat. Without Gonzalo’s knowledge, Reyna Isabela accepts the challenge. Gonzalo thus finds himself caught between his loyalty to the queen and his love for Zulema. When Gonzalo fails to arrive on time, Conde de Lara puts on Gonzalo’s armor and kills Almanzor. Gonzalo then rushes to Zulema to explain what had happened, but he is captured by Boabdil’s men and is sentenced to death. The wounded Lara hears this and he confesses that it was he who killed Almanzor. Refusing to have his friend sacrifice his life for him, Gonzalo insists that he is guilty. The matter is settled when Lara exhibits the wounds he received during that fateful combat. Muley Hassem is so moved by the friendship between the two men that he releases them both. Angered, Boabdil imprisons his father and his sister. In response to Zulema’s plea for help, Gonzalo invades Granada. On behalf of Spain, he claims the city of Granada and, on his own behalf, claims the hand of Zulema.

article.value: This Kapampangan kumidya is only one of many similarly romanticized accounts of Gonzalo de Cordoba’s life. What distinguishes Fajardo’s version from the others is its epic proportions. Possibly the longest work in Philippine literature, it consists of three volumes of 832 pages and 31,000 lines. The three volumes correspond to its formal division into three jornadas (day’s journeys). When it was staged, the performance took seven nights. Its scope appears to run the entire gamut of human experience because the poet-priest Fajardo took the opportunity to moralize on all aspects of human experience. The work became a veritable treasury of maxims, both spiritual and secular.

The work was most appealing to the ears of its Kapampangan audience because of its lyrical manipulation of the Kapampangan language: the richness of its vocabulary, the refinement of its rhetoric, and the intricate turns of phrasing. The most famous Kapampangan kumidya, it is regarded as a regional masterpiece. What Florante at Laura is to the Tagalog, Gonzalo de Cordoba is to the Kapampangan.  Written by Edna Z. Manlapaz

article_title: Gran Comedia De La Toma Del Pueblo De Corralat Y Conquista Del Cerro
text:
(Grand Play on the Capture of the Town of Corralat and the Conquest of the Hill). 1637. Comedia in Spanish. Script, Hieronimo Perez, SJ. First staged in Manila on 15 Jul 1637.

This comedia is believed to have been shown to celebrate the victory of Gov-Gen Sebastian Hurtado de Corcuera over Cachil Corralat (Sultan Kudarat) of Mindanao. When Corcuera arrived in the Philippines in 1635, he had orders from Philip IV to punish the Muslim pirates severely and stop their raids in the Visayas and Luzon. His victory over Kudarat in May 1637 climaxed a long campaign that had begun in February, and in which Jesuit missionaries and his chaplain, Marcello Mastrilli, SJ, helped by bearing news, recruiting Visayan soldiers, and finally accepting the submission of the datus. With troops consisting of Spaniards, Kapampangan, and Visayan, Corcuera’s assaults caused Kudarat to withdraw to a stronghold on a cerro or hill, which was finally taken. Corcuera returned to Manila on 24 May and was welcomed in triumph, the Jesuits making special preparations, including a triumphal arch and declamations. On 6 Jun, some boys started to play moros y cristianos (moors and christians), enacting Corcuera’s battle so enthusiastically that the boy who played Kudarat fell from the wall and had five stitches taken in his head. This may or may not have influenced the fact that on 15 Jul, at the formal celebration in thanksgiving for the victory, the Gran Comedia was presented, telling of the events of the campaign and of the zeal, faith, and piety of the Society of Jesus. There was also a loa and a torneo (tournament) with prizes.

Both events—the boys’ play and the Jesuits’ play—were recorded. The boys’ play is the first time in the country that the Moor-Christian conflict had been rendered in a theatrical manner while the Jesuits’ play is the first play written in the country with Philippine subject matter. The later komedya did not deal with the Muslims of Mindanao but with the bearded Moor of imported Spanish literature. The Gran Comedia is the first Spanish play written in the Philippines that dealt with an actual encounter between the Moors and Christians of Philippine history.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

 

Source

Retana, Wenceslao E. 1909. Noticias Historico-Bibliograficas de el Teatro en Filipinas desde Sus Origines hasta 1899. Madrid: Libreria General de Victoriano Suarez.

article_title: Ang Gutom Sang Negros, Gutom Sang Banwa
text:
(The Hunger of Negros, The Country’s Hunger). 1980. Two-act play with prologue, in Hiligaynon. Direction and script, Alan Abadesco. Cast: Out-of-school youths playing the roles of obreros (workers), a union member, the amo (landlord or master), and government employees. First staged by Teatro Pangkatilingban in Negros Occidental in 1980.

This play demonstrates the complexity of the feudal relationship between hacendero (sugar plantation owner) and obrero by placing it in the national and global context of that era. Interspersed in the play’s actions are the workers’ discussions in both dialogue and song, clarifying the structural and systemic causes of their oppressed condition.

Before the start of the dramatic action, there is a prologue in song, which provides an analytical framework for the play. The cast sings of the abundance of natural resources in the Philippines and asks why there is hunger amid this abundance.

In a kampo (cane field), obreros reenact the karga-tapas (the cutting and loading of cane) in slow motion. The dance is over and they sit down to rest, groaning with hunger. The hacendero arrives on the scene and shouts invectives at them for malingering. The scene dramatizes the feudal relationship between a bullying amo and his workers who are typically cowed, except one who is resentful of the amo’s verbal abuse. When the workers explain to their amo that they are too weak with hunger to continue working, he brusquely replies that he is unable to pay the workers their just wages because he himself is being cheated by the government. He exits, and the workers continue their discussion. One obrero, a union member, explains to his fellow workers that the sugar industry has collapsed due to the Philippine government’s dependence on US economic policies. Another worker observes that prices of agricultural equipment have gone up. The union member traces these various conditions to the worldwide recession that began in the 1970s. The workers realize that the legal, political, and wage systems are interrelated. Martial law itself has legalized unjust wages and enforces the laws that maintain these by curtailing freedom of assembly and speech. To assuage their hunger, the workers apply for a rice loan with the state-controlled Philippine Sugar Marketing Association. At its office, they go through the application process but are caught up in the government bureaucracy, filling up form after form although there is no loan in sight.

In the end, the play reveals that hunger is not caused solely by an oppressive landlord but is the symptom of the power relations among the various systems, which are all protected and upheld by the fascistic forces of the state. The workers’ inevitable recourse is to call for unity of all social classes and sectors. They go on strike, which the play stresses is in heroic defiance of martial law. They are violently dispersed by the military. The play’s denouement presents a collage of current events in Negros in the way of a docudrama. Thus, events in Negros are shown to be not isolated but are dramatic illustrations of the interlocking relationship of the state’s political and fascistic forces.

An earlier version is a plot-driven one-act play, Gutom sang Negros, staged in 1979. It presents the class conflict as that between good and evil—the good being the oppressed workers’ class and the villain being the harsh and exploitative hacendero class. The expanded 1980 version is an expository play aimed at conscientization, which is the process of understanding the roots of social injustice and countering these with the appropriate measures. Thus, a conscientisizing play deliberately goes against the grain of melodrama: actions and dialogues function to inform and raise the audience’s political consciousness and ends neither in defeat nor in victory but with a call to action.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero

article_title: Half an Hour in a Convent

photos.desc: Half an Hour in a Convent, Manila Grand Opera House, 1941 (UP Library Collection)

text:
1938. One-act play in English. Script, Wilfrido Ma.Guerrero. Written in 1934, it was published in the The Literary Apprentice, 1936. First read over radio station KZRM on 4 Apr 1937 under the direction of Lamberto V. Avellana, with the following cast: Daisy P. Hontiveros, Patria Panajon, Cita Trinidad, and Nati N. Valentin. First staged on 15 Jan 1938 at the University of the Philippines (UP) Little Theater by an acting and directing class at UP, under the direction of Jean Edades with the following cast: Luz Baluyot, Justa Valdez, Nellie Sevillano, and Felisa Manzano. Its Filipino version, Kalahating Oras sa Isang Kumbento, by Lilia F. Antonio was published in 18 Plays Translated in Pilipino, 1985.

 

This play shows the suffering of a sensitive and highly emotional girl, Yolanda, a convent-school girl, found by the nuns to be inattentive to her studies, rebellious, disobedient, and quarrelsome. She is caught reading forbidden books and speaking to a boy-servant and is threatened with expulsion. Sister Vitalis tries to understand Yolanda, who fears her father, yearns for the love she did not find in her own home since her mother died, and writes letters to the servant whom she believes loves her. However, the Mother Superior, adhering strictly to rules and believing that the incident is a disgrace to the convent school, wishes to expel her so as not to set a precedent. Her father agrees, and it is decided that she return to her family. Dreading her father’s anger and the prospect of returning to the province, Yolanda pleads with the Mother Superior for reconsideration, promising to obey convent rules. She is refused, and Sister Theresa is asked to take her to pack her things while her father waits in the hall. On her way, Yolanda falls down the marble stairs and dies instantly. Although Sister Theresa thinks it was an accident, the Mother Superior believes it was deliberate. “Poor Yolanda,” exclaims Sister Vitalis, “To the end misunderstood!”

Half an Hour in a Convent is the first play in the country to deal with the subject of suicide and the repression of Catholic convent schools. Its ending has been adapted by whoever produced it according to particular circumstances (e.g., Catholic schools altered the ending by showing Yolanda either going home to her father or staying on with the nuns; the secular schools retained its original ending). It is one of the most staged plays in the country, forming part of the repertoire of the UP Dramatic Club and then the UP Mobile Theater, both under the direction of the playwright.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis

photos.desc: Sining Kambayoka Ensemble’s Halik sa Kampilan, 1987 (Nicanor G. Tiongson Collection)

text:
(Kiss on the Sword). 1978. Musical dance-drama in Filipino. Direction and script, Frank G. Rivera. Cast: Sining Kambayoka ensemble. The play was first staged as part of the Pistang Kambayoka at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) in 1978. The play has had over one thousand productions in local and international theater festivals since. The play was published as Frank G. Rivera’s Halik sa Kampilan: Dulang Kambayoka (Frank G. Rivera’s Kiss on the Sword: Kambayoka Play), 2006.

The play opens with the rebel Abdul doing the rite of paghuhuramentado or running amok after he found his parents dead in their house that was burned by the foreigners. Jamail and Fatima, an educated Muslim couple from affluent families, argue on Christian and Muslim values and customs, on maintaining traditions versus defying them, and on their stance about colonialism and colonization. Three new characters—Spanish, American, and Japanese—are introduced as selfish magnates who wish to buy the land in Mindanao for their business expansions. The businessmen win in coaxing the people to sell their precious lands, and in holding Jamail and other innocent natives captive. As the play ends, Fatima agrees to sell her family’s land in return for Jamail’s freedom, but she has been deceived. The play ends with an image of Jamail kissing the kampilan as he joins Abdul and the rebels.

 

Halik sa Kampilan is Sining Kambayoka’s most prominent production. However, an issue concerning its authorship and originality surfaced in the theater community after the play was first shown. The title of the play came from an original script by Leonardo V. Ilagan, which won third prize in the 1969 CCP Playwriting Contest. The script by Ilagan was supposed to be part of the CCP’s Pistang Kambayoka and was given to Frank G. Rivera for direction. Rivera, perceiving the script as anti-Muslim, changed the material and produced a new work while retaining the title. He patterned some scenes after the plays Ai’dao!, which tackles political dynasties and landgrabbing, and Hawla (Cage), which concerns illegal logging. He inserted several distinguishable Muslim rites during the show so as to further introduce to the audience the Muslim community and to provide the audience a background as to where the issues of the conflict were coming from. The play has been boldly staged several times during the martial law.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis

 

Source

Casanova, Arthur P., Felix P. Tapongot, and Louela B. Floresca, eds. 2006. Frank G. Rivera’s Halik sa Kampilan (Dulang-Kambayoka). Manila: UST Publishing House.

photos.desc: PETA’s Halimaw, featuring Lito Flores and Angie Ferro, Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Manila, 1971 (PETA Library and Archives)

text:
(Monster). 1971. Sarsuwela in three acts, in Filipino. Direction, Felix Padilla Jr aka Nonon Padilla; libretto, Isagani R.Cruz; music, Lutgardo Labad Jr; costume design, Brenda Fajardo; lighting design, Duk Hyoong Yoo. Cast: Carlito Antolin, Lito Flores, Socrates Topacio aka Soxie Topacio, Spanky Manikan, Noemi Manikan-Gomez, Joy Soler, Ma. Martha Fucoy, Marichelle Roque Maloles, Alma Cruz, Angie Ferro, Ding Quejada, Moises de los Reyes, Jose Gruta, Malynne Fernandez, Melvi Pacubas, Mariano Elepaño, Buddy Lopez, Ariosto Reyes, and Raul Salvador. First staged by Cecile Guidote and Teodoro F. Valencia for the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) Kalinangan Ensemble on 25 Sep 1971 at the Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Fort Santiago, Manila. It was published in Isagani R. Cruz’s Josephine and Other Plays, 1988.

This play is about three princesses kidnapped by three monsters, and the quest to find them. Their father, a Muslim king, rules the land from the palace. His many wives complain of not being able to see him more than once a year. His favorite daughters—Maria 1, Maria 2, and Maria 3—were taking an afternoon stroll on Jones Bridge when they were blown away by a strong wind, and delivered into the clutches of three monsters. The servant Alberto, known to be the most stupid, volunteers to find the princesses. In his journey, he acquires boots that transport him to far places; anuno’s (gnome) ring that answers questions; a kapre’s (tree giant) hat that makes one disappear; twin brothers Juan 1 and Juan 2, who hold keys for opening and closing any door; and a guitar that can make everyone dance endlessly. Armed with anting-anting (amulets), Alberto finds the princesses. Maria 3 is found in the kingdom of Binibining Sirena, who has been promoting drug use among the youth. Maria 2 is found in the kingdom of Ginang Purista, whom Alberto defeats in a bugtungan (riddle contest), aided by the ring. Maria 1 has been brainwashed to work as secretary of the three-headed Ginoong Dragon. Love develops among the princesses and their rescuer, much to the king’s dismay. Toward the end, Alberto kicks the king toward the angry activists, and is hailed as the new king. Alberto, just like the previous king, succumbs to wealth and power, practicing beheading as a form of punishment. He gives everyone a gift of marijuana, and decides to marry all three princesses, and more wives, for his harem.

 

Halimaw was the first to use the sarsuwela form in contemporary theater, and assumed that if it had been allowed to grow instead of being stifled by bodabil and the movies, it would have been tremendously influenced by current theatrical trends. It combines themes and techniques from folk literature, Brechtian epic theater, the theater of the absurd, the Broadway musical comedy, Chinese revolutionary theater, and underground theater to come up with a metaphor of its time.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis

It combines themes and techniques from folk literature, Brechtian epic theater, the theater of the absurd, the Broadway musical comedy, Chinese revolutionary theater, and underground theater to come up with a metaphor of its time.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis

article_title: Hanggang Dito na lamang at maraming salamat

photos.desc: Manny Castañeda, at the back, and Lino Brocka in PETA’s Hanggang Dito na Lamang at Maraming Salamat Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Manila, 1974 (Nicanor G. Tiongson Collection)

text:
(This is All, and Many Thanks). 1974. Full-length play in Filipino. Direction, Lutgardo Labad Jr; script, Orlando R. Nadres. Cast: Lino Brocka (Fidel Palma), Bembol Roco (Efren Reynoso), and Manny Castañeda (Julie). First staged by the Philippine Educational Theate rAssociation (PETA) Kalinangan Ensemble in Dec 1974 at the Dulaang Dambana, Fort Santiago, Manila.

Fidel Palma, a middle-aged man who keeps his homosexuality secret, finances the education of Efren Reynoso, for whom he feels a fatherly affection that eventually turns into sexual attraction. Efren ironically hates gays. Julie—whose real name is Julius Caesar Aquino—is Fidel’s best friend and keeper of his secret; Julie is homosexual and a transvestite.

 

The play takes place in a quiet provincial town, in summertime. Fidel has just received a letter from Efren, who plans to take a brief vacation from his studies and do part-time work in a factory in Manila. Like all the letters and season cards he has written Fidel, this one ends with “Hanggang dito na lamang, at maraming salamat po.” Seemingly content, Fidel quietly prepares for Efren’s arrival, all the while confiding his feelings to Julie, who advises him to come clean and tell Efren about his affection—and thus his homosexuality. Efren arrives, and meets Julie, whom he regards coldly. Their conversation is less than friendly, and in it Julie insinuates that Efren’s education is being supported by a homosexual. Disgusted, Efren reports this to his Tiyo Fidel, and recalls his encounter with his landlady’s gay son, who cornered him one day. Calling gays names, Efren proudly recalls how he kicked the guy’s private parts and punched him in the stomach. Full of emotion, Fidel can no longer contain himself, and his actions betray him. Seeing his Tiyo Fidel as he truly is, Efren struggles to get away. In the last scene, Julie, who just entered wearing a gown from a gay beauty contest, nags the crestfallen Fidel, pointing out how weak he was. Fidel loses his temper and grabs and tears Julie’s gown. Julie runs, holding on to the sash he had won in that night’s contest. Efren drops by to say goodbye before catching his train. Fidel tells him how he hated being a man, because his father had been so cruel. He asks Efren to allow him to love him—while expecting nothing in return. Efren kisses his hand in respect, and quietly leaves.

Hanggang Dito na Lamang is the first play to openly tackle the gender issue, showing an empathetic understanding of homosexuals and their humanity, and how society regards and treats them. It has been presented in many towns and cities outside Metro Manila, often to full houses of mixed audiences.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis

article_title: Hibik at Himagsik nina Victoria Laktaw Atbp.

photos.desc: Dulaang UP’s Hibik at Himagsik nina Victoria Laktaw Atbp., UP Diliman, 2002 (Dulaang UP Collection)

text:
(Plea and Revolt of Victoria Laktaw and Others). 2002. Sarsuwela in three acts, in Filipino. Direction, Alexander Cortez; script, Bienvenido Lumbera and Lucien Letaba; musical direction, Butch de Juan; musical arrangement, Melvin Corpin; choreography, Myra Beltran; stage and costume design, Salvador F. Bernal; lights, Voltaire de Jesus; sounds, John Ballesteros. Cast: Michelle Montero (Chayong), Arnold Reyes/Al Fermin Gatmaitan (Bindoy), Agnes Barredo/Jeannelle Bihag (Conching), Raymond Roldan (Tino), Gamaliel Viray (Don Goring), Sonia Valenciano (Maestra Ticang), Greg de Leon (General Malvar), Chynna Roxas (Ayang), Jean Judith Javier (Gare), Jovy Peregrino, Randel O’Neal Mendoza, and Edna Mae Landicho. First staged by Dulaang Unibersidad ng Pilipinas (UP) at the Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero Theater in UP Diliman on 13 Feb 2002.

The play is inspired by the poem “Hibik Namin” (Our Plea), which was published by the Heraldo Filipino on 17 Feb 1899 to bring attention to the fate of Filipino women who were victims of rape by American soldiers. The play narrates the stories behind the women who authored the poem under the pseudonyms Victoria Laktaw, Felipa Kapuloan, Feliza Kahatol, Victoria Mausig, Patricia Himagsik, Salvadora Dimagiba, Dolores Katindig, Honorata Dimaiuga, and Deodata Liwanag.

 

The play opens in the year 1899 in Lipa, Batangas, where six young women—Chayong, Conching, Andang, Petring, Ayang, and Gare—are rehearsing for a performance in honor of Maestra Ticang’s birthday. Chayong stays behind after the rehearsals, and Bindoy grabs this chance to woo her. At first, Chayong doubts Bindoy’s sincerity, but eventually admits that she has feelings for him. Overjoyed, Bindoy tells Tino the good news. Tino, however, reminds Bindoy that they live in an era of war. The two soon receive a letter ordering them to go to General Malvar’s camp in the mountains. They decide to leave the women in the town. But Chayong and Conching insist that they are just as capable as men and refuse to be left behind. At General Malvar’s camp, Chayong receives news of two sisters, Sabel and Pinang, who were brutally raped by American soldiers. She then suggests to Don Goring that they publish the story in the Columnas Volantes. Don Goring agrees and Asun coaxes Sabel, the older of the victims, to relate what happened. As Sabel finishes her story, Conching suggests that they publish the wrongdoings of the American soldiers, but withhold the identities of the sisters to shield them from shame and probable backlash. Conching suggests publishing a poem instead, with the verses written by Chayong. Chayong agrees but only with the help of all. As preparations are made to leave the camp for the war, Bindoy speaks to Chayong, asking her to stay with him. She refuses, stating that she has to take care of the hysterical Pinang. Reluctantly, Bindoy agrees. In the midst of the revolution, Pinang runs away from the American soldiers and Chayong chases after her. Chayong is captured by the American soldiers. In 1902, Chayong, Conching, Ayang, and Gare gather and reminisce. Then Tino and an American soldier, Peter, come to escort Chayong to her English lessons. Peter denies Tino’s accusations of American abuses and asks for proof of such wrongdoing. Chayong presents herself as proof, bringing to light how she was raped by the Americans. Peter excuses himself. Having heard Chayong’s plight, Bindoy apologizes to Chayong for abruptly disappearing; the two reconcile. Sabel arrives and says that the Republic of the Philippines is waiting for Victoria Laktaw. Chayong says Victoria Laktaw is ready.

The play makes use of the sarsuwela’s simple framework for presenting the ideological and historical aspects of the play, but enriches the narrative and the characterizations through song and dance. This makes the play much more engaging and comprehensible to the contemporary audience. The play serves as a reminder of the lives lost during the Philippine-American War and to give prominence to the women who have been silenced by the pages of history though they were instrumental in the liberation of the Filipino people. The play shared second place with two other sarsuwelas in the sarsuwela contest sponsored by the National Centennial Commission in 1998.  Written by Athena Angela Aquino

 

Source

Lumbera, Bienvenido L. 2003. Sa Sariling Bayan: Apat na Dulang may Musika. Maynila: De La Salle University Press.

photos.desc: Gantimpala Theater Foundation’s Hiblang Abo, starring, from left, Lou Veloso, Ces Aldaba, Dante Balois, and Bodjie Pascua, Gantimpala Theater, 2009 (Photo courtesy of Gantimpala Theater Foundation)

text:
(Strands of Gray). 1980. Three-act play in Filipino. Direction, Tony Espejo; script, Rene O. Villanueva; music, Lucrecia R. Kasilag; production design, Ray Albano; lighting design, Tony Espejo. Cast: Venchito Galvez, Bruno Punzalan, Joe Gruta, Peanuts Rigonan, Ginnie Sobrino, Michael de Loyola, and Pen Medina. First staged by Bulwagang Gantimpala on 5 Sep 1980 at the Bulwagang Gantimpala, later Tanghalang Huseng Batute, of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). Restaged by the same company in 1984, after the death of Galvez and Punzalan, with the addition of Joonee Gamboa, Mervyn Samson, and Sabatini Fernandez. It has also been staged by the University of the East and Teatro Santa Ana. It was published in The Literary Apprentice, 1981-82, and in Linangan (Field), 1992. Its English translation, Strands of Gray by Doreen G. Fernandez, was published in Modern ASEAN Plays, 1992, edited by Nicanor G.Tiongson.

The play tells of life in a home for the aged, revolving around themes of conflict and death and focusing on four male residents, aged 70-75. Huse, once a komiks writer, recalls how burlesque slowly took over bodabil, leading to the closure of the Clover Theater. Blas, who keeps his past mysterious, is a former worker who turned against the union, and was responsible for the death of some union leaders. Only one of the others knew him then, Sotero, a former inmate at Muntinlupa. Sotero lives in the past, often dreaming, and pretending to see his youngest daughter Victoria. He too has his secrets: Victoria, forced to work in the household of Don Sixto as payment for the land Sotero tilled; her rape by the landlord; the loss of land and dignity; his having killed Don Sixto; Victoria’s death at 15; his imprisonment and the illness that brought him to a home for the aged and abandoned. Pedro, once a robust breadwinner, had a wife with whom marriage was a constant fight; when illness diminished him, he became a family burden and was abandoned.

 

As the strands of life—the title refers both to graying hair and fading lives—wear thin, death becomes for all four a hounding reality that they fear to confront. But they go, one by one. Sotero is strangled by his former Muntinlupa companion. Blas dies after being arrested by the police. Pedro, who feared death the most, takes his own life. Huse, waiting endlessly, is left alone in the dark, visited by memories and waiting for the end as the curtain falls.

Hiblang Abo won second prize in the 1980 CCP Playwriting Contest. It is one of the best contemporary plays using modern realism.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis and Nicanor G. Tiongson

article_title: Hinabing Pakpak ng ating mga Anak

photos.desc: Dulaang UP’s Hinabing Pakpak ng Ating Mga Anak, UP Diliman, 2008 (Dulaang UP Collection)

text:
(The Woven Wings of Our Children). 2008. Two-act play in Filipino. Concept, script, and direction, Anton Juan Jr; choreography, Dexter M. Santos; dramaturgy and assistant direction, Pat Valera; set design, Leo Abaya; lights design, John Ilao Batalla; sound and music design, Jethro Joaquin; costume design, Carlo Pagunaling; makeup design, Carlo Cannu; photography, Paul Mondok. Cast: Earl Ignacio (Mata 1), Joel Saracho (Mata 2), Mara Marasigan/Via Antonio (Rosemarie), John Carlo Santos/Zaf Masahud (Bakwit), Ava Santos/Nikka Angeles (Grace), Inno Martin/Rico del Rosario (Haram), Olive Nieto/Chic San Agustin/Lucky de Mesa (unnamed housemaid), Katherine Sabate/Claudine Patajo (Marian), Mary Jane Alejo (Meybuyen), Ronnie Martinez (Darna), Therese Carlos, Cai Cortes, and Jules de la Paz. The play was first staged on 16 Jul 2008 at the Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero Theater of the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman as part of Dulaang UP’s 33rd season.

The play progresses in fragmented and overlapping scenes with no definite chronology and setting. Two writers, referred to as Mata 1 and Mata 2, discuss ideas on various topics such as religion, comics, environmental degradation, childhood, military conflicts in the countryside, the dark, the moon, dreams, children in the literature, writing, food, and hope for society’s children. Interwoven in these exchanges are the children’s narratives. Rosemarie, a rag seller who is sexually abused by her uncle and becomes pregnant, dies upon giving birth. Bakwit, a displaced Bagobo, sells sampaguita leis. Haram, a Sama Dilaut (Badjao) fleeing the war in Tawi-Tawi, becomes a snatcher. Taken by the police, he is forced to an underground combat arena where he is killed by a fellow street kid named Darna, a gay prostitute. After the fight, Haram is handed to a group of medical practitioners for forced organ donation. A battered unnamed housemaid snaps and murders the family of her employers. In exchange for scrap metal, Grace prostitutes herself to construction workers. Marian, a poverty-stricken bright girl who dreams of continuing school, commits suicide. Toward the end, Mata 1 narrates that when Rosemarie died, Bakwit took her child to the land of his ancestors; and that Bakwit told the newborn that its mother has become a goddess with a thousand breasts who nurtures dead children. A Bagobo chant is heard. The goddess Meybuyen appears. The children move to receive nourishment from Meybuyen’s breasts. The children merrily laugh as they undress—before crossing the river. Meybuyen continues her chanting. In their final exchanges, Mata 1 jokingly calls Mata 2 Reuel but immediately retracts when Mata 2 gets upset. Mata 1 then calls Mata 2 in his real name which is Rene. Mata 1 tells Rene that the children are now ready to cross the river, and that Rene should welcome them. Rene bids them farewell.

 

Hinabing Pakpak ng Ating mga Anak was Anton Juan Jr’s homage to fellow playwright Rene O. Villanueva who passed away in Dec 2007. Juan interwove excerpts of Villanueva’s poetry, stories for children, and plays to juxtapose narratives of maltreated children in society and the often mis/adventurous lives of children depicted in literature. During the production phase, after a series of frustrating rehearsals where the actors themselves were not able to get into their characters’ psyche, Juan obliged them to immerse themselves in an urban poor settlement along the ports of Manila. Some of the actors were also directed to devise and improvise their parts in the play.  Written by Erick Dasig Aguilar

text:
(I Am Not Dead). 1981. Drama simboliko in Tagalog. Script, Juan Matapang Cruz, allegedly. First staged at the Teatro Libertad in Singalong, Manila, then at the Teatro Nueva Luna in Malabon. It was staged by the University of the Philippines (UP) Repertory Company in 1981 at the Puerta Real Gardens in Intramuros, Manila, using the Tagalog translation by Bonifacio Ilagan of the English translation of the play preserved in Arthur Stanley Riggs’s The Filipino Drama (1905), 1981.

This play is one of the revolutionary plays of 1900-1905. The names and situations (as well as the lines and references) convey the play’s allegorical meaning: Pinagsakitan (pains; the Mother Country) is the mother of Karangalan (honor; the Philippines and its natural resources), whose husband had left instructions that Karangalan was not to marry a foreigner without the agreement of all her family. Her brother Ualang-Hinayan (traitor; the native pro-American/collaborator) wishes her to marry Macamcam (greedy; the American insular government) because he is given money and promised a position. Tangulan (defender; the Filipino patriot) and Karangalan love each other, and agree to marry. Katuiran (reason; the rights of Filipinos), Kauri and Kakulay (of the same race and color; Filipino compatriots) do not agree with the plan of Tangulan, who is then wounded in a fight with Macamcam and thought to be dead. Maimbot (avaricious; the United States), Macamcam’s father, comes to witness the marriage. Tangulan’s body is brought to the wedding site on the way to burial, and from the coffin he rises, saying “Hindi aco patay!” and saves Karangalan and Pinagsakitan from Macamcam, Maimbot, and the traitor Ualang-Hinayan.

Considered seditious during its time, Hindi Aco Patay invited strong reactions from the colonial authorities. A drunken American soldier hurled a beer bottle through the Katipunan sun as it rose over one scene, while his companions wrecked the production set. On 10 May that year, the play was banned in mid-performance at Teatro Nueva Luna in Malabon, and the troupe, including the playwright’s wife, was arrested and imprisoned. Cruz was later arrested and imprisoned at Bilibid. In court, he testified that on 3 Jan 1903, he organized the Karangalan Dramatic Theatrical Company for the purpose of presenting Hindi Aco Patay. The play seems to have been presented many times—sometimes advertised under different names—and to have won enthusiastic audiences.

The play and the subsequent arrest and trial of the playwright were dramatized by Bonifacio Ilagan in his play Estados Unidos bersus Cruz, Abad at Tolentino (United States versus Cruz, Abad and Tolentino), directed by Behn Cervantes for the UP Repertory Company in 1981 at the Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero Theater, UP Diliman.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

article.value: (I Am Not Dead). 1981. Drama simboliko in Tagalog. Script, Juan Matapang Cruz, allegedly. First staged at the Teatro Libertad in Singalong, Manila, then at the Teatro Nueva Luna in Malabon. It was staged by the University of the Philippines (UP) Repertory Company in 1981 at the Puerta Real Gardens in Intramuros, Manila, using the Tagalog translation by Bonifacio Ilagan of the English translation of the play preserved in Arthur Stanley Riggs’s The Filipino Drama (1905), 1981.

This play is one of the revolutionary plays of 1900-1905. Tangulan (defender; the Filipino patriot) and Karangalan love each other, and agree to marry. text:
2013. Musical in two acts in Filipino. Direction, Tuqxs Rutaquio; adaptation and libretto, Rody Vera; music, Carol Bello; sound design, TJ Ramos; choreography, Alden Lugnasin; lighting design, Katsch SJ Catoy; costume design, Leeroy New. Cast: Trixie Esteban/Jenine Desiderio (Oryol), May Bayot (Gugurang), Cheeno Macaraig (Handyong and Makusog), Myke Salomon (Handyong), Jonathan Tadioan (Asuwang), Nicolo Magno (Baltog), Red Nuestro, Delphine Buencamino, Tara Cabaero, Opaline Santos, Kristofer Kliatchko, Cyril Balderama, Philip Palmos, Marco Viaña, Regina de Vera, and Doray Dayao. First staged at the Tanghalang Aurelio Tolentino of the Cultural Center of the Philippines by Tanghalang Pilipino for its 26th theater season in Feb 2013. It was restaged in Legazpi City in celebration of the annual Ibalong Festival in Aug 2013.

The musical begins with half-serpent, half-human young girl Oryol playing with the various monsters of the underworld. She is the daughter of the leader of the underworld, Asuwang. Asuwang, Oryol, and the monsters lord it over the land. Baltog arrives as a greedy conqueror who seeks to mine the underworld’s gold. Baltog kills Oryol’s best friend Opon, a giant boar. For this, Baltog becomes known as chief hunter of Ibalong.

 

Handyong is the second conqueror who seeks not just conquest but also revenge. With parents killed by monsters of the underworld, his task is to tame the land and rid it of monsters. The inhabitants of the underworld resist this process of conquest and domestication, and the war between humans and monsters continues until Handyong and Oryol come of age. Oryol, finding her land suffering under Handyong’s conquest, offers him marriage with the promise of getting her side of the underworld to surrender and her becoming completely human. Oryol cuts off her tail as proof of this promise. Before they marry, Handyong kills Rabot, Oryol’s betrothed. Oryol gives birth to a son Makusog, who seeks now to conquer the sky world of Gugurang. Gugurang strikes Makusog with lightning as the child tries to climb up to the heavens. She then offers Handyong a deal: she will resurrect Makusog if Handyong sacrifices himself. Upon Makusog’s resurrection, Oryol tells him that he is half-monster half-human, and can thus represent the balance needed between man and nature.

Ibalong is a dance-musical adaptation of the Bikol epic using neo-ethnic rock to cater to a younger audience. Highly sculptural and elaborate costumes and matching growls and movements identify each monster. The costumes and lighting design effectively create the world of monsters and humans, of earth and sky. The music becomes the vehicle through which monsters, gods, and warrior heroes are bound together into just one world. Ibalong won in the 2013 Philippine Legitimate Stage Artists Group Gawad Buhay! for Outstanding Choreography for Play or Musical and Outstanding Costume Design.  Written by Katrina Stuart Santiago

text:
(Ilocula: The Ilocano Dracula II). 1983. Street play in Filipino. Direction and script, Chris Millado; song lyrics, Joi Barrios; masks and props, Paeng Altavas. Cast: Lito Peila, Lia Moran, Chyn San Juan, Malou Maniquis, Bong Antonio, Boboy Betco, Gerry Asuncion, Joi Barrios, Chris Millado, Nicolas Pichay, and Marivic Teodosio. First staged by Peryante in 1983 at the Palma Hall Steps at the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman. Later performances were held during mass actions. The play was published in The Politics of Culture: The Philippine Experience, 1984, edited by Nicanor G. Tiongson.

Ilokula II is a sequel to Ilokula I, 1980, which focuses on nepotism and the unexplained wealth of the Marcos family. The play opens as the Circus Barker invites one and all to come into the circus to see the greatest, most exciting, and most shocking show on earth. The show begins with the audience creating the sounds of a dog’s howls and of strong winds on a scary night, as well as of screams and of pounding heartbeats, which punctuate the atmosphere. Then one by one, the creatures of the night begin to appear and introduce themselves. Dra Maxima Bareta is the monster-minister of finance. She sings a song about her “development” plans for the country, all to be funded by all the foreign loans she can get her hands on. Dr Barile and Dr Rebolber, on the other hand, is the two-headed monster, whose songs promise to shoot all dissenters. Then, the Queen of Monsters is announced with big fanfare—Madam Kula, the wife of Ilokula. Although her plane from Geneva is late, she graciously gives in to her welcomer’s request and sings a song of love and mercy. The monster explains the reason for the glittering assembly: the king of darkness, Ilokula or the Ilocano Dracula, is coming to life again. On the eve of the monster’s world anniversary, he is resurrected amid more horrific sounds. Ilokula comes back to life, but moans with pain. He is immediately examined by experts, scanned by an X-ray machine. His heart is healthy, with the chambers of finance, defense, agriculture, and natural resources well supplied with blood. His small intestines are in good condition, with the continuous operation of the minor industries and of agriculture; the big intestines’ multinational and transnational corporations are also found to be healthy and strong, for they are securely attached to the country’s rich natural and human resources. The problem is finally traced to his stomach, which is suffering from indigestion because of gluttony. After a transfusion from the International Mumu Fund and World Blood, and some USAID and CIA medication, Ilokula is operated on. From his stomach, dismembered parts of the human body are recovered: the fist of a worker on strike, a farmer’s shoulder, a student’s leg, a professional’s brain, an artist’s tongue, the hearts and livers of the many who were martyred for the country, and the people’s blood and flesh, which have been served on a platter to strangers from other lands. Ilokula is dying and no one can save him. On 21 Sep 1983, he comes back to life after receiving CIA injections and IMF-WB dextrose. As he strongly denies rumors that he is about to die, his wife and other monsters deny all rumors of preempting more power. As a wondrous Christmas carol is sung, the dismembered parts thrown into the trash heap slowly reform into a human being. At this point, the audience is asked to participate in making noise to protest tyranny. Finally, the people onstage surround the monster family and deliberately raise their fists to hit them. As they freeze with arms raised, the play ends.

 

Ilokula borrows the format of a circus-vaudeville to showcase the song-and-dance numbers of the government minister-monsters, and the magic-horror portion where Ilokula is operated on. To establish rapport with the audience and encourage audience participation, the Peryante come out at the beginning of the play and ask the audience to create the sound effects to be used in the play. Once established, the rapport with the audience is maintained through witty statements (e.g., “I do not intend to die”) or songs (e.g., “Feelings”) associated with the leaders of the regime. The laughter elicited by all these devices makes the injection of political analysis (Eric Baines or US imperialism sends a CIA injection and an IMF-WB dextrose to the ailing Ilokula) painless and almost pleasurable.  Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

text:
(In This Corner). 1978. Full-length play in Filipino. Direction, Anton Juan Jr; script, Reuel Molina Aguila; lighting design, Audie San Juan and Edgardo Avila. Cast: Crispin Pineda, Mario Elumba, Pitt Albano, Malou de Guzman, Betty Mae Piccio, Emerita Abadilla, Cris Vertido, Joel Cruz, Lou Veloso, Al Garcia, Ismael Payawal, Nards Vercudia, Behn Cervantes, Rene O. Villanueva, Chris Millado, and Ces Mangay. First staged by Dulaang UP on 30 Nov 1978 at the Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero Theater, University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman. It was published in Ligalig at Iba Pang Dula (Disquiet and Other Plays), 1989.

In Dis Korner is an exposé of corruption in the boxing world. Mr Lorenzo, big-time manager of boxers and owner of Lorenzo Stadium, fixes the fights by arranging who wins and loses in every game, to ensure his bet against money put up by a certain Mr Lee and Mr Sanchez. Most of the ring fighters are easily bribed—agreeing to win or lose as he dictates—because of their own weaknesses. Kid Alaminos wants to become a champion, to give his girlfriend Rita a life better than simply raising placards announcing the next round. Joe Bikol is a parasite whose weakness is sex and women. Speed Max wants to win clean money to invest in a sari-sari (variety) store business, but is not strong enough to go against the system. Only Flash Gonzaga, the veteran boxer, sticks to his principles and maintains his self-respect by refusing to succumb to the wishes of the powerful; he would rather lose a fight than be fixed. Although pressured by his premature baby’s condition in the hospital, he refuses to accept unclean money from his buddy Max, who had earlier been bribed to lose a fight with Kid. Meanwhile, Kid Alaminos, who was supposed to fight Flash in the next fight, has been told by boxer-turned-sidekick Joe Bikol, that Mr Lorenzo wants him to lose this fight, a bigger bet having been placed on Flash winning. With this, Kid’s straight-win record would be tarnished, disqualifying him for the championship round. Mr Lorenzo also uses Rita, by telling Kid that his girl was actually Lorenzo’s girlfriend. Demoralized and in tears, he tells Flash that he has been fixed to lose against him. Flash realizes that although he is the better boxer and a sure winner against Kid, if he wins it would mean victory for the slimy Mr Lorenzo and company. In the last scene, with bettors egging the boxers on, Kid and Flash size up one another in the first two rounds, each refusing to make a decisive move to beat his opponent. Their thoughts are heard in a voice-over narration: each has to lose, Kid to follow the system, and Flash to fight it. Realizing that Kid refuses to fight, Flash ignites the situation by bombarding Kid with his left hook and insulting remarks, calling him a coward, and urging the young boxer to fight. Kid wakes up and unleashes his left-right combination, hitting Flash on the face and sides, causing the veteran boxer to fall several times. Still he gets up, smiles, and drives on until his last fall gives his opponent the advantage. Kid eventually wins the fight. The last scene shows Kid a sad-faced winner, Mr Lorenzo defeated, and the veteran Flash looking triumphant about having lost—and thus won.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis

article_title: In My Father's House/Sa Tahanan Ng Aking Ama

photos.desc: Ina Azarcon, left, Ian Casocot, Leo Mamicpic, Dessa Quesada-Palm, Earnest Hope Tinambacan, and Carla Angeline Mongado in Silliman University’s In My Father’s House, Luce Auditorium, 2013 (Urich Calumpang, photo courtesy of Silliman University Culture and Arts Council)

text:
1987. Three-act play in English. Direction, Antonio Mabesa; script, Elsa Martinez Coscolluela; translation, Raul Regalado; set design, Amiel Y. Leonardia; costume design, Ogie Juliano; lighting design, Dennis Marasigan; music selection, Rey Echevarria. Cast: Amiel Y. Leonardia (Carlos Santamaria), Sonia Valenciano (Amanda Santamaria), Jun Farin (Miguel Santamaria), Chris Michelena (Franco Santamaria), Shamaine Centenera (Isabel), Marilou Sadiua (Cristy), Jonas Sebastian (Captain Haroda), Patrick Kimpo (Emilio), Tess Dumpit (Marisa), Ogie Juliano (Benito), and Luis Cortez (Victor).

First staged by the University of the Philippines (UP) Playwrights’ Theater at the Faculty Center Studio, later Teatro Hermogenes Ylagan, UP Diliman, and the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Tanghalang Huseng Batute in 1987 and at the Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero Theater in 1989. The 1989 production at the Guerrero Theater also staged its first Filipino translation titled Sa Tahanan ng Aking Ama by Raul Regalado. In the same year, it became the country’s official entry in the 11th Singapore Drama Festival. Its productions in the United States include one at the Astor Place Theater, New York, by the Ma-Yi Theater Company in 1990 and at the Hudson Theatre, Los Angeles, by Stage West in 1996, both directed by Chito Jao Garces. In Japan, it was presented at the Clapbard Garden Theatre, Kyoto City, in 1995 by the Kapatiran-Kyoto, a network of Filipino scholars, co-directed by Matthew M. Santamaria and Josefina Estrella (Luzares and Santamaria 2003). In 2010, a new translation in Filipino by Jerry Respeto was presented by ENTABLADO at the Rizal Mini Theater, Ateneo de Manila University, co-directed by Respeto and Jethro Tenorio. Its production in 2013 at the Claire Isabel McGill Luce Auditorium, Silliman University, was dubbed “homecoming” because of its staging by the alma mater of the playwright Coscolluela and the director Leonardia (Casocot 2013). The play is published in The Likhaan Book Drama 1991-1996: From Page to Stage, 2000.

 

The play spans the years from 1941 to 1944. It is 31 Dec 1941, New Year’s Eve, and the landed Santamaria family of Dumaguete City is having dinner. At the onset, they talk about what to do with the sakada’s (seasonal cane workers) unrest on the impending arrival of the Japanese forces to the city and the still to be harvested sugarcane. Miguel and Franco reveal to their mother Amanda and to their wives Isabel and Cristy, respectively, that they are being called by the Americans to active duty. Miguel mentions the American forces have retreated to Bataan and various American strongholds are now in ruins. Amanda is devastated. Her youngest son Carlito, early on, was already called to service, and now her two elder sons. The church bells peal and siren sounds are suddenly heard.

Miguel and Franco have just returned from military service. On 16 Jun 1942, the Santamarias talk about the atrocities of the Japanese forces in the city of Dumaguete. Miguel is advised not to get involved with the resistance because he is under surveillance. They still have no news on the whereabouts of Carlito. Miguel and Franco argue about the surrender of the Americans. Amanda pleads with them to stop. Captain Haroda visits the family. He offers the position of provincial governorship to Franco. Franco refuses the offer. Haroda delivers another news that their house is to be the High Command’s residence. Carlos does not object. Before leaving, Haroda instructs Franco to see him the next day.

The family has transferred its living quarters at the church sacristy. Miguel has joined the resistance; while Isabel and their children are now with Isabel’s parents in Santa Catalina. On 10 Aug 1942, Carlos, Amanda, and Cristy are having dinner when Benito, their bookkeeper, comes in and announces the arrival of Emilio, who was sent by Miguel. Emilio requests the Santamarias to take in his girlfriend Marisa. Benito leaves for he is expected to be at the High Command’s residence by supper. Emilio and Marisa detail the hardships of guerrilla living in the mountains and being pursued by the Japanese forces, and how they barely escaped the raid that sent them to the Santamarias. The two teenagers also relay the news that Miguel is safe. Emilio leaves to meet other underground personalities in the city. Cristy assists Marisa to the sleeping quarters. Alone, Carlos and Amanda discuss Franco’s collaboration with the Japanese. Franco arrives to visit them. Carlos and Franco argue to the point of Carlos’s disowning his son. article_title: La India Elegante Y El Negrito Amante
text:
(The Elegant India and Her Aeta Suitor). 1860. Saynete in Tagalog. Script, Francisco Baltazar. First staged in 1860 in Udyong, later Orion, Bataan. Staged in 1973 by Dulaang Babaylan under the direction of Dez Bautista at the Philamlife Auditorium, Manila; and in 1990 by the University of the Philippines (UP) Anak-Tibawan under the direction of Toytoy Velayo at the Abelardo Hall Auditorium in UP Diliman and the Philamlife Auditorium in Manila. The text of this saynete was first published in Hermenegildo Cruz’s Kun Sino ang Kumatha ng “Florante” (On the Author of “Florante”), 1906. The saynete was also included in Simplicio Flores and P. Jacobo Enriquez’s Sampung Dulang Tig-iisang Yugto (Ten One-Act Plays), 1950.

This playful saynete (one-act interlude) is about love; it is set in a town preparing for a fiesta. Uban, the pusong (jester), sweeps the plaza for the komedyante (komedya actors). Kapitan Toming, an ita (Aeta), appears. He is courting Menangge, and is wearing a Spanish costume. Menangge had not paid him attention when he went dressed as an ita (“damit-damitang natural”), mestizo (“damit-mestisong Tagalog”), Chinese (“baro’t salawal insik”) bearing gifts, or as a Muslim (“damit-morong Balangingi”). Now:

 

Aber, kung siya’y di suminta

ngayong ako’y de-lebita,

pagka’t ang aking hitsura

kastila’t hindi na ita.

 

(Let’s see if she won’t fall for me

now that I am wearing a frock coat

because now I look like a Spaniard,

no longer an Aeta.)

 

Uban makes fun of him, and Toming refuses to help sweep because of his costume, with its 39 trouser buttons. Menangge appears, lamenting her not having an escort: Titoy has left her for Panggoy, Andoy for Neneng, and Iroy is out of commission. Toming appears with bow and arrow, and there is a lively exchange between the two about suitors, presents, and love. Although she resists at first because “ako’y tagalog/ita kang taga-bundok” (I am Tagalog/you are a mountain Aeta), he reprimands her for looking at “ang balat, hindi ang laman” (the covering, not the content). He courts her as himself, an ita, and wins her. Menangge says:

 

Sa pagsinta’y ualang hindi sumusuko

ang lalong mailap ay napaaamo

ang tigreng mabangis na uhaw sa dugo

daig ng pag-ibig at napasusuyo.

 

(To love everyone surrenders

the wild one is tamed

even the fierce tiger thirsty for blood

is overwhelmed and falls in love.)  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

 

Source

Flores, Simplicio, and P. Jacobo Enriquez, comp. 1950. Sampung Dulang Tig-iisang Yugto. Manila: Philippine Book Company.

text:
(A Day in the Carnival). 2009. One-act play in Filipino. Direction, Chris Millado; script, Nicolas B. Pichay. Cast: Skyzx Labastilla (Toni) and Paolo O’Hara (Zaldy). First performed on 27 Jun 2009 at the Tanghalang Huseng Batute as part of the Virgin Labfest 5. Restaged as a revisited entry for the Virgin Labfest 6 in 2010; it was chosen together with three other plays—also gathered from the Virgin Labfest—for a Tanghalang Pilipino production called Eyeball: New Visions in Philippine Theater, 2012. The play is included in Mga Piling Dula mula sa Virgin Labfest 2009-2012: Ikalawang Antolohiya (Selected Plays from the Virgin Labfest 2009-2012: Second Anthology), 2013.

 

Two friends, a young woman Toni and a young man Zaldy, decide one day to meet in a run-down carnival, the Enchanted Empire. What at first appears to be flirtatious banter dissipates as their central stories are revealed: they have both lost a family member, and both family members are desaparecidos (the disappeared). Zaldy’s younger sister was kidnapped, while Toni’s father was abducted in the middle of a Mayo Uno (May 1) rally. Zaldy has already found his sister’s body while Toni is still searching for her father; he is resigned, she is hopeful. As they move around the carnival, Zaldy finds out that Toni is six months pregnant. Zaldy wants Toni to keep the child, but she is uncertain. They then take a “roller coaster horror ride” and continue their conversation. Just as the roller coaster takes a steep slide, Toni announces that she plans to abort the baby. When the ride ends, Toni gets off unfazed while Zaldy is still in shock. She tells Zaldy that tomorrow, she is going to Tuguegarao where there is another lead on her father. As Zaldy tries to dissuade her, Toni gives him a present for his birthday. Zaldy opens the box and in it is a feces-shaped candy. Toni has already walked away.

In both the 2009 and 2012 productions (in Tanghalang Huseng Batute and Tanghalang Aurelio Tolentino, respectively), sets and props were minimalist. There was only a bench in the middle of the stage and hidden behind it were the props that defined the different spaces the characters visited in the carnival. A rifle is aimed at the audience to indicate that the two characters were in a shooting booth, while a steel bar served as the roller coaster harness. And to simulate the roller coaster’s twisting track, the actors jumped, rolled, and moved around, taking the audience on a horrific ride. Two types of horror were presented here: the fantastic and the real. The real horror imposed by the state confronted both characters. But while Zaldy preferred to stay in Wonderland, Toni struggled on, believing that justice could only be served by searching for the truth.

Isang Araw sa Karnabal won first prize in the one-act play category in the 2010 Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature.  Written by Carlo Pacolor Garcia

text:
(A Great Citizen of the Republic). 2006. Monologue in Filipino. Direction, Regina Ronquillo; script, Rene O. Villanueva. Cast: Mae Paner (Lola Gloria). First staged on 13 and 14 Jul 2006 at the Tanghalang Huseng Batute, Cultural Center of the Philippines, as part of Virgin Labfest 2. The play was restaged by the University of the Philippines (UP) Repertory Company in 2011 and by Artistang Artlets of the University of Santo Tomas in 2013.

The monologue is set in a small turon (fried banana roll) and banana cue stall along Recto Ave in Manila. It is night and Lola Gloria, 76 and overweight, waits for the police to arrest her. She speaks as if the surroundings are already littered with gossipers. She begins by asking if the police are near and muses on how nothing could be kept secret in Manila. She does not even try to escape for fear of being shamed and televised just like what happened before when someone decided to commit suicide not far from her turon and banana cue stall. She says if one decides to kill one’s self, death should be swift. She reminds the gossipers to prompt the police if ever the mobile car passes by the area. Besides, she has nowhere to go. She narrates how she acquired and started her stall when Marcos was still president. She ponders how even though government administrations have changed since the time of Marcos up until her namesake president, her status in life did not. She remembers her daughter Elsa whom she lost to a good-for-nothing neighbor. She adds how Elsa had 10 consecutive pregnancies and how thankful she was that only three children survived.

 

She then talks to the heavens and speaks of how devoted she is to the Black Nazarene of Quiapo. She laments how even though the church is so near, heaven is so far and their cries cannot be heard. Nonetheless, she is thankful for she was given the strength and longevity to endure hardships. She asks forgiveness for questioning at times why the heavens decided to leave the last three of her grandchildren. When Elsa and her husband separated, Elsa left the three children to Lola. Lola’s only consolation is that her youngest grandchild Edita looks exactly like Elsa. Lola muses that Edita, who is sickly, would often call her “Yoya! Yoya!” easing her fatigue after a day’s work. Lola enumerates what she had tried to do to cure Edita for she had been sick for the last two weeks. It came to a point where Lola was forced to bring Edita with her, aggravating her work in the stall. Dealing with so much work, and seeing Edita convulsing, Lola’s mind snapped. She takes her granddaughter’s life by hitting her head on the cement. At last, the police arrive while Lola holds on to Edita’s body.

The play represents how society’s neglect breaks an individual, forcing one to take a loved one’s life.  Written by Erick Dasig Aguilar

article.value: (A Great Citizen of the Republic). 2006. Monologue in Filipino. Direction, Regina Ronquillo; script, Rene O. Villanueva. Cast: Mae Paner (Lola Gloria). First staged on 13 and 14 Jul 2006 at the Tanghalang Huseng Batute, Cultural Center of the Philippines, as part of Virgin Labfest 2. The play was restaged by the University of the Philippines (UP) Repertory Company in 2011 and by Artistang Artlets of the University of Santo Tomas in 2013.

The monologue is set in a small turon (fried banana roll) and banana cue stall along Recto Ave in Manila. It is night and Lola Gloria, 76 and overweight, waits for the police to arrest her. She speaks as if the surroundings are already littered with gossipers. She begins by asking if the police are near and muses on how nothing could be kept secret in Manila. She does not even try to escape for fear of being shamed and televised just like what happened before when someone decided to commit suicide not far from her turon and banana cue stall. She says if one decides to kill one’s self, death should be swift. She reminds the gossipers to prompt the police if ever the mobile car passes by the area. Besides, she has nowhere to go. She narrates how she acquired and started her stall when Marcos was still president. She ponders how even though government administrations have changed since the time of Marcos up until her namesake president, her status in life did not. She remembers her daughter Elsa whom she lost to a good-for-nothing neighbor. She adds how Elsa had 10 consecutive pregnancies and how thankful she was that only three children survived.

value.desc: Scene from Isang Dakilang Mamamayan ng Republika (CCP Collection)

article.value: She then talks to the heavens and speaks of how devoted she is to the Black Nazarene of Quiapo. She laments how even though the church is so near, heaven is so far and their cries cannot be heard. Nonetheless, she is thankful for she was given the strength and longevity to endure hardships. She asks forgiveness for questioning at times why the heavens decided to leave the last three of her grandchildren. When Elsa and her husband separated, Elsa left the three children to Lola. Lola’s only consolation is that her youngest grandchild Edita looks exactly like Elsa. Lola muses that Edita, who is sickly, would often call her “Yoya! Yoya!” easing her fatigue after a day’s work. Lola enumerates what she had tried to do to cure Edita for she had been sick for the last two weeks. It came to a point where Lola was forced to bring Edita with her, aggravating her work in the stall. Dealing with so much work, and seeing Edita convulsing, Lola’s mind snapped. She takes her granddaughter’s life by hitting her head on the cement. At last, the police arrive while Lola holds on to Edita’s body.
The play represents how society’s neglect breaks an individual, forcing one to take a loved one’s life.  Written by Erick Dasig Aguilar

text:
(A Dreamed Fili). 2008. Musical in two acts, in Filipino. Direction, Tony Mabesa and Floy Quintos; script and lyrics, Floy Quintos; music, Ceejay Javier; choral direction, Cholo Gino; choreography, Dexter Santos; costume design, Eric Pineda; set design, Tuxqs Rutaquio; lights, Luther Gumia; sounds consultant, Jethro Joaquin; video, Winter David. Cast: Franco Laurel/Joel Molina (Jose “Pepe” Rizal), Onyl Torres/Eric dela Cruz (Tunying Ibañez), Greg de Leon (Kabesang Tales), JC Santos/JM de Guzman (Basilio), Mica Pineda/Delphine Buencamino (Juli), RJ Solis/RJ Camangon (Isagani), Marilie Fernandez-Ilagan, Jacques Borlaza, Peter Serrano, Stella Cañete, Ces Quesada, Meynard Peñalosa, Astarte Abraham, and Carlo Cannu. First staged on 10 Sep 2008 at the Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero Theater of the University of the Philippines (UP) in Diliman, Quezon City by Dulaang UP. The musical was restaged on 24 Nov 2010 as Dulaang UP’s prelude to the sesquicentennial birth anniversary of Jose P. Rizal.

 

Isang Panaginip na Fili follows the story of Jose “Pepe” Rizal in a small bedroom in Hotel Fleur de Madeleine in 1891. Pepe desperately tries to finish his novel, El Filibusterismo (Subversion) while his dreams bewilder him. Also, he is worried about his lack of funds to publish it. Pepe shares the room with Tunying Ibañez, an ilustrado or member of the Filipino educated class during the late 19th century Spanish colonial period, and member of Indios Bravos, a group of Filipino propagandists in Europe. Tunying does nothing but enjoy the luxurious life in Europe. Although their personalities and ideas clash, Tunying eventually flips through the early draft of Pepe’s novel. Tunying takes on the character of the jeweller, Simoun—as he puts on spectacles—and finds himself interacting with and manipulating Pepe’s characters such as Kabesang Tales, Juli, and Basilio. Simoun finds the perfect opportunity to detonate an explosive hidden in a kerosene lamp during a wedding where high ranking officials are expected to attend. Basilio stops Simoun’s attempt to wipe out the corrupt officials and friars by telling Isagani about the explosive. Isagani then throws the lamp into a river. Tunying disagrees with Pepe about the ending of the novel. Pepe leaves the room. The last scene shows Rizal’s execution in Bagumbayan.

Quintos merged chapters of the novel into the play; and through the direction, shifted from the interior and exterior of the hotel room and back to the novel, and vice versa. Isang Panaginip na Fili won the Best Stage Actor in a Musical award for Laurel in the 2009 Aliw Awards.  Written by Olivia Nieto
