text:
(Scholar of the People). 1976. Tula-dula (Poem-play). Direction, Behn Cervantes; Poetry, Richie Valencia and Ed Vencio. Cast: Dennis Estrada/Sonny Oliveros (freshman Iskolar or Scholar), Philip Waite/Bien Fernandez (narrators), and Madeleine Nicolas. The second play of the protest theater genre known as tula-dula was first mounted at the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman by the UP Repertory Company (UP Rep) in 1976. The tula-dula’s first performances were during a demonstration at the College of Arts and Sciences Building (Palma Hall) lobby and as an accompaniment to the play Vida at the UP Protestant Chapel. It is the first tula-dula written specifically as a script for the stage. Its full title is Mga Unang Araw sa Buhay ng Iskolar ng Bayan (First Few Days in the Life of a New Scholar of the People).

Valencia and Vencio, collaborators since their days in the UP High School, became staffers of the Philippine Collegian, the student publication of UP. In Sep 1975, Valencia published in the Philippine Collegian a satirical essay titled “Masyadong Makulit: Ang Iskolar ng Bayan” (Too Pesky: The Scholar of the People). With Vencio, she collaborated on long parody poems such as “Gutom sa Pagkain ang Iskolar ng Bayan” (The Scholar of the People Is Hungry for a Meal) and “Sa ROTC: Sunog sa Araw ang Iskolar ng Bayan” (In ROTC: The Scholar of the People Is Burnt under the Sun), published in Oct and Nov 1975, respectively.

 

Fresh from staging the very first tula-dula, Ang mga Kagila-gilalas na Pakikipagsapalaran ni Juan de la Cruz (The Amazing Adventures of Juan de la Cruz), UP Rep members saw the potential of the poems published by Valencia and Vencio. They invited the duo to expand what they had written into a tula-dula and have it published in the Philippine Collegian. The authors wrote the piece in their unique comic style—only this time, influenced by the activism of the previous tula-dula production they had seen. The poem “Mga Unang Araw sa Buhay ng Iskolar ng Bayan” was published in its entirety in one whole page of the Philippine Collegian on 24 Jun 1976. In the tula-dula’s first performance, the narrators tore the page from the Philippine Collegian and used it as their actual script. The presentation of the play during freshman orientation eventually became a tradition in UP Diliman until 1991.

The tula-dula narrates the experience in the first few weeks of a freshman in UP during the martial law period. In the first part, the freshman Iskolar receives the news that he gets accepted to the university. He then goes to the infirmary where he is subjected to various medical examination procedures. After, he passes his admission slip and is perplexed when the officer tells him about his status of being in a quota or non-quota program. Juggled from one room to another, he falls in line to enlist for subjects. In the second part, he attends his first class under a terror professor who gives the class a long list of requirements to pass the subject. In his next class, he is exposed to the worn-out facilities of the chemistry laboratory, which explodes before the session ends. During lunchtime, he realizes that the everyday menu is limited to tahong (mussel) viands, and with his insufficient pocket money, a decent meal cannot be had. After class, the Iskolar, with his fellow students, experiences the hassle of the “rush hour.” Saturday morning, he goes to the barbershop where the barber almost cuts off all his hair. He then attends the military science class and undergoes the circuitous drills. In the third part, the Iskolar takes action about his struggles in the university by joining a rally with his fellow scholars. He is mauled by the state police and is taken to jail. He is charged with “illegal assembly, disturbing the peace, and creating disorder inside the university premises.” News of what happened to the Iskolar spread. Other students hear of his fate and rise up against the establishment.

As is characteristic of the tula-dula form, one actor played the main character, Iskolar, and another, called Miscellaneous, played multiple roles. Both mimed in the play while a third performer, the narrator, read the poem-script. It was an ideal modern protest theater form as it employed a minimum number of actors to reach the widest audience possible.

In 1992, UP Rep performed a revision of Iskolar ng Bayan, titled Isko, by Ma. Zarina Natividad. The tula-dula’s transformation into Isko was performed from 1992 up to the early years in the decade of the 2000s.  Written by Tim Dacanay

text:
1971. Three-act play in English. Direction, costume, and set design, Rolando S. Tinio; script, Virginia R. Moreno. Cast: Vic Silayan, Daisy Hontiveros-Avellana, Teddy Yabut, Nick Agudo, Jaime Asencio, and Nestor U. Torre (Young Actor). First staged at the Inaugural Drama Festival to open the Little Theater, later Tanghalang Aurelio V. Tolentino, of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) on 27 Aug 1971. In November of the same year, it was staged by the University of the Philippines as its official entry in the Third World Drama Festival held in Liliw, Laguna, under the direction of Anthony Juan Jr aka Anton Juan Jr; set design by Jaime Arevalo de Guzman; music by Lucrecia R. Kasilag; cast, Lolita Rodriguez, Vic Silayan, Manuel Ojeda, Edgar Oira, Ed Villapol, Bobbit Calderon, Antonio Pajaro, Jose Bautista, Phil Cabanos, Nieves Campa, Lito Carating, and Larry Silayan. It was translated into Tagalog as Itim Asu by Wilfredo P. Sanchez in 1971, and adapted into a ballet by Alice Reyes, which was staged before the play itself at the Main Theater, later Tanghalang Nicanor S. Abelardo, of the CCP in 1970. It was published in Gantimpala (Prize), 1980.

It is a play within a play. The frame story has a group of actors set to perform at the Teatro Zorrilla; the stories within are drawn from La Loba Negra (The Black She-Wolf) and Jose Rizal’s El Filibusterismo (Subversion), with inspiration from chroniclers Murillo de Velarde, Mallat, and Karuth.

The actors aim to influence the Spanish authorities in the selection of street names, hoping that the names of popular native heroes would be chosen. In act 1, scene 1, set in 1719, natives present papers of identification to the Piskal-Asesor, who has called upon the heirs of Raha Lacandola and Raha Soliman to appear before the courts. A rich merchant, Don Jose Lacandola y Yatco, a Chinese-Tagalog mestizo, claims to be the heir of Lacandola; a young boy, Angelito de los Santos y Soliman, is presented by a friar as heir to Soliman, accompanied by his mother, who is epileptic and descended from a line ofcatalonan(priestess). In scene 2, 1906, the actors prepare for a performance amid the tension of the American insular government’s hunt for rebels, of which the Young Actor is found to be one.

Almost in mime, act 2 enacts the story of La Loba Negra. Masked men attack the residence of Governor-General Bustamante and kill him. His death is avenged by a mysterious woman—his widow—who hides in the house of the peasant Juan, father of the boy Angelito. She dons the black skirt of Angelito’s dead mother and transforms into Itim Asu, who kills one friar after another in Laguna. Killed by a bullet, she is succeeded in her quest for vengeance by her daughter and Angelito Soliman. With a pomegranate lamp between them, they marry in a blood compact, and become Sandugo, Itim Asu’s heir.

Act 3 returns to the actors, now preparing for the scene from El Filibusterismo —the wedding feast of Paulita Gomez. The dynamite-filled pomegranate lamp is Simoun’s wedding present. Basilio tells Isagani, who loves Paulita, about the dynamite. Isagani runs up the stairs. Simoun is shot. Isagani comes down the stairs holding the lamp aloft.

The play ends with the actors naming the streets after old heroes, and a procession of men bearing a boat in which is a dead man, led by a woman with streaming black hair.

The Onyx Wolf won third prize in the first CCP Literary Contest for the years 1969-70.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis

 

Source

Moreno, Virginia R. 1971. Itim Asu: Isang Dulang Tagalog na may Tatlong Yugto. Quezon City: Sentro ng Pagtuturo ng Agham.

text:
(Joe Cool: Applicant). 2011. One-act play in Filipino. Direction, Levi Albania; script, Joshua Lim So; production design, Mark Tumang and Naho Sakamoto; costume design, Santi Obcena; lighting design, Kel Serrano; technical director, Alexandra Veneracion; graphic design, Kirby Pinedes; sound design, Earl Limjoco, Aman dela Cruz, and Jensen Gomez; stage management, Nimrod Sarmiento; production management, Carla Barretto. Cast: MA Castro/Yuji Tajima (Joe Cool) and Natileigh Sitoy/Sheri Anne Altarejos (Miss Lyka). First staged on 23 Feb 2011 at the Augusto and Rosario Gonzalez Theater of the De La Salle–College of Saint Benilde (DLS-CSB), Taft, Manila. In 2011-12, Joe Cool: Aplikante was also staged in the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman and the University of Santo Tomas, and was performed as part of the Crossroads Theater Festival in DLS-CSB. Destiyero Theater Commune, where Lim So is artistic director, restaged the play at The Buoy restaurant in 2012.

 

The play features the encounter of young job applicant Jhoenard Jhun Abelar Kulata aka Joe Cool with interviewer Maria Lyka Kabayan Agurela aka Miss Lyka. Joe Cool is desperately looking for a job to pay his bills and attend to his personal needs and leisure. He has been a contractual worker in his past jobs and thinks that he has mastered the system. He is both excited and nervous on his nth job interview that he hopes would be the last. However, his interview process for the Dohesta Corporation is challenged by the impulsive and roller-coaster ways of Miss Lyka, the secretary of a mysterious boss who speaks in broken English. First, Joe Cool is compelled to follow directions that he later realizes are repetitive and nonsensical. Second, he is forced to use ungrammatical language and follow illogical ideas just to satisfy her interviewer. Finally, he is physically harassed in the process of applying for the job. Miss Lyka later cleans up her table like a worker on her final day of contract. In the end, their situation is reversed—Joe Cool becomes the company secretary on an intercom and Miss Lyka becomes the applicant.

The play presents characters controlled by an omniscient but unseen authority within a routinary and cyclical situation. It presents the absurd realities in an industrial setting, where workers are mere pawns in a system unsympathetic toward them. The script won first prize in the one-act play in Filipino category of the Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature in 2012.  Written by Joanna Lerio

text:
1978. Three-act play in Filipino. Direction and set design, Antonio Mabesa; script, Isagani R.Cruz; costume design, Salvador Bernal; music, Edru Abraham. Cast: Betty Mae Piccio, Cris Gosalvez, Dindo Fernando, Tito Araneta, Henry Strzalkowski, Amor Escalante, Tuts Valencia, Edgar Sandalo, Mario Silva Jr, Chito Cortez, Edru Abraham, and Boy Madarang. First staged on 14 Sep 1978 by Dulaang Unibersidad ng Pilipinas (DUP) at the Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero Theater, UP Diliman. Staged in 1980 at the Dalubdulaan of the Manila Metropolitan Theater under the direction of Edmundo Farolan with Betty Mae Piccio, Buddy Palad, Bon Vibar, Jay Valencia-Glorioso, Edu Manzano, Emig Tagle, Guillermo Gomez, Jeffrey Soriano, Lito Torres, and Caloy Pimentel. Josephine was published in Isagani R. Cruz’s Josephine at Iba Pang Dula (Josephine and Other Plays), 1988.

The author introduces the play thus: “This is not a historical play, although its characters are historical. This is not a transformation play, although its techniques are transformational. This is not a realistic play, although its language is realistic. This is not an absurdist play, although its philosophy is absurdist. This may not even be a play.”

 

The form is innovative. The main narrative thread is that of Josephine Bracken bringing her stepfather George Taufer to the Philippines for an eye operation, meeting Rizal, falling in love, and being with him till his execution. The multilayered unfolding also brings in Rizal’s roles in Dapitan as a teacher, interacting with and developing the community, and serving as doctor; and in the reform movement, with Rizal’s debate with the Church, the popular perception of friars and of Jesuits. It also reveals Filipino women’s perceptions of their womanhood in Rizal’s time and in the present, Rizal’s poetry and his plays El Consejo de los Dioses (Council of the Gods) and Junto al Pasig (Beside the Pasig), the question of the language in which Philippine literature should be written, and the roles of the poet and the historian.

Characters transform, even in mid-scene: Josephine and Manuela Orlac from their 19th-century selves into 20th-century streetwalkers, and in another scene into contemporary Taglish-speaking housewives gossiping about friends having affairs. As background of Rizal’s unsuccessful operation on George Taufer, Manuela transforms into Teodoro Alonzo, and Rizal into his younger self, realizing his mother’s blindness. Josephine and Rizal, in the midst of their discussion about the future—she pleading that he leave the country; he insisting he is needed—transform into Baby and Jun, graduate students in New York—she wanting to return home after her doctoral studies; he insisting there are no opportunities there.

Languages proliferate in these multivoiced and multilayered worlds: Josephine speaks English and Spanish and eventually Tagalog; George Taufer English and German; Rizal Tagalog, Cebuano, English, and Spanish; the men and women of Dapitan, Cebuano and Tagalog; the women into and out of which Josephine and Manuela transform, all of the above and German and French.

It is a play, despite the author’s proffered disclaimer, that weaves the historical moment of Rizal and Josephine with the other strands that unravel because of them, and because they were who they were: that of colonial Philippines, its politics and society; that of women and their self-view (“Women’s place is in the home,” and onward); those of language and literature, reform and revolution, desire and commitment. Some situations are historical, some absurd, some repetitive, some insolvable, all interconnected and real.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

text:
1979. Three-act play in Filipino. Direction, Joel Lamangan; script, Malou Jacob; production design, Brenda Fajardo; music, Ed Pagayon. Cast: Roberto Padua aka Toffy Padua (Juan Tamban), Cecilia B. Garrucho, Ed Pagayon, Edgar Instrella, Spanky Manikan, Tessie Padua, Dante Balois, Estrella Antonio, Arlene Abuid, and the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) Kalinangan Ensemble. A commissioned play, Juan Tamban was first staged by the PETA Kalinangan Ensemble on 4 Jan 1979 at the Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Fort Santiago, Manila. Staged and translated by different regional groups in the Ilocos, Cebu, Davao, and Butuan. Its staging by the Ateneo de Manila University’s ENTABLADO in 2014 was dubbed Ang Juan Tamban ni Malou Jacob (Malou Jacob’s Juan Tamban), under the direction of Charles Yee and adaptation by Guelan Varela Luarca. In 1984 it was published in book edition in Manila and won the National Book Award from the Manila Critics Circle in 1985. Its English translation, Juan Tamban, by the author herself, was anthologized in Modern ASEAN Plays, 1992, edited by Nicanor G. Tiongson.

The play opens on the boy Juan Tamban and his “magic” act of eating lizards and rats. This brings him up against the authorities, who send him to a hospital, where the social worker Marina is assigned to his case. Although she comes up against the blank wall of his noncooperation, she persists, if this case is to be her master’s thesis. In the process of investigating Juan’s family—a mother who had cherished him, stressed honesty, and made him hope for an education and a future; a father who gathered and sold junk, and encouraged him to steal to help family finances—Marina faces the reality of the boy, society, and herself.

 

Eventually Marina wins Juan’s friendship, and he wins her loyalty, to the extent that she confronts her superior about the unwelcome publicity that victimizes Juan and his father. With these she faces objections from her fiancé and family. The publicity alerts a policeman, who has been looking for Juan since his escape from a detention center where the boy had been confined because of an accusation of bag snatching. At the court hearing and then at the social workers’ convention, Marina stands by Juan. In the end, he escapes from the detention center to which he had been returned, to go home to his father.

Juan Tamban stems from an actual incident, reported in the newspapers, about a boy who ate cockroaches and lizards to gain attention. It triggered PETA to do an inquiry, which led to the idea of writing a play for the International Year of the Child. Juan Tamban is a landmark in Philippine modern theater because of its well-researched and realistic portrayal of contemporary social problems, and its combination of both realism and nonrealistic styles.

It won second prize in the three-act play category, Filipino Division, of the Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature in 1979.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez, updated by Athena Angela Aquino

text:
2004. Neo-sarsuwela in two acts, in Hiligaynon. Direction, Kevin P. Piamonte; libretto and adaptation, Alice Tan Gonzales; set design, Roman Sanares; music design, Crista Sianson-Huyong; lights design, Katsch SJ Catoy; costume design, Susan Ong; cinematography, Rhodora Solis. Cast: Ma. Asela Labaro (old Juanita), Faith Pinedes (young Juanita), Mel Madriguera (Nita), Basti Salazar (Ely Macavinta), Winston Lee (Don Macario), Debbie Andaya (Donya Beatriz), Elsie Flores-Gancia (Yaya Sitang), Archie Arenga, and Robert Rodriguez. First staged in Aug 2004 at the Our Lady’s Hall of the Colegio del Sagrado Corazon de Jesus in Iloilo City. In the same year, the play was restaged at Santa Isabel College and the Cultural Center of the Philippines as part of Dayon Visayan Theater Festival.

The play is set during the late 1800s up to the first decades of the 20th century in Iloilo. An opening composo or song is performed as a prologue introducing the play’s narrative. The play starts with the old Juanita, with her Yaya Sitang, reminiscing her life. Juanita sees her young self while reminiscing. She is the carefree daughter of Don Macario and Donya Beatriz. She has a playmate named Nita who is a peasant’s daughter. For this friendship, Juanita is always nagged by her mother. At a young age, Juanita is exposed to the hierarchical, exploitative, and unjust setup in the society. Such injustice she personally experiences when her friend Nita gets sick and dies because of poverty.

Juanita grows up and is betrothed by her parents to another wealthy family’s son, whom she does not love. One day, she meets and falls in love with Ely Macavinta, a peasant. With Yaya Sitang, the only person who knows about the relationship, Juanita secretly sees Ely before he leaves for Spain to become a singer in hopes of improving his life. Their relationship is discovered by Don Macario and Donya Beatriz. Feeling betrayed, her father punishes her by not allowing her to go outside the house premises. She commits suicide by drowning in the sea and is later believed to be dead by her parents. Her body is washed ashore in another place. She survives and is adopted by a rich family. She changes her name to Celia de Asis, and becomes the heiress of her adoptive parents. Ely returns as a world-renowned singer. Believing that Juanita is dead, he courts Celia. After Celia reveals her true identity to Ely, they get married. As the revolution progresses, the couple help advance the revolutionary cause. Ely is wounded in battle and dies in the arms of Juanita. She then returns to her parents and is forgiven, but continues her support for the revolutionary movement. The play then goes back to the present, to the old tenants and her Yaya Sitang. In the final scene, her old friend Nita arrives to welcome and escort her to the other side.

The play is an adaptation of Magdalena Jalandoni’s novel of the same title. This kind of adaptation is a first in the history of Panay theater. Innovative too is the technique of filming parts of the play, and incorporating these in the staging. For example, the actors, using the same costume, exit the stage and enter the film, and vice versa. These visual effects intensify the action of the play.  Written by Erick Dasig Aguilar

 

Source

Piamonte, Kevin P. 2015. E-mail message to Erick Dasig Aguilar.

text:
(Beside the Pasig). 1880. Zarzuela in one act, in Spanish. Libretto, Jose Rizal; music, Blas Echegoyen. First performed by Rizal’s schoolmates at Ateneo Municipal de Manila on 8 Dec 1880. Staged in the Tagalog translation by the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) in 1974, under the direction of Nonon Padilla, and with music by Lutgardo Labad, and Emman Lacaba playing the lead role. It was translated into English by Nick Joaquin in Complete Poems and Plays of Jose Rizal, 1976.

The theme is Christianity versus paganism, presented in a debate between innocence and evil. It is the feast of Our Lady of Antipolo, whose image will be traveling on a banca passing the barrios and villages lining the banks of the Pasig River. Children excitedly await the Blessed Mother, comparing the gifts they have brought for her: flowers, songbirds in a cage, a bamboo flute, and fireworks. Everyone is happy except for Satan, who finds his realm taken over by Mary. Leonido enters alone, seemingly lost, although he recognizes the road to town, the river, his house, and the church. As he turns to go, Satan appears to him, dressed as a diuata (goddess), and declares that it is he who once reigned, as absolute god of the native peoples. Leonido counters that there is but one true God, and a debate ensues on Christianity and Paganism, which is joined by a chorus of demons. It is stopped by Leonido’s guardian angel, who announces the coming of the Virgin. Leonido awakens and is joined by Candido, Pascual, and the other children, who salute the Virgin, who comes brilliantly illuminated.

The play was written by Rizal at the University of Santo Tomas when he was 19, at the request of his former teachers at the Ateneo for the annual celebration of the Virgen de la Purisima. It is probably the first zarzuela written by a Filipino in Spanish.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

text:
(Cabeza Tales). 1975. Play in 26 scenes in Filipino. Direction and production design, Felix Padilla Jr aka Nonon Padilla; script, Paul Dumol; music, Lutgardo Labad; costume design, June Guzman and Manny Castañeda. Cast: Mario O’Hara, Orlando R. Nadres, Bey Vito, Mia Gutierrez, Mary Joan Fajardo, Laura Aloba, Chiqui Xerez-Burgos, Potenciano Guzman, George Bicbic, Jan Villamayor, Spanky Manikan, Joe Gruta, Jojo Purisima, Maryo delos Reyes, Socrates Topacio aka Soxie Topacio, Alan Glinoga, Lito Tiongson, Edwin O’Hara, Brenda Fajardo, Cecilia B. Garrucho, Tessie Padua, Estrella Alfon, Dante Balois, Melvi Pacubas, and the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) Kalinangan Ensemble. First staged by PETA in 1975 at the Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Fort Santiago, Manila. In 1997, it was staged by Tanghalang Pilipino at the Tanghalang Aurelio V. Tolentino under the direction of Nonon Padilla. O’Hara and Nanding Josef, who were both part of the original production, took up different roles for the 1997 production. Kabesang Tales was published in Sagisag in Jul 1975.

The play draws material from Rizal’s El Filibusterismo (Subversion), chapters 4, 7, 8, 9, and 10. It starts with Tales moving his father Selo, his wife Victoria, and children Juli, Tano, and Lucia to Sagpang. There they clear land, which exacts its toll: Victoria and Lucia fall ill and die. A day before the first harvest, Fray Clemente claims the land as belonging to his order, and charges Tales rental fees. Although Tales knows that the friar had moved the markers to make the claim, he pays the rental, because it is low and he can afford it. The harvests are good; Tales is able to build a better house, and is eventually appointed cabeza de barangay (barangay captain), a position of honor and responsibility: he collects the village taxes. He makes plans to send his children to school, especially Juli, whose sweetheart, Basilio, is studying to become a doctor.

 

Fray Clemente pursues him, however, raising the rent gradually. Tales is pushed to the wall, refuses to pay, and decides to take Fray Clemente to court, even though Tandang Selo, his father, points out that he is “a clay pot knocking against an iron skillet,” because no one ever won such a case, and he would be judged even before the case is heard. Tales insists that the friars have no proof of ownership of the land. His case is lost gradually and painfully: cheating scribes, a good judge removed, hearings postponed, a withdrawal by the governor of his privileges as cabeza, and a judgement against him, which he decides to appeal. The friars install a new tenant in the land he cleared.

Personal pain also mounts: Tano is conscripted; Tales’s weapons of gun, then bolo, are confiscated, and he is reduced to Selo’s axe, until he is taken by outlaws, who ask for ransom. Juli borrows money for the ransom, and becomes a servant to repay it. After she leaves home, Selo is struck dumb. When Tales is freed, Simoun comes and asks to use his house to show the jewelry he is selling. He also offers to buy the agnos (medallion) of Maria Clara, but Tales wishes to consult Juli first.

In the last scenes, Fray Clemente and the new tenant are found dead. Simoun shows a letter from Tales explaining that he took Simoun’s gun, left Maria Clara’s medallion in exchange, and joined the outlaws.

Dumol takes matter from Rizal’s fiction and—in short, effective scenes—presents the growth of Tales’s consciousness from submission to rebellion.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez, updated by Athena Angela Aquino

Although Tales knows that the friar had moved the markers to make the claim, he pays the rental, because it is low and he can afford it. The harvests are good; Tales is able to build a better house, and is eventually appointed cabeza de barangay (barangay captain), a position of honor and responsibility: he collects the village taxes. He makes plans to send his children to school, especially Juli, whose sweetheart, Basilio, is studying to become a doctor.

value.desc: Orlando Nadres, left, Mario O’Hara, and Mia Gutierrez in PETA’s Kabesang Tales, Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Manila, 1975 (PETA Library and Archives)

article.value: Fray Clemente pursues him, however, raising the rent gradually. Tales is pushed to the wall, refuses to pay, and decides to take Fray Clemente to court, even though Tandang Selo, his father, points out that he is “a clay pot knocking against an iron skillet,” because no one ever won such a case, and he would be judged even before the case is heard. Tales insists that the friars have no proof of ownership of the land. His case is lost gradually and painfully: cheating scribes, a good judge removed, hearings postponed, a withdrawal by the governor of his privileges as cabeza, and a judgement against him, which he decides to appeal. The friars install a new tenant in the land he cleared.

Personal pain also mounts: Tano is conscripted; Tales’s weapons of gun, then bolo, are confiscated, and he is reduced to Selo’s axe, until he is taken by outlaws, who ask for ransom. Juli borrows money for the ransom, and becomes a servant to repay it. After she leaves home, Selo is struck dumb. When Tales is freed, Simoun comes and asks to use his house to show the jewelry he is selling. He also offers to buy the agnos (medallion) of Maria Clara, but Tales wishes to consult Juli first.

In the last scenes, Fray Clemente and the new tenant are found dead. Simoun shows a letter from Tales explaining that he took Simoun’s gun, left Maria Clara’s medallion in exchange, and joined the outlaws.

Dumol takes matter from Rizal’s fiction and—in short, effective scenes—presents the growth of Tales’s consciousness from submission to rebellion.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez, updated by Athena Angela Aquino

text:
(Patchwork Life). 1989. Skit. Script, Danny Misajon, Allison “Ariel” Opaon, Evelyn Tila, Nancy Belmonte, and Cathy Benedicto. Cast: Evelyn Tila (Kuapao), Nancy Belmonte (Siopao), and Cathy Benedicto (Siomai).

The play is a hilarious skit on the workers’ plight, for three chubby female actors, who sing, dance, and deliver lines using popular melodies, with lyrics changed to highlight workers’ and peoples’ conditions and demands. It has allusions to popular movie titles and puns on television commercials. Bodabil-inspired, this is Teatro Pabrika liberated from agitprop conventions. In 1989, this three-actor piece, accompanied by a guitarist, was improvised by Misajon, Opaon, Tila, Belmonte, and Benedicto, cultural workers from various unions in Quezon City factories at that time. A relatively polished version with dramaturgical and directorial inputs from Apolonio B. Chua and Oscar Roman appeared in 1991, in the Folk Arts Theater concert-play production Haranang Bayan (People’s Serenade). It became a staple in rallies up to the administration of Fidel Ramos. The different variants of the script and annotations are published in both Bangon: Antolohiya ng mga Dulang Mapanghimagsik (Revolt: Anthology of Revolutionary Plays ), 1998, and Simulain: Dulambayan ng Manggagawa sa Konteksto ng Militanteng Kilusang Unyonismo, 1980-1994 (Guiding Principle: Workers’ Dulambayan in the Context of the Militant Unionism Movement, 1980-1994), 2009.

The skit is set on a payday. At the factory gates, the debt collectors intercept workers as they come out of the factory and collect payments. But Kuapao cunningly stays behind in the factory to elude them. With a very small salary, she cannot afford to pay her loans and bills. She feels bad and to console herself sings a popular Sharon Cuneta song “Tubig at Langis” (Water and Oil), with modified lyrics that complain about the prices of goods and not having enough food to eat. Siopao enters, wailing exaggeratedly and covering one eye with her hand. She had a fight with her husband, who gave her a black eye. Siopao joins Kuapao in singing about their plight. Siomai, a union leader, joins them, and the three berate the leaders of the government for the people’s woes. The disillusionment with the Cory Aquino administration is also rendered through song sequences and a parody of a popular television commercial for rubber sandals at that time, “Marupok ka! Wala kaming tibay na maaasahan. Binoto pa naman din kita noong eleksiyon. Hinarang pa namin ang mga tangke de giyera.” (Weak! We cannot expect strength from you. To think I voted for you in the last election. We even barricaded military tanks.) But they also criticize themselves. Siomai alludes to workers’ weaknesses, as well as their reluctance to participate in mass actions. A strong male voice-over is heard; it is Kuapao’s domineering husband asking her if she has started cooking rice. Kuapao is frightened, but Siopao and Siomai encourage the submissive wife to be strong and fight. After the two leave, Kuapao practices some aikido movements.

Rather than developing a narrative, the improvisation is a string of lapat-awit (new lyrics fitted unto existing popular tunes). Workers’ predicaments as well as social and national issues of the period were touched upon in as comic a manner as possible. Depending on the issue at hand, lines were adjusted. For example, during the Ramos administration, the line “He did nothing but smoke a cigar,” was added. Also a part of the skit directly addressed the audience with questions like “Anybody here knows how much we owe IMF-WB?” Of the skit’s numerous performances, the actors wore colorful attires, including bandannas knotted like ribbons on their heads.

The skit was given the gold prize in 1992 by an award-giving group, Kritika.  Written by Apolonio B. Chua

text:
(Yesterday, Today, and Tomorrow). 1903. Drama simboliko in three acts, in Tagalog. Script, Aurelio V. Tolentino. First staged on 14 May 1903 at the Teatro Libertad in Manila. Staged by the Dulaang Babaylan under the direction of Anton Juan Jr in 1977, and by the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) under the direction of Chris Millado in 1991. The play was first published in E. Arsenio Manuel’s Dictionary of Philippine Biography, volume 2, 1970.

The dramatis personae of Kahapon, Ngayon at Bukas indicate the tenor and intent of the play, the use of allegory and symbol by this genre of political theater, and indeed the plot structure. The hero Taga-ilog (the man from the river—the Filipino people), countryman of Masunurin (obedient—the Filipino woman) and Walangtutol (the unprotesting—the Filipino citizen), is the son of Inangbayan (Mother Country). His father, she tells him, is Kalayaan (Freedom). In act 1, tribute is demanded by Haring Bata (the young king—king of China), who is, however, defeated by the Filipinos. In act 2, the people are persecuted by Matanglawin (hawk-eyed—the Spanish colonial government), Dilat-na-bulag (blind but with eyes open—Spain), and especially by Halimaw (monster—the Spanish friar), who demands even the jewelry and personal possessions of the women. Forces led by Taga-ilog, however, conquer the Spaniards. Bagongsibol (newcomer—America) and Malaynatin (who knows?—the American government) enter, claiming that anyone whom they help is freed from slavery. In act 3, however, the Americans attempt to conquer Inangbayan and her people. Taga-ilog and his forces, equipped with such modern equipment as airships, cannons, electric bullets, and movable fortifications, fight back. In the end, Bagongsibol and Malaynatin grant the people their liberty because the children had asked them for it. All throughout, the foreign invaders are helped by two native-born traitors: Asalhayop (beastly mannered) and Dahunpalay (snake—traitor).

 

Kahapon, Ngayon at Bukas is considered Tolentino’s “most significant contribution to Filipino drama” and the most sensational of the era’s “seditious” plays. When it was first presented, some Americans perceived it subversive, and smashed the furniture and the sets. Tolentino (who also played the hero, Taga-ilog) was also charged with sedition. The court maintained that the “principal object and intent of the author was to incite the people of the Philippine Islands to open an armed resistance to the constituted authorities, and to induce them to conspire together for the secret organization of armed forces, to be used when the opportunity presented itself, for the purpose of overthrowing the present government and setting another in its stead.” Tolentino was defended by the young lawyer Manuel L. Quezon, but was sentenced to two years of imprisonment—one out of his nine—and a fine of 2,000 dollars in gold. Rafael Palma and two American lawyers appealed the sentence, but the Supreme Court upheld it and found Tolentino guilty on 6 Mar 1906.

The extant script is the one presented as court evidence at the trial of Tolentino, and seems favorable to the American authorities, and not cause for a charge of sedition. This play not only used sarsuwela and drama plots and characters as symbol, allegory, and statement, but also used stage effects (tombs appearing as Inangbayan sinks, the forbidden Philippine flag shaped onstage by girls in formation, the forbidden “Himno Nacional” or National Anthem played without warning, or a hero-in-hiding suddenly addressing the audience), and dialogues—often unscheduled—to make their statements. The script on record may not have been the actual production script, and was quite possibly revised or “executed,” as the American authorities thought, “in the attempt to deceive the American authorities.”

The play was revived several times during the martial law era—in parts, in adaptation, and in its entirety—as an effective recalling of history, as well as protest against the contemporary situation. Its 1991 production, directed by Chris Millado, had three Taga-ilogs from different periods of Philippine history—a precolonial datu, a revolutionary leader against Spain, and a contemporary rebel.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

text:
(The Wallet). 1902. One-act sarsuwela in Filipino. Libretto, Severino Reyes; music, Fulgencio Tolentino. First staged by the Compañia Lirico-Dramatica Tagala de Gatchalian e Ilagan on 3 Apr 1902 at the Teatro Libertad in Manila. Staged by the University of the Philippines (UP) Anak-Tibawan, under the direction of Rene Arambulo, in Sep 1983 at the Little Theater of the College of Arts and Sciences, UP Manila.

The play opens with Remedios lamenting her husband Eduardo’s nightly carousing with his friends to the neglect of his family. That same evening, her friend Rosario comes looking for her husband, Nicolas, who has also been away for three successive nights. She is desperate enough to consider divorce or suicide, but is dissuaded by Remedios, who argues that such a scandal would surely ruin the reputation only of the woman and not of the man, and that the best recourse is simply to pray, to wait patiently for their husbands to recover from a temporary illness, and to guide them back to the right path. Returning home drunk as usual, Eduardo orders the startled maid, Kulasa, to open another bottle, and scares his mother-in-law, Juana, with a corkscrew. When tears and entreaties fail, Remedios and Juana finally subdue him by beating him up. Undeterred, Eduardo joins his friends, Nicolas and Antonio, the next day for yet another visit to the house of three Japanese entertainers. Led by Juana to the place, Remedios and Rosario are shocked to see the men with geishas, all six fast asleep from heavy drinking. Noticing Eduardo’s wallet in a geisha’s hands, Remedios is dismayed to find in it a letter from another woman, and is unconsoled by the accompanying reply of rejection from Eduardo. Remedios orders two cocheros (rig drivers) to take the three men to her home. Waking up, the men discover that the women beside them now are actually Remedios, Rosario, and Juana disguised as geishas. The humbled Eduardo and Nicolas beg for forgiveness and promise to reform. While Antonio fends off Juana who has taken a fancy to him, the married couples renew their vow of love and fidelity.

Ang Kalupi is one of the first, if not the first, Tagalog one-act sarsuwela. It is a companion piece to R.I.P., a satire on the komedya, written by the same playwright. This was intended to turn the audience away from the “exaggerated and artificial” komedya and toward the more natural and realistic sarsuwela.  Written by Pacita C. Gavino

text:
(Cantata of Daragang Magayon, Warrior Woman). 2000. Musical-dance drama in Bikol. Direction, Jazmin B. Llana; script, Reynaldo T. Jamoralin and Jazmin B. Llana; translation, H. Francisco Peñones Jr; music, Ramil Chavenia and Ildefonso Maldo III; assistant direction, Julio Mendoza; choreography, Julio Mendoza and Aries Clemeno; costume design, Patricia San Jose-Lacerna; props, Eldefonso Maldo. Cast: Sama-samang Tinig ng mga Aktor na Gumagalaw sa Entablado and the Sorsogon Community-Based Theater Group (CBTG) ensemble. First performed in 2000 in Aquinas University in Legaspi, Albay, the play was a collaborative production by the Aquinas University, the Sorsogon CBTG, and Letra, a Bikol magazine. The play was also presented during the Sandiwaan Festival by the National Commission of Culture and the Arts (NCCA) at the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 2001. Also, under an NCCA grant, the play was toured in almost all the provinces in Mindanao, as well as in Manila and the University of Baguio in Luzon.

The story tells of Daragang Magayon, who is aware that, eventually, she will be the chieftain of her tribe. However, the future is threatened by the ambitious Datu Pagtuga, a mighty warrior and hunter who is already beginning to conquer neighboring tribes. Daragang Magayon will not allow such a thing to happen. On her own, she trains to become a warrior with the help of her nurse Sirangan. She wants to prove that being a woman will not hinder her from defending her tribe. Datu Pagtuga, desiring to make Daragang Magayon his wife, abducts her father Datu Makusog. But Daragang Magayon is already smitten by the charm of Ulap, a gallant warrior from a distant land. A battle ensues between the peoples of Daragang Magayon and Datu Pagtuga, killing most of the warriors in Daragang Magayon’s tribe. The morning after the battle, cries and wailings of widows and orphans are raised to high heavens and down the bottomless seas. Datu Pagtuga is killed by Ulap. Daragang Magayon runs to embrace Ulap. A stray arrow pierces Daragang Magayon. As Ulap embraces the dying Daragang Magayon, a man from Datu Pagtuga’s tribe impales Ulap’s back with a spear, killing him instantly. The two are eventually buried in a place where the beautiful Mayon Volcano now stands.

 

Jamoralin and Llana adapted to stage Peñones’s translation of Merlinda Bobis’s Cantata of Daragang Magayon, Warrior Woman, 1993. The musical-dance drama deviates from the traditional representation of Daragang Magayon as a submissive maiden to becoming a warrior woman who wages war when her people are threatened by an oppressor. The production incorporates Bikol movements such as halya or “to drive away evil” and Bikol rituals.  Written by Rebeccca Razo

First performed in 2000 in Aquinas University in Legaspi, Albay, the play was a collaborative production by the Aquinas University, the Sorsogon CBTG, and Letra, a Bikol magazine. The play was also presented during the Sandiwaan Festival by the National Commission of Culture and the Arts (NCCA) at the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 2001. Also, under an NCCA grant, the play was toured in almost all the provinces in Mindanao, as well as in Manila and the University of Baguio in Luzon.

The story tells of Daragang Magayon, who is aware that, eventually, she will be the chieftain of her tribe. However, the future is threatened by the ambitious Datu Pagtuga, a mighty warrior and hunter who is already beginning to conquer neighboring tribes. Daragang Magayon will not allow such a thing to happen. On her own, she trains to become a warrior with the help of her nurse Sirangan. She wants to prove that being a woman will not hinder her from defending her tribe. Datu Pagtuga, desiring to make Daragang Magayon his wife, abducts her father Datu Makusog. But Daragang Magayon is already smitten by the charm of Ulap, a gallant warrior from a distant land. A battle ensues between the peoples of Daragang Magayon and Datu Pagtuga, killing most of the warriors in Daragang Magayon’s tribe. The morning after the battle, cries and wailings of widows and orphans are raised to high heavens and down the bottomless seas. Datu Pagtuga is killed by Ulap. Daragang Magayon runs to embrace Ulap. A stray arrow pierces Daragang Magayon. As Ulap embraces the dying Daragang Magayon, a man from Datu Pagtuga’s tribe impales Ulap’s back with a spear, killing him instantly. The two are eventually buried in a place where the beautiful Mayon Volcano now stands.

value.desc: Aquinas University’s Kantada ni Daragong Magayon, Mandirigma, Legazpi, Albay, 2000 (Photo courtesy of Kaloi Garcia, Aquinas University)

article.value: Jamoralin and Llana adapted to stage Peñones’s translation of Merlinda Bobis’s Cantata of Daragang Magayon, Warrior Woman, 1993. The musical-dance drama deviates from the traditional representation of Daragang Magayon as a submissive maiden to becoming a warrior woman who wages war when her people are threatened by an oppressor. The production incorporates Bikol movements such as halya or “to drive away evil” and Bikol rituals.  Written by Rebeccca Razo

photos.desc: Aicelle Santos, center, in Spotlight Artists Centre’s Katy! The Musical, CCP, Manila, 2013 (Franco Laurel)

text:
1988. Musical in two acts, in Filipino. Direction, Nestor Torre Jr; script and lyrics, Jose Javier Reyes; music, Ryan Cayabyab. Cast: Mitch Valdes (Katy), Celeste Legaspi (Olivia), Ten Ten Muñoz (young Katy), Bernardo Bernardo (Tatay), Marco Sison (Peping), Robert Seña (Dolphy), Pinky Marquez (Hanna), Arlene Borja (Patsy), Gigi Posadas (Mary), Lou Veloso, and Beverly Salviejo. Produced by Musical Theater Philippines of Girlie Rodis and Celeste Legaspi. First performed in Nov 1988 at the Rizal Theater in Makati, with a repeat performance in Jan 1989, with substantially the same cast, at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Tanghalang Aurelio V. Tolentino. Restaged by Spotlight Artists Center in Jul and Aug 2013 at the CCP and the Meralco Theater, with Isay Alvarez (Katy), Aicelle Santos (teen Katy), Yedda Lambujon and Leanna Tabunnar (young Katy), Dulce (Olivia), Tirso Cruz III (Tatay), Gian Magdangal (Peping), Epy Quizon (Dolphy), Tricie Jimenez (Hanna), Celine Fabie (Patsy), and CJ Mangahis (Mary).

In act 1, the old Katy visits the old theater where she used to perform when she was considered the “Queen of Bodabil.” The play then flashes back to her childhood, when she would beg her father to take her to the plaza, where, to the band’s music, she would sing to the crowd and earn a few coins. Not fond of books, Katy eventually drops out of school. The father scolds her for being hardheaded but Katy says she would rather do what she is good at, which is singing. Just then an impresario hires Katy to sing at the cockfighting arena, where she earns bigger amounts. Katy continues to perform between film screenings in Manila theaters, and earns enough to buy all the family’s needs. But her father still fears for her daughter in a business that is not kind to women. Katy reassures her father that she can take care of herself. Just then, an American impresario hires Katy to star in bodabil shows at the famous Teatro Lux.

 

In act 2, Katy is now famous as the best jazz singer in bodabil, a real star that can attract crowds to her shows. But even as she enjoys her newfound stardom, her personal life undergoes a crisis when she and her husband Peping, a playboy, go their separate ways. She goes into a depression but soon learns to cope with the problem by attending to her child and devoting her life to performing with bodabil artists who have become close friends, including chorus girls and singers Hanna, Mary Walter, and Patsy, and dancer comedian Dolphy who is known as Golay. Katy becomes famous for her scatting technique and her naughty songs like “Balut” and “Saging,” and remains at the top of the heap for many more decades until she migrates to California. In the end, the play goes back to the old Katy in the run-down theater, where the lights are turned on for the last time, as Katy reprises one of the original songs of the musical, “Minsan ang Minahal Ay Ako” (Once It Was Me You Loved), to the full accompaniment of the band and the chorus of singers and dancers.

Katy is considered one of the most successful original Filipino musicals of the country.  Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

photos.desc: Atang de la Rama in a prewar production of Ang Kiri (Nicanor G. Tiongson Collection)

text:
(The Flirt). 1926. Sarsuwela in three acts, in Tagalog. Libretto, Servando de los Angeles; music, Leon Ignacio. Cast: Atang de la Rama. Restaged in 1974 at the Main Theater, later Tanghalang Nicanor S. Abelardo, of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) under the direction of Rolando S. Tinio, with additional music by Willy Cruz; sets and costumes by Salvador Bernal; lighting design by Teddy L. Hilado; choreography by Simon Mossessgeld; cast, Conching Rosal in the title role, together with Aurelio Estanislao, Emmanuel B. Gregorio, Constantino Bernardez, Gamaliel Viray, and Jovita Castro. It was also staged under the direction of Isagani R. Cruz at the Metropolitan Theater in Manila in 1979. It was made into a movie by Diwata Films as Mahiwagang Binibini (Mysterious Lady) in 1939 under the direction of de los Angeles, and starring Atang de la Rama, Precioso Palma, Carmen Rosales, and Gregorio Ticman. In 2009, Dulaang Unibersidad ng Pilipinas (DUP) presented their rendition of the play for the monthlong Sarsuwela Festival hosted by UP. It was published in 1974 by Manlapaz Publishing.

The sarsuwela revolves around Sesang, the kiri, a fun-loving and party-giving flirt. In act 1, which opens on a party in her house, her four suitors—Ramon, old and rich; Norris, a congressman; Soter, a fiscal; and Pepe, a poet—take turns bribing Amboy, the servant, for information and for assurance that each is the only man in her life. Ramon pays for her house, servants, and driver; Soter and Norris contribute to her expenses; and Pepe wants to marry her. But she falls in love with Jacinto, a law student and the childhood sweetheart of Pilar, her seamstress. Sesang asks Jacinto to stay in her house, promising help with his studies. In act 2, which opens with a game of golf, Ramon is furious to discover that Jacinto is in Sesang’s house. Jacinto’s mother, Aling Biang, and Pilar, who is in tears because of the betrayal, are able to convince him to go home to the province. In act 3, Sesang goes to the province to seek him, whom she sees as her salvation from the life she is leading. She finds him married to Pilar, and although she still tries to win him, she finally surrenders to reality. In the end, she explains how she became what she is in a famous song written by Jose Corazon de Jesus: “Inakay na ibon … uhaw sa ligaya’t sabik sa liwanag hindi sinasadya’y nahulog sa lusak …” (A foundling … thirsty for happiness and eager to see the light … accidentally falls into the murk …). She not only wins the sympathy of Aling Biang and of Pilar, but realizes that Pepe, the poet, has been faithful, and indeed offers her true love.

 

Ang Kiri is one of the best-known sarsuwela of the prewar era with over 351 performances on record. It is the first to present the kontrabida (antihero) as bida (hero).  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez, updated by Athena Angela Aquino

 

Sources

De los Angeles, Servando, and Leon Ignacio. 1974. Ang Kiri (The Coquette): Operetang May Tatlong Yugto. Manila: Manlapaz Publishing.

Tiatco, Sir Anril P., and Amihan Bonifacio-Ramolete. 2010. “Performing the Nation Onstage: An Afterthought on the University of the Philippines Sarsuwela Festival 2009.” Asian Theatre Journal 27 (2): 307-32.

article_title: Kung Paano ko Pinatay si Diana Ross

photos.desc: Melvin Lee, standing at left, in PETA’s Kung Paano Ko Pinatay si Diana Ross, Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Manila, 1991 (PETA Library and Archives)

text:
(How I Killed Diana Ross). 1991. Five-act play in Filipino. Direction, Soxie Topacio; script, Rodolfo C. Vera aka Rody Vera. Cast: Linus Sto. Tomas (Andy), Melvin Lee (Diana Ross), Chie Concepcion (Susan), Louie Pascasio, Khryss Adalia, Carme Sanchez, Wylie Casero, Jack Yabut, and Angie Cantero-Castrence. First staged on 22 Nov–15 Dec 1991 at Fort Santiago by the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) on its 25th season. The script came to print in 1995 as part of PETA Script Series, as well as in Vera’s collection titled Tatlong Dula (Three Plays), 2011.

In act 1, the child Andy enters with a toy gun on his shoulder and sees Diana Ross on television singing “Baby Love.” Andy becomes engrossed in the performance and begins imitating Diana Ross’s movements and singing style. Soon after, Andy’s parents arrive and his father attempts to entice Andy into a game of basketball. However, Andy’s attention remains on Diana Ross. This first act ends with the introduction of a cross-dresser Diana Ross whom Andy has befriended.

 

In act 2, the young Andy and his friends Alphons and Leo are in the seminary, happily recounting the fashion show they did earlier that day. The conversation then turns to one of their seniors, Brother Pascal, and his romantic relationship with Alphons. These revelations reach Father Bobby, resulting in their dismissal from the seminary. The scene ends with Andy asking the omnipresent Diana Ross to leave him alone.

In act 3, Andy’s friends throw a stag party for him a week before his marriage to a girl named Susan. His friends have paid a stripper, Lolita, to “prepare” Andy for the honeymoon, but Andy’s attempt to become intimate with the stripper fails despite Diana Ross’s help. The act ends showing a drunk Andy being attended to by his best friend, Mike. Later, slides of Andy’s wedding are projected on screen.

The height of tension is in act 4 when Mike tells Andy of his plan to go to the United States. Upset, Andy embraces Mike. Susan witnesses the passionate embrace and calls for Andy’s parents who encourage him to ask forgiveness and kill Diana Ross. Andy shoots himself and ends up in a hospital.

In the last act, Andy finally accepts his homosexuality. Susan leaves him. Mike explains to him the reality of being gay. The play ends with a projection of slides showing photos of Mike and Andy together, to an upbeat tune and dancing à la Chippendales.

Kung Paano Ko Pinatay si Diana Ross tackles the internal and external conflicts faced by gays as they come out of their suppressed and restricted selves. The play won second prize in the full-length play in Filipino category of the Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature in 1992.  Written by Ronald H. Biñas and Athena Angela Aquino

 

Source

Vera, Rody. 2011. Tatlong Dula. Quezon City: The University of the Philippines Press.

photos.desc: Ben Rubio and Rita Gomez in Dalubdulaan’s Kuwadro, Manila Metropolitan Theater, 1980 (Nicanor G. Tiongson Collection)

text:
(Portrait). 1980. Monologue in Tagalog. Direction, Antonio Mabesa; script, Isagani R. Cruz; set design, Amiel Leonardia; costume design, Roland Olvega. Cast: Rita Gomez, Francis Montilla, Jay Valencia-Glorioso, and Ben Rubio. First staged on 18 Apr 1980 at the Dalubdulaan of the Manila Metropolitan Theater. It was restaged on 29 Jul 1981 by Antonio Mabesa at the same venue, with the addition of Spanky Manikan and Antonio Mabesa to the cast; in 1992 by Mars Cavestany at the Tanghalang Huseng Batute of the Cultural Center of the Philippines, with Lorli Villanueva in the lead role. Other actors who have played the lead role during various occasions are Fides Cuyugan-Asencio, Susan Valdez, Sujata Mukhi, and Sunita Mukhi, who translated and read it in English at the De La Salle University in 1985. It was published in Isagani R. Cruz’s Josephine at Iba Pang Dula (Josephine and Other Plays), 1988.

 

Set in 1935, it opens with Katerina Alonso, an aging sarsuwela star, waiting for an audience that does not come, for offers that are no longer made. She talks to herself—to a young lover, and a young woman, neither of whom answers. She remembers when, at 10, the guards at the Teatro Rizal already knew her, and she decided that she would become queen of the sarsuwela. She remembers how she used to sweep floors at the Teatro Zorrilla, in the days of Atang de la Rama, and how Dalagang Bukid, the Hermogenes Ilagan sarsuwela, became a film and Atang de la Rama had to sing from behind the screen. She recalls the days of her glory as star, the songs she sang and the plays in which she starred—and how bodabil and the movies eclipsed the sarsuwela. She assures the young man that Don Isagani de los Amores, her patron, is not due to arrive yet. Anyway, he is lithe and young, and able to jump out of windows and escape into the streets. She reminisces about first meeting Don Isagani when she was not quite 17, about his plays in English that never saw the stage, about how he loved, supported, and housed her—and how, if not for him, she might have married and had children. Hopes and illusions rise again as Don Isagani enters, and she talks of other sarsuwela to come, asking him to court her, to tell her he was going to make her happy forever, and to worship her, Katerina Alonso, his queen, and queen of the Filipino sarsuwela.

Kuwadro, written by Cruz especially for Rita Gomez, won second prize in the Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature in 1980.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

article_title: Labaw Donggon: Ang Banog ng Sanlibutan

photos.desc: Ateneo ENTABLADO’s Labaw Donggon, Ateneo de Manila University, 2013 (Christie K. Lim)

text:
(Labaw Donggon: The Hawk of the Universe). 2013. Musical-drama. Direction, Jerry C. Respeto; script, Nicanor G. Tiongson; production design, Gino Gonzales; music, Jema Pamintuan, Teresa Barrozo, and Maynard de Guzman; movement and choreography, Gio Gahol and Ma. Elena Laniog; lighting and sound design, Voltaire de Jesus. Cast: Nicco Manalo/Gio Gahol (Labaw Donggon), Jethro Tenorio/Jesus Ignacio (Saragnayan), Mark Philippe Legaspi (comic sidekick), Banaue Miclat-Janssen (Alunsina), Ronah Adiel Rostata (narrator-chanter), Timee Gorecho/Camille Luber (Ginbitinan), Icee Po/Lemelen Palad (Doronoon), Angel Garcia/Nareeza Bainto (Nagmalitung Yawa Sinagmaling Diwata), Paul Niccolo Claustro/Ian Segarra (Asu Mangga), Victor Robinson/John Michael del Rosario (Baranugun), Richard de Guzman, Randy Solis, Juan Miguel Ocampo, Danilo Villarey III, Zennon Jean Gosalvez, Maria Fatima Gabito, and Sheryll Ceasico. First staged by Ateneo ENTABLADO in Jan 2013 at the Cervini Open Ground, Ateneo de Manila University.

The play is a musical adaptation of the Panay epic Labaw Donggon to mark ENTABLADO’s 30th anniversary, upholding its tradition of staging socially relevant plays especially outside the confines of a theater hall. Interpreting the epic as an allegory, the play, with the assistance of a narrator-chanter and a comic sidekick, follows the hero Labaw Donggon as he embarks on a journey to restore peace in a world rent asunder by envy, greed, and selfish ego. He unites the divided worlds—the Underworld, the Middleworld, and the Upperworld—by marrying a binukot or princess from each of the three realms. But, in order to do this, he needs to best formidable adversaries guarding each binukot. After overcoming the Kapre Manaluntad through the power of his pamlang (magical oil), he marries Ginbitinan of the Underworld, by whom he has a son, Asu Mangga. text:
1953. One-act play in English. Direction and script, Severino Montano. Cast: Corazon S. Vigilia (Mrs Paring Gomez), Pilar Acuña-Amos (Simang), Jose Feliciano (Antonio Maripal), Consuelo S. Pacquing, Amparo S. Javier, Esther S. Reyes, Gabriela J. del Rosario, Emilia Vito, Agustina T. Ancheta, Dalisay F. Domingo, Teofila Borbon, Filomena Daywan, Fortunata T. Cruz, and Luz de la Cruz. It was first performed on 6 Mar 1953 at the Normal Hall of the Philippine Normal College by the then newly formed Arena Theater Company, which Montano also established. It was first staged as part of a trilogy with Montano’s Sabina and Parting at Calamba. The trilogy, together with the full-length The Love of Leonora Rivera, would later on become staples in the Arena Theater tours around the provinces from the late 1960s to the early 1980s. The tours aimed to build what Montano called “theater from the grass-roots” and bring it “closer to the masses.” The play was later published in Montano’s Selected Plays, 1982.

 

In an apartment living room in Washington, DC, USA, the housewife Mrs Paring Gomez, and her maid Simang, are busy preparing for a meeting of the Filipino Women’s Club and the arrival of an important guest, a visiting senator from the Philippines, Sen Antonio Maripal. After the members parade in one by one and settle down, the ladies gossip in quaint Filipinized English about marital indecencies, practices of nepotism and corruption, including those linked to the senator. Eventually it becomes apparent that the ladies are all wives of either Filipino government officials or militia men stationed in the USA. The ladies bicker whether it is acceptable to have the senator as an honorary member of their club, despite his alleged lavish spending “at the expense of the Filipino people’s money.” But while most of the ladies question and disagree with the motion from the onset, the politician’s flamboyant personality and flowery, over-the-top rhetoric eventually clinches the chattering ladies’ decision to adopt the senator.

In 2005, the University of the Philippines (UP) Playwrights’ Theater in UP Diliman presented Tatlong Maikling Dula ni Severino Montano (Three Short Plays by Montano) directed by Ogie Juliano, showcasing once more the trilogy to which this play belongs. Juliano’s gender-bending take—the ladies were played by male actors and the senator, by a woman—was most effective not so much for its queerness but for underlining the absurd, through the glittering and bawdy camp costumes reminiscent of the 1950s, an era obsessed with “moral decency.  Written by Carlo Pacolor Garcia

text:
(Heavenly Quicksand). 1978. Chamber play. Direction, concept, script, lyrics, and short story, Antonio Victor L. Reyes aka Icktoy Reyes. Cast: Ed Pagayon (Luis), Marie Reyes Marciano (Simeona), Orlando R. Nadres (Candido Atienza), Tessie S. Padua (Nyora Bebang), Arlyn Abuid, Tony Corpus Reyes, Estrella Antonio, Aida Carmona, Edgar Zabala, and members of the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) Kalinangan Ensemble. First staged in 1978 at the Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Intramuros, by the PETA Kalinangan Ensemble. The play was restaged in 2015 at the Museo de Lipa, Plaza Independencia, Lipa City, by the Lipa Actors Company. The short story was anthologized in Daluyan: Katipunan ng Maiikling Kuwento, 1972-1978 (Source: Collection of Short Stories, 1972-1978), 1978, and in Kamao: Mga Kuwento ng Protesta (Fist: Stories of Protest), 1987.

The play is set in the Lantorre family’s vast expanse of coconut, kalamunding (calamondin), and chico plantation lands in Barrio Magapi. Though not explicitly stated, the environs are assumed to be located in the remote areas of Lipa and Malvar, Batangas, during the second half of the 20th century, where the system of landownership exacted every possible profit out of agricultural produce, leaving the farmhands, including the katiwala (caretaker), in perpetual bondage and deprivation.

The narrative starts with the death of Candido Atienza, the katiwala to the Lantorre lands in Barrio Magapi and father of Luis. Grief permeates the funeral, but Candido’s widow and Luis’s mother Simeona refuses to shed even a single tear. Luis asks how she can remain stoic at her husband’s funeral, firm in her stance as her husband is buried at the back of the Lantorre mausoleum in the town’s cemetery. The narrative then presents a flashback where Simeona unravels the oppressive system of land monopoly that has led to backwardness and underdevelopment of rural Batangas.

For generations, the tenants and farmhands of the Lantorres were obedient to the owners. Every year, on the birth anniversary of the Lantorre patriarch Kabesang Islaw on 30 Aug, the Lantorre clan and friends troop to Magapi for a celebration, where a lavish feast is served. The guests go for a swim in the river, and 10- and 20-peso bills are distributed to the barrio folks’ children. The event’s highlight comes when the landowner’s son displays his guns and shoots at hanging coconut shells, deafening all ears in the plantation.

As a young bride to Candido, Simeona saw how her father-in-law sank into submissiveness and surrender to the Lantorre so she decided to resist the Lantorre supremacy.

Once, Simeona and Candido, as representatives of the farmworkers, were called to a meeting with Nyora Bebang and Kabesang Islaw. A meticulous accounting of the land’s produce was conducted, where every conceivable expense incurred by every farmhand was deducted from the farmhands’ share. In the meeting, Nyora Bebang offered Simeona her used and old dresses made by the best seamstresses of the town. With Simeona’s rejection, Nyora Bebang ordered her helper to use the dresses as rags in the kitchen.

Later, Simeona narrated how her mother-in-law also refused to shed tears during the funeral of her father-in-law. Simeona lamented how her husband’s family had served their masters so well that even their final resting places are located at the back of the Lantorre’s mausoleum, remaining loyal to their masters even in the afterlife. There can be no grief in this setup; Simeona tells her son who is to be the next katiwala. It is now Luis’s turn to decide whether to continue his family’s tradition of bondage or not.

Based on a short story on the agrarian issue, the play was PETA’s closest venture, if not the only venture, into chamber theater. Native mats and bamboo served as flooring and background décor for the static staging of the production. The play employed slides, a koro (chorus) that borrowed the traditional “kinoryente” tune of the Batangas pabasa (chanting of pasyon) and sang songs composed by Tony C. Reyes especially for the production. One of the songs titled “Matapat na Lahi” (Faithful Race) became part of Inang Laya’s repertoire for decades. Reyes’s short story won second prize in the Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature in 1978.  Written by Apolonio B. Chua

text:
(Last Order at Penguin). 2000. Three-act play in Filipino. Direction and script, Chris Martinez; choreography, Dexter Santos; set design, Jonathan Alday; lights design, Ohm David; costume design, Edwin Serrano; sound design, Jobin Ballesteros. Cast: Tuxqs Rutaquio (Tuxqs), Harlene Bautista-Sarmenta (Harlene), Teresa Jamias (Tess), Thess Antonio (Tess and Sang), Charissa Pascual (Sang), Dyna Padilla-Hone (Dyna), Mario Magallona/Roy San Luis (Mario), John Lapus (Sweet), Romnick Sarmenta/Andoy Ranay (Nicko), Edwin Serrano/Dave Tolentino (Edwin), Sheryl Torres/Jojet Gorrez (Sheqs), Mhon Baya/Paulo Paulino (Marcel), and Justeen Niebres. The play was first staged on 9 Nov 2000 by the University of the Philippines (UP) Theater Council at the Teatro Hermogenes Ylagan in UP Diliman. The play had a regular run at the Penguin Bar in Malate in Dec 2000 and was restaged at the Aldaba Recital Hall of the UP Theater in 2001. Succeeding restagings of the play were done by different theater groups, both professional and nonprofessional, such as Teatro Tomasino of the University of Santo Tomas in 2003 and Dulaang UP Baguio in 2008. The script was published by the UP Press in 2003.

Artist-friends Tuxqs, Harlene, Tess, Dyna, and Mario are regular patrons of Penguin Café, a gallery-cum-café-cum-bar. They are always attended to by waiter Marcel and Sweet, who nags them about buying his red roses that get more expensive every time she enters. The play begins with Tuxqs’s arrival at the Penguin Café. After being welcomed by Marcel, Tuxqs starts contacting friends who are still on-the-way. Harlene arrives and is unnerved by the paintings exhibited at the café. She confides to Tuxqs how her four-year live-in relationship is collapsing. Tess arrives and comments how undesirable the paintings are. Tess, who used to date a lot of boys, discloses her current sex life which involves a lesbian, Sheqs. Tuxqs and Harlene scrutinize Tess’s change of sexual preference. Their discussion goes from Tess’s qualms about having a lesbian lover, to Harlene’s unfulfilled sexual needs with her live-in partner Nicko, and Tuxqs’s fear of growing old, single, and alone. Dyna and Mario arrive. Mario introduces Sang. Dyna expresses her revulsion for jologs (coarse, low class people)—only to reveal, upon the group’s inquiry, that she is dating Edwin, a 16-year-old jolog. She is actually ashamed of introducing him to the group. The group, wanting very much to meet Edwin, pins Dyna to the couch and contacts Edwin to come to the café. Meanwhile, Mario narrates his epiphanic transformation from a drug user to a drug pusher because of his near-death experience, adding how he and Sang met. Sang reveals she is older than the rest of them and expresses her contentment in having four kids, shocking the group. Edwin arrives and is comfortable speaking to them. The group, much to Dyna’s embarrassment, is amused that Edwin abhors jologs. Sheqs arrives and offers marriage to Tess, which she neither accepts nor rejects. Harlene and Nicko are not able to resolve the issue of a long-term relationship gone stale. Dyna and Edwin are at odds because of their different upbringing. Mario and Sang, having no issues to begin with, end the same way they began. Except for Tuxqs, everyone leaves the Penguin Café. Tuxqs, loveless and drunk, debates with Sweet, who is disappointed because she never got to sell any of his red roses. As they get high on marijuana, their debate centers on whose problem is graver.

 

Last Order sa Penguin lightly tackles heavy topics like drugs, same-sex relationships, midlife crisis, poverty, discrimination, and momentary escape from all these problems through alcohol and café talk. The characters in the play are based on their real-life counterparts and namesakes who are good friends of the playwright. The script won first prize in the 2001 Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature.   Written by Trixie Dauz

text:
1952. Three-act play in English. Script and direction, Severino Montano. Cast: Chito Madrigal, Naty Crame-Rogers, Elizabeth Baylon, Amada Buñag, Jesusa Montano Saddam, Sagrario Arreza, Purificacion Banaag, Zenaida Pavon, Edith Zaide, Feliza Lardizabal, Luisa Jose, Rudy Francisco, Nick Agudo, Fred Principe, Renato Canto, Elisa Farin, Elsa Aenlle, Severino Montano, Jose Feleciano, Raul Zamora, Rebecca Alcantara, Victoria Abelardo, James W. Dunhill, and the Arena Theater Ensemble. First staged by the Arena Theater of the Philippines on 26 Nov 1952 at the Ladies’ Dormitory of the Philippine Normal College, later University, in Manila. It was presented in many Philippine towns and schools from 1953 to 1964, often with Crame-Rogers as Leonor Rivera, as well as in the United States and in Mexico City where it was staged in Spanish as El Amor de Leonor Rivera. In 1984 it was staged at the Little Theater, later Tanghalang Aurelio V. Tolentino, of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) under the direction of Naty Crame-Rogers, with music by Lucrecia R. Kasilag, musical arrangement by Rosario Buencamino-Licad, lighting design by Teddy L. Hilado, Rowena Quial and Catherine Roxas alternating in the title role, and Albert Licad as Jose Rizal. In 1987 it was restaged by Naty Crame-Rogers in her Filipino translation titled Ang Pag-ibig ni Leonor Rivera for the Philippine Drama Company at the same venue with Tommy Abuel playing the role of Jose Rizal. It was published in Selected Plays of Severino Montano, Volume I, 1981.

The play is about the love of Leonor Rivera for Jose Rizal, and how it persisted through his sojourn in Europe, her marriage, his exile in Dapitan, until her death.

 

Act 1 opens on Leonor’s 15th birthday on 11 Apr 1882, and her joy in having her friends Chengoy and Choleng, aunts Isabel and Carmen, and the prospect of Pepe arriving to celebrate with her. Their joy is marred by the decision made by Don Antonio, her father, and Paciano, his brother, to send Pepe to Europe. This to ensure his safety from the Spaniards and his freedom to observe and write. Pepe asks to be allowed to marry Leonor before leaving, but is refused.

Act 2 opens on Leonor six years later in 1880, still waiting for Pepe, who is still in Europe. Doña Silvestra, her mother, obviously favors the suit of Charles Henry Kipping, the British engineer building the Tarlac railroad, but Leonor waits only for Rizal and his letters, which do not come, although she writes him daily. In scene 2 she wearily agrees to marry Kipping, but speaks of death: “I want you to realize that I shall not want to live long …” In scene 3, she marries him on 17 Jun 1891, a day on which she finds out how her mother had intercepted all Rizal’s letters, and bribed the postmaster not to mail hers. She sees Pepe in a vision, and they pledge their love.

Act 3 is set in Aug 1893; Leonor has had a child, and is dying, with “clear symptoms of deep melancholia.” Kipping’s devotion is deep and selfless, but Leonor has not learned to love him. Ailing, she lives in her memories. She rises from her sickbed, and appears wearing the blue dress in which she had pledged herself to Rizal, and receives her last visitor, Choleng, who tells her that Rizal is in exile in Dapitan, and has never stopped loving her. She dies peacefully in that knowledge, and the play closes on Doña Silvestra’s contrition, and Jose’s spirit coming for Leonor: “Goodbye to you, beautiful but cruel earth! … Do not forget our songs!”  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez and Cynthia San Juan

 

Source

Montano, Severino. 1981-82. Selected Plays Volume 1. Quezon City: New Day Publishers.

photos.desc: Luna: An Aswang Romance, AFP Theater, 2000 (Photo courtesy of Shoko Matsumoto)

text:
2000. Two-act play in Filipino. Direction, Anton Juan Jr; script, Rody Vera; set design, Mig Chaves, Ning Encarnacion Tan, and Wendy Regalado; lighting design, Shoko Matsumoto; costume design, Ann Wizer, Steve de Leon, and Gigi Escalante; artistic direction and score, Manuel Chaves; production, Gilda Cordero-Fernando. Cast: Edna Vida (Glorietta), Cecilia CB Garrucho (Alegria), Roeder Camañag (Jacobino), Alya Honasan (Mrs Manalangin), Alan Paule (Mio), Chin-Chin Gutierrez (Luna Mallari), Malou Crisologo, Len Ag Santos and Liza Deocampo (Mrs Manalangin’s three friends), Ernest Santiago (Maria), Joy Virata (Dionisia), Dexter Santos (director), and Floy Quintos (Amante). First staged in Feb 2000 at the Armed Forces of the Philippines Theater in Camp Aguinaldo, Quezon City. The script is included in Vera’s collection titled Tatlong Dula (Three Plays), 2011.

The play opens with an aswang orasyon, a ritual of the malevolent being presided over by Glorietta, Alegria, and Jacobino, three members of an aswang family. Mrs Manalangin is informed by her son Mio that he has proposed marriage to Luna Mallari, the aswang family’s descendant. Mrs Manalangin’s three friends visit her and gossip about the alleged aswang—namely, Maria, Glorietta, Alegria, and Jacobino, as well as Dionisia, Luna’s supposed mother who is human. Mrs Manalangin believes them and resolves that she does not want to have an aswang for an in-law.

 

A director follows Amante, the aswang buster, to document his life story. Amante wants to eradicate all aswang because his daughter was killed by one. He explains that he has aswang detector oil that boils whenever aswang are nearby. Mrs Manalangin arrives to offer Amante a mission to terminate a few aswang. Meanwhile, Luna tries to convince her family to accept Mio. Glorietta, Alegria, and Jacobino go to Mio’s house and read his mind, but see no thoughts of Luna there. As daybreak approaches, they leave.

Mio and his mother visit the Mallari household for the pamamanhikan or the formal visit of the man’s family to ask for the woman’s hand in marriage from her parents. Glorietta, Alegria, and Jacobino put aswang saliva in his favorite food, kare-kare, in an attempt to turn him into an aswang. Amante’s aswang detector oil boils, leading him to the kare-kare. He dips his finger into it and licks his finger. Mrs Manalangin prohibits Mio from marrying Luna.

Maria passes on a black chick to the crestfallen Luna, who decides to become an aswang. The family performs the transformation ritual, while Amante also turns into an aswang. Luna, now an aswang, asks Mio to love her in her aswang form. Mio reveals that he has loved her in her true form all along. He explains that her family did not find thoughts of her in his head because she is in his heart. Luna kisses him and flies away.

The play is the first serious dramatic work that tackles the phenomenon of the aswang with insight. It was also distinguished by its outstanding production design. The play won first prize in the full-length play in Filipino category of the Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature in 1999.  Written by Walter Ang
