text:
1991. Three-act play in Filipino. Direction, Nonon G. Padilla; script, Jose Y. Dalisay Jr; stage manager, Shax Siasoco; assistant stage manager, Dong Manuel; production manager, Jojo K. Casim; assistant production manager, Gina Evangelista; set and costume designer, Don Escudero; lighting designer, Dennis Marasigan. Cast: Bernardo Bernardo (Mac Malicsi), Irma Adlawan (Sally), Shamaine Centenera-Buencamino (Wendy Van Winkle), Ony de Leon (Pete Pihado), RJ Leyran (Dwight), Garry Lim (Pio), Ilma Barayuga (Adel), and Olga Natividad. First staged by Tanghalang Pilipino on 18 Oct–10 Nov 1991 at the Tanghalang Huseng Batute, Cultural Center of the Philippines, under the direction of Ishmael Bernal. In 1992, a new character, Pio De Puga, was integrated into the play. Tanghalang Pilipino staged this version at the Toyama International Amateur Theater Festival in Toyama, Japan, on 1-7 Aug 1992. With CCP’s outreach program, the play went on a national tour. The play script was published with another play in Butihing Babae ng Timog/Mac Malicsi TNT (Good Woman of Timog/Mac Malicsi TNT), 1997.

In a hotel in Milwaukee, Mac Malicsi bitterly muses how wonderful life is in America to his companion Pio. Dwight, an American national, enters and asks Mac for whiskey in return for a cigar. Dwight is refused when he asks if he can stay the night. Growing suspicious, he asks if Mac is in any trouble. Mac denies this and adds that he has been a tourist for eight years. Addressing the audience, he confesses that he entered the United States (US) on a tourist visa to run away from Sen Tommy Tirador of the Philippines, whose daughter he knocked up. He narrates the odd jobs he did as an illegal migrant and how he is currently on the run from the Midwestern Association of Filipino Immigrants in America (MAFIA). Dwight falls asleep and is robbed by Mac, who goes to Minneapolis, Minnesota, with Pio. They leave the still-asleep Dwight to deal with the Immigration and Naturalization Service (INS), the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and the hotel manager who later bursts into the room looking for Mac.

On the train, Mac goes by another name and meets the hairdresser Wendy Van Winkle and the immigrant Pete Pihado who is now a professor in Ohio. Mac convinces them that he is an investment counselor and manages to get money from them. Arriving at Minneapolis, Pete leaves the group. Wendy decides to have dinner with Mac and tells him about her life as a former lover of Frank, a MAFIA member. Pete returns with Adel, also a member of the MAFIA, who has lost her way to the annual MAFIA Christmas Party. Mac and Adel note their familiarity with each other. Pete and Adel describe the MAFIA Christmas party and invites Mac and Wendy to attend, unaware that their conversation is being recorded. Mac refuses and invites Wendy to spend the night with him instead. At the hotel, Mac, thinking Wendy is asleep, takes her purse and goes to the bathroom. Once Mac is out of sight, Wendy likewise takes Mac’s wallet from his pants’ pocket and finds out he has been deceiving her the whole time. Mac emerges from the bathroom disgruntled upon seeing his ID in Wendy’s hands and snatches it back. He tells the audience that it is his most prized possession—the one proof of an honest attempt to live a decent life. Outraged by Mac’s attempt to steal from her, Wendy accuses him of being a fugitive. Mac denies this by saying that he is merely a “lost Pinoy.” Wendy threatens to call the police, but Mac argues that she has been lying to him as well. She admits to planning to steal from Mac from the beginning, and tells him of the difficulties she faced as an orphan that led her to where she is now. Mac is moved and gives Wendy his last one hundred dollars. Before parting ways, he tells her to find her aunt. Mac heads back to Chicago, and Wendy is reunited with Frank, who turns out to be the MAFIA chasing after Mac. At the train station to Chicago, Pio decides to live honestly and bids Mac goodbye.

In Chicago, Mac is reunited with Sally and asks her to marry him. Sally refuses and admits to tipping off the INS on Mac. Initially, she thought of going with him once he gets deported, but she is now soon to be married to an American. The next day, Mac goes to the INS office to turn himself in. Before he enters, the office announces that illegal aliens who entered before 1982, with proof of residency, are to be granted amnesty. Mac is overjoyed. Pio arrives and tells Mac of his plan to return to the Philippines to take care of his mother. Pio leaves, and a Filipino couple applying for amnesty arrive. However, they have no documents to prove that they were in the United States before 1982. Mac introduces himself as an immigration law attorney and offers to help them.

The play presents, in a comic way, what drastic measures some Filipinos who stay as illegal migrants in the United States resort to in order to chase the “American Dream.”  Written by Athena Angela Aquino

photos.desc: PETA’s Macli-ing, Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Manila, 1988 (PETA Library and Archives)

text:
1988. Three-act play in Filipino. Direction, Soxie Topacio; script, Malou Jacob; production design, Mel Bernardo; costume design, Boy Aquino Jr and Phil Noble; music, Louie Pascasio, Connie Lauigan-Chua, Ronnie Quesada, Vince de Jesus, Mhalouh Crisologo, Carme Sanchez, and Mae Paner; choreography and movement, Mary Joan Fajardo and Jack Yabut. Cast: Nanding Josef, Cirilo Bawer, Chiqui Xeres-Burgos, Joel Lamangan, Khryss Adalia, Connie Lauigan-Chua, Mary Joan Fajardo, Raul Alfonso, and the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) Kalinangan Ensemble. First staged by PETA on 15 Apr 1988 at the Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Fort Santiago, Manila.

The play dramatizes the lives, beliefs, and culture of the people of the Cordillera or Kaigorotan. In act 1, the Kalinga recall the death of their beloved leader Apo Macli-ing Dulag who was killed in the conflict over the Chico River Dam Project. Now they are confronted with a new enemy, Puraw, who arrived with his military forces and his women, presenting the natives with gifts to hide his real objective—to continue the building of the Chico River Dam. Through an apparition, a tree that sprouts on the grave of the fallen leader, the community tries to find out whether it is vengeance that Macli-ing seeks or a message he wants to get across to them. A priestess performs a ritual and Macli-ing speaks through her. The leader laments the prevailing disunity of the Cordillera people and warns of the fallibility of leaders. He says further that the new enemy is no different from the previous one, recalling the encroachment on their lives and ancestral rights by the National Power Corporation (NPC), whose presence they all defied in unity.

 

In act 2, the havoc created by their struggle with the NPC is shown: the burning of granaries, the stealing of heirlooms, rape, and torture. The priestess and the women go into a collective trance as the sins against the Cordillera are recalled. In one long scene, Macli-ing is shown speaking to his son, whom he teaches about bravery and justice in the face of exploitation and suffering among his people. The death of Macli-ing is shown at the end of the act through a dance of death.

Act 3 shows the bodong (Cordillera peace pact) as a unifying instrument of the Cordillera people, a source of strength that lowlanders, driven by self-interest, seek to destroy. With the revival of the bodong, Macli-ing says that his people have already avenged his death. The bodong culminates in a dance of war which denounces all forms of deception and divisiveness.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis

 

Source

Atienza, Glecy C. 1990. “Subersyon sa Dula sa Ilalilm ng Batas Militar: Mga Dula ng PETA 1975-1981.” MA thesis, College of Arts and Letters, University of the Philippines Diliman.

Boyles/Ninfa de Lara Mirasol (Emerita), Sylvia Garde/Nanie Gonzales (Selmah), Roberto Castro (Aran), Oya Arriola/Nacel Garduce (Karbah), Juliet Alcantara (Natividad), Alex Plagata (Id-an), Peter Serrano/Gwyn Guanzon (Rangkatulang), Shiela Manipon (Aurora Alba), Stella Balucas, Beryl Tianero, Meliza Orara, Joyce Sudiakal, Nestor Leyson, Rowena Pilar, Rochel Pilar, Michael Cruz, Danz Verzola, Binky Mendoza, Heidi Badjon, Maru Quiwa, Ron Domingo, Jorick Y. Maikling Buhay ng Apoy revolves around the story of Led-Ah, a girl from a lineage of powerful priestesses called babaylan, in the invisible island of Pulao-Pulao. Led-Ah’s curiosity and adventurous spirit accidentally lead to the death of her younger sister, Selmah. As everyone celebrates the surpahan, a sacred ritual where the oldest babaylan Lola Abet-A passes on her fire to Tandang Veneracion, Led-Ah is abducted by the kukok or shape-shifters. Emerita seeks everyone’s help to search for her daughter Led-Ah. Led by their king, the shape-shifters cause mayhem between husbands, wives, relatives, and friends. Other unfortunate events take place. The handsome Ramako is killed by a wild boar. Natividad, the invisible, mourns the death of Ramako and is taken by the king of shape-shifters as his wife. The two beget Busilak, the pure. Blamed for all the misfortunes of Pulao-Pulao, Led-Ah puts on the mask of ugliness, while her cousin Karbah grows to be a skilled and beautiful priestess.

The appearance of the Busilak comes with the waning of the fire of life of Tandang Veneracion. It is time for Tandang Veneracion to pass on her leadership to one of her daughters—Resureccion the healer or Emerita the frightful one—but only after one of them passes the test. Resureccion points to her daughter Karbah. Led-Ah arrives, volunteers herself, and wins the test. Not able to bear the shame of losing, Karbah seeks revenge. She kills the Busilak and her childhood sweetheart Id-an. With the sweat, tears, and blood of the Busilak, Karbah brings back to life Rangkatulang, the absolute evil. As Led-Ah takes the place of Tandang Veneracion, Rankatulang arrives, defeats Tandang Veneracion and Led-Ah, and makes everyone evil.

With the magic of Rangkatulang, Led-Ah is sent to another world, where a man driving a jeepney rapes her. Led-Ah conceives and is visited by Parimanis, the ultimate beauty, who is also Natividad. Parimanis tells Led-Ah that Pulao-Pulao is not alone. The world is big and colonizers have conquered even the outside of Pulao-Pulao. Back in Pulao-Pulao, Rangkatulang orders Karbah to kill her mother, Resureccion. Led-Ah arrives to stop her, and Karbah kills Rangkatulang instead. Led-Ah gives birth to Aurora Alba, Selmah, and Aran, a boy. Pulao-Pulao is now seen by the outside world. The story of the brief life of a fire comes to an end with the birth of a son in the lineage of the priestesses. The prophecy is fulfilled. The fire dies but burns forever.

In the wooded area beside the UP Faculty Center, Solito set up both the stage and the audience space, bringing the cast closer to the audience and the audience nearer the essence of the mythic story. Experimental music and indigenous-inspired chants added energy to the scenes as they were amplified through the trees. Solito allowed the audience a glimpse of Palawan’s magical characters through meticulously chosen cast with whom he shared the story of his people in Palawan.  Written by Maria Carolina Rodriguez Bello

text:
(Free). 1902. Drama simboliko in three acts, in Tagalog. Script, Tomas Remigio. First staged on 26 Aug 1902 at the Dulaang Luzon in Santa Cruz, Manila. Restaged by Dulaang Babaylan under the direction of Anton Juan Jr at Manuel Roxas High School, Quezon City, in 1979.

The play is a political allegory hidden in the love story of the heroine, Malaya (spirit of independence), and the hero, Magtanggol (the Filipino army). His rival, Manlupig (the Spanish/American government), seizes Malaya in an effort to claim her love, holding her father, Katwiran (Filipino rights), prisoner in his own home, with the help of Magtanggol’s own brother, Nagbalik (returnee; former traitor). Realizing the harm his ambition had wrought, Nagbalik returns to free Katwiran and with Magtanggol, plans to free Malaya. Meanwhile, Malaya mourns her being held captive. Nagbalik informs her of the plan, and Malaya tells Manlupig that she accepts his offer of marriage, in order to gain his trust. Sugod, however, informs Manlupig that a man was talking to Malaya. Manlupig orders the man captured, and Sugod returns with Magtanggol. During the confrontation, Magtanggol gives way to Manlupig’s claim to the hand of Malaya in marriage, but Manlupig, appearing to be just, gives way to Magtanggol, while plotting to prevent the marriage. Promised a reward, Sugod places a dead body under Malaya’s window, announces a murder, and accuses Magtanggol of it. In captivity, Malaya and Magtanggol renew their commitment. Magtanggol challenges Manlupig to a duel, as Malaya declares that she would choose death over marriage to Manlupig. Nagbalik arrives, pointing to Manlupig as traitor, and ordering Karugo and Kalahi to seize Manlupig, who tries to distract them by throwing money on the floor. Still, Manlupig is seized. Nagbalik is reunited with his mother Busilak (Mother Philippines), who asks her son to free Manlupig in an act of forgiveness. Freed, Manlupig goes to Katwiran and stabs him. The play ends with a tableau of all gathered around the dying Katwiran, as Dalisay shouts to the audience, enjoining them to take part in the struggle, or become slaves.

Written in Spain in 1898, Malaya is the earliest of the drama simboliko or “seditious” plays. The text as translated for the American court shows it to be anti-Spanish; other records report it to be anti-American. It is written in prose and verse.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis

 

Source

Riggs, Arthur Stanley. 1981. The Filipino Drama (1905). Manila: Intramuros Administration.

text:
(Fading). 2009. One-act play in Filipino. Direction, Edna Vida Froilan; script, Reuel Molina Aguila; lights design, Ingrid Velasquez; sound design, Mixkaela Z. Villalon. Cast: Bembol Roco (father), Gigi Escalante (mother), and Julia Enriquez/Kat Castillo (Lenny). First staged as part of Virgin Labfest 5 at the Cultural Center of the Philippines in Jun 2009. It was restaged and retitled Walang Maliw (Unfading) by the Departamento ng Filipino at Panitikan ng Pilipinas at the Teatro Hermogenes Ylagan of the University of the Philippines in Sep 2010. It also became part of a Tanghalang Pilipino production called Eyeball: New Visions in Philippine Theater, 2012. The play is included in Mga Piling Dula Mula sa Virgin Labfest 2009-2012: Ikalawang Antolohiya (Selected Plays from the Virgin Labfest 2009-2012: Second Anthology), 2013.

The play happens in the wake of the 30th birthday celebration of an elderly couple’s daughter, Lenny, who has been missing for the past five years. The couple, who only refer to each other as “mommy” and “daddy” throughout the play, reminisce about happier times, their courtship and political activism in the 1970s, and ultimately the uncertain fate of their daughter who followed in their footsteps. The father is reticent, resigned to the possibility that Lenny is dead and counted among the many young activists who have been abducted by the military. In contrast, the mother clings to hope that Lenny will return some day. This leads into an argument, with the husband accusing his wife of neglecting herself and the family, resigning from her teaching position to waste away by joining political rallies for the disappeared. In turn, the wife accuses her husband of giving up on their daughter and pretending that everything is okay. Both reflect on the loss of their child, at one point blaming themselves for raising politically engaged children, and then declaring themselves proud of Lenny’s choice and sacrifice. Before long, the couple makes amends and the father retires for the night.

 

As the mother cleans up the remains of the celebration, she is surprised by Lenny’s unexpected return home. Mother and daughter catch up with each other, with the mother desperately asking Lenny where she has been for the past years. Lenny replies she has to leave at once before authorities catch her, and asks her mother if she would come with her. The mother hesitates, but takes the opportunity to tell her daughter everything she needs to say. When Lenny leaves, the father awakens and asks his wife to come to bed. At this point, the mother finally makes her peace and comes to accept her daughter’s absence.

Maliw draws its gravitas and parallelisms from the abduction of political activist Jonas Burgos in 2007. Jonas’s mother Edith Burgos has since been embroiled in highly publicized protest actions and human rights investigative hearings. While instances of political disappearances were more highly publicized during martial law, the disappearance of Jonas proves that the heinous practice continues to the present. In its premier, the production acknowledged Edith Burgos in the audience and dedicated the performance to all disappeared political activists. Besides its clear political positioning, Maliw also hits a universal nerve in tackling a parent’s struggle for closure after the loss of a child.  Written by Mixkaela Z. Villalon

text:
(The Patcher). 1900. One-act sarsuwela in Kapampangan. Libretto, Mariano Proceso Pabalan Byron; music, Amado Gutierrez David. First staged on 13 Sep 1900 at the Teatro Sabina in Bacolor, Pampanga.

This sarsuwela is built around a domestic quarrel. Doña Juana threatens to leave her husband, Don Diego, whom she suspects of playing around with other women. The situation is aggravated when she discovers a woman’s handkerchief on the living-room sofa. The maid, Sianang, however, claims that the handkerchief is hers. She makes the observation that the size of an object varies from small to large, depending on which side of the lens it is examined.

Doña Juana is appeased by the sound counsel and changes her mind about leaving. Meanwhile, Don Diego returns home. Sianang, not wishing to be discovered alone in the room with the houseboy, Pablo, tells him to hide under the sofa. To allay her master’s suspicions, Sianang claims that the dog, Managpe, is responsible for the noises Don Diego hears coming from underneath the sofa. However, Pablo’s mistimed sneeze reveals his hiding place. Doña Juana arrives to find her husband confronting the lovers. Don Diego upbraids Doña Juana for her jealousy, which he claims has caused her to neglect her duties as mistress of the house. Doña Juana apologizes for her past behavior and they happily reconcile. The title refers both to the dog and to Sianang, who patches up the quarrel.

Ing Managpe is considered the first Kapampangan sarsuwela since it has the earliest documented performance date.  Written by Edna Z. Manlapaz

 

Source

Manlapaz, Edna Zapanta. 1981. Kapampangan Literature, A Historical Survey and Anthology. Quezon City: Ateneo University Press.

Javillonar, Ely. 1961. “The Significance of Mariano Proceso Pabalan in Capampangan Dramatic Literature.” MA thesis, College of Arts and Sciences, University of the Philippines Diliman.

text:
(Apathy). 1991. Musical in three acts. Direction and choreography, Paul Alexander Morales; script, Arturo Calo aka Auraeus Solito; lyrics, Carina Evangelista, Eraserheads, Vincent de Jesus, and Auraeus Solito; musical direction, Vincent de Jesus; set design, Paul Albert Quiaño; lights design, Bat Fajardo. Cast: RG de la Lama/Omar Mendoza (Bantugan Buenaventura), Christine Bersola/Cara Javier (Lam-ang Panganiban), Connie Lauigan-Chua (Mamalahim-ma), Jojo Urquico (Radia), Peter Pantilla (Apolaki Regalado), Auraeus Solito/Aimee Santos (Gawigawen), Wena Basco/Liza Quintos (Urduja), Peaches Gallegos (Lagrimas), Michelle Reyes, Jay Cruz, Paul Alexander Morales, Johanna Cabili, Tips Akalal, Wichelle Escobar, Cordelia Conquilla, Naomi Villa, Paul Albert Quijaño, Sharon Villaluz, Patria Diaz, Nacel Garduce, Chingbee Templo, Nimfa Mirasol, Buddy Caramat, Jun Accullador, Richard Yaneza, Pieta Agatha Verdadero, Ralph Semino Galan, Mark Delfin, Romeo Lee, and Vinia Pamplona. First staged by the UP Tropa Experimental Theater Company at the lobby of the Palma Hall Building, University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman, in 1991. Manhid was then moved to the Folk Arts Theater in Manila. The play was later presented at the Philippine Science High School as a small student production in 1996, under the direction of Tips Akalal. It was also restaged as a musical and dance production by the Ballet Philippines, co-presented by the Tanghalang Pilipino, at the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo of the Cultural Center of the Philippines, under the direction and choreography of Morales, as well as choreography by Alden Lugnasin, in Feb 2015 as part of the Ballet Philippines’s 45th season, the Manila Fringe Festival, and in celebration of the 29th anniversary of the EDSA Revolt.

 

The play is set in a fictional Philippines after the failure of the 1986 EDSA Revolt. The government has formed the Solution of Eternal Peace, through which the military eliminated all rebels and activists. As a final form of protest, the activists named their 39 children born on that day after the gods and heroes of the epics. Now in their early 20s, these children are scattered and unaware of their origins and source of their supernatural powers. Journalist Bantugan Buenaventura, one of these children, discerns that when he awakens to his power of dreaming, he forms a connection with the other children of protest, specifically Lam-ang Panganiban, the leader of the underground group Maragtas. Through the Maragtas’s babaylan (priestess), Gawigawen, Lam-ang learns he is not alone and discovers the higher purpose of his powers: to find a cure for the epidemic of kamanhiran (apathy) that is spreading throughout the country. Kamanhiran turns its victims’ skins white and renders them emotionless and soulless. Through Bantugan, the Maragtas tries to locate and recruit the other children to their cause but they are pursued and thwarted by the tulisan ng bayan (town bandits), the other children of protest who are loyal to the government, specifically to Mamalahim-ma, the minister of humanity. The tulisan’s leader Apolaki Regalado believes that their powers were given to them so they can rule the world and enslave humanity. Ambushed by the tulisan in their hideout, the Maragtas are defeated and have no choice but to flee when Lam-ang is killed and Bantugan is captured. The tulisan torture Bantugan to force him to reveal the whereabouts of the other scattered children. The capture and purging of the other children of protest continue. Upon discovering the location of Urduja, the last child of protest, the tulisan send Radia to seduce and capture her. Radia is a shape-shifter who can compel anyone to fall in love with him, and yet upon meeting Urduja, it is he who falls in love with her. After professing their love for each other, they infiltrate the Ministry of Humanity. Assuming Urduja’s form, Radia allows himself to be captured in her place while Urduja rescues Bantugan and the other captured Maragtas. They search the seas for the body of Lam-ang and she is resurrected by the combined powers of Gawigawen, Lagrimas, and Urduja. Now stronger, the Maragtas regroup and begin their revolution, curing the apathetic while fighting the tulisan. Their presence inspires ordinary people to feel awe and astonishment, to question, and to fight back. To stop this crusade, Mamalahim-ma holds Lagrimas hostage and proposes a final battle between the Maragtas and the tulisan. If the former win, true freedom is granted with the end of apathy and a chance for free elections. If the latter win, the Maragtas must end their crusade and let themselves be enslaved by the tulisan. The final fight does not end well, with many children killed on both sides including Mamalahim-ma. Before he is killed, Bantugan dreams of the solution, which centers on Lagrimas. The remaining Maragtas understand what they must do and through Lagrimas’s final sacrifice, her tears and ashes, which return to the land through the rain, cleanses and heals, restoring the peace and setting the people free.

Manhid was inspired by American superhero comic books and Salman Rushdie’s Midnight’s Children. The play attempted to find a form for a comic book narrative in drama, music, and dance which expressed the creative team’s anxiety over the continuing presence of the American bases and the colonial mind-set of Filipinos. The production gathered the talents of the then student rock band The Eraserheads, soprano Cabili, and punk artist Lee. Direction and choreography, Paul Alexander Morales; script, Arturo Calo aka Auraeus Solito; lyrics, Carina Evangelista, Eraserheads, Vincent de Jesus, and Auraeus Solito; musical direction, Vincent de Jesus; set design, Paul Albert Quiaño; lights design, Bat Fajardo. article.value: The play is set in a fictional Philippines after the failure of the 1986 EDSA Revolt. The government has formed the Solution of Eternal Peace, through which the military eliminated all rebels and activists. As a final form of protest, the activists named their 39 children born on that day after the gods and heroes of the epics. Now in their early 20s, these children are scattered and unaware of their origins and source of their supernatural powers. Journalist Bantugan Buenaventura, one of these children, discerns that when he awakens to his power of dreaming, he forms a connection with the other children of protest, specifically Lam-ang Panganiban, the leader of the underground group Maragtas. Through the Maragtas’s babaylan (priestess), Gawigawen, Lam-ang learns he is not alone and discovers the higher purpose of his powers: to find a cure for the epidemic of kamanhiran (apathy) that is spreading throughout the country. Kamanhiran turns its victims’ skins white and renders them emotionless and soulless. Through Bantugan, the Maragtas tries to locate and recruit the other children to their cause but they are pursued and thwarted by the tulisan ng bayan (town bandits), the other children of protest who are loyal to the government, specifically to Mamalahim-ma, the minister of humanity. The tulisan’s leader Apolaki Regalado believes that their powers were given to them so they can rule the world and enslave humanity. Ambushed by the tulisan in their hideout, the Maragtas are defeated and have no choice but to flee when Lam-ang is killed and Bantugan is captured. The tulisan torture Bantugan to force him to reveal the whereabouts of the other scattered children. The capture and purging of the other children of protest continue. Upon discovering the location of Urduja, the last child of protest, the tulisan send Radia to seduce and capture her. Radia is a shape-shifter who can compel anyone to fall in love with him, and yet upon meeting Urduja, it is he who falls in love with her. After professing their love for each other, they infiltrate the Ministry of Humanity. Assuming Urduja’s form, Radia allows himself to be captured in her place while Urduja rescues Bantugan and the other captured Maragtas. They search the seas for the body of Lam-ang and she is resurrected by the combined powers of Gawigawen, Lagrimas, and Urduja. Now stronger, the Maragtas regroup and begin their revolution, curing the apathetic while fighting the tulisan. Their presence inspires ordinary people to feel awe and astonishment, to question, and to fight back. To stop this crusade, Mamalahim-ma holds Lagrimas hostage and proposes a final battle between the Maragtas and the tulisan. If the former win, true freedom is granted with the end of apathy and a chance for free elections. If the latter win, the Maragtas must end their crusade and let themselves be enslaved by the tulisan. The final fight does not end well, with many children killed on both sides including Mamalahim-ma. Before he is killed, Bantugan dreams of the solution, which centers on Lagrimas. The remaining Maragtas understand what they must do and through Lagrimas’s final sacrifice, her tears and ashes, which return to the land through the rain, cleanses and heals, restoring the peace and setting the people free.

text:
(Bitter Coco). 1980. One-act play in Filipino. Direction, Brenda Fajardo; script, Reuel Molina Aguila; production design, Khryss Adalia; lights, Alex de Guzman; music, Gigi Carunugan, Lucien Letaba, and Upeng Galang. Cast: Maryo J. de los Reyes (Panyo), Mario Layco (Tonyo), Ernie Cloma (Mang Inggo), Gamay Arkoncel (Odet), Don Catedral, Mary Joan Fajardo, Beth Mondragon, Khryss Adalia, Tess Pau, Edgar Zabala, and Archie Adamos. First staged by the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) on 28 Feb 1980 at the Dulaang Rajah Sulayman in Fort Santiago, Intramuros, Manila. The script is included in Aguila’s collection of plays titled Ligalig at Iba Pang Dula (Disquiet and Other Plays), 1989.

 

Mapait sa Bao starts with Mang Inggo narrating the legend of the coconut. As Mang Inggo’s children Panyo, Tonyo, and Odet mourn for him, they narrate the events in their lives before their father’s death. The eldest son Panyo is borrowing money from the already-ailing Mang Inggo to help process his papers for a job in Saudi Arabia. Unable to give him money, Panyo considers pawning the only piece of land they have on the coconut farm, believing that he will be able to buy it back once he gets a job in Saudi Arabia. Mang Inggo disapproves of the plan, and his siblings also disagree. Tonyo, an economics student, nags and gives Panyo reasons why pawning the land is not advisable. But Panyo refuses to listen and tells his younger brother to focus on his studies. Panyo pawns the land to the wealthy Mr Reyes, in exchange for the money he needs to go to Saudi Arabia. This breaks Mang Inggo’s heart, and both Odet and Tonyo cannot do anything to stop Panyo. A month after, Panyo is still unable to leave for Saudi Arabia. Mr Reyes comes to collect his payment and decides to confiscate the land. Out of his goodwill and upon the recommendation of his caretaker Paeng, who happens to be Odet’s suitor, Mr Reyes allows Panyo to work in his warehouse and to put up a hut behind the warehouse. The flashback ends, and the three siblings stand in front of their father’s grave again. Panyo is now a worker for Mr Reyes’s warehouse and still believes he will make it to Saudi Arabia one day. Odet is now married to Paeng and is the one her brothers run to when they need to borrow money. Tonyo works as a conductor while trying to finish his studies, believing he will be able to help the family in the future.

Based on the story Sabaw ng Mantika (Soup of Oil) by Len Santos, Mapait sa Bao focuses on the plight of coconut farm workers. It uses slide projections and a chorus playing native instruments; it has characters directly addressing the audience and sitting to one side when not performing. These alienation devices make sure that the audience is not focused solely on the narrative and the characters, which many Filipinos can relate to, but are able to analyze the misfortune of the family.  Written by Ma. Clara Rosario C. Palma

text:
(Make Haste, Lord). 1974. Dance-drama in three acts. Direction, script, and production design, Rodulfo Galenzoga. First staged by the Kolambugan Dance Theater ensemble on 21 Aug 1974 at Kolambugan, Lanao del Norte. Subsequently staged at the University of the Philippines Diliman and Ateneo de Manila University, Quezon City, in Feb 1975.

Maranatha tells of a kingdom under attack by a mysterious black bird that kills its people. One day, a stranger is washed ashore at the time the princess is held captive by the bird. He subdues the bird and kills it. Everyone rejoices except the king who fears and envies the stranger, who has come to be regarded as the people’s redeemer. The king banishes the stranger, who predicts that tribulations shall come upon the kingdom. He throws his sandal into the lake and says that until the sandal is recovered, no peace shall come to the kingdom. In an effort to assuage his people’s fears, the king orders the best divers to retrieve the sandal. Meanwhile, in her sleep, the princess dreams of an underwater kingdom with divers swimming into the kingdom of the octopus (portrayed as the king) in search of the sandal. The divers struggle with the octopus-king and subdue him, but the octopus manages to throw the sandal away (into the audience). The next dream sequence depicts the tribulations in Lanao, with both Muslims and Christians becoming victims of politico-economic oppression and militarization, of politicians and their peace conferences. The scene heightens as evacuation continues. The princess awakens suddenly and realizes what her dream means: that the sandal is not to be found in the lake but in the very hearts of all who seek peace and happiness. Its recovery depends on all Muslims and Christians. Toward the end of the play, the entire cast comes in, held in chains by the oppressors, while singing the song “Umanhi Ka, Ayaw Paglangan Ginoo” (Come, Do Not Delay Lord).

The play uses dance as idiom, including the singkil (dance of the Marano) in the fight between the stranger and the black bird. It features the malong (tubular skirt of the Maranao) and other indigenous costumes, with Lake Lanao as backdrop. Despite the dangers during the Marcos regime, the Kolambugan Dance Theater group staged 135 performances of this play in various parts of the country between 1974 and 1975. In the early years of martial law, it was a brave statement in metaphorical, folkloric form, exhorting the people to save themselves from oppression by acting and working together.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

 

Source

Temple, Flor S. 1980. “The Study of the Kolambugan Dance Theater.” MA thesis, Ateneo de Manila University.

text:
(Maria Entertainer). 1983. One-act play in Filipino. Direction, Soxie Topacio; script, Soxie Topacio, Gigi Carunungan, Ellen Ongkeko, Boy Aquino Jr, Reggie Balingit, Jun Gozarate, Gigette Reyes, Carme Sanchez, Ruby Ruiz, Mimi Villareal, Avic Ilagan, Arlene Abuid, Glecy C. Atienza, and Rody Vera; production management, Bey Vito and Ed Zabala; music, Louie Pascasio, Noel Kintanar, Manny D. Pambid, Khryss Adalia, and Jojo Atienza; lights, Paolo Lopez, Rolly Navarro, and Jham Panda; slides, Marilou Jacob, Jojo Sanchez, and William Tan. Cast: Gigi Carunungan (Tess), Ellen Ongkeko (GP), Boy Aquino Jr (Lito), Reggie Balingit (Rommel), Jun Gozarate (Eric), Gigette Reyes (Yoly), Carme Sanchez (Luz), Ruby Ruiz (Cindy), Mimi Villareal (Karen), Avic Ilagan (Peachy), Arlene Abuid (Amy), Marichu Belarmino (voiceover for Amy), Glecy Atienza (Imay), and Joven Velasco (interviewer). First staged by the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) Kalinangan Ensemble on 21 Apr 1983 at the Dulaang Rajah Sulayman in Fort Santiago, Intramuros, Manila. It was twin-billed with Si Huwan Pabrika (Juan Factory). It was restaged on 10 Aug 1984 at The Plaza Restaurant in Greenbelt.

 

The play is set in two different places of Ermita, which is known as one of the red-light districts of Manila. The interviewer calls the attention of Tess and asks permission to interview her about her job as a hostess, for a slide show project. Just as Tess finishes explaining how she answers to whatever name her customers call her, taxi dancer GP, callboys Lito and Eric, and macho dancer Rommel join her and they all answer the interviewer’s questions. Soon after, they are joined by burlesque dancer Yoly, hostess Luz, and three teenage girls—hooker Cindy, pickup girl Karen, part-time pickup girl and part-time pimp Peachy. A mute hostess Amy drags over to them a bruised Imay, a teenage masseuse. The interviewer then begins probing into their lives and how they managed to get into the industry. Some were abused and sold off by their families; some were in financial need; others suffered from boredom. The cast members admit that to get by, they also engage in prostitution aside from their jobs. The interviewer then asks how they feel about their work. Peachy, Eric, and Luz admit that they do not like the work, but Cindy and Rommel would rather be doing that and earn more money than work on “legal” jobs. When asked how these entertainers would feel about prostitution being eradicated, they give conflicting answers but all agree that it will be difficult to remove people like them. When they turn to the interviewer to ask for his opinion, they find that he is gone after getting what he needs from them.

Mariang Aliw uses an interview as a framework. A researcher gathers materials for a slide show, which is flashed onstage. The script was written by the director and the cast based on their research. The use of a documentary-drama style allowed for experimentation that focuses on workers in the red-light districts.  Written by Ma. Clara Rosario C. Palma

text:
2013. Musical in three acts, in Filipino. Direction and choreography, Dexter Santos; script and lyrics, Nicolas Pichay; music, William Evin Manzano, JJ Pimpinio, Janine Santos, with additional lyrics by Arkel Mendoza; production designer, Gino Gonzales; lights designer, John Neil Ilao Batalla; technical director, Ohm David; assistant director, Emman Feliciano; associate choreographer, Stephen Viñas. Cast: Jayvhot Galang (Maximo Oliveros), Roeder Camañag/Nazer Salcedo (Paco Oliveros), Jojo Riguerra (Victor Perez), Al Gatmaitan/OJ Mariano (Boy Oliveros), Jay Gonzaga (Bogs Oliveros), Aaron Ching (Nar), Nomer Limatog, Jr (Leslie), Teetin Villanueva (Monique), Eo de Guzman/Merdin Mojica (Peter), and Greg de Leon (Chief Dominguez). The ensemble is composed of Ruth Alferez, John Paul Basco, Jules de la Paz, Irene Delarmente, Elliot Eustacio, Karyl Factora, Jim Andrew Ferrer, Francelle Fetalvero, Al Bernard Garcia, Jeffrey Hernandez, Ronah Rostata, and Christian Velarde. The band is composed of William Elvin Manzano and Rigil Borromeo (guitar), Van Quiaong (keyboard), Jonah Ruiz (drums), and Allen Mamaid (bass). Produced by Bit by Bit Company of Darwin Mariano and Carlo Miguel Francia in cooperation with the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) Theater Center and the Cultural Center of the Philippines.

In act 1, Maxie, a 13-year-old gay boy, serves breakfast to his widower father Paco, and two older brothers Boy and Bogs, all of whom are petty thieves. After breakfast, Maxie performs errands for his father, collecting and delivering jueteng bets and winnings to their neighbors. He also goes out to watch pirated DVDs with his group of young gays, losing himself in the fantasy world of films. But today is special, not only because it is the fiesta of their barangay (complete with the usual procession and dancing) but because he is joining the gay beauty pageant. The contest ends at midnight and Maxie rushes home, but is harassed by two drunken men. He screams for help and the newly arrived policeman Victor comes to his aid. Victor brings him home safe but he refuses the reward money offered by Paco. Maxie falls for the handsome and kind Victor. After the policeman leaves, Boy arrives in a bloodied shirt. He has just robbed and killed a student. Maxie hides the bloodied shirt.

 

In act 2, Maxie and a friend deliver a policeman’s jueteng winnings at the police precinct. There they witness Victor bringing in a snatcher whom he apprehended. Maxie admires Victor’s bravery. Meanwhile, the two men who harassed Maxie are found unconscious and naked on a garbage heap, the handiwork of Boy and Bogs to avenge Maxie. Soon, Maxie and Victor are able to talk, and the latter advises the young boy to go back to school. That night, the chief of police and Victor visit Paco’s house to find out if they know anything about the murder of the student. After the police leave, Maxie burns Boy’s bloodied shirt, but Victor sees him do it from afar. Later, Victor asks Maxie about the shirt, and succeeds in confirming that the shirt belonged to one of his brothers. Guilty, Maxie tells his family about his revelation. Paco then discovers Boy’s crime and beats him up for it, saying, “I raised you to be thieves, not murderers.” To protect Boy, Paco gets a group together and they beat up Victor to discourage him from pursuing the case. Secretly, Maxie goes to Victor’s house to attend to his wounds and ask forgiveness for having indirectly caused his mauling. Victor forgives Maxie, who then gives him a kiss on the lips. Maxie spends the night beside Victor.

In act 3, Paco strictly forbids Maxie from seeing Victor ever again. Arguing that Victor is only doing his job, Maxie defies his father and writes Victor a love letter. He replies by asking Maxie to find someone his own age. Bogs comforts Maxie. Meanwhile, a new police chief Dominguez, together with Victor, has stepped up the drug bust operations. Victor and a few policemen raid Paco’s house. Maxie is shocked at the change in Victor. Bogs too is mistakenly arrested and jailed for the murder of the student. Paco with his gun in tow confronts his old enemy, Dominguez, but ends up being shot dead instead by Victor and in full sight of Maxie. The community mourns Paco’s death. Released from prison, Bogs connives with Boy to avenge Paco’s death but Maxie pleads with them not to leave him an orphan. The brothers decide to give up revenge and instead protect Maxie. The next day, they prepare Maxie for school. On his way to school, Maxie passes by Victor who is obviously waiting for him. Maxie walks past Victor, without even looking at him.

The musical is based on Michiko Yamamoto’s screenplay Ang Pagdadalaga ni Maximo Oliveros (The Blossoming of Maximo Oliveros), which was directed by Auraeus Solito for UFO Pictures. After its premiere in Cinemalaya in 2005, the film became a commercial and critical success. The musical has about 28 songs, including those for a riot connected with a demolition scene and for policemen and prisoners singing while taking a shower in the buff in two separate shower rooms.  Written by Jerry C. Respeto

article.value: 2013. Musical in three acts, in Filipino. Direction and choreography, Dexter Santos; script and lyrics, Nicolas Pichay; music, William Evin Manzano, JJ Pimpinio, Janine Santos, with additional lyrics by Arkel Mendoza; production designer, Gino Gonzales; lights designer, John Neil Ilao Batalla; technical director, Ohm David; assistant director, Emman Feliciano; associate choreographer, Stephen Viñas. Cast: Jayvhot Galang (Maximo Oliveros), Roeder Camañag/Nazer Salcedo (Paco Oliveros), Jojo Riguerra (Victor Perez), Al Gatmaitan/OJ Mariano (Boy Oliveros), Jay Gonzaga (Bogs Oliveros), Aaron Ching (Nar), Nomer Limatog, Jr (Leslie), Teetin Villanueva (Monique), Eo de Guzman/Merdin Mojica (Peter), and Greg de Leon (Chief Dominguez). The ensemble is composed of Ruth Alferez, John Paul Basco, Jules de la Paz, Irene Delarmente, Elliot Eustacio, Karyl Factora, Jim Andrew Ferrer, Francelle Fetalvero, Al Bernard Garcia, Jeffrey Hernandez, Ronah Rostata, and Christian Velarde. The band is composed of William Elvin Manzano and Rigil Borromeo (guitar), Van Quiaong (keyboard), Jonah Ruiz (drums), and Allen Mamaid (bass). Produced by Bit by Bit Company of Darwin Mariano and Carlo Miguel Francia in cooperation with the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) Theater Center and the Cultural Center of the Philippines.

In act 1, Maxie, a 13-year-old gay boy, serves breakfast to his widower father Paco, and two older brothers Boy and Bogs, all of whom are petty thieves. After breakfast, Maxie performs errands for his father, collecting and delivering jueteng bets and winnings to their neighbors. He also goes out to watch pirated DVDs with his group of young gays, losing himself in the fantasy world of films. But today is special, not only because it is the fiesta of their barangay (complete with the usual procession and dancing) but because he is joining the gay beauty pageant. The contest ends at midnight and Maxie rushes home, but is harassed by two drunken men. He screams for help and the newly arrived policeman Victor comes to his aid. Victor brings him home safe but he refuses the reward money offered by Paco. Maxie falls for the handsome and kind Victor. After the policeman leaves, Boy arrives in a bloodied shirt. He has just robbed and killed a student. Maxie hides the bloodied shirt.

value.desc: Bit by Bit Company’s Maxie: The Musicale, PETA Theater Center, Quezon City, 2013 (Photo courtesy of John Batalla)

article.value: In act 2, Maxie and a friend deliver a policeman’s jueteng winnings at the police precinct. There they witness Victor bringing in a snatcher whom he apprehended. Maxie admires Victor’s bravery. Meanwhile, the two men who harassed Maxie are found unconscious and naked on a garbage heap, the handiwork of Boy and Bogs to avenge Maxie. Soon, Maxie and Victor are able to talk, and the latter advises the young boy to go back to school. That night, the chief of police and Victor visit Paco’s house to find out if they know anything about the murder of the student. After the police leave, Maxie burns Boy’s bloodied shirt, but Victor sees him do it from afar. Later, Victor asks Maxie about the shirt, and succeeds in confirming that the shirt belonged to one of his brothers. Guilty, Maxie tells his family about his revelation. Paco then discovers Boy’s crime and beats him up for it, saying, “I raised you to be thieves, not murderers.” To protect Boy, Paco gets a group together and they beat up Victor to discourage him from pursuing the case. Secretly, Maxie goes to Victor’s house to attend to his wounds and ask forgiveness for having indirectly caused his mauling. Victor forgives Maxie, who then gives him a kiss on the lips. Maxie spends the night beside Victor.

In act 3, Paco strictly forbids Maxie from seeing Victor ever again. Arguing that Victor is only doing his job, Maxie defies his father and writes Victor a love letter. He replies by asking Maxie to find someone his own age. Bogs comforts Maxie. Meanwhile, a new police chief Dominguez, together with Victor, has stepped up the drug bust operations. Victor and a few policemen raid Paco’s house. Maxie is shocked at the change in Victor. Bogs too is mistakenly arrested and jailed for the murder of the student. Paco with his gun in tow confronts his old enemy, Dominguez, but ends up being shot dead instead by Victor and in full sight of Maxie. The community mourns Paco’s death. Released from prison, Bogs connives with Boy to avenge Paco’s death but Maxie pleads with them not to leave him an orphan. The brothers decide to give up revenge and instead protect Maxie. The next day, they prepare Maxie for school. On his way to school, Maxie passes by Victor who is obviously waiting for him. Maxie walks past Victor, without even looking at him.

The musical is based on Michiko Yamamoto’s screenplay Ang Pagdadalaga ni Maximo Oliveros (The Blossoming of Maximo Oliveros), which was directed by Auraeus Solito for UFO Pictures. After its premiere in Cinemalaya in 2005, the film became a commercial and critical success. The musical has about 28 songs, including those for a riot connected with a demolition scene and for policemen and prisoners singing while taking a shower in the buff in two separate shower rooms.  Written by Jerry C. Respeto

text:
(There Are Whispers). 2007. One-act play in Filipino. Direction and lighting, Christian Bautista; script, Job Pagsibigan; sounds, Grace Lloreta; stage management, Ram Tolentino and Grace Lloreta. Cast: Paul Santiago (Gerald), Edwin Barrios Serrano (Alex), Raymond Talavera (young Gerald), Noel Escondo (young Alex), and Sigrid Andrea P. Bernardo (Ruzelle). First performed on 6 and 8 Jul 2007 at the Bulwagang Amado V. Hernandez of the Cultural Center of the Philippines as part of the Virgin Labfest 3.

In the living room of a well-off but decaying house in Malolos, Bulacan, young Gerald hears moans and tries to find where the sound is coming from. Suspicious, he opens the closet. His older brother Alex bursts out scaring Gerald. Alex then invites Gerald to take a bath with him. Alex is set to leave to continue school in the University of the Philipppines Diliman the next day. Alex leaves the room and Gerald hears the moaning sound again.

Ten years pass. It is the ninth day after the death of Gerald and Alex’s mother. Alex asks if their mother continued her panata or oath to go to church every day in the last 10 years just for him to come back. She kept her oath for three years but stopped when she heard news that Alex, who became a member of the New People’s Army (NPA), had allegedly died in a military encounter. Alex decides to bring their mother’s ashes to their house in Pasig and tells Gerald he is putting the old house on sale. It is revealed that Gerald is an adopted child. Gerald does not recognize his brother in Alex anymore. Alex tells him that he is marrying an American and will be migrating to the United States. Gerald reveals that the house is in his name now. After hearing news of Alex’s death, their mother had a heart attack and later changed her last will and testament, leaving her properties to Gerald in the event of her death. Gerald narrates how their mother endured the gossips surrounding Alex’s real father. Gerald then challenges Alex to name Alex’s real father. Alex answers: it is the parish priest Father Emil. Gerald pleads with Alex not to sell the house and says he is willing to serve Alex. Alex is unmoved. Gerald then tells him where to find the land title and Alex leaves.

 

Alone, Gerald recalls his encounter with Ruzelle, the slutty girl from high school whom he tried to have sex with but was not able to because of his premature ejaculation. Ruzelle shamed him in school then. Gerald, at that time, felt helpless. One night, under the sheets, Gerald saw his brother masturbating. Alex caught him watching what he was doing. From there, they began their secret sexual relationship.

Alex returns furious on not finding the land title. Gerald asks why Alex left 10 years ago. Alex tells him to just hand the land title first and he would be very much willing to help Gerald in whatever way. Gerald gets the gun under the altar drawer and aims at Alex. Gerald tells him that the gun was left there by his “real brother” with a caution that if ever in the future, someone returns and claims to be his brother, that person should be killed. Alex speaks of the trauma he endured while living as an NPA. This leads to Gerald revealing that on Alex’s last night in the house 10 years ago, their mother saw them having oral sex inside the bathroom. Softened by the revelation, Alex attempts to embrace Gerald while promising never to leave if it is what Gerald wants. Gerald fires the gun and Alex drops, moaning in pain. Gerald drags him inside the closet.

Back to the scene 10 years ago, young Gerald hears the moaning sound again from the closet. Young Alex enters and urges Gerald to go now to the bathroom with him.

The play is a haunting presentation of what incest and trauma do to brothers.  Written by Erick Dasig Aguilar

text:
(There Was a Soldier). 1981. One-act play in Filipino. Direction, Anton Juan Jr; script, Rene O. Villanueva. Cast: Susan Valdez (prostitute) and Fanny Quiocho (soldier). First staged in 1981 by Dulaang Malaya, a factory-based workers’ theater, at the Faculty Center Theater, later Teatro Hermogenes Ylagan, University of the Philippines Diliman. The script is included in Villanueva’s collection of plays titled May Isang Sundalo: Limang Maikling Dula (There Was a Soldier: Five Short Plays), 1988. The script is also anthologized in Ang Sining ng Pagkatha ng Tula at Dula (The Craft of Writing Poetry and Drama) and Kamao: Mga Dula ng Protesta 1970-1986 (Fist: Protest Plays 1970-1986), both published in 1987, and Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature 1980-1989: Antolohiya ng mga Nagwaging Akda (Anthology of Winning Works), 1990.

In Samar in 1981, a prostitute recollects a moment she had with a soldier a year before, amid an electricity blackout and ongoing military operations, not far from where she now stays. She lights a candle and relives the moment when the soldier intrudes upon her rented room, asking if he could spend the night there. She is appalled and says she does not practice her work there. The soldier says he only wants to talk. He had seen her a few nights ago at the bar where she works and thought she was friendly. Despite her doubts, the prostitute allows him to stay. She pretends to seduce him, but he rejects her advances. She then articulates how the people from the countryside loathe and scorn the military. She insults him by describing the torture mechanisms the military use on the rebels, or alleged rebels, adding that the rebels had every reason to fight. She narrates the difficult life her people are experiencing in the countryside because of militarization. He asks if she has any plans of returning to her hometown. She says she no longer has a place to return to. The soldier decides to leave, and leaves money on the table. Insulted, the woman insults him back and asks why he even bothered to come. He admits that she reminds him of his sister. He tells her of the comrades he has lost to the rebels and how he is very much tempted to go AWOL, but his obligation to his family is stopping him. He notes that his sister has joined the rebellion and fears that one day, they might have to face each other in the battlefield. This time, the prostitute asks him if he ever plans to return home. The soldier says he no longer has a place to return to, and leaves. Alone once more, the prostitute laments the soldier’s fate. Before blowing the candle out, she muses that maybe those who have decided to join the rebellion are in a much better disposition than they are.

 

The play presents the struggles faced by the different Filipinos through the clashing beliefs of the prostitute and the soldier during martial law. The play won first prize in the one-act play in Filipino category of the Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature in 1981.  Written by Athena Angela Aquino

 

Source

Villanueva, Rene O. 1988. May Isang Sundalo: Limang Maikling Dula. Quezon City: New Day.

text:
(Reason Has Its Reason). 1981. Play in 18 scenes with prologue and epilogue, in Filipino. Direction and script, Rolando S. Tinio; music, Lucrecia R. Kasilag and Rolando S. Tinio; lighting design, Teddy L. Hilado. Cast: Rolando S. Tinio, Joey Ocampo, Mervyn Samson, Tommy Alcantara, Ed Alcantara, and Mars Cavestany. First staged by Teatro Pilipino on 9 Oct 1981 at the Little Theater, later Tanghalang Aurelio V. Tolentino, of the Cultural Center of the Philippines in Manila.

 

The play has two main characters: the Senyor, who represents the landed class or the pampered rich; and the Kasama, who represents the lower-class majority. The Senyor must cross forest, rivers, and mountains to get to the spot from where he will be rescued by a helicopter sent by his father. He makes the peasant build him a raft with which to cross a river, but when the raft threatens to break apart, he pushes the Kasama into the water to lighten the load, promising to offer prayers for his safety. The Kasama makes it across. When the two sit down to eat the bread and cheese they have with them, the Kasama suggests equal division, but the Senyor invokes his concept of social justice: whoever needs more should get the bigger share; thus, since he is used to fat rations, he should have a larger share, especially since he owns the food. The Kasama suggests that he not be given any, but the Senyor asserts that in Christian charity he should give the Kasama half a piece of bread. Soon, some tulisanes or bandits approach, and the Senyor, afraid for life and money, exchanges clothes with the Kasama, whom the bandits take away and kill upon finding out that he has no money. The Senyor then reveals his identity and, to prove it, shows them all the money he has. As they are about to gang up on him, the helicopter arrives, like an angel from heaven. From the helicopter, machine-gun shots kill the tulisanes, leaving the Senyor with his arms outstretched to be taken up into the machine, and into heaven.

May Katwiran is an analysis of class in society. It is probably one of the best Filipino plays written in the Brechtian tradition. The play has been toured by Teatro Pilipino to different provinces and staged in schools as instructional theater.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

text:
1979. Play in four parts, in Filipino. Direction, Lutgardo Labad; script, Emmanuel Lacaba, Al Santos, and Malou Jacob; original music, Joey Ayala; music and sounds, Edna May Landicho and the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) music pool; production design, Weni Gamboa, Al Manrique, Brenda Fajardo, Ping Ortega, and the PETA costume pool; lighting, Jonathan Romulo and the PETA lights pool. Cast: Jonathan Romulo, Greg Sta. Ines, Joel Lamangan, Joe Gruta, Domingo Landicho, Grace Amilbangsa, Benjie Ledesma, Spanky Manikan, Weni Gamboa, Toffy Padua, Ramram Xerez-Burgos, Mario Batac, Efren Kibtiani, Louie Pascasio, Louella Albornoz, and the PETA Kalinangan Ensemble. First staged on 24 May 1979 at the Dulaang Rajah Sulayman in Fort Santiago, Manila.

The play was based on Lacaba’s original concept which was rewritten and finished, after his death, by Santos and Jacob.

Part 1 tells of how Raha Sulayman marries Ligaya who is from Panday Pira’s community. He remains jealous of Magat Salamat, Ligaya’s former lover, whose gift of a wooden portrait she treasures. Sulayman has Salamat arrested and imprisoned.

In part 2, Panday Pira questions Salamat’s arrest by Soliman and ends up debating the merits and demerits of their social systems. Sulayman defends his family’s land monopoly and the institution of slavery. Pira maintains his belief that a new seed shall bring the sangkatauhan (humanity) back to the way of life of their earliest forefathers. Facing defeat, Sulayman admits his jealousy, the true motive behind Salamat’s arrest.

 

Meanwhile, Martin de Goiti and the Spaniards break the blood compact to defend Maynilad, leading to a battle that leaves the city state in ashes. Ligaya gives birth to a daughter, May-I, whom Sulayman treats coldly. Pira takes care of the child. In their next attack, the Spaniards use a combined strategy of divide and rule. Maynilad is sacked; Sulayman is captured and taken to Maalat (Malate). Ligaya flees to Lagyo (Ermita), is raped by Spanish soldiers and friars, and dies from shock and exhaustion. The wooden sculpture, Salamat’s gift to Ligaya, is found and is believed to be the miraculous statue of the Virgin Mary, called Nuestra Señora de Guia, which presently stands in the Ermita Church. Lakandula surrenders, while Pira and his men fight but lose, quietly witnessing the destruction and burning of his entire legacy. Only May-I, the baby, remains—the last legacy of his lost world.

In part 3, Pira, in exile at Maalat, is compelled to build cannons for the enemy. Alive, Salamat finds out about Pira’s work for the enemy and curses the day he had Pira as his guro (teacher). Pira blinds himself so that the Spaniards can no longer make use of him. He and May-I leave for Laguna and the Makiling mountains.

One day, Augusto de Legaspi, a descendant of Lakandula, grieves over the loss of his wife and property, stolen by friars. In the forest where he weeps, he hears Salamat’s voice. He spreads the news that Salamat lives, and droves of people come to push the huge rock away from the mouth of the cave where Salamat has been imprisoned for 17 years. An armed insurrection erupts over land and sea.

In part 4, the rebellion spreads, and Pira hears about it. Meanwhile, friars spread the rumor that May-I is an evil encantada (enchantress). People nearby, however, think of her as benevolent, and later call her Maria Makiling. The story goes that Maria falls in love with a young man, who, in his desire not to serve time as a soldier of the Spanish army, marries a mestiza belonging to the principalia (ruling class). Meanwhile, the rebellion is crushed due to the treachery of a government agent, Surabao. Salamat is hanged. Pira slowly wanes and from his deathbed summons Maria and tells her his whole life story. He instructs Maria to pass the story to others. Heartbroken by the loss of both her lover and foster father, Maria leaves Makiling for a place unknown.

May-I, May-I not only reached into the pre-Hispanic past for its drama, but also for its theater. Research into martial arts and rituals provided movements and moments that fleshed out history and brought the audience in touch with its mythic past.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis

 

Source

Atienza, Glecy C. 1990. “Subersyon sa Dula sa Ilalilm ng Batas Militar: Mga Dula ng PETA 1975-1981.” MA thesis, College of Arts and Letters, University of the Philippines Diliman.

Maynilad is sacked; Sulayman is captured and taken to Maalat (Malate). Ligaya flees to Lagyo (Ermita), is raped by Spanish soldiers and friars, and dies from shock and exhaustion. The wooden sculpture, Salamat’s gift to Ligaya, is found and is believed to be the miraculous statue of the Virgin Mary, called Nuestra Señora de Guia, which presently stands in the Ermita Church. Lakandula surrenders, while Pira and his men fight but lose, quietly witnessing the destruction and burning of his entire legacy. Only May-I, the baby, remains—the last legacy of his lost world.

In part 3, Pira, in exile at Maalat, is compelled to build cannons for the enemy. Alive, Salamat finds out about Pira’s work for the enemy and curses the day he had Pira as his guro (teacher). Pira blinds himself so that the Spaniards can no longer make use of him. He and May-I leave for Laguna and the Makiling mountains.

One day, Augusto de Legaspi, a descendant of Lakandula, grieves over the loss of his wife and property, stolen by friars. In the forest where he weeps, he hears Salamat’s voice. He spreads the news that Salamat lives, and droves of people come to push the huge rock away from the mouth of the cave where Salamat has been imprisoned for 17 years. An armed insurrection erupts over land and sea.

In part 4, the rebellion spreads, and Pira hears about it. Meanwhile, friars spread the rumor that May-I is an evil encantada (enchantress). People nearby, however, think of her as benevolent, and later call her Maria Makiling. The story goes that Maria falls in love with a young man, who, in his desire not to serve time as a soldier of the Spanish army, marries a mestiza belonging to the principalia (ruling class). Meanwhile, the rebellion is crushed due to the treachery of a government agent, Surabao. Salamat is hanged. Pira slowly wanes and from his deathbed summons Maria and tells her his whole life story. He instructs Maria to pass the story to others. Heartbroken by the loss of both her lover and foster father, Maria leaves Makiling for a place unknown.

May-I, May-I not only reached into the pre-Hispanic past for its drama, but also for its theater. Research into martial arts and rituals provided movements and moments that fleshed out history and brought the audience in touch with its mythic past.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis

text:
(May 21 and Other Chapters). 1978. Three-act play with prologue, in Filipino. Direction, Joel Lamangan; script, Al Santos; original music, Ahnee Montano; production design, Javy M. Villacin and Romy M. Gacad; lighting design, Edgardo Avila. Cast: Fernando Josef, Mia Gutierrez, Nel Bermio, Bettie Gobencion, Eugene Lopez, La Rainne Abad, Greys Balquin, Marievic Ebetuer, Ruben Felipe, Lily Layog, Zaldy Mercado, Ike Obcena, Lito Obcena, Jun Obligacion, Joy Padua, and Bai Jamila A. Tamano. First staged by the University of the Philippines (UP) Samahan ng Mag-aaral sa Pilipino and the Department of Filipino on 20 Nov 1978 at the Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero Theater, UP Diliman, Quezon City. It was published in Mithi 3 in 1985.

In an earlier play also in Filipino, Si Tatang Atbp. mga Tauhan ng Aming Dula (Tatang and Other Characters in Our Play), 1975, the playwright focused on Valentin “Tatang” de los Santos’s last hours in a mental hospital, replaying his life story through improvisations and pantomime. In this play, the progression is chronological: from birth to death, and in between, the development of a leader and “Second Messiah” for the oppressed.

In verse, prose, and song, the story is presented with the aid of radio announcements; slides; labels indicating time, place, and identities; and three tagapagpahayag or narrators who, at the end, play roles themselves.

Act 1 opens on the end of the “first war,” the Spanish era. Tatang’s father is killed by the “first power,” the Spaniards. The boy grows up in the church, also hearing of the power of the anting-anting (amulet). The “second power,” the Americans, arrive. Valentin enters the seminary, but the Messiah appears to him and asks him to leave the seminary to fulfill his mission: to take his people to their long-dreamed-of salvation. He goes into the world and meets suffering people. Then he gets married. The “third power,” the Japanese, come, along with new sufferings. Act 1 ends with a radio broadcast on the formation of the Lapiang Malaya.

 

Act 2 presents the development of Tatang as leader, writing records of, and guidelines for the lapian (association), gathering followers who like him are poor and oppressed, sacrificing his personal time and life, developing the practices for which the group became known—prayers, meetings, the use of anting-anting, a flag. In May 1967, the members gather and prepare, led by Tatang and his ministers and generals, to march to Malacañan, armed only with anting-anting and bolo, symbolic of their unity, to present their plaints to the authorities. They are shot down by soldiers, and act 2 ends with a radio broadcast on and slides showing the Lapiang Malaya massacre.

Act 3 has Tatang in the mental hospital, cross-examined by a doctor, an investigator, and a judge, with all his answers interpreted as proof of insanity, in spite of the testimony of witnesses (“Tatang is our true hero, and never will die …”). The play ends with a radio broadcast announcing Tatang’s death in a “brawl” in the mental hospital, in which he was murdered by another inmate.

The playwright “in developmental analysis touches upon the root of such organizations as Lapiang Malaya … [and] traces the origins of the peasant’s need for land in feudal exploitation by [the] Church in Spanish times and imperialist depredation by American business in the 20th century.” It is “a lament over the lot of the oppressed who are forced to turn to quasi-religious superstition in their search for liberation” (Lumbera 1981). Mayo A-Beinte Uno won the first prize in the full-length play category, Filipino division, of the Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature in 1977.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

 

Sources

Lumbera, Bienvenido L. 1981. “The Nationalist Struggle and the Filipino Writer.” Cultural Research Bulletin 2 (Jan-Mar): 20.

article_title: Mga Ama, Mga Anak/Fathers and Sons

photos.desc: Marco Viaña and Madeleine Nicolas, left, Robert Arevalo, in portrait, Cris Villonco, Celeste Legaspi, and Nanding Josef in Tanghalang Pilipino’s Mga Ama, Mga Anak, CCP, 2014 (Edgardo Manuel, Tanghalang Pilipino Collection)

text:
1977. Three-act play in Filipino. Direction, Lino Brocka; script, Nick Joaquin; translation, Jose F. Lacaba; production design, Brenda Fajardo, Jojo Purisima, and Melvin Flores; music direction, Lutgardo Labad. Cast: Ben Rubio, Margot Pimentel, Mario O’Hara, Laurice Guillen, Bembol Roco, Mia Gutierrez, Brenda Fajardo, Joel Lamangan, and Ed Pagayon. First staged by the Philippine Educational Theater Association on 20 Jan 1977 at the Dulaang Rajah Sulayman in Fort Santiago, Manila. The original text in English was published in Nick Joaquin’s Tropical Baroque, 1979.

Mga Ama, Mga Anak, a translation of Nick Joaquin’s three-act play Fathers and Sons, 1975 (which in turn is based on his short story “Three Generations”), revolves around the conflicts in the family of Zacarias Monzon, king of horses and caretela (horse-drawn carriages) in his town. The large, powerful man is in his grand house, which is dominated by a long, thick and solid dining table. His strength is leaving him, and after two strokes, he is tied to a wheelchair, mourning the women and children who have already left him. Those who have remained are Nena, his unmarried daughter, and Bessie, a baylarina (nightclub dancer) who was sold by her parents to a nightclub owner and who is presently Zacarias’s woman. Celo, his son, forbids him his women, declaring his disgust over his father’s lust. His grandson, Chitong, wishes to enter the seminary. Celo’s wife, Sofia, a practical woman, sees that her husband seeks revenge on a father he both fears and hates and beside whom he feels sexually inadequate.

 

The action of the play takes 24 hours. Celo and Chitong arrive at the grand house to find Bessie adamant about staying with the only man who has made her feel like a woman and not a commodity. Celo drives her away. Sofia arrives, livens the old man with a drinking bout, but he makes a grab for her, thinking that she is one of his women. Chitong realizes his grandfather’s character and need, and brings Bessie back but is confronted by Celo who grabs the old man’s whip and lashes at his son, hitting him on the face. Chitong utters the same words Celo himself said when his father struck him years ago. Only then does Celo realize his own cruelty and inadequacies. Bessie comes out of the bedroom and announces that the old man is dead. Celo orders the long table chopped up to fuel a great fire to burn his father’s boots, hat, gun and holster, and whip. Chitong leads the family in the prayers for the dead.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis

 

Source

Atienza, Glecy C. 1990. “Subersyon sa Dula sa Ilalilm ng Batas Militar: Mga Dula ng PETA 1975-1981.” MA thesis, College of Arts and Letters, University of the Philippines Diliman.

text:
(The Guerrillas of Powell Street). 2008. Two-act play in Filipino. Direction, Chris Millado; script and adaptation, Rody Vera; costume design, Bobot Lota; set design, Clint Ramos; music direction, Jed Balsamo; sound design, Jethro Joaquin; guitar coach, Noel Mendoza. Cast: Bembol Roco/Tommy Abuel (Fidel), Lou Veloso/Bodjie Pascua (Ciriaco “Tex” Santos), Dido de la Paz (Ruben), Paolo O’Hara (Arnel), Joe Gruta (Major Amor), and Mailes Kanapi (Svetlana). First staged on 7 Nov 2008 by Tanghalang Pilipino (TP) at the Tanghalang Huseng Batute, Cultural Center of the Philippines. The play was restaged by TP in 2009. It was also performed twice at the Armed Forces of the Philippines Theater, Camp General Emilio Aguinaldo, Quezon City, sponsored by the Department of National Defense and the Philippine Veterans Affairs Office. It was subsequently staged in 2014 at Bindlestiff Studio, San Francisco, using an English translation by Vera, directed by Lorna Velasco.

The play was based on Benjamin Pimentel’s novel of the same title, published in 2007, which won the Juan C. Laya Award for Fiction in the 2008 National Book Awards. The novel is based on Pimentel’s English short story “Waiting on Powell Street,” which won the 1991 Bienvenido Santos Short Story Writing Contest.

 

Five elderly Filipinos are shown waiting for their train along Powell Street in San Francisco. They do not have jobs and spend their days at this station, reminiscing about their past days during World War II, the women they have loved, and family members that they left behind in the Philippines. They long for the day when the US government will pass legislation that will allow them to claim benefits as veterans—a benefit that other veterans enjoy. They have filed a petition to be recognized and compensated as war veterans. From their conversations, it is revealed that they all share the common dream of dying in their homeland instead of in the USA. Ciriaco “Tex” Santos talks about his philandering wife, a Filipina who readily kicks him out of his own house after he took her in and promised to help her get a green card. Tex dies of a broken heart. The remaining men revise their wish to die in their homeland. Now they wish for their bodies to be sent back whole to the homeland, refusing to be cremated into ashes. But even this wish may not be granted to all of them as travel costs for the coffin is terribly expensive. As they pay their respects to the ashes of one of their fallen friends, a funny incident with the ashes leaves them all surprised. Soon, one by one, they pass away. Ruben talks about his sex life with the bombshell Svetlana. His time with her is the only thing that makes him feel alive. He suffers a heart attack in the middle of a “heavenly” encounter. Fidel learns to accept the radical ideas of his son Arnel. He reminisces that his son’s own life has paralleled his. Arnel became a guerrilla of the revolutionary movement in the 1980s. Fidel finds out that Arnel has been killed in his own fight for freedom and justice, through a fellow veteran who now works as a delivery man. In the end, the train these veteran guerrillas are waiting for arrives and the audience realizes that the station they are in is actually a holding area before moving on to the next life.

The play exposed audiences to the struggles of Filipino veterans based in the United States who are still waiting for their benefits. They have to be in the United States in order to claim their monthly stipend, which does not really cover the amount of their living expenses. The Philippine Veterans Office notes that, as of 2008, up to as many as 500 veterans die every month without receiving their benefits.  Written by Walter Ang

article_title: Ang Mga Kagila-gilalas na Pakikipagsapalaran ni Juan De La Cruz
text:
(The Amazing Adventures of Juan de la Cruz). 1975. Tula-dula (poem-play). Poetry, Jose F. Lacaba. Cast: Raul Dealino (Juan de la Cruz), Sonny Oliveros, and Philip Waite. Ang mga Kagila-gilalas … is the first tula-dula and is known to be the first street play during the repressive martial law period of the mid-1970s. It was first produced by the University of the Philippines Repertory Company (UP Rep) in 1975 at the Mater Dei Auditorium of St. Joseph’s College in Quezon City.

It was the time of martial law and UP Rep members were tasked by theater director and UP professor Behn Cervantes to develop new forms of protest theater that would take into consideration the limitations in the use of amplified sound or in slide projection, and in the number of actors and props to be transported. Inspiration struck UP Rep chairman Cecile de Joya when she saw fellow company officer, Raul Dealino, practicing his oral interpretation piece for a speech class. Dealino was using the poem by Lacaba, which was in the class manual. The first tula-dula performance of the play was then staged in Mater Dei. After seeing the performance, UP Rep founder Behn Cervantes took over direction and replaced the “grim-and-determined” acting with a lighter, comedic touch. Subsequent actors were Jolly de la Torre, Benjie Oliveros, and Millie Ambrosio.

The poem tells of how an ordinary citizen, named Juan de la Cruz, experiences being repressed from doing what he wants in the city. The bus fare collector tells him that smoking is not allowed and bars him from getting on the bus. The city street impresses on him that parking and peeing anywhere is not allowed. The movie theater stops his entrance through the signage “Passes Not Honored Today.” The congress deputy cautions him to beware of dogs. The Malacañan Palace keeps him “off the grass.” The pimp says to him, “Credit is good but we need cash.” The bay walk signage says dumping trash in the sea is forbidden and stops him from taking a dip. The church sign states “In God We Trust,” while the bishop says, “All others pay cash.” When Juan de la Cruz becomes hopeless and hungry, he goes to the mountains and rises against the established order. He then becomes a fugitive and is “Wanted: Dead or Alive” by the Philippine Constabulary.

The form that eventually developed had two actors miming in the tula-dula: one played the major character and the other, called Miscellaneous, performed the other roles. A third actor was the narrator who read the poem in front of a microphone on one side of the stage. With a minimum number of actors, props, and amplification, performances by UP Rep members were done simultaneously in different venues.

Ang mga Kagila-gilalas … was used to gather protesters for mass actions in the UP campus. It was also performed during UP Rep’s stage productions either at the start of longer plays or during intermissions. The tula-dula inspired other writers, such as Richie Valencia and Ed Vencio as well as members of the UP Rep, to write other tula-dula performance pieces.  Written by Tim Dacanay

The tula-dula inspired other writers, such as Richie Valencia and Ed Vencio as well as members of the UP Rep, to write other tula-dula performance pieces.  Written by Tim Dacanay
