text:
(Stories of Grandma Basyang). 2005. Two-act play in Filipino. Direction, Phil Noble and Nor Domingo; script, Christine S. Bellen; music, Noel Cabangon; musical arrangement, Bob Aves; choreography, Dudz Teraña; set and costume design, Ogie Juliano; lighting design, Ian Torqueza. Cast: Ron Ryan Alfonso, JK Anicoche, Bernah Bernardo, McDonnel Bolaños, Lotlot Bustamante, Wilfredo Casero, Eric de la Cruz, Miles Pasamanero, and Neomi Gabanao. First staged by the Philippine Educational Theater Association from 25 Aug to 3 Sep 2005 at SM Centerpoint in Santa Mesa, Manila.

For the opening, the main characters come out onstage and introduce themselves. Lola Basyang comes in with her cane, and introduces herself and the three tales she will recount.

“Ang Prinsipeng Mahaba ang Ilong” (The Prince with the Long Nose) is about a prince who would have been considered handsome, except for his kilometric nose, the result of a curse made by an unrequited suitor of the prince’s mother, the queen. To take her son’s mind off his nose, the queen advises the prince to pass the time away in the forest with his guard. They get lost in the forest, with the prince almost falling prey to a wild pig had it not been for a girl gathering firewood. Strangely, the girl, who has black skin, does not laugh at the prince’s nose and instead builds a bonfire to keep the wild animals at bay. Just then, two denizens of the forest, Duling (Cross-eyed) and Bungal (Toothless), enter and make fun of both the prince’s nose and the girl’s black skin. But soon enough, Duling falls into a ravine and is saved and brought up from the ravine by the prince’s nose. It is then that the girl articulates the moral of the story: that the goodness of a person’s heart cannot be seen from the outside. The prince and the girl fall in love with each other, and because of that love, the prince’s long nose is replaced with a normal one.

 

In “Ang Binibining Tumalo sa Mahal na Hari” (The Girl Who Bested the Great King), Sharay, the daughter of the slave of Datu Abdul, has fallen in love with the datu’s son, Prinsipe Pido, and vice versa. Both have broken the datu’s law that strictly forbids the love between a slave and a royale. To punish the presumptuous girl, Datu Abdul subjects her to three tests, which she must pass or die. The datu is sure that Sharay will not pass the tests because she is only a girl and he is the smartest man in the kingdom. Through his first slave Lamukot, the datu orders Sharay to kill a small pipit bird and make 12 tasty dishes out of it. Since the 12 viands will have to be placed on silver platters, Sharay asks the datu to turn her silver hairpin into 12 silver platters. Sharay passes the first test. In the second, the king orders Sharay to sell one sheep for an ounce of gold, but to bring it back to him together with the ounce of gold. Sharay challenges Lamukot to a riddling contest and wins the ounce of gold from the slave. She then sends the gold, the sheep, and a sheepskin to the king, the last as a gift. The datu and Lamukot are outwitted. In the third test, the datu orders Sharay to provide him with milk from a male carabao, so that his skin rashes, caused by Sharay’s gift, will go away. He also announces that he will take a bath in the river to relieve the itch, and forbids anyone from washing anything in the river while he bathes. Deliberately, Sharay washes a mat full of blood in the river, polluting the waters and drenching the datu with blood. Angry, the datu asks Sharay why she broke his order. The girl reasons out that she had to immediately wash away the blood from the mat on which her father had just given birth. The blood was actually from a pig that was butchered on the mat. The datu says it is impossible for a male to give birth. By the same token, Sharay argues, a male carabao cannot produce milk. Impressed by the girl’s wit, the datu repeals the law forbidding the union of slaves and princes, believing that Sharay’s intelligence will work for the benefit of the kingdom. Indeed, he says, class differences should not be an obstacle to true love.

In “Ang Prinsipeng Duwag” (The Cowardly Prince), the prince detests all forms of violence and instead loves music and art. Disgusted with a son who is a “coward,” the king banishes the prince from the kingdom. In the forest, he strays into another kingdom and there finds a princess, Malaya, who also loves music. They fall in love with each other. Soon the prince must hide because the Gurkos arrive, with instructions from their chief, who wants Malaya for himself at all costs, to torture anyone who courts Malaya. The prince hides but when the Gurkos threaten Malaya’s life, he comes out of hiding and demolishes them all. The prince says he loves peace but he is prepared to go to war when necessary.

The trilogy retells three stories of Severino Reyes for today’s youth, editing them for conciseness, tweaking them to endorse feminist and other transformative values, and rewriting narration and dialogue into contemporary colloquial language, including street slang and colegiala (schoolgirl) English. The play exemplifies how traditional stories can acquire new meaning and relevance to the millennial generation.  Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

text:
(Maranao Tales). 1974. Three-act play presented in five languages: Maranao, Cebuano, Filipino, English, and Spanish. Direction and production design, Frank Rivera; script, Sining Kambayoka Ensemble; music direction, Nelson Echevarria, Edgarito Riconalla, and Philip James Tremedal; lighting design, Didhony Esma and Edgarito Riconalla. Cast: Danny Posadas, Jehovenn Honculada, Charlet Aliwanag, Cecile Balisado, Eppie Endencia, Leo Ochia, Marilou Rabe, Sunset Yahya, and the Sining Kambayoka Ensemble. Produced by the Mindanao State University–Sining Kambayoka. First staged on 30 Dec 1974 at the Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Fort Santiago, Manila. Performed more than 1,000 times, nationwide, from 1974 to 1991.

The play consists of 13 different stories revolving around the adventures and misadventures of the folk hero and trickster Pilandok. It begins with the rivalry between him and another con artist, Bombola, his archenemy. Always the underdog, Pilandok seeks the help of the spirits of the forest and emerges victorious. He falls in love with the witch’s daughter, Bagoaraga, but is frustrated and brokenhearted. Because of the hurt, he is motivated to change for the better. He meets the sultan’s daughter, Prinsesa, and falls in love again. But the sultan and his wife are vehemently against the union and do everything to stop the lovers. In the end, Pilandok proves to be the better person and saves the kingdom from the leader’s corruption.

 

Mga Kuwentong Maranao is one of the first plays to emerge from Mindanao which use the regional ethnic culture to create a new dramaturgy. Not only are the costumes and colors Maranao; so are the movements and dances. The malong (traditional tubular skirt of the Maranao) provided not only the costume but also stage sets, props, curtains, dividers, and color. Sining Kambayoka derived its name, dynamics of speech or verse style from bayok or verse debate, and Pilandok, the archetypal folk hero, who rises from the community where he is an ordinary member to leadership and heroism.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis

text:
(The Seamtresses). 2008. One-act play in Filipino. Direction, Paul Santiago; script, Rogelio Braga. Cast: Diana Malahay (Hamida), Kristine Balmes (Juhayra), Aimee Joy Aringo (Saliha), Anne Gelene Tobias (Farhana), Emmanuel Freeman Paloma (Alberto), and Majo Calugtong (Salem). First staged as part of the Virgin Labfest 4 at the Tanghalang Huseng Batute of the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 2008. The script is included in the collection Sa Pagdating ng Barbaro at Iba Pang mga Dula (The Coming of the Barbarians and Other Plays), 2015.

Set in West Mindanao in the late 1970s, the play opens with Hamida, around 50, doing embroidery work on some patches, saying that many Muslim women have worn her handiwork. She continues her monologue on love; on how she first met Akbar who could have been her lover; and how in their next chance meeting, Akbar was already a fighter for the Bangsamoro cause. She muses that if she can dress Muslim women, she can also do her handiwork for Akbar and the Bangsamoro.

 

Saliha and Farhana, both teenagers, enter and begin working on the patches. The tension between them becomes evident—Saliha being the better seamstress. Hamida instructs them to work double time for they have a thousand patches to finish before the early morning sambahayang or prayer. Juhayra, in her 40s, arrives and begins to work as well. She hopes for safe passage for her husband and two sons. Hamida muses how she was able to take the best seamstresses in town to work on the patches that she will give to Akbar and his comrades.

While working in a corner, Farhana accuses Saliha of breaking the rule forbidding women to listen to men’s discussions. Juhayra praises Hamida as she works while singing. Hamida narrates how she became an orphan after her parents died in an armed encounter with government forces, and how she struggled living alone as a seamstress. Farhana says Saliha wants to be named the best seamstress, even mocking her fondness for dolls. Hamida stops the bickering. Gunshots are fired and Hamida dismisses them as the new commander’s way of showing off. Saliha realizes it may be a raid. Juhayra wonders when the discontent will end but Saliha asserts that there is no peace because there is no freedom. Hearing this, Hamida asks if Saliha listens to men’s discussions, which the latter denies.

Somebody knocks. Farhana opens the door and finds the 10-year-old Alberto. He asks if he could also work as an apprentice for the seamstresses. Hamida agrees and lets him in. Farhana accuses Alberto of being a spy while Saliha disagrees. Juhayra concurs with Hamida and Saliha. Farhana continues her tirades on Saliha’s denial of listening to men’s discussions, challenging her to reveal what the men in her family talk about. Persuaded, Saliha narrates how one night, a man arrived in their home and started talking with her father and brothers about freedom.

Juhayra’s neighbor Salem reports that Juhayra’s family has been killed. Juhayra resolves to continue making patches. Hamida instructs Saliha to sit in the machine to work on the patches’ borders. Farhana complains again about Saliha. Saliha narrates her experience one morning when she was about to go to school and her classmates, including Farhana, left early so Saliha had to go on her own. She says on that morning, she passed by a battalion of soldiers. She was so scared she peed. She asks Farhana why they left her that morning. Farhana asks for forgiveness. Saliha decides to join the movement to fight for the Bangsamoro cause. She tells Farhana to continue the work she will leave behind, and that Farhana will be the best seamstress in the years to come. Farhana attaches a patch to Saliha’s dress. It is already the hour of the early morning sambahayang. Saliha bids her fellow seamstresses farewell.

The playwright notes the play should be staged outside the hours of salat (prayers) without images of masjids or areas in Mindanao destroyed by war or of dead Moro/Bangsamoro freedom fighters holding weapons of war, and without background music of Mindanao ethnic instruments. The play discusses the lives of Muslim Mindanao Bangsamoro fighters/supporters with focus more on Muslim women’s views of achieving freedom and peace.  Written by Erick Dasig Aguilar

 

Source

Braga, Rogelio. 2015. Sa Pagdating ng Barbaro at Iba Pang mga Dula. Naga City: Ateneo de Naga University Press.

text:
(People Saints). Play in 17 scenes, in Filipino. Script, Tomas Remigio. It was written in 1901 and staged by the Tanghalang Kabataan under the direction of Antonio Mabesa in 1975; by the University of the Philippines (UP) Kompanyang Samutsari under the direction of Jorge Hernandez in 1977; and by the UP Anak-Tibawan under the direction of Rene Arambulo at the Little Theater of the Rizal Hall, UP Manila, in 1983 and again in 1990.

The 17 tagpo or scenes tell the story of Ambrosio and Titay and their comic revenge on the powerful. Ambrosio opens the play with a lament on how hard life is even in a country that is “sagana sa yaman at dilag” (filled with riches and beauty). Titay consoles him, saying she has a plan to make some money, revealing that the kura (priest), the piskal (prosecutor), and sakristan mayor (head sacristan) all desire her. She has not told Ambrosio earlier because she is still able to defend her honor. But the time to act has come, since the kura, because of her refusals, has plans to accuse him falsely. Ambrosio is all for taking up his gulok (bolo); Titay stops him and unveils her plan. As each eager suitor visits her, she agrees to have him return in the evening, bringing what he had promised, each at a specified time. Ambrosio conceals himself to listen.

The kura comes first, at seven o’clock, with a bag of derechos or parish fees. He is impatient, and attempts to embrace her. She wards him off by offering dinner, but he presses, and is stopped only by a knock on the door. Saying it must be her husband, Titay hides him in the next room, where the santos are kept. She makes him assume the pose of the Nazareno, puts a cross on his shoulder, and assures him that if he does not move, he will not be recognized.

The sakristan mayor, who had knocked at eight o’clock, enters with his bag of church money. He too presses his attentions on her, and she is saved by another knock, which he thinks is her husband. He too is forced to hide in the next room, beside the Kura, but this time disguised as Christ crucified, arms outstretched, one foot on top of the other.

The piskal comes in at nine o’clock, money in hand, swearing lifelong service, and pleading, “Ipalasap mo na, Titay, ang ligaya” (Let me taste the joy, Titay). In the next room the kura and the sakristan are sweating and listening. The piskal’s insistence is stopped by a knock on the door, and he too hides in the next room, in the guise of the Ecce Homo.

Ambrosio comes in, gulok in hand, threatening to chop up all three (“pagpipikadilyuhin ko”) and make them martyrs. A manong (elderly man) and a manang (elderly woman), however, call out at the door. They are looking for santos for the procession. Titay and Ambrosio welcome them, saying they have many such, “mga natural na natural po” (very real ones, sir). Titay lights their way to the next room, where they examine the three sweating saints. They are impressed with their naturalness, with their realistic sweating, with their suffering faces. Ambrosio and Titay’s teasing remarks add to the rascals’ discomfiture. The manong and manang want all three, are quoted a price, and decide to take them. Ambrosio offers to show them a miracle, and holds his candle to the bald pate (or the bottom) of the kura, who drops his cross and runs, followed by the sakristan mayor and the piskal. Ambrosio draws his bolo, Titay restrains him, and the manong and manang fall to their knees, exclaiming: “A miracle! A miracle!” as the curtain falls.

Mga Santong Tao was one of the earliest comedies of the first decade of the 1900s.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

 

Source

UP Anak-Tibawan. 1983. Gran Magia. Souvenir program.

She makes him assume the pose of the Nazareno, puts a cross on his shoulder, and assures him that if he does not move, he will not be recognized.

The sakristan mayor, who had knocked at eight o’clock, enters with his bag of church money. He too presses his attentions on her, and she is saved by another knock, which he thinks is her husband. He too is forced to hide in the next room, beside the Kura, but this time disguised as Christ crucified, arms outstretched, one foot on top of the other.

The piskal comes in at nine o’clock, money in hand, swearing lifelong service, and pleading, “Ipalasap mo na, Titay, ang ligaya” (Let me taste the joy, Titay). In the next room the kura and the sakristan are sweating and listening. The piskal’s insistence is stopped by a knock on the door, and he too hides in the next room, in the guise of the Ecce Homo.

Ambrosio comes in, gulok in hand, threatening to chop up all three (“pagpipikadilyuhin ko”) and make them martyrs. A manong (elderly man) and a manang (elderly woman), however, call out at the door. They are looking for santos for the procession. Titay and Ambrosio welcome them, saying they have many such, “mga natural na natural po” (very real ones, sir). Titay lights their way to the next room, where they examine the three sweating saints. They are impressed with their naturalness, with their realistic sweating, with their suffering faces. Ambrosio and Titay’s teasing remarks add to the rascals’ discomfiture. The manong and manang want all three, are quoted a price, and decide to take them. Ambrosio offers to show them a miracle, and holds his candle to the bald pate (or the bottom) of the kura, who drops his cross and runs, followed by the sakristan mayor and the piskal. Ambrosio draws his bolo, Titay restrains him, and the manong and manang fall to their knees, exclaiming: “A miracle! A miracle!” as the curtain falls.
Mga Santong Tao was one of the earliest comedies of the first decade of the 1900s.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

text:
1988. Musical in English. Direction, Zeneida Amador; libretto, Joy Virata and Freddie Santos; music, Ian Monsod; musical arrangement, Ed Nepomoceno, Ditoy Aguila, and Noel Zarate; musical direction, Baby Barredo; choreography, Jaime del Prado; set design, Jun Cumagon; costume design, Rogelio Juliano; sound design, Gidget Tolentino. Cast: Rem Zamora/Robert Seña (Emilio “Miong” Aguinaldo), Liesl Batucan/Maya Barredo (Yayang), Elver Esquivel (Don Carlos), Jay Glorioso (Kapitana Teneng), JM Rodriguez (Baldomero Aguinaldo), Noel Rayos (Andres Bonifacio), and Lawrence Villegas (Santiago). First staged by the Repertory Philippines in 1998 at the Armed Forces of the Philippines Theater, Camp Aguinaldo, Quezon City.

It is Holy Week, 1869, in Kawit, Cavite. The Spaniards have ruled the Philippines for more than 300 years. Ensemble sings “Under the Bells.” Kapitana Teneng gives birth to Emilio “Miong” Aguinaldo. A few years later, a mutiny erupts in the Cavite arsenal and many Filipinos are persecuted, including Don Carlos, Miong’s father. When Miong is eight years old, his father dies, leaving him with an admonition to study hard in order to become like the ilustrados (the educated).

 

Miong tries hard but cannot fulfill his father’s wish. He convinces his mother to let him drop out of school and successfully embarks on a trading venture. Against his wishes, his mother bargains with the parish priest, Father Blas, for the position of cabeza de barangay (barangay captain) for Miong. He is 17 years old. Later on he becomes a capitan municipal (municipal head or mayor). He tries to solve differences among the people but is warned by Father Blas not to interfere. He meets and falls in love with Yayang and they marry.

Despite his success, Miong is full of self-doubt. He feels he has let his father down by not finishing school and that he is letting his people down by not being able to change their lives significantly as they continue to suffer under the friar’s cruelty and greed. His cousin, Baldomero Aguinaldo, convinces him to join, first, the masons and then the Katipunan secretly. He meets with Andres Bonifacio. Miong is given the name Magdalo and, secretly using his position and his family’s closeness to the church, brings many Caviteños (locals of Cavite) from all walks of life into the Katipunan.

When the revolution starts in Manila, Miong and his men wait for orders to join the attack. But when they get word that the revolt has failed, the decision is made to start the revolution in Cavite. With Miong leading the Magdalo forces (a Katipunan faction) and his friend Santiago leading the Magdiwang forces (a Katipunan faction), the Katipuneros win the battles in Cavite. But dissension over leadership begins, which Aguinaldo, busy in battle, is unable to quell. The Spaniards launch their counterattack and the events continue to their tragic end with the death of Bonifacio and the eventual exile of Miong and other leaders to Hong Kong.

In Hong Kong, Miong is plagued by self-doubt. Betrayed by the Spaniards who promised reform and unsure of American promises, he decides to finally go back to the Philippines, take matters into his own hands, and continue the revolt. He has a flag designed, brings it home along with arms he has purchased with Spanish money, commissions a national anthem, reunites his people, and continues the revolution, winning back all the provinces from the Spaniards. On 12 Jun 1898 in Kawit, Cavite, he declares to the world that the Philippines is now a free and independent nation.

Miong is the first musical in English that traces the life of Pres Emilio Aguinaldo. The musical looks at the personal side of Aguinaldo—his personality, his uncertainties, his strengths, his conflicts, his family, and the people he loved. The musical was also Repertory Philippines’s sole attempt at creating an original work, in connection with the centennial of the Philippine revolution, after decades of staging foreign materials.  Written by Walter Ang

text:
1915. Play in three scenes, in English. Direction, Mary H. Fee; script, Jesusa Araullo and Lino Juan Castillejo. First staged on 11 Dec 1915 at the Philippine Normal School and restaged two other times. A typescript is kept at the Ateneo de Manila University Library.

The play, which has some occasional songs and a dance, is set in Nueva Ecija. Catalino loves Filipina, a nurse recently graduated, who does not seem to care for him. Tica, his conservative mother, opposes his courtship because she does not believe in modern girls. She watches her daughter Maria closely, to keep her from speaking to or even looking at men. The vivacious Filipina, full of common sense and new ideas, makes fun of Catalino’s protestations of love. At a picnic celebrating Maria’s birthday, she meets Andres, a student from Manila, who is interested in her. Tica meets Kiko, a widower-farmer from another town who, hearing of her lands and carabaos, proposes marriage so that he can help her take care of her property. In spite of her rules, Tica accepts him, but her children oppose the marriage. Filipina, with her modern ideas, sides with Tica: “Is it necessary for a woman to devote her whole life to the memory of her dead husband? She may keep his memory, but that ought not to prevent her from marrying a second time.” Catalino tests Filipina’s feelings by falling from a guava tree and pretending to be hurt. Filipina is solicitous, and finally accepts his proposal, as she had intended to do from the start. Tica, at the prodding of Kiko, who wishes to be rid of his stepchildren, accepts Andres as a suitor for Maria, and all ends happily. Filipina is “the modern Filipina,” who speaks frankly and intelligently, and makes her own decisions, in contrast to the dependent Maria and the conservative Tica.

A Modern Filipina is the first play written by Filipinos in English. It became the basis of subsequent plays about modern Filipinas.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez.

text:
1971. One-act play in Filipino. Direction, Bing de Guzman; script, Rogelio Sicat. Cast: Ma. Araceli Dans, Royce Reyes, et al. First staged in 1971 at the College Cafeteria of Ateneo de Manila University in Quezon City. Subsequently staged in 1974 by the University of the Philippines (UP) Repertory Company under the direction of Behn Cervantes; in 1975 at the Little Theater, later Tanghalang Aurelio V. Tolentino, of the Cultural Center of the Philippines to celebrate the 25th anniversary of the Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature; in 1990 by the UP Tropa Experimental Theater Company in UP Diliman under the direction of Auraeus Solito; as well as in the provinces. It was published in Isang Kalipunan ng mga Nagwagi sa Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards (An Anthology of Award Winners in the Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards), 1976, and in Panitikan at Kritisismo (Literature and Criticism), volume 2, 1980, edited by RosarioTorres-Yu.

The epigraph “Apoy sa apoy, sugat sa sugat, latay sa latay” (fire for fire, wound for wound, bruise for bruise) is from Exodus (21:25). The play is set in the province of Rizal, in the middle-class apartment owned by Regina Calderon, a widow and a teacher of civics and government. She lives with her sister Ana, and her children Tony, Aida, and Ben. The plans being made and the tension revealed in the opening scene are slowly explained: Aida, who is turning 18, has been raped by the son of a town mayor. Regina, who believes in justice, is determined to sue. The mayor and a councilor come to see her and, indirectly but clearly, ask her to withdraw the case, citing the fruitlessness of her endeavor: the judge is a compadre (friend) of the mayor’s and a “brad sa cursillo” (brother in the cursillo). When she asks the mayor what he would have felt if his daughter had been raped, he suggests that she avoid the pain of having her daughter cross-examined. When she counters that at the next election his son’s crime will be known, the councilor reminds her that the mayor has been in office for 13 years. She declares that she will ask for a change of judge. The councilor asks which judge would not be on the mayor’s side? When they offer her a check, she refuses, and they leave cursing. Tony agrees that suing would be fruitless, and argues for an Old Testament kind of justice: “An eye for an eye …” When his father was killed right in front of their house, he tells her, he pondered on what they should do, and found his answer in the Bible. He wants to kill the mayor’s son while she insists on pursuing the case. He is sent out to buy medicine for Aida. She finds out that he has taken a gun with him.

In the final scene, Tony comes running in: he has killed the mayor’s son, and wants them all to flee. Regina refuses, and tells him to surrender and to give her the gun. The mayor and his men arrive, and Regina assures them that Tony will surrender peacefully. They grab Tony, and tell him to run—obviously to shoot him “while resisting arrest.” Regina shoots Tony. “Why?” asks the Mayor. “Because you were going to kill him,” she answers. “You do not know the meaning of justice … Yes … take me to the precinct, to the court … anywhere. I will answer for my son’s death. I killed my son …”

 

The play has been performed again and again by different drama groups, in different schools and settings. Just before martial law was declared, one version had Regina killing the mayor instead of her son.

Moses, Moses won first prize in the one-act play category, Filipino division, of the 1968-69 Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

text:
(Noble Rivalry). Sarsuwela in two acts and an epilogue, in Ilocano. Script, Mena Pecson Crisologo. No date of first performance is recorded but it is known to have been staged at the Manila Grand Opera House in 1932, with Leon Pichay playing the part of Castillo, together with Bienvenido Azurin, Jakel Blancagen, Primitiva de Resurreccion, Franca Nueza, and Valentin Alcid. It was published in Alejandrino G. Hufana’s Mena Pecson Crisologo and Iloko Drama, 1963, and Komisyon sa Wikang Filipino’s Don Calixtofano de la Kota at Natakneng a Panagsalisal: Dalawang Dula ni Mena Pecson Crisologo (Don Calixtofano de la Kota and Noble Rivalry: Two Plays by Mena Pecson Crisologo), 2014.

 

The play is set during the Philippine-American War. Capt Antonio Castillo and Emilia Castañeda, a young woman traveling with her aunt in search of a brother in the army, meet when the two women are brought to his camp. Castillo’s men have rescued them from the soldiers of Major Castro. Castillo finds out that Emilia is the sister of a good friend, Lt Alfredo Morales. When Castro barges in and forces Emilia to go with him, there is an exchange of fire. A bullet grazes Castillo’s arm while Castro is hit in the chest and lies unconscious. Emilia and Antonio tell each other of their lives: his sweetheart was killed in an American raid; her betrothed is believed to have been killed in battle. Love grows between them, but Emilia needs to be sure that she is not betraying Carlos. Bidding farewell, Antonio has the women escorted to the house of Captain Ambros where Emilia finds her brother about to wed Cecilia, Captain Ambros’s daughter. Meanwhile, the war is ending and Antonio and Alfredo are among those who lay down their arms on the promise of independence. Antonio and Emilia are about to marry when Carlos reappears and explains the delay behind his return. The two men agree that whoever survives the war would marry Emilia. Breaking their oath of allegiance to the United States, the noble rivals leave. When the fighting is over, Antonio returns; Carlos has died of fever in an army hospital, his last words a request for Antonio to marry Emilia and love her always. Emilia, meanwhile, has been taken home to Balaoan to recover from the shock of Carlos’s death. She regains her health, but her family fears a relapse and asks Antonio to break the news gently to her. Although she decides to live the rest of her life as a nun, Antonio persuades her not to become his torturer, and she agrees to marry him on condition that she is not to be taken to his hometown. He agrees but must first visit his grandfather who has made him his heir. Their formal engagement is announced at Emilia’s birthday celebration.

Alejandrino G. Hufana, who did his master of arts thesis on Mena Pecson Crisologo, considers Natakneng a Panagsalisal to be Crisologo’s best play.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

text:
1908. Sarsuwela in three acts and two scenes, in Hiligaynon. Libretto, Valente Cristobal; music, Teodoro Gallego. First staged at the Teatro F. Malhabour on 3 Jul 1908 in Iloilo City.

This sarsuwela centers on Nating, a virtuous and well-bred girl, who has three suitors: Aniceto, a lawyer who is preferred by her father because of his learning; Enrique, a rich man who is preferred by her mother because of his means; and Jose, a farmer whom Nating loves because of his industry.

She is kidnapped by Roberto, leader of a band of men farming in the mountains. He has heard of her beauty and virtue, and wants to make her queen of his domain. The situation serves as a test for her three suitors. It also creates the occasion for Roberto’s men to speak of themselves, and the fate, fortune, or injustice that led them to a life in the mountains. It further proves the staunch honor, the courage and strength of Nating, who convinces Roberto that she will never yield to him and that he should take her back and face her parents honorably. When he does, he discovers that Nating’s godchild and the latter’s mother, Rita, are the wife and child whose assumed loss had made him abandon his old life and take to the mountains. In the meantime, Jose has gone to look for Nating, and her parents, realizing his worth, consent to their marriage. The play ends with preparations for the wedding of Nating and Jose.

Nating was Valente Cristobal’s first full-length work, and his most popular sarsuwela, called by critics “a work to learn from … that corrects the evil ways and excesses of the authorities, of the learned, of the rich, who because of their power, learning and money, oppress the poor … that teaches young ladies to preserve the modesty of maidenhood … wives to preserve their marital fidelity … men to uphold the honor of women … a work that has many teachings that are good to follow in the different paths that life can take” (Fernandez 1978).  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

 

Source

Fernandez, Doreen G. 1978. The Iloilo Zarzuela: 1903-1930. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

The situation serves as a test for her three suitors. It also creates the occasion for Roberto’s men to speak of themselves, and the fate, fortune, or injustice that led them to a life in the mountains. It further proves the staunch honor, the courage and strength of Nating, who convinces Roberto that she will never yield to him and that he should take her back and face her parents honorably. When he does, he discovers that Nating’s godchild and the latter’s mother, Rita, are the wife and child whose assumed loss had made him abandon his old life and take to the mountains. In the meantime, Jose has gone to look for Nating, and her parents, realizing his worth, consent to their marriage. The play ends with preparations for the wedding of Nating and Jose.

Nating was Valente Cristobal’s first full-length work, and his most popular sarsuwela, called by critics “a work to learn from … that corrects the evil ways and excesses of the authorities, of the learned, of the rich, who because of their power, learning and money, oppress the poor … that teaches young ladies to preserve the modesty of maidenhood … wives to preserve their marital fidelity … men to uphold the honor of women … a work that has many teachings that are good to follow in the different paths that life can take” (Fernandez 1978).  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

text:
(The Nazarene Woman). 1984. One-act play. Direction, Joi Barrios; script, Chris Millado. Cast: Shamaine Centenera/Connie Lauigan-Chua (Sisa), and Fernando Josef/Augusto Quesada (Pedring). First staged in Aug 1984 at the Faculty Center Theater, University of the Philippines Diliman, as part of the trilogy Kutsilyo, Pamaypay, at Yantok (Knife, Fan, and Cane). It was also staged at the De La Salle University in Mar 1986; and at the Tanghalang Huseng Batute, Cultural Center of the Philippines, as part of the trilogy in 2009. Likewise, the trilogy was presented by the Embassy of the Philippines in Paris, France, as part of Buwan ng Wika (National Language Month) celebration in Aug 2013.

This dramatic exploration of the character Sisa, one of Jose Rizal’s most popular female characters, is set in the 19th century. The play opens with Sisa falling asleep while awaiting her sons’ return. She awakens, quickly lights a candle by the image of the Virgin Mary and begins to pray. However, she soon loses herself to fear because her sons have yet to return home. She begins to imagine herself speaking to her sons and lamenting how they have to bear the burden of working for the family. She imagines herself speaking to her husband, relaying her fear that her children might have been hurt at the hands of the friars. She tells him that he shouldn’t hurt their children, for they might do the same to him when they grow up. She admits her fear of her husband, of his temper that brings him to the point of beating her. She tells him of how her own mother was hurt by her father, and after all that, how she would kneel and ask forgiveness from her father. She tells him of how her mother finally found the courage to hurt Sisa’s father the way he hurt her and her children, using the very same cane her husband used in the dream she had while waiting for her children to come home.

Sisa is jolted out of her reverie by the arrival of her husband. She tries to talk to him, telling him of the difficult time their sons are going through. Her husband shrugs her off and demands to be fed. Sisa replies that she didn’t know that he was coming home, so she had only prepared food for their sons. Just the same, Sisa grudgingly obliges her husband and prepares food while telling him not to be harsh toward their sons. Her husband grows irritated, and refers to their children as “your children.” Sisa is enraged, and she begins yelling at her husband in anger. She becomes delusional and imagines that she has picked up the cane her husband uses on her and her sons. She thinks she is now hitting him and tells him that she had long dreamt of this moment. But her husband beats her with the real cane and tells her that she has been possessed by the demon. He leaves her in the middle of the mess. Moments later, she gets up and begins cleaning up the house, not hearing the voice of a child calling out for her to open the door.

In its introspection of Rizal’s character Sisa, the play sheds light on the timeless plight of women and children who suffer from domestic abuse.  Written by Aura Albano Abiera

text:
1958. One-act play in Filipino. Direction, Daisy Hontiveros-Avellana; script, Marcelino Agana Jr. First staged by the Far Eastern University (FEU) Drama Guild at the FEU Auditorium in Manila with Baby de Guzman as Kikay. It was staged many times by the Barangay Theater Guild, first under the direction of Lamberto V. Avellana with Rustica Carpio in the role of Kikay, playing opposite different actors in different productions: Jaime de la Rosa, 1958; Robert Arevalo, 1960; Eddie Rodriguez, 1961; Amancio Donato, 1969; Samuel Fernandez, 1969; and, under the direction of Jose Mari Avellana, Henry Duvall, 1969. Later, Sining Silangan, under the direction of Rustica Carpio, repeatedly staged it at the Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila, the Philamlife Auditorium, and in 1983, in China. In 1982, it was staged at the Bulwagang Gantimpala, later Tanghalang Huseng Batute, of the Cultural Center of the Philippines under the direction of Tony Espejo with Adul de Leon, Tommy Abuel, Ariosto Reyes Jr, Nanette Moscardon, and Celeste Legaspi in the cast. In 1987, the University of the Philippines Playwrights Theater, under the direction of Antonio Mabesa, presented it in the 10th Singapore Drama Festival with Betty Mae Piccio as Kikay.

 

This play revolves around Kikay, a Tondo girl, newly arrived from a year’s stay in New York. She has adopted the New York style, manner, and culture, and insists on imposing them on her Tondo home and family. The play opens with Tony, bouquet of flowers in hand, arriving to greet her. He is met by Aling Atang, Kikay’s mother, who is almost unrecognizable because of her new look, and is most uncomfortable with being called “Mrs Mendoza,” as her daughter insists. Kikay, she informs Tony, is to be called Francesca, and is still asleep, since New Yorkers don’t rise till noon. Totoy and then Nena arrive as well, and the three recall their childhood together. Tony, it seems, was secretly engaged to Kikay but is now engaged to Nena. He was to have broken his first engagement the night before and Nena scolds him for not having done so. They try therefore to find a way for him to tell Kikay, who enters in a New York-type gown, silk kerchief in one hand, and in the other a cigarette in a long holder. When Tony is finally alone with her, she hurries to tell him that their engagement should be forgotten, since the girl he was engaged to no longer exists. When Nena reveals her engagement to Tony, Kikay claims she has not released Tony yet. The two women fight, and Tony blames Nena for hitting Kikay, while Totoy warns Tony against insulting the woman he loves. Totoy and Nena leave, and the hurt Francesca reverts back to being Kikay, the girl who fell in love with a Tondo boy.

New Yorker in Tondo is one of the most popular Filipino comedies and has been produced many times through the years.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis

text:
(Noli and Fili in the Decade of the 2000s). 2008. Two-act play in Filipino. Direction, Soxie Topacio; script, Nicanor G. Tiongson. Cast: Lex Marcos (Ibarra Marasigan and Kumander Simoun), Julia Enriquez (Clarissa Santos), Gilbert Onida (Gov Santiago Santos), Bembol Roco/Bodjie Pascua (Bishop Damaso Villareal), Robert Seña (Col Salvi Salvatiera), Ian Segarra (Isagani), Joseph Grantusa (Basilio), Jack Yabut (Kumander Elias), Upeng Galang-Fernandez, Ernie Cloma, She Maala, Noemi Tabanao-Gonzales, Eric V. dela Cruz, Norbs Portales III, Raffy Tajeda, and Randy Villarama. First staged from 18 Jul to 26 Aug 2008 by the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) at the PETA Theater Center and different venues in the provinces. It was restaged in the same venue in Jul to Aug 2009. Later restaged by PETA in a Quezon City venue in Sep 2015.

The play focuses on Ibarra Marasigan, the idealistic new mayor of Maypajo town in the Southern Tagalog region.

In act 1, Ibarra enlists the support of his fiancé Clarissa Santos as well as key members of civil society, such as the parish priest, the barangay chairman, the principal of the local school, and childhood friends Basilio and Isagani, to introduce alternative livelihood programs to the town and stop logging operations in their area. Unbeknownst to Ibarra, certain community leaders, including the provincial commander Col Salvi Salvatiera, Bishop Damaso Villareal, and Ibarra’s future father-in-law Gov Santiago Santos, are connected to the illegal logging operations. A confrontation between Ibarra and the opposition leads to political maneuvers that radically upend Ibarra’s life—he is ousted from office, his fiancé is blackmailed into marrying Colonel Salvi, and his childhood friend and member of the National Liberation Army (NLA), Kumander Elias, is killed while helping Ibarra escape from prison.

 

Act 2 begins three years later. Ibarra has become the leader of the NLA going by the name Kumander Simoun. He makes plans to exact revenge on the people who wronged him and to liberate Maypajo. Meanwhile, the average townsfolk led by Basilio do their best to uplift their conditions through market cooperatives, overseas Filipino workers unions, and community service even if corrupt government and religious leaders still hold sway. While Basilio and Ibarra hope to improve the town’s situation, their means are radically different, with Ibarra advocating violent revolution and Basilio advocating social reform. Ibarra/Simoun’s plans to assassinate Colonel Salvi and save Clarissa fails and results in Clarissa’s death. Simoun’s allies soon turn on him for hijacking the revolution in favor of his own interests and expels him from the NLA. Ibarra/Simoun’s final, desperate ploy allows him to kill Salvi but results in his fatal wounding. In the epilogue, the surviving townsfolk and Basilio scatter Simoun’s ashes in the air and dream of a community that will no longer be burdened by social ills.

Noli at Fili Dekada 2000 is a modern retelling of Jose Rizal’s classic novels Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not) and El Filibusterismo (Subversion). While leaning closely to the structure of Rizal’s narrative, the play significantly differs in the emphasis on the pressing national concerns in the early 2000s such as deforestation, corruption, labor export policies and migrant workers, collusion between the government and church, and rebellion. The play was based on interviews with survivors of the flash flood in Infanta, Quezon.  Written by Mixkaela Z. Villalon

text:
(Touch Me Not: The Musical). 1995. Musical in three acts, in Filipino. Direction, Nonon Padilla; adaptation and libretto, Bienvenido Lumbera; musical direction, Ryan Cayabyab, set and costume design, Salvador Bernal, dramaturgy, Rody Vera; set design, Mio Infante; lights design, Masaaki Sano, choreography, Edna Vida. Cast: Monique Wilson/Gigi Posadas/Emy Punsalan-Cayabyab/Regine Velasquez (Maria Clara), Audie Gemora/John Arcilla (Crisostomo Ibarra), Bernardo Bernardo/Bodjie Pascua (Padre Damaso), Raul Roxas/Armand Malig (Padre Salvi and Elias), Eugene Villaluz/Sheila Francisco/Nanette Inventor (Donya Victorina), Lou Veloso/Ony de Leon/Garry Lim (Don Tiburcio de Espadaña), Pablo Molina (Kapitan Tiago), Irma Adlawan/Mia Ongkiko (Sisa), Clottie Gealogo (Tia Isabel), Emmanuel Bulalacao (leper), Roden Araneta, Victor Yamane, Mio Infante, and Rommel Singson. The musical was first staged by Tanghalang Pilipino on 10 Feb 1995 at the Cultural Center of the Philippines. It was restaged by Tanghalang Pilipino for its silver anniversary on 5 Aug 2011 at the Cultural Center of the Philippines under Audie Gemora’s direction, Jed Balsamo’s musical direction, Katsch SJ Catoy’s lights design, and Agnes Locsin’s choreography. The cast in the 2011 production were Cris Villonco (Maria Clara), Mark Bautista/Gian Magdangal (Crisostomo Ibarra), Jerald Napoles/Riki Benedicto (Elias), Al Gatmaitan (Padre Salvi), Ring Antonio (Donya Victorina), Garry Lim/Jonathan Tadioan (Don Tiburcio de Espadaña), Red Nuestro (Kapitan Tiago), Jenny Villegas (Tia Isabel), Angeli Bayani (Sisa), Bodjie Pascua (Padre Damaso), and Paolo Rodriguez (leper).

 

After years of staying in Europe, Crisostomo Ibarra arrives in the Philippines only to find out that his father Don Rafael is already dead. The first person he visits is his childhood friend and sweetheart Maria Clara and her father Kapitan Tiago. He relates an encounter with San Diego’s former parish priest Padre Damaso, who behaved coldly toward him despite his friendship with Don Rafael. As Kapitan Tiago dismisses him, he meets Maria Clara at the azotea (terrace) where they reaffirm their love for each other and plan their engagement. In the convent, Padre Damaso reveals that he has two letters containing the secret of Maria Clara’s birth—he is Maria Clara’s real father. He also reveals that he dislikes Ibarra for Maria Clara. Meanwhile, Ibarra goes to the cemetery where his father was interred, only to find that the body had been exhumed. The gravedigger admits to throwing the remains in the lake since he thought it a better fate for Don Rafael than to be buried in the Chinese cemetery, as originally instructed by the parish priest. Padre Salvi, the new parish priest of San Diego, brushes off Sisa who is looking for her missing sons Basilio and Crispin. There, Ibarra confronts Padre Salvi about his father’s disinterment, only for the gravedigger to reveal that Padre Damaso, not Padre Salvi, ordered it. Ibarra and Padre Salvi cross paths again at Kapitan Tiago’s house, where Ibarra, Maria Clara, and their friends meet before going to a picnic. The priest seemingly forgives Ibarra for his actions, even accepting the invitation to join them in the picnic and fishing at the lake. During the fishing, the nets are discovered to have entangled a crocodile. The boatman Elias, followed by Ibarra, jumps into the lake and successfully kills the crocodile. Later on, Ibarra and Tia Isabel talk about the new school he intends to put up in memory of his father with Padre Salvi, who disagrees with his ideas. Padre Salvi excuses himself, and begins plotting Ibarra’s downfall. The second act opens with the social-climbing couple Donya Victorina and Don Tiburcio de Espadaña making their grand entrance. Meanwhile, Kapitan Tiago reflects on his life: how he has befriended both the government and the church, how he has pandered to everyone, and how proud he is of having a daughter like Maria Clara. Later on, Padre Damaso has a talk with Kapitan Tiago, dissuading him on Maria Clara’s engagement to Ibarra. Meanwhile, Elias secretly approaches Ibarra who is out with Maria Clara and their other friends, and warns him of a plot against him. A leper receives the pity of Maria Clara, who gives him a necklace she received from Kapitan Tiago. Once the leper leaves, Ibarra asks Elias why he should be trusted, to which Elias replies that he owes him his life. He introduces himself as the boatman from that incident with the crocodile. Ibarra and several others go to the site where the school is to be built. There, an incident ensues when the derrick suddenly falls apart, dropping the heavy block of stone hanging from it. Ibarra is unhurt, the only casualty being the yellowish man who operated the machine. Ibarra realizes that Elias is right and there are people out to destroy him. At dinner that night, Padre Damaso belittles Ibarra’s foreign education and for putting up a school. It is only when Padre Damaso insults his father’s honor that Ibarra lunges at the priest with a knife in hand, threatening to kill him. Fortunately Maria Clara intervenes. In the convent, Padre Salvi discovers the letters containing the secret of Maria Clara’s birth, and resolves to use it as a way to steal her from Ibarra. Meanwhile, Ibarra and Maria Clara talk about Ibarra’s excommunication from the church, and promise to stay true to each other despite the obstacle. Maria Clara falls sick with fever, and the de Espadaña couple, with Don Tiburcio masquerading as a doctor, come over to heal her. His wife Donya Victorina intends to introduce her cousin Linares to Kapitan Tiago and Padre Damaso, a scheme to have him marry Maria Clara. Meanwhile, Maria Clara trades Ibarra’s letter for the two letters Padre Salvi has. The final act begins with the end of Ibarra’s excommunication. When he visits Maria Clara, he learns of the plans for her engagement with Linares. After, Ibarra meets with Elias at the lakeside. Elias suggests that because of Ibarra’s education and position in society, he can ask the Spanish government to implement radical reforms including fewer privileges for religious corporations, security for citizens and more respect for a man’s dignity. Ibarra objects and reasons that institutions such as the priesthood, religious corporations, and the civil guard are necessary evils that must be tolerated by the society. Meanwhile, Padre Salvi hatches an attack on the town, but intends to frame Ibarra for it. As Ibarra is arrested and thrown out of San Diego, an old man encourages him, saying that perhaps the country is not ready for the changes Ibarra is pushing for. Before Ibarra’s escape, he meets Maria Clara in secret one last time. There, Maria Clara reveals the secret contained in the letters. The play ends with Maria Clara and Ibarra bidding farewell to their love, before Maria joins the other nuns of the convent, while Ibarra stands powerless to do anything.

The 2011 production served as the launch of a national campaign, in cooperation with the Commision on Higher Education and the Department of Education, to encourage high school students to join forces with the Kabataang Rizal Movement to promote Rizal’s ideas and vision for the Philippines.

The musical has gone through several restagings since then, and toured several countries such as the United States, Malaysia, and Japan. In the 2011 Philippine Legitimate Stage Artists Group Gawad Buhay!, it won Outstanding Female Lead Performance in a Musical (Villonco), Outstanding Original Libretto, Outstanding Adaptation or Translation, and Outstanding Musical Composition.  Written by Ma. Clara Rosario C. Palma, with notes from Ronald H. Biñas

article.value: After years of staying in Europe, Crisostomo Ibarra arrives in the Philippines only to find out that his father Don Rafael is already dead. The first person he visits is his childhood friend and sweetheart Maria Clara and her father Kapitan Tiago. He relates an encounter with San Diego’s former parish priest Padre Damaso, who behaved coldly toward him despite his friendship with Don Rafael. As Kapitan Tiago dismisses him, he meets Maria Clara at the azotea (terrace) where they reaffirm their love for each other and plan their engagement. In the convent, Padre Damaso reveals that he has two letters containing the secret of Maria Clara’s birth—he is Maria Clara’s real father. He also reveals that he dislikes Ibarra for Maria Clara. Meanwhile, Ibarra goes to the cemetery where his father was interred, only to find that the body had been exhumed. The gravedigger admits to throwing the remains in the lake since he thought it a better fate for Don Rafael than to be buried in the Chinese cemetery, as originally instructed by the parish priest. Padre Salvi, the new parish priest of San Diego, brushes off Sisa who is looking for her missing sons Basilio and Crispin. There, Ibarra confronts Padre Salvi about his father’s disinterment, only for the gravedigger to reveal that Padre Damaso, not Padre Salvi, ordered it. Ibarra and Padre Salvi cross paths again at Kapitan Tiago’s house, where Ibarra, Maria Clara, and their friends meet before going to a picnic. The priest seemingly forgives Ibarra for his actions, even accepting the invitation to join them in the picnic and fishing at the lake. During the fishing, the nets are discovered to have entangled a crocodile. The boatman Elias, followed by Ibarra, jumps into the lake and successfully kills the crocodile. Later on, Ibarra and Tia Isabel talk about the new school he intends to put up in memory of his father with Padre Salvi, who disagrees with his ideas. Padre Salvi excuses himself, and begins plotting Ibarra’s downfall. The second act opens with the social-climbing couple Donya Victorina and Don Tiburcio de Espadaña making their grand entrance. Meanwhile, Kapitan Tiago reflects on his life: how he has befriended both the government and the church, how he has pandered to everyone, and how proud he is of having a daughter like Maria Clara. Later on, Padre Damaso has a talk with Kapitan Tiago, dissuading him on Maria Clara’s engagement to Ibarra. Meanwhile, Elias secretly approaches Ibarra who is out with Maria Clara and their other friends, and warns him of a plot against him. A leper receives the pity of Maria Clara, who gives him a necklace she received from Kapitan Tiago. Once the leper leaves, Ibarra asks Elias why he should be trusted, to which Elias replies that he owes him his life. He introduces himself as the boatman from that incident with the crocodile. Ibarra and several others go to the site where the school is to be built. There, an incident ensues when the derrick suddenly falls apart, dropping the heavy block of stone hanging from it. Ibarra is unhurt, the only casualty being the yellowish man who operated the machine. Ibarra realizes that Elias is right and there are people out to destroy him. At dinner that night, Padre Damaso belittles Ibarra’s foreign education and for putting up a school. It is only when Padre Damaso insults his father’s honor that Ibarra lunges at the priest with a knife in hand, threatening to kill him. Fortunately Maria Clara intervenes. In the convent, Padre Salvi discovers the letters containing the secret of Maria Clara’s birth, and resolves to use it as a way to steal her from Ibarra. Meanwhile, Ibarra and Maria Clara talk about Ibarra’s excommunication from the church, and promise to stay true to each other despite the obstacle. Maria Clara falls sick with fever, and the de Espadaña couple, with Don Tiburcio masquerading as a doctor, come over to heal her. His wife Donya Victorina intends to introduce her cousin Linares to Kapitan Tiago and Padre Damaso, a scheme to have him marry Maria Clara. Meanwhile, Maria Clara trades Ibarra’s letter for the two letters Padre Salvi has. The final act begins with the end of Ibarra’s excommunication. When he visits Maria Clara, he learns of the plans for her engagement with Linares. After, Ibarra meets with Elias at the lakeside. Elias suggests that because of Ibarra’s education and position in society, he can ask the Spanish government to implement radical reforms including fewer privileges for religious corporations, security for citizens and more respect for a man’s dignity. Ibarra objects and reasons that institutions such as the priesthood, religious corporations, and the civil guard are necessary evils that must be tolerated by the society. Meanwhile, Padre Salvi hatches an attack on the town, but intends to frame Ibarra for it. As Ibarra is arrested and thrown out of San Diego, an old man encourages him, saying that perhaps the country is not ready for the changes Ibarra is pushing for. Before Ibarra’s escape, he meets Maria Clara in secret one last time. There, Maria Clara reveals the secret contained in the letters. The play ends with Maria Clara and Ibarra bidding farewell to their love, before Maria joins the other nuns of the convent, while Ibarra stands powerless to do anything.

The 2011 production served as the launch of a national campaign, in cooperation with the Commision on Higher Education and the Department of Education, to encourage high school students to join forces with the Kabataang Rizal Movement to promote Rizal’s ideas and vision for the Philippines.

The musical has gone through several restagings since then, and toured several countries such as the United States, Malaysia, and Japan. In the 2011 Philippine Legitimate Stage Artists Group Gawad Buhay!, it won Outstanding Female Lead Performance in a Musical (Villonco), Outstanding Original Libretto, Outstanding Adaptation or Translation, and Outstanding Musical Composition.  Written by Ma. Clara Rosario C. Palma, with notes from Ronald H. Biñas

text:
(Nuclear I & II). 1982 (Nukleyar I), 1985 (Nukleyar II). Musical in Filipino. Direction, Manny Pambid and Khryss Adalia (I), and Al Santos (II); script, Al Santos; music, Joey Ayala; choreography, Maribel Legarda and Mimi Villareal; production design, Soxy Topacio (I), Boy Aquino Jr (II); props/masks, Jun Saturay; set, Ric de Leon; mural, Papu de Asis. Cast: Paul Galang, Joey Ayala, Gwenn Galvez, Khryss Adalia, Nuklus, Jake Nebreja, Jervin Sy, Atchen Cabaquing, Ronnie Quesada, and the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) Kalinangan Ensemble (I); Jojo Atienza, Willie Casero, Jopye Dizon, Mary Joan Fajardo, Ric de Leon, Melvin Lee, Maribel Legarda, Phil Noble, Mae Paner, Ditchay Roxas, Gamay Sta. Ines, Rody Vera, Mimi Villareal, Ellen Ongkeko, Carme Sanchez, Ricky Malulo, Bing Austria, Ernie Cloma, Bodgie Pascua, Kitteh Lopez, Connie Lauigan-Chua, and Ronnie Quesada (II). Nukleyar I was first staged by PETA in 1982 at the Dulaang Rajah Sulayman in Fort Santiago, Intramuros, Manila, while Nukleyar II was staged in 1985 in the same venue. Nukleyar II was published in Kamao: Mga Dula ng Protesta 1970-1986 (Fist: Plays of Protest 1970-1986), 1982.

Nukleyar is a two-part dramatization that utilizes the rock-music idiom through narrative, dance, and music to tell of the present-day threat to the human race: nuclear annihilation.

 

Nukleyar I dramatizes the unending quest for knowledge as one discovers life’s mysteries such as fire and, finally, atomic fission. This discovery leads to the development of nuclear weapons that governments and the military are exploiting, beginning with the setting up of large laboratories for its manufacture. Nukleyar II showcases the bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki during World War II as death continues to hound those who survived the holocaust. It also chronicles the series of events that led to the present-day arms race. Superpowers, shown as dancing “angels of death,” position their weapons and targets to serve as deterrents to any nuclear attack from the opposite camp. A speculative situation arises in which strategy fails, and the red button of doom has to be pressed. Whoever survives the nuclear holocaust will emerge the victor. With no means of protecting themselves, people run as fast and as far away as they can, not knowing that the effect of a nuclear explosion can reach a radius of thousands of miles. Carrying their santos and rosaries, these people desperately seek the power of prayer to deliver them from what seems a nightmare. At this point, the gigantic figure of Inang Bayan (Mother Land), symbol of unity, appears from above. The entire cast enjoins the audience to put an end to the arms race so that the world may have a peaceful tomorrow.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis

 

Source:

Atienza, Glecy C. 1990. “Subersyon sa Dula sa Ilalilm ng Batas Militar: Mga Dula ng PETA 1975-1981.” MA thesis, College of Arts and Letters, University of the Philippines Diliman.

photos.desc: Peryante’s Oratoryo ng Bayan, 1984 (CCP Collection)

text:
(People’s Oratorio). 1983. Play in 10 scenes, in Filipino. Direction, Apolonio B. Chua; script, Rody Vera and Alan Glinoga; music, Lutgardo Labad, Ronnie Quesada, Louie Pascasio, Lucien Letaba, Noel Kintanar, Upeng Galang, Linus Sto. Tomas, and Kitteh Lopez. Cast: Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) Kalinangan Ensemble. First staged by PETA on 30 Dec 1983 at the Dulaang Rajah Sulayman in Fort Santiago, Manila. Subsequently staged by Peryante and Patatag in 1984 at the Palma Hall lobby in the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman, then in 1985 at the College Cafeteria of the Ateneo de Manila University in Quezon City, the parking lot of the College of Medicine of UP Manila, and at the UP College in Baguio. It was published in The Politics of Culture: The Philippine Experience, 1984, edited by Nicanor G. Tiongson.

The play is divided into 11 cantos or songs, each dealing with a particular provision of the Human Rights Declaration of the United Nations, 1948. Additional material is taken from the poetry of Amado V. Hernandez, Andres Bonifacio, Jose Corazon de Jesus, Francisco Baltazar, Rio Alma, Bienvenido Lumbera, Jose F. Lacaba, and Pablo Neruda. Highly improvisational, each provision is dramatized in the context of Philippine reality, interspersed with vignettes, choruses, mime, dances, and songs. Canto 1 is the prologue, showing a mother singing her baby to sleep because the “Old, Lightning’s Knife” is burning bright. Canto 2 dramatizes the right not only of individuals but of entire peoples to life and self-determination, which must be respected by other governments and peoples. Canto 3 presents a journalist who speaks on government and peoples, the right to form publications that will expose the truth, and the muzzling of the mass media in the Philippines. Canto 4 exposes the problems of peasants and workers who do not have the right to be heard and to protest and strike. Canto 5 underscores the right to go to school and get a nationalist education. Canto 6 focuses on the right to militant protest against the image-building projects and development projects of the discredited Marcos government. Canto 7 speaks of the right to forge one’s own culture and reject the culture of the oppressor, who seeks to mask the ugly realities of poverty, and to propagate a colonial, escapist culture. Canto 8 demands respect for the minorities. Canto 9 is a powerful indictment of military torture, hamletting, and salvaging in the Philippines. Canto 10 exposes American imperialist control of the Philippine economy. The final canto summarizes all the songs of the oratorio and the nine articles of the True and Free Declaration. The Oath to Freedom, Justice, and Self-Determination is recited and the oratorio ends with the same mother singing a song to waken her child, and tell her of the country’s hopes for freedom and self-determination.

 

Oratoryo ng Bayan strung together a series of skits and songs, in serious or comic mold, to underscore the oppressive nature of the Marcos regime. The juxtaposition of scenes (e.g., the irreverent spoof on government projects and the caricature of personalities), followed by the heavy soulful songs narrating the kinds of tortures perpetrated by the military, enables the oratorio to touch a whole range of emotions in its audience. The Peryante version used different street theater forms such as bodabil, newspaper theater, mock ballet, and choral recitation.  Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

 

Source

Tiongson, Nicanor G., ed. 1984b. The Politics of Culture: The Philippine Experience. Record of the proceedings and anthology of essays, poems, songs, skits and plays of the MAKIISA I People’s Culture Festival, Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Fort Santiago, Intramuros, Manila, 28-30 Dec 1983. Manila: PETA and PRC-PARUD.

text:
(Orosman and Zafira). ca 1857-60. Komedya in three acts, in Filipino. Script, Francisco “Balagtas” Baltazar. Orosman at Zafira is believed to be one of a number of komedya written by Balagtas for the Teatro de Tondo between 1857 and 1860 while in prison. It is known to have been staged in Batangas by a certain Simeon Luz. In the 20th century, it was first staged by Teatro Pilipino at the Little Theater, later Tanghalang Aurelio V. Tolentino, of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) in 1977. Direction and design, Rolando S. Tinio; music, Lucrecia R. Kasilag; lighting design, Teddy L.Hilado. Cast: Tommy Abuel (Orosman), Celeste Legaspi (Zafira), Aurelio Estanislao, Rey Malte Cruz, Willie Esposo, Jose Mari Avellana, Nomer Son, Dads Habito, Ella Luansing, Gary Reyes, Sol Oca, Jose Ocampo, Bon Vibar, Ding Navasero, Rudy de Leon, Rene Requiestas, Bert Olivar, Paul Araneta, Jarro Cambe, Alex Francisco, Froilan Managnan, Bert Moreno, Ronnie Moreno, Dante Ornedo, and Rolly Tan. The University of the Philippines (UP) Anak-Tibawan, under the direction of Jonas Sebastian, staged the play in 1989 in UP Manila. In 1993, Sebastian restaged it for Tanghalang Pilipino at the Tanghalang Aurelio V. Tolentino of the CCP with Irma Adlawan-Marasigan and Alan Paule in the title roles. In 2008, Dulaang UP staged a modern musical adaptation of the play as part of the Komedya Fiesta hosted by UP. The production was received with much critical acclaim, and was restaged by Dulaang UP for its 35th season in 2010, and at the SM Mall of Asia Arena in 2011. In 2012, Orosman and Zafira was presented in the 4th National Theater Festival, as a collaboration between Dulaang UP and CCP. The 1932 typescript based on an 1877 script was found by Buenaventura S. Medina Jr in the Julian Cruz Balmaseda Collection of the National Library. This was later edited and introduced by Medina Jr and published by De La Salle University Press, 1990.

 

This verse play is about warring kingdoms in the Middle East. Boulasem, gran pasha (a political and military rank or title in the Ottoman Empire) of Tedents or Flea, suspects the Sultan Mahamud of Marruecos of hatching a plot to kill him. He has the latter assassinated. His sons Abdalap and Orosman meet and fall madly in love with Zafira, the murdered sultan’s beautiful daughter—to the woe of Zelima, Abdalap’s sweetheart and daughter of the almansor earlier deposed by Mahamud. While Zafira vows revenge on Boulasem and all his kin and repeatedly repulses Abdalap’s attentions and preferred protection, she falls in love with Orosman, who time and again snatches her from danger. Defeated in her first battle, Zafira joins forces with Zelim, pasha of Duquela and another aspirant to the throne of Marruecos, for another bid to overthrow Boulasem. Partly through treachery, Boulasem’s army under Abdalap’s command wins again. After this triumph, Abdalap dethrones and exiles his father, who had forbidden his love for Zafira and ordered him to wed Gulnara instead. Abdalap then dishonors Zelima, orders Gulnara to be forced into his seraglio on the morrow, jails Orosman, and threatens Zafira to have Orosman beheaded in her presence if she does not capitulate to his desire. Moving swiftly, Zafira, Zelima, and Gulnara join Zelim and Aldervesin in hatching and executing a plan that leads Abdalap to his death by Zelima’s sword—and Orosman out of prison and up to the throne of Marruecos.

Orosman at Zafira deviates from standard komedya formulae: there is no Moro-Christian conflict, and heroes as well as villains are such because of character rather than religion.  Written by T. Gonzales, updated by Athena Angela Aquino

text:
(The Musician’s Return). 1978. One-act play in Filipino. Direction, Antonio O. Mabesa; script, Nonilon V. Queaño; stage management, Fred de Leon; artistic direction, Joonee Gamboa; music and sound, Joeprey Marian. Cast: Nil Buan (Saro), Sally Santiago (Dolor), Jojo Nacion (Pepe), Alner Alonzo (Huse), Rhodora Montemayor (Lucila), Alfie Alonzo (Karlos), Deo Aguinaldo (Felix), and June Evangelista (woman). First staged by the University of the Philippines College Baguio (UPCB) Summer Theater Arts Workshop at the UPCB Auditorium in Baguio City on 12 May 1978. The script is included in the playwright’s collection of plays titled Ang Katutubo at Dalawa Pang Dula (The Native and Two More Plays), 1983.

The play is about a family whose luck in the city has run out and is forced to return to the barrio. Headed by Saro and his wife Dolor, they settle in an unfinished house by the cemetery in the small town where Saro grew up. While daughter Lucila tends to the plants around the house, she encounters a woman who asks for some of Lucila’s roses. The woman boasts about her vast garden filled with all kinds of flowers. Lucila asks to visit the garden sometime. The woman agrees and leaves saying that she needs to find her husband. As she leaves, the woman sings a song about a lost lover. Meanwhile, Saro meets up with an old friend Huse, and the two reminisce about their time as musicians. Saro remembers the city’s filth and delights in his hometown’s rich soil and fresh air. Huse insists that their town is no longer the heaven that Saro remembers it to be. He speaks of the troubles their musician friends went through, about the farmers going hungry, the thugs terrorizing the townsfolk, and the selfishness that now marks the townspeople. The family has dinner while listening to the broadcast of a radio play written by their firstborn Pepe about two separated lovers—an affluent woman and a man barely surviving as a broadcaster and playwright. Their second son, Karlos, who was assaulted by thugs, is brought home by Saro’s old friend and the cemetery’s caretaker Felix. Saro finds that Felix has been doing better than when they were still musicians. Their conversation is interrupted when Huse arrives and accuses Felix of molesting his daughter. Felix denies this and before things escalate into a fistfight, Saro convinces them to sleep it off and meet as friends the day after. Toward the end, when all is settled, the family hears someone sobbing. They find the woman, whom Lucila spoke with. She says that she could not find her husband. The family tries to comfort her by saying that he will surely return. Saro asks the woman where she lives and she points to the cemetery.

Written and staged during martial law, the play brings attention to the plight of the informal settlers who have nowhere else to go and are forced to live in a space reserved for the dead. The script received an honorable mention from the Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature in 1977.  Written by Athena Angela Aquino

text:
(Love for the Native Land). 1902. Sarsuwela in Cebuano. Direction and script, Vicente Sotto. Cast: Celestina de la Cerna, Natalia Bondoc, Wenceslao Rosales, Filomeno Roble, Marciano Ufana, Valeriano Ragor, Leon Violango, Pedro Noel, and Cristina Bugtong. First staged by Vicente Sotto on 1 Jan 1902 at the Teatro Junquera, later Teatro Oriente, in Cebu City. The text of Ang Paghigugma sa Yutang Natawhan was printed by Sotto’s Imprenta Filipina in 1902.

Sotto, who criticized the linambay (stage play in verse) and religious plays that were the staple of Cebuano-language theater in his time, was challenged by a friend to produce an alternative play. He wrote Ang Paghigugma saYutang Natawhan over a period of three days in Dec 1901. He then proceeded to conscript players from among friends and employees at his press. Rehearsals were held at the Club Popular on corner Norte America, later D. Jakosalem St, and Colon St. The play proved to be a success and “everyone from the richest to the poorest came to the theater” (Bag-ong Kusog 1924).

 

The action of the play is set in Cebu in 1897 and tells of the abuses of Spanish rule, personified by a materialistic, cruel, and lecherous Augustinian friar, who gets punished with the triumph of the revolution. The simple plot is built around the love of Maming and Ricardo and the obstacles put in its way by the friar and the backward-thinking mother of Maming, Señora Tiay.

The play was so successful it earned a net income of more than 1,000 pesos on the first night. It earned much more in later performances. Most importantly, it opened up the possibility of plays that spoke of contemporary realities.  Written by Resil B. Mojares

 

Sources

Bag-ong Kusog. 1924.

Mojares, Resil B. 1985. Theater in Society, Society in Theater: Social History of a Cebuano Village 1840-1940. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

Ramas, Wilhelmina Q. 1982. Sugbuanon Theater from Sotto to Rodriguez to Kabahar: An Introduction to Pre-War Sugbuanon Drama. Quezon City: Asian Center, University of the Philippines.

text:
(Love for the Native Land). Sarsuwela in three acts, in Bikol. Script, Asisclo Jimenez. The script was finished on 23 Apr 1907 in Sorsogon. The date of its first staging is unknown. It was published in Philippine Drama: Twelve Plays in Six Philippine Languages, 1987.

The play is set during the revolution against Spain. Alfredo must go to war, but his wife Conchita is torn between her personal concerns and her duty to country. She eventually allows her husband to go. In his absence, the guardias civiles (constables) pester her with suspicions and accusations but she shows mettle and spirit. When the Spaniards insult her and spank her helper Esteban, she fights back, oblivious of her own safety. The guardias civiles, who think she is naive, congregate in her house and prepare to entrap Alfredo there. Unknown to them, she schemes to have them wiped out by the Katipunero. Alfredo and his men make a surprise attack and eventually defeat the Spaniards. The play ends in rejoicing for Alfredo and his men.

Pagkamoot revolves around the idea that love and sacrifice triumph over the ruthless and powerful. Striving to protect her husband and country, Conchita puts up a resistance against the guardias civiles who restrict her movement. In this play, Jimenez demonstrates that national change can be effected by armed revolt. Pagkamoot was very popular in Sorsogon.  Written by Maria Lilia F. Realubit

article_title: Ang Paglalakbay ni Sisa: Isang Noh sa Laguna

photos.desc: UP Center for International Studies’ “Dance of Sisa,” an excerpt from Ang Paglalakbay ni Sisa: Isang Noh sa Laguna, UP Diliman, 2006 (UPCIS)

text:
(Sisa’s Journey: A Noh in Laguna). 1977. Noh drama. Direction, Antonio Mabesa; script, Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio; set design, Monino S. Duque; costumes and mask design, Salvador Bernal; lighting design, Audie San Juan; choreography, Corazon Generoso-Iñigo; special panels design, Jose Joya. Cast: Tonton Santos, Antonio Mabesa, Pitt Albano, Mario Trio, Chito Roño, George Carag, Laura Centeno, Anton Juan Jr, Dennis Marasigan, Amihan Bonifacio, Monnette E. Alfon, Antee Bass, Amy Flores, Mariquita Magat, Fely Luz Marcos, Ruth Pambid, Suzette Querubin, Marla Sagun, Felipe M. de Leon Jr, and Jonathan Malicsi. First staged on 1 Sep 1977 at the Abelardo Theater of the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music in Diliman. It was choreographed by Corazon Generoso-Iñigo for the UP Filipiniana Dance Group on 7 Mar 1978 at the University Theater of the UP Diliman, and by the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Dance Company for their 1978-79 season at the CCP. The UP production was set to the music of Ohana-Pipo with the dance cast led by Nadine Guytingco, Douglas Nierras, Jinn Ibarrola, and Alex Lanag, while Laura Centeno and Tonton Santos led the vocal cast. In the CCP production, music was by Lucrecia R. Kasilag, set and costume design by Salvador Bernal, lighting design by Monino S. Duque with lead dancers Alice Reyes, Nonoy Froilan, Jinn Ibarrola, and Nes Jardin. In 1992, it was staged by UP Anak-Tibawan under the direction of Khryss Adalia at the Philamlife Auditorium in Manila. In 2006, Paglalakbay was staged by the UP Center for International Studies (UPCIS) under the direction of Noh Grandmaster for Shite Naohiko Umekawa, then restaged by Jina Umali for UPCIS in 2012, 2013, and 2014.

 

The play is set in Laguna and built around characters in Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1887, seen as souls unable to find rest. Padre Salvi reaches the long, narrow bridge in search of the woman to whom, in life, he had been unjust. His journey is an act of penitence; every step he takes is like walking knee-deep in a mire of ashes. Every moment, he is assailed by his conscience, as shadows of the past creep into his senses. The priest returns to his former parish to fulfill a promise: to pray over the grave of Sisa, and to ask for forgiveness. Along the way, he meets two fishers and two woodcutters, carrying on their backs the day’s labor: cut wood and a net of fish. From them he finds out that Sisa has been cremated, and no one knows where her body and that of the man Elias were burned. The restless soul of Sisa roams the surface of the earth, dressed in a bright yellow gown of jusi adorned with gold beads, but underneath she still wears her old, patched clothes. Masked by a yellow ribbon, she walks very slowly, and at times swings her body round in full abandon. Her two sons, Crispin and Basilio, also roam the earth barefoot, masked, and wearing the patched black shirts and loose pants of their poverty. Amazed, Padre Salvi falters in his speech when he asks the woman if she is Sisa. He wails, seeing the woman who would not allow his mind to rest. She, whom he thought was in ashes, is now standing before him, cursing him for his unjust treatment of her children and family. Sisa recalls her frailty, freezing with fright, feeling the pain of her children’s bruised palms whenever she heard the church bells ring. Her children who were her only joy had been wrongly accused of stealing church money, and the iniquitous priest beat them and locked them up inside the church tower. Basilio escapes, and seeing his mother walking aimlessly in the streets, calls out and runs to her, tears streaming down his cheeks. Sisa, thinking the calls were those of her accusers, runs and hides behind a wall. Basilio climbs the wall to convince his mother that it is her beloved son, calling out to her. He loses his balance and falls in front of Sisa, who recognizes him. The sight of her bloodied son snaps Sisa’s last thread of sanity. Branded as a prostitute, a leech, and mother of thieves, she realizes that the dignity of the poor is as thin as a strand of thread. With her last breath Sisa bewails the misfortunes of her poor family, as she accepts the fire that burns every inch of her body, in that darkest and longest day of her life. As the sea calms, Padre Salvi asks Sisa to calm the raging waves in his heart as he promises to pray always for her soul. Sisa thanks the priest, but tells him to pray for himself, a slave of his own weaknesses. As she bids goodbye, Sisa repeats the last words uttered by Elias before he breathed his last: “I shall die without even seeing the break of dawn … in my beloved country; you, who shall witness this event, do not forget us, who fell in the midst of the dark night.”

The play adapts the idea (restless souls) and technique (slow movement, chanting) of a Japanese Noh drama, using a koro or chorus (as in the pasyon) to narrate the movement of a play carved out from the Noli, and thus from Philippine fiction and history. Paglalakbay won third prize in the CCP Literary Contest in 1976.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis
