text:
(The Trial of Old Serapio). 1969. One-act play in Filipino. Direction and script, Paul Dumol. Cast: Clifford Hawkins Jr, Michael Escaler, Augusto Lopez-Dee, Eugenio Perez Jr, Cristino Panlilio, Roberto Vergara, Romulo Ramirez, Renato Claravall, Jose Nolan, Guillermo Gutierrez, Roberto Crisol, Rene Bermio, David Garcia, and Felix Naval. It was first staged at the Ateneo High School in 1969. It was also staged by the Philippine Educational Theater Association at the Dulaang Rajah Sulayman in Fort Santiago, Manila, in 1970, under the direction of Joy Soler and Jonas Sebastian, and in 1971, under the direction of Felix Padilla Jr aka Nonon Padilla. It was used by the Cultural Center of the Philippines in its First National Drama Competition in 1989.

This play is about man’s inhumanity to man, and the hope that glimmers even in the bleakest lives. It centers on the trial of Mang Serapio, a beggar, by his peers. The charge: taking care of a child, which is forbidden by the beggars’ federation because it diverts money from the group’s coffers. Before the hukom (judge), two tagapagtanong (examiners) question Mang Serapio, revealing not only his circumstances but the rules of the federation. He is classified as karaniwan (ordinary) because he has no special talent or trick; does not rent a child as prop; play a musical instrument; or pretend to be deaf, blind, lame, or mute; nor does he have a real disability. Mang Serapio denies the accusation, and the witnesses bring forth a trunk taken from his hovel, in which is found a doll, the “Sol” they had heard him addressing. Mang Serapio is revealed to be a widower whose only child, Sol, had been run over by a jeep three years earlier. The court taunts him by tossing the doll about as he begs for it, then orders his eyes gouged out—so that he would ascend to a better “class” of beggar. The play closes with the unang tagapagtanong (first examiner) asking the audience to understand that they had to blind Mang Serapio because he taught the beggars to dream of the impossible—a humane life.

It won first prize in the Paligsahang Pandulaan of the Dulaang Sibol of Ateneo in 1969.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

text:
(After the Darkness). 1920. Sarsuwela in three acts, in Tagalog. Libretto, Precioso Palma; music, Leon Ignacio. First staged in 1920 with Atang de la Rama as Estrella, it ran for 116 performances. A major revival was by Rolando S. Tinio in 1969 for Ateneo de Manila University, staged at the Girl Scouts of the Philippines Auditorium on Padre Faura St, with Noemi Manikan (Estrella), G. V. Misa (Ricardo), Sonia Malasarte-Roco (Caridad), Joy Soler (Maring), Daisy Avellana (Doña Carmen), Jimmy Asencio (Don Torcuato), Toto Malvar, Laurice Guillen, Ella Luansing, Ditas Rivera, Leo Rialp, Nicanor Tiongson, Dez Bautista, Rodolfo Dula, and Edwin Santayana, among others. In 1991 it was staged by Tanghalang Pilipino at the Cultural Center of the Philippines’s (CCP) Tanghalang Aurelio V. Tolentino under the direction of Nonon Padilla with Noemi Manikan-Gomez as Estrella and Celeste Legaspi as Caridad. The text of the play, together with cassette tapes of one performance and a minus one of the same performance, was published by CCP in its sarsuwela series in 1991 to aid those who want to mount the play.

This sarsuwela is one of the most famous in the country. Act 1 opens on the grounds of Club Bagongtao, where a party is ongoing to celebrate Ricardo’s having finished his course in medicine. His friend Martin deems it a “new weapon” that can open new paths: to finding a beautiful wife who can accompany him to a career in politics, and giving him license to kill with impunity. Ricardo loves Estrella, a mahinhing dalaga (demure maiden), but is being pursued by Caridad, a flirt. Caridad’s mother, Doña Carmen, talks rich and dresses young, while her father, Don Torcuato, lives in his past since he figured in the Revolution of 1898. Ricardo’s buddies (Martin, Felipe, and Luis) and Estrella’s friends (Maring, Liling, and Pakita) aid and abet the action.

 

Act 2 transfers the cast and action to the countryside, where Ricardo hosts a picnic for his friends. Love is blossoming between Ricardo and Estrella, while Caridad is determined to make him her fiancé. She plies him with champagne, and when they emerge from the fisher’s hut at the palaisdaan (fishpond), her parents demand that he uphold her honor.

Act 3 opens on Maring’s birthday party, with all the friends present except Estrella, who sends a present and a letter explaining the sadness in her heart. When Estrella arrives, Ricardo declares himself, explains that he was not at fault, and is forgiven. Their engagement is announced, to Caridad’s consternation. When Ricardo is confronted by Doña Carmen, he produces proof of a liaison between Caridad and Don Juanito, and all ends well for the sweethearts.

Paglipas ng Dilim is a pleasant comedy of manners that presents and comments on Filipinos when they were turning from their Spanish to their Yankee years. Caridad, Martin, Luis, and Felipe sing comic songs about manggang hilaw (unripe mango) with shy innuendo, Chabacano, and the Japanese girls in the Sampaloc district. Paquita is teased by all about her attempts to speak English. Doña Carmen and Don Torcuato speak Spanish and live in the past. The traditional Filipina in Estrella is given the bold Caridad as foil, and the hero is no longer the poet of old but the doctor, a professional of the new world.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

text:
(Burst of Light). 1980. Three-act play in Tagalog. Direction, Adul de Leon; script, Jose Y. Dalisay Jr; production design, Jun Flavier-Pablo; lighting design, Tony Espejo; sounds, Noel Calimpong. Cast: Mary Walter, Juan Rodrigo, Tommy Abuel, Cora Alforja, Jennifer Decolongon, Jonathan Romulo, Ray Ventura, Aurora Yumol, Ed Murillo, and Mabbi Vasallo. First staged by Bulwagang Gantimpala on 3 Oct 1980 at the Bulwagang Gantimpala, later Tanghalang Huseng Batute, of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). It was staged by the Tanghalang Ateneo in 1986 under the direction of John Flores at Ateneo de Manila University and by the University of the Philippines (UP) Repertory Company in 1991 under the direction of Chris Martinez at the Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero Theater of UP Diliman. It was published in Mithi 3, 1985, edited by Virgilio S. Almario. With another play, it is also published as Pagsabog ng Liwanag/Aninag, Anino: Dalawang Dula ng Naantalang Rebolusyon (Burst of Light/Glimmer, Shadow: Two Plays on the Stalled Revolution), 1996.

The story of this play in Tagalog is set during the period before and after World War II, from 1931 to 1951. The three sons of Señora Aurora were born during the turbulent days of the Filipino-American War. They reached adulthood during the Japanese occupation. They meet for the last time during the last attempts of the Filipino revolutionary forces to regain the war from the American forces who claim victory over the Japanese imperialists.

Within the ranks of the revolutionaries, there are contradictions between members who believe in arms as the principal instrument for liberation and those who do not. Within the family, only Señora Aurora’s concern remains constant: a mother will always be a mother to her children whatever they become.

 

Señora Aurora’s eldest son, Homer, a graduate of Penn State College, is a lawyer and hopeless ideologue who romanticizes the revolution, his Marxist-Leninist theories, even his love for an American, Lizzie. He brings home his radical ideas and forms a radical group, in which he involves his younger brother Aristeo, who has been an armchair revolutionary all this time. Failing to apply his theories to the present conditions of his country, Homer resigns from his post as political education officer of the central committee, believing that radicalism has turned his family into a bunch of cold-blooded executioners.

Aristeo develops into a real revolutionary, committed but always seeking answers to his questions, and refusing to blind himself to what he sees as the inherent contradictions of Marxist-Leninist theories. A writer, he has a firm grasp of Philippine reality during that time and sees armed struggle as a mere tactical move to even out the odds against the superior arms of the Japanese. He dies in the anti-Japanese struggle, in the middle of writing his own autobiography after politicizing his younger brother, Jaime.

Jaime dreams of being the best photographer in the field, but the war wipes out his future. Out of frustration, he learns to make homemade bombs to avenge everything that made his life miserable. Finally, Jaime falls under the influence of his brother Aristeo, who tempers and reorients his anger and tells him to put mind over emotion, and politics over gunpowder. Aristeo asks Jaime to join the anti-Japanese resistance movement, and later on he becomes an important leader.

War ends and Jaime becomes disheartened when the Filipino anti-Japanese forces are massacred, and suppressed by the American forces who now lay absolute claim to victory over the retreating Japanese forces. Aristeo is buried in the central plains and Homer is reduced to an opportunistic lawyer who earns from helping the rich reclaim the wealth they lost during the war. On the run, Jaime has a last mission to accomplish: to annihilate Homer, whom he believes has betrayed him and Aristeo, and the revolution Homer himself convinced them to join.

Homer knows that he has a political debt to pay, and fears the day when his youngest brother would come to collect it. One day, before break of dawn, Jaime finally arrives, worn-out and restless. Afraid that the authorities would trace Jaime to the house and consequently find out his previous involvement ending his career, Homer pulls out his gun to drive out his brother, but it is too late. Jaime has already planted a bomb by the door, and carries another in a box; both are timed to explode simultaneously. Señora Aurora, awakened by her sons’ voices, comes out of her room to welcome her children. At that moment, the whole house explodes, in a “burst of light.”

Pagsabog carries a strong statement about revolutions and revolutionaries. It underscores the danger of revolutionary theories that are not adapted to actual conditions. It also indicts revolutionaries who join the revolution for selfish motives and undergo no real remolding of character. Although it speaks of another period in the past, its insights into the revolutionary movement are very relevant to the present, specifically to movements with similar concerns as those of the anti-Japanese underground. The play won an honorable mention in the CCP Playwriting Contest of 1980.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis

text:
(People’s Worship). 1977. Three-act play in English. Direction, Leo Rimando; script and translation, Bonifacio Ilagan. Cast: Members of the National Council of Churches in the Philippines (NCCP). Pagsambang Bayan was written for a liturgical conference of NCCP in Hong Kong in 1976. Later, Ilagan expanded and translated it into Filipino, which was the version staged in the Philippines. The Filipino translation was first staged by the University of the Philippines (UP) Repertory Company on 18 Aug 1977 at the Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero Theater in UP Diliman, under the direction of Behn Cervantes and set design by Rafael del Casal. The cast includes: Orestes Ojeda, Jerry Fernandez, Armand Sta. Ana, Madeleine Nicolas, Ces Mangay, Nimfa Camacho, Rene Agbayani, Cris Gosalvez, Teza Mendoza, and the UP Repertory Company ensemble. It was toured by the same company to different schools, and in 1980 and 1984 was restaged at the original venue. Other productions were reportedly done by various groups in Manila, Pampanga, Cebu, Dagupan, and Iligan. The play has been translated into Bikol, Ilocano, Pampango, Cebuano, and Waray, and has had at least 100 performances until 1984. It was published in Kamao: Mga Dula ng Protesta 1970-1986 (Fist: Plays of Protest 1970-1986), 1987, edited by Alfrredo Navarro Salanga et al.

The play takes on the structure of the Catholic Mass as a theological instrument and symbol, with the priest not merely an interpreter of the Word or the world but an active participant in changing both. An altar at center stage is the focus of action, and around the celebrant is a congregation of peasants, workers, students, tribal minorities, urban poor and professionals, interacting with the priest and relating their daily struggles.

The Mass has three divisions: the Preparation, the Consecration, and the Communion. In part 1, the Gospel is read, followed by the sermon, with the parable of the Good Samaritan as theme. The scene is simultaneously enacted in mime, depicting Inang Pilipinas (Mother Philippines) as under attack from three robbers costumed as imperialism, feudalism, and bureaucrat-capitalism. Two men of prominent and noble positions ignore the prostrate victim, while the Samaritan, shown as a peasant or laborer (or in Pagsambang Bayan II, 1980, an armed man from the hills), comes to her aid. Part 2 is a symbolic transformation of bread and wine into Christ’s body and blood. As the people participate in the transformation, they themselves are transformed, just as the priest in the play is, dedicating himself to the pursuit of peace and equality and to the liberation of the poor and oppressed. Part 3 is a collective partaking of the body and blood of Christ. The sacrament of the Holy Eucharist and the Thanksgiving are meaningfully depicted in the play as the priest changes from liturgical robes into the attire of the masses, and ties a bolo to his waist, showing his union with the people and acceptance of his new role as a coworker and liberator. As the ritual draws to a close, the priest and congregation become one in stirring resolve to continue Christ’s work in this world in the only manner that can be considered meaningful today.

 

Pagsambang Bayan I featured a communion of puto (rice cake); a collection for the urban poor, detainees, and others; and hymns and biblical passages relevant to the issues of the time incorporated in the lines. Pagsambang Bayan III, staged after the Aquino assassination, was much more direct in its protest, featuring slide projections that laid the blame for the Aquino murder squarely at the
feet of the Marcos regime.

Since the play was staged during the martial law period, fear of military harassment and arrest was always in the air; in fact, Cervantes, together with the musical director, was arrested during the 21 Sep 1977 performance in a Tondo slum area. Ilagan, fresh from a 22-month detention, was ordered to submit a copy of the play. A production in Samar never opened due to military harassment. International papers and magazines mentioned the play as a sign of the resurgent people’s movement and the early cracking of the Marcos rule.

Pagsambang Bayan won in the 1977 Palihang Aurelio V. Tolentino playwriting contest.  Written by Bonifacio Ilagan and Malou L. Maniquis

 

 

Source

UP Repertory Company. 1977. Pagsambang Bayan. Souvenir program.

text:
(Valentin’s Palace). 1998. Sarsuwela in Filipino. Direction and set design, Antonio Mabesa; libretto, Mario O’Hara; costume design, Ogie Juliano; lighting design, Amiel Leonardia. Cast: Julienne Mendoza (Valentin), Banaue Miclat (Diding), Maynard Penalosa (Alfonso), Mirren Alvarez (Carlota), and Luther Gumia (Toto). First staged by the University of the Philippines (UP) Playwrights Theater at the Tanghalang Hermogenes Ilagan (Faculty Center lobby), UP Diliman, 1999. Full production was carried out by the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) to inaugurate the new PETA Theater Center in Quezon City in Sep-Oct 2005, under the direction of Soxie Topacio; set design, Boni Juan; costume design, Ogie Juliano; music, Minda Azarcon; choreography, Maribel Legarda; cast, Nonie Buencamino (Valentin), Cynthia Culig-Guico and She Maala (Diding), Chinggoy Alonso and Cesar Xerez Burgos (Alfonso), Gigette Reyes (Carlota), Chris Anthony Gonzales (Toto), Jude Edgar Balsamo, Vincent de Jesus, CJ Javier, Jeffrey Hernandez, Jess Evardone, and Ernie Cloma.

It is the evening of the 7th of Dec 1941, the day before the Japanese warplanes dropped the first bombs on Intramuros. In an old theater that shows old Tagalog movies, Valentin, the theater projectionist, is drinking with Toto, the young janitor that Valentin hired. On his natal day, Valentin ends up narrating his life story. The characters of that story enter from the past.

 

Diding, the beautiful daughter of Senyor Marcelo, Valentin’s piano teacher, has been the object of his affection since they were children. Senyor Alfonso, the owner of the theater and producer of the sarsuwela, recruits Diding, who wants to be an actress. Alfonso asks Valentin to teach Diding the songs, and Valentin obliges but demands that Diding should communicate not with her beauty but with her soul. Carlota, Alfonso’s Spanish wife and principal actress, overhears Valentin’s statement and reminisces about her golden days as an actress in Madrid, where she was sought after by so many suitors although she knew she was not a real artist. Then Carlota falls in love with Deodato, a young medical student, who later kills himself. She ends up with Alfonso whom she has never loved. In fact, Carlota has had a string of lovers, the last one being the native Basilio, who also commits suicide. After Basilio’s death, Alfonso stops coming home to Carlota.

Meanwhile, Valentin is horrified to discover Diding in bed with Alfonso. She explains that she gave herself to the director for the promise of stardom. But, at rehearsals, Alfonso shames her, ordering the devil character to grab Diding’s breast. Diding protests that she is not a prostitute. Alfonso later reveals that he had paid 50 silver pieces to Diding’s mother for the girl’s virginity and another thousand pesos to make Diding his wife. In despair, she tries to drown herself in the river but Valentin saves her, as he once saved her from a rampaging carriage that then ran over Valentin’s leg and gave him a limp for life.

With Mang Juan, the man who hired Valentin for the theater, Valentin joins the Katipunan but the two are found out and arrested. Carlota is able to save Valentin’s life, and makes love to her in gratitude. Knowing how deeply in love Valentin is with Diding, Carlota tells him to save the pregnant Diding from Alfonso, who has threatened to kill her after finding out about her condition. He is certain the paternity is not his, because he is sterile. Valentin and Diding try to escape but Valentin is shot by a guardia civil (constable) and incarcerated in Fort Santiago, where another prisoner, Jose Rizal, ministers to his wounds. Out from prison, Valentin learns of Diding’s death. He exhumes Diding’s body, slits her stomach open, and sees the bullet embedded in the heart of his unborn child. He swears to avenge the death of both mother and child.

Meanwhile, the two guardias civiles Alfonso hired to arrest Valentin are found dead, hanging on the main stage of the theater. Alfonso shakes with fear and Carlota laughs at him. A confrontation ensues and Alfonso admits to killing Deodato and all of Carlota’s lovers, including Basilio. Carlota decides to leave Alfonso for good, but he shoots her dead. Alfonso sells the theater and hides. Valentin takes over the theater and buries Diding’s body under the main stage, so that Diding can rise from her grave and sing a song onstage any time she wishes to. The spirit of Diding does appear onstage to tell Valentin how Alfonso prevented her from visiting him in jail by chaining her to the bed and later shooting her. Unable to hunt down Alfonso, who has fled to Spain, Valentin devotes himself to a higher cause, which is the revolution against Spain and, later, the war against America. He ends up with Sakay who gives him a gun.

After the Americans take over, Valentin goes back to the theater and reinvents himself as the local Charlie Chaplin. Later, he works as a projectionist for the movies, still in pursuit of Alfonso. One day, he finds Alfonso—now acting on the screen. Valentin discovers his whereabouts and, during the film shoot, kills Alfonso with Sakay’s gun.

It is now the 8th of Dec 1941 and as the bombs fall on Intramuros, the spirit of Diding rises from the grave once more to embrace Valentin and finally tell him how much she had loved him from childhood. The bomb hits the theater, obliterating it forever.

Palasyo won first prize in the Centennial Literary Prize, sarsuwela division, sponsored by the Philippine Centennial Commission in 1998. Its significance rests on its introduction of radical changes in the content and form of the sarsuwela compared to the traditional kind: (1) Palasyo proposes a new system of values, which is based not on class or morality but on “purity of heart,” enabling one to love another person selflessly even as both of them wallow in the mud of “immorality”; (2) Palasyo unmasks society of its pretensions, revealing the selfishness and cruelty that are the rule in such a society, this in contrast to endorsing the hierarchy and morality of the ruling establishment; and (3) Palasyo adopts the form of a memory play, following a nonlinear plot that incorporates songs that are not decorative but diegetic, and takes on a cynical and gothic tone that is alien to the traditional sarsuwela.  Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

 

Source

Tiongson, Nicanor G. 2008b. “Palasyo ni Valentin: Radical Transformation of the Sarswela.” Philippine Humanities Review 10: 3-14.

First staged by the University of the Philippines (UP) Playwrights Theater at the Tanghalang Hermogenes Ilagan (Faculty Center lobby), UP Diliman, 1999. Full production was carried out by the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) to inaugurate the new PETA Theater Center in Quezon City in Sep-Oct 2005, under the direction of Soxie Topacio; set design, Boni Juan; costume design, Ogie Juliano; music, Minda Azarcon; choreography, Maribel Legarda; cast, Nonie Buencamino (Valentin), Cynthia Culig-Guico and She Maala (Diding), Chinggoy Alonso and Cesar Xerez Burgos (Alfonso), Gigette Reyes (Carlota), Chris Anthony Gonzales (Toto), Jude Edgar Balsamo, Vincent de Jesus, CJ Javier, Jeffrey Hernandez, Jess Evardone, and Ernie Cloma.

It is the evening of the 7th of Dec 1941, the day before the Japanese warplanes dropped the first bombs on Intramuros. In an old theater that shows old Tagalog movies, Valentin, the theater projectionist, is drinking with Toto, the young janitor that Valentin hired. On his natal day, Valentin ends up narrating his life story. The characters of that story enter from the past.

value.desc: Ricky Davao in Palasyo ni Valentin, College of Saint Benilde, 2015 (Trixie Dauz)

article.value: Diding, the beautiful daughter of Senyor Marcelo, Valentin’s piano teacher, has been the object of his affection since they were children. Senyor Alfonso, the owner of the theater and producer of the sarsuwela, recruits Diding, who wants to be an actress. Alfonso asks Valentin to teach Diding the songs, and Valentin obliges but demands that Diding should communicate not with her beauty but with her soul. Carlota, Alfonso’s Spanish wife and principal actress, overhears Valentin’s statement and reminisces about her golden days as an actress in Madrid, where she was sought after by so many suitors although she knew she was not a real artist. Then Carlota falls in love with Deodato, a young medical student, who later kills himself. She ends up with Alfonso whom she has never loved. In fact, Carlota has had a string of lovers, the last one being the native Basilio, who also commits suicide. After Basilio’s death, Alfonso stops coming home to Carlota.

Meanwhile, Valentin is horrified to discover Diding in bed with Alfonso. She explains that she gave herself to the director for the promise of stardom. But, at rehearsals, Alfonso shames her, ordering the devil character to grab Diding’s breast. Diding protests that she is not a prostitute. Alfonso later reveals that he had paid 50 silver pieces to Diding’s mother for the girl’s virginity and another thousand pesos to make Diding his wife. In despair, she tries to drown herself in the river but Valentin saves her, as he once saved her from a rampaging carriage that then ran over Valentin’s leg and gave him a limp for life.

With Mang Juan, the man who hired Valentin for the theater, Valentin joins the Katipunan but the two are found out and arrested. Carlota is able to save Valentin’s life, and makes love to her in gratitude. Knowing how deeply in love Valentin is with Diding, Carlota tells him to save the pregnant Diding from Alfonso, who has threatened to kill her after finding out about her condition. He is certain the paternity is not his, because he is sterile. Valentin and Diding try to escape but Valentin is shot by a guardia civil (constable) and incarcerated in Fort Santiago, where another prisoner, Jose Rizal, ministers to his wounds. Out from prison, Valentin learns of Diding’s death. He exhumes Diding’s body, slits her stomach open, and sees the bullet embedded in the heart of his unborn child. He swears to avenge the death of both mother and child.

Meanwhile, the two guardias civiles Alfonso hired to arrest Valentin are found dead, hanging on the main stage of the theater. Alfonso shakes with fear and Carlota laughs at him. A confrontation ensues and Alfonso admits to killing Deodato and all of Carlota’s lovers, including Basilio. Carlota decides to leave Alfonso for good, but he shoots her dead. Alfonso sells the theater and hides. Valentin takes over the theater and buries Diding’s body under the main stage, so that Diding can rise from her grave and sing a song onstage any time she wishes to. The spirit of Diding does appear onstage to tell Valentin how Alfonso prevented her from visiting him in jail by chaining her to the bed and later shooting her. Unable to hunt down Alfonso, who has fled to Spain, Valentin devotes himself to a higher cause, which is the revolution against Spain and, later, the war against America. He ends up with Sakay who gives him a gun.

After the Americans take over, Valentin goes back to the theater and reinvents himself as the local Charlie Chaplin. Later, he works as a projectionist for the movies, still in pursuit of Alfonso. One day, he finds Alfonso—now acting on the screen. Valentin discovers his whereabouts and, during the film shoot, kills Alfonso with Sakay’s gun.

It is now the 8th of Dec 1941 and as the bombs fall on Intramuros, the spirit of Diding rises from the grave once more to embrace Valentin and finally tell him how much she had loved him from childhood. The bomb hits the theater, obliterating it forever.

Palasyo won first prize in the Centennial Literary Prize, sarsuwela division, sponsored by the Philippine Centennial Commission in 1998. Its significance rests on its introduction of radical changes in the content and form of the sarsuwela compared to the traditional kind: (1) Palasyo proposes a new system of values, which is based not on class or morality but on “purity of heart,” enabling one to love another person selflessly even as both of them wallow in the mud of “immorality”; (2) Palasyo unmasks society of its pretensions, revealing the selfishness and cruelty that are the rule in such a society, this in contrast to endorsing the hierarchy and morality of the ruling establishment; and (3) Palasyo adopts the form of a memory play, following a nonlinear plot that incorporates songs that are not decorative but diegetic, and takes on a cynical and gothic tone that is alien to the traditional sarsuwela.  Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson
Source

value.source: Tiongson, Nicanor G. 2008b. “Palasyo ni Valentin: Radical Transformation of the Sarswela.” Philippine Humanities Review 10: 3-14.

article_title: Ang Panunuluyan ng Birhen Maria at San Jose sa Cubao, Ayala, Plaza Miranda Atbp. Lugar sa Loob at Labas ng Metro Manila

photos.desc: Mario O’Hara and Cecilia B. Garrucho in PETA’s Ang Panunuluyan ng Birhen Maria at San Jose sa Cubao, Ayala, Plaza Miranda Atbp. Lugar sa Loob at Labas ng Metro Manila, 1979 (Nicanor G. Tiongson Collection)

text:
(Virgin Mary and Saint Joseph’s Search for an Inn in Cubao, Ayala, Plaza Miranda, and Other Places Inside and Outside Metro Manila). 1979. Full-length play in Filipino. Direction, Joel Lamangan; script, Alan Glinoga, Al Santos, and Rody Vera; production design, Brenda Fajardo; music, Lutgardo Labad. Cast: Mario O’Hara, Cecilia B. Garrucho, Toffy Padua, Lino Brocka, Alan Glinoga, Greg Sta. Ines, Dante Balois, Ed Zabala, Tessie Padua, Maribel Legarda, and the Philippine Educational Theater Association Kalinangan Ensemble (PETA-KE). First staged by PETA-KE in Dec 1979. It was published in PETA-KE Script Series 4, 1984.

A Christmas presentation, this play draws on the traditional folk form, the panunuluyan, which presents San Jose and Santa Maria going from house to house in search of an inn on the first Christmas Eve. The story of the poor couple from Nazareth is adapted to the contemporary Philippine setting.

The scene opens on a carro (processional float) bearing the images of Jose and Maria on their 1979th panunuluyan. The two come alive and go down from the float. They start out in Biblical costume but, in their interaction with and sympathy for the Filipino poor, end in Philippine workers’ clothing.

 

Jose and a pregnant Maria seek a place to stay in the Philippines. They first stop in Quiapo, where the vendors along Carriedo St are being interviewed by a roving broadcaster, who asks what Christmas means to them. They meet the boy Hesus who orients them on life in the country, where poverty is rife. The couple reaches the ManilaHotel, where a Christmas party for the rich and powerful is taking place. The revelers see the couple, suspect them to be impostors, and throw them out. Micah, the prophet, appears before the disheartened couple, reminding them that they have to go on with their panunuluyan, over and over again if need be, for only through the experiences they gain will people realize the truth. They meet Hesus once more, who takes them to the colony of informal settlers where he lives. Among the poor and downtrodden, the couple seek shelter for the night until the child’s birth. They first go to the community of batilyo (fish stevedore) from whom they hear laments, their catch having been stolen from them by the crews of large Japanese fishing boats. Next, they go to the farm fields and stay among the discontented peasants, tenants of Don Pilong. Jose and Maria finally reach a factory and see the workers’ conditions. The people of each sector realize that they have a cause to fight for and that they have strength if they are united. The batilyo sign a petition against the setting up of a fish port for foreign boats; the peasants act on their land problem; the workers go on strike. Seeing that the people have gathered their strength together, Jose and Maria feel that they have prepared the way for Jesus’s coming. Maria gives birth. The koro (chorus) sings: “Salubungin ang Bagong Araw” (Greet the New Day).  Written by Malou L. Maniquis and Nicanor G. Tiongson

 

Source

Atienza, Glecy C. 1990. “Subersyon sa Dula sa Ilalilm ng Batas Militar: Mga Dula ng PETA 1975-1981.” MA thesis, College of Arts and Letters, University of the Philippines Diliman.

photos.desc: Teatrong Mulat ng Pilipinas’s Papet Pasyon, 2017 (Vladimeir B. Gonzales)

text:
(The Passion of Jesus Christ in Puppetry). 1985. Puppet play. Script and narration, Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio; artistic direction, Amihan Bonifacio-Ramolete. Cast: Teatrong Mulat ng Pilipinas puppeteers, majority are Bonifacio family members. Following the suggestion of National Artist Lucresia Kasilag, the premiere staging of Papet Pasyon was held at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) with the following artistic ensemble: music, Rodolfo de Leon and Lester Demetillo; voices, Elmo Makil, Elena Mirano, University of the Philippines Cherubims & Seraphims, Tonton Santos, Tony Mabesa, Cristina Gosalvez, Edgardo Crisol, Fe Corazon Ramos, Jorge Hernandez, Monnette E. Alfon, Caesar Corpuz, Suzzette Querubin; puppeteers, Teatrong Mulat ng Pilipinas puppeteers. For almost 29 years, Teatrong Mulat ng Pilipinas has been performing the puppet play annually during Holy Week in various places.

Papet Pasyon is a one-hour narrative on the passion of Christ. As with other Teatrong Mulat ng Pilipinas performances, it starts with a prayer and flower offering, opens with the story of creation, and tackles the life of Jesus up to his resurrection. Presented like a sinakulo performance, Papet Pasyon is a story of the life and the sufferings of Jesus. The main actors of the play are the puppets of Jesus, Mary, Mary Magdalene, the apostles John and Peter, Judas, and the narrator, a crippled boy. The characters’ dialogues are pre-taped and then played during the show. The play incorporates video projections as background and as a showcase of the less apposite events in Jesus’s life.

 

Annually on Palm Sunday, there is a free Papet Pasyon performance in the Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio Teatro Papet Museo, formerly known as Tita Amel Children’s Theater, located at 64 Mapagkawanggawa St, Teachers Village West, Diliman Quezon City. Children are invited to see this reenactment of Jesus’s life and his sufferings, whose script is yearly altered to suit the tender emotions of the young audiences. The puppet play mirrors the melancholy of Jesus’s crucifixion in an empathetic manner, as it initially builds the virtues of kindness and compassion in Jesus’s life before the crucifixion.

Noteworthy are the physical appearance of the puppets used in the play. Led by the “Filipino” Jesus and Mary, the puppets are not the usual fair-skinned and blue-eyed foreign passion characters but are especially designed to look typically Filipino—dark-skinned and flat-nosed.

Believed to be the first puppet play that narrates the widely popular subject of Jesus’s sufferings, Papet Pasyon stands true to Teatrong Mulat ng Pilipinas’ vision of awakening Filipino children to the arts and culture of the country. Every year, the 250-seater theater is crowded with children and adults eager to learn the passion of Jesus Christ enacted by puppets.  Written by Ronald H. Biñas

photos.desc: Tanghalang Pilipino’s Paraisong Parisukat, starring Soliman Cruz and Rina Reyes, CCP, Manila, 1989 (CCP Collection)

text:
(Square Piece of Paradise). 1974. One-act play in Filipino. Direction and script, Orlando R. Nadres. Cast: Melvi Pacubas, Precy Castro, Kooch Mapua, Nanding Josef, Lorli Villanueva, Domingo Landicho, and Roger Mariscal. First staged by the Philippine Educational Theater Association in 1974 at the Dulaang Dambana in Fort Santiago, Manila. It was staged by Jose Ocampo for the Tanghalang Ateneo at Ateneo de Manila University in 1983, and by Spanky Manikan for Tanghalang Pilipino in 1989 at the Tanghalang Huseng Batute of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) in Manila. Under the direction of Lino Brocka, it was made into a telemovie in 1975, the premiere episode of the weekly drama anthology Tanghalan (Theater) on GMA Channel 7 featuring Bembol Roco, Mitch Valdes, Lorli Villanueva, Laurice Guillen, Fernando Josef, Joonee Gamboa, Domingo Landicho, and Melvi Pacubas. In 1976, it was made into a full-length movie starring Christopher de Leon, Alma Moreno, Lorli Villanueva, Barbara Luna, and Nova Villa. It was published in the 1989 Script Series Program of the CCP Coordinating Center for Dramatic Arts.

This play is set in the G. Mirasol and Sons store, in the cramped stockroom above the display and customer area, from where clerks hurl down through a chute the shoe models and colors requested by salespersons below. The denizens of this “square paradise” are Simplicia Cruz or Isya, the heroine, who is in her early 20s; Emy, single and fun loving; and Belen, married and unhappy. Tomas, the janitor, is a frequent visitor; Ate Pastora Dimagiba, spinster and head saleslady, is the voice of authority and keeper of the rules. The higher authority is the voice of Don Gerardo Mirasol, owner of the store, whose precepts and tenets on Mirashoes and the organization occasionally issue from the loudspeaker.

 

True to her name, Isya is simple and content with her job, especially since she has been awarded a medal for seven years of loyal and efficient service. Belen complains not about her work but about her marriage and her husband’s treatment of her (e.g., he refuses to take her to the company picnic), while Emy’s discontent is with the job, the hours, the pay, and the oppression by Ate Pastora. Isya’s secure little world changes when Alberto Reyes, a new employee, is admitted into it. She and Al start by sharing lunch, then their lives, dreams, then feelings, and when he tells her, “Leave this place. You’ll get nowhere, staying here,” she is shaken, and at first cannot understand his anger. He says, “I am angry … at all the shoeboxes … at my mother and all mothers like her … at all the Simplicia Cruzes in this world because they have no ambitions … at all the Alberto Reyeses in this world because they have high ambitions yet nothing will happen in spite of all their efforts … at this whole world … at this life.” The walls of her paradise crumble. In the end, Isya decides not to follow Al; she turns her back on happiness, and decides to stick to her little corner of “paradise.”

The play has been called one of the best structured, and is one of the most often performed, one-act plays in the country. It is, the playwright writes in the introduction, “about human beings, ambitious and ambitionless, virtuous and vicious together … about the simple, the common, the unknown, the popular and the poor, the rude …a kuwentong-masa (story of the masses).”  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

 

Source

Hernando, Mario A., ed. 1993. Lino Brocka: The Artist and His Times. Manila: Sentrong Pangkulturang Pilipinas.

photos.desc: Julia Enriquez and Ian Segarra in PETA’s Pasaporte, 2005 (PETA Library and Archives)

text:
(Passport). 2005. Tula-dula (poem-play). Direction, Nor Domingo; script, Janneke “Nex” Agustin; composition and musical direction, Vincent A. de Jesus; stage manager, Patricia Liwanag. Cast: Carlon Matobato/Ian Segarra (Manolo Dimakaahon), Julia Fernandez (Dina Asenso), and Vincent A. de Jesus (Supernumerary). First staged at the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) Theater Center as part of PETA Dulaang Laboratoryo in 2005. The tula-dula was restaged as part of PETA’s season offering titled Pinoy Wannabes in 2006. It was also performed in Vancouver, Canada, in the same year, as PETA’s entry to the Earth: World Urban Festival.

The tula-dula opens with a parody of West Side Story ’s “America,” which speaks of how hard it is to live in the Philippines and how much the people want to work in the United States. A public school teacher, Dina Asenso, and a guy from the province, Manolo Dimakaahon, enter and enumerate a number of requirements and non-requirements for a US visa application. Supernumerary narrates how Dina and Manolo prepared for their appointment at the embassy. They experience the travails of going to the Department of Foreign Affairs (DFA) to apply for a passport. The supernumerary sings a reworded version of “Limang Dipang Tao” (Five Yards of People). During another metro rail transit ride, Dina and Manolo remember a letter and an email, which they received a few days back. Manolo’s parents are urging him to quickly get his papers, while enumerating a series of domestic problems. Dina’s friend, who is already in the United States, encourages her to hurry as well so she can experience what the United States can offer her. They arrive at the DFA where fixers welcome them and offer a sure-and-easy-way to get a passport. The two ignore the fixers. They undergo a series of elimination rounds just to enter the DFA building. Inside, they await for their names to be called. Their hopes are renewed when their names are finally called. The passport application ends. The supernumerary sings “The American Dream” from Miss Saigon. Weeks and months pass. Dina and Manolo finally return to the US Embassy for their interview. As they wait for their turn, their minds wander once again, imagining their return to their school and saying farewell to their family. Their names are called and they are interviewed but in the end their applications for US visas are rejected.

 

Pasaporte foregrounds the obsession of many Filipinos to go abroad, particularly to the United States, a country tagged as the “land of milk and honey.” Despite the comic relief and exaggerated choreography, the tula-dula is a stinging critique of the illusion that progress can only be achieved by going abroad.  Written by Erick Dasig Aguilar

The supernumerary sings a reworded version of “Limang Dipang Tao” (Five Yards of People). During another metro rail transit ride, Dina and Manolo remember a letter and an email, which they received a few days back. Manolo’s parents are urging him to quickly get his papers, while enumerating a series of domestic problems. Dina’s friend, who is already in the United States, encourages her to hurry as well so she can experience what the United States can offer her. They arrive at the DFA where fixers welcome them and offer a sure-and-easy-way to get a passport. The two ignore the fixers. They undergo a series of elimination rounds just to enter the DFA building. Inside, they await for their names to be called. Their hopes are renewed when their names are finally called. The passport application ends. The supernumerary sings “The American Dream” from Miss Saigon. Weeks and months pass. Dina and Manolo finally return to the US Embassy for their interview. As they wait for their turn, their minds wander once again, imagining their return to their school and saying farewell to their family. Their names are called and they are interviewed but in the end their applications for US visas are rejected.

article.value: Pasaporte foregrounds the obsession of many Filipinos to go abroad, particularly to the United States, a country tagged as the “land of milk and honey.” Despite the comic relief and exaggerated choreography, the tula-dula is a stinging critique of the illusion that progress can only be achieved by going abroad.  Written by Erick Dasig Aguilar

text:
(Philippines circa 1907). 1982. Sarsuwela in two acts, in Tagalog. Direction, Soxie Topacio; libretto, Nicanor G. Tiongson; music, Lutgardo Labad, Louie Pascasio, and Lucien Letaba; musical direction, Lutgardo Labad; musical arrangement, Chino Toledo; production design, Brenda Fajardo; choreography, Mary Joan Fajardo; technical direction, Paolo Lopez. Cast: Nanette Moscardon, Lirio Vital, Lorraine Natividad, Joel Lamangan, Ric Segreto, Irma Potenciano, Bodgie Pascua, Spanky Manikan, Dido de la Paz, Ditchay Roxas, Evelyn Vargas, Connie Lauigan, Beth Mondragon, Carme Sanchez, Avic Ilagan, Joey Galvez, Cecilia B. Garrucho, Spencer Damask, and the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) Kalinangan Ensemble. First staged by PETA in Jan 1982 at the Dulaang Rajah Sulayman at Fort Santiago, Intramuros, Manila.

The sarsuwela was restaged by Nonon Padilla, with design by National Artist Salvador Bernal for Tanghalang Pilipino (TP) in 1992 at the Tanghalang Aurelio V. Tolentino of the Cultural Center of the Philippines with Noemi Manikan-Gomez, Nonie Buencamino, Cynthia Culig, John Arcilla, Naty Crame-Rogers, Jojo Isla, Gamaliel Viray, Lou Veloso, Evelyn Vargas, and the TP actors. In 2007, it was once again staged by Tanghalang Pilipino under the direction of Dennis Marasigan, set design by Leo Abaya with some of the costumes coming from the 1992 production. It was also staged in Davao City, Cebu City, Dumaguete City, and Batangas City between 1982 and 1986. In 1989, the play was translated into English by Tiongson and was produced at the University of Hawaii at Manoa Kennedy Theater, under the direction of Tony Mabesa, musical direction of Ricardo Trimillos, and costumes by Salvador Bernal. Pilipinas circa 1907 was published by PETA (introduction, production script, English translation, notes, score for piano and voice) in 1985. The book won the Manila Critics Circle Award in 1986.

 

The play alludes to Severino Reyes’s sarsuwela Filipinas para los Filipinos (Filipino Women for Filipino Men), 1905, which Tiongson was asked by St. Paul College to update for presentation in 1978. The original conflict based on reactions to the Davis Bill prohibiting American women from marrying Filipino men, was changed to “the bigger conflict of the First Decade between Filipino and American interest in the economy (the American attempt to monopolize the tobacco industry), in politics (Federalistas vs Nacionalistas), and in culture and education (the Americanized vs the Nationalist).”

The result was a new sarsuwela, Pilipinas circa1907, which opens in the elegant home of Señora Pilar on Arlegui St in Quiapo. Her daughter Leonor loves Emilio, a nationalist poet, but is also courted by Robert, an American. Pura, her cousin, who stays with her, loves Andres, a worker. Bad news comes in a newspaper announcing the upcoming nuptials of Emilio and Patria Gatlaya of Malolos, Bulacan. Deeply hurt, Leonor is upbraided by Emilio for going around with Robert. She pleads that her Uncle Pardo has asked her to entertain him, and she cannot refuse. At Leonor’s birthday party, the ilustrados (the educated) led by her Uncle Pardo are ranged against the folk: Andres, Juan the family servant, and the workers at Germinal, the family-owned tobacco factory that Pardo is plotting to sell to the Americans. Also revealed are Pardo’s pro-American feelings, echoed by the Americanized girls who see Americanization as progress, and the nationalist sentiments of Emilio, the workers, Andres, Pura, and Señora Pilar.

In act 2, the lovers’ differences are cleared up when Emilio reveals the symbolism of his supposed engagement: Patria Gatlaya is named for Motherland and Independence, and Malolos is the birthplace of the First Republic. Andres bids Pura goodbye. Pardo has the workers who opposed him arrested, and is now looking for Andres and Emilio. Avoiding prison, Andres decides to join the revolutionaries fighting the Americans in the hills. Emilio is arrested by soldiers and Pardo, who strikes his sister Pilar for disowning him as traitor, is attacked by the workers. In the tussle, a Germinal worker is killed. Leonor decides that the only way to save Emilio is for her to marry Robert as Pardo wishes. At the wedding, however, she refuses to take Robert as husband, because, she reveals, he is already married. Dorothy, who had come to the country ostensibly to marry Porong, a musician, is revealed as the wife Robert had abandoned in the United States. The play ends with Emilio freed, Pura leaving to join Andres in the hills, and the chorus singing “Philippines for the Filipinos.”

Although clad in the raiment of old—choruses, love linking two gallant heroes and two beautiful heroines, comic songs by Juan and the girls, period manners, and domestic situations—this sarsuwela has contemporary accents: tragedy, reality, problem, and solution. The manner, humor, and language of an earlier period make a point for today, which proves that the sarsuwela can take in new content while retaining its old charm.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez, updated by Athena Angela Aquino

Atienza, Glecy C. 1990. “Subersyon sa Dula sa Ilalilm ng Batas Militar: Mga Dula ng PETA 1975-1981.” MA thesis, College of Arts and Letters, University of the Philippines Diliman.

article_title: A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino/Larawan

photos.desc: Musical Theater Philippines’s Ang Larawan: The Musical, featuring Celeste Legaspi and Rachel Alejandro as Candida and Paula, respectively, both in Nazarene red, CCP, Manila, 1997 (Photo courtesy of Shoko Matsumoto)

text:
1955. Three-act play in English. Direction, Lamberto V. Avellana; script, Nick Joaquin; music, Angel Avellana. First staged in 1955 by the Barangay Theater Guild (BTG) at the Aurora Gardens in Intramuros, Manila. Cast: Daisy Hontiveros-Avellana (Candida), Dolly Benavides (Paula), Armando Goyena (Tony Javier), Totoy Avellana (Bitoy Camacho), Sarah K. Joaquin (Pepang), Nick Agudo (Manolo), Francisco “Koko” Trinidad (Don Perico), Patsy Mateo (Violet), Belle Gonzales (Susan), Oscar Keesee (Don Alvaro), Veronica Palileo (Doña Pepang), Alfred Xerez Burgos (Don Aristeo), Butch Josue (Don Pepe), Johnny Wilson (Detective 1), and Jun Manalang (Detective 2). In subsequent performances, the role of Paula was played by Inday Magalona and later by Naty Crame-Rogers. In 1966, with Manny de Leon as producer, it was made into a film by Avellana with Daisy Hontiveros-Avellana (Candida), Naty Crame-Rogers (Paula), Conrad Parham (Tony Javier), and Vic Silayan (Bitoy Camacho) in the lead roles, supported by Sarah K. Joaquin, Nick Agudo, Francisco Trinidad, Oscar Keesee, Veronica Palileo, Alfred Xerez Burgos, Pianing Vidal, Nena Perez Rubio, Manuel Ojeda, Rino Bermudez, Nena Ledesma, Polly Anders, and Miriam Jurado. The BTG toured it in different towns and cities outside Manila and in 1975 restaged it at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). It was also staged in New York at the Barbizon Plaza Hotel by the Philippine Theater Guild of New York in 1965. Portrait was first translated into Filipino by Alfred Yuson and Franklin Osorio as Larawan, first staged by the Philippine Educational Theate rAssociation (PETA) in 1969 at the Dulaang Rajah Sulayman in Intramuros. Under the direction of Cecile R. Guidote, the lead roles were played by Rita Gomez (Candida), Lolita Rodriguez (Paula), Raul Paredes (Bitoy Camacho), and Dante Rivero (Tony Javier). The Filipino version was restaged by Lino Brocka for PETA in 1979, by Behn Cervantes for the University of the Philippines (UP) Repertory Company in 1982, and by Nonon Padilla for Tanghalang Pilipino in 1989. A subsequent translation, also titled Larawan, was made by Bienvenido Lumbera and staged by Padilla for Tanghalang Pilipino in 1992, and by Anton Juan Jr for Dulaang UP in a back-to-back production with the English version in 1993. Some of the actors who played the lead roles of Candida and Paula in various productions of both Portrait and the different versions of Larawan are Lolita Rodriguez and Charito Solis, 1979; Barbara Perez and Susan Valdez, 1982; Tessie Tomas and Noemi Manikan-Gomez, 1989; Celeste Legaspi and Noemi Manikan-Gomez, 1992; Gina Alajar and Malou de Guzman, 1993; and Joy Soler-de Castro and Nieves Campa, 1993. In 1997, the play was adapted as a musical, Ang Larawan: The Musical, with libretto by Rolando Tinio and music by Ryan Cayabyab, staged by Musical Theater Philippines and the CCP. Portrait was first published as “an elegy in three scenes” in the Women’s Weekly Magazine in 1952. It was published in book form in Prose and Poems, 1952, by Graphic House; A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, 1966, by Alberto S. Florentino; and Tropical Baroque: Four Manileño Theatricals, 1979, by National Bookstore Inc.

Set in the year 1941, the two Marasigan sisters, Candida and Paula, of the once well-to-do Marasigan family struggle to make ends meet, while their father, the once prolific painter Don Lorenzo Marasigan, isolates himself within his personal quarters. Bitoy Camacho, an old family friend, visits them one afternoon to get information on a painting Don Lorenzo has finished, called “A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino.” Tony Javier, a musician who is renting a room at the house, recognizes Bitoy as an old friend and tells him he has failed to convince the two sisters to sell the portrait. The painting brings a number of unpleasant personalities to the Marasigan residence, including Bitoy’s fellow journalists and Tony’s bodabil friends who view the portrait and play critic.

 

Manolo and Pepang, the older siblings of Candida and Paula, along with the senator Don Perico, pay their father a visit. Manolo and Pepang try to convince their younger sisters to sell the house, and move Don Lorenzo to a hospital. Don Perico tries to convince the two sisters to donate the painting to the government in exchange for a handsome pension. Candida and Paula refuse. Manolo and Pepang argue with Candida and Paula, and the two sisters are forced to confess that the painting was the result of their ugly confrontation with their father. Devastated by the accusation that he had ruined his daughters’ lives, the father painted the portrait—his supposed final piece of work—gave it to his daughters to sell, and attempted suicide. After their siblings leave, the two sisters become bitter about their poverty. Candida tells Paula that she did not get the job she applied for—catching rats. Then Tony appears and manages to convince Paula to elope with him, promising her an escape from poverty.

Days after, the Marasigans are once again visited by Bitoy and the other journalists, as well as Don Perico’s wife, Doña Loleng, and her companions after learning of the disappearance of the painting, and Paula’s departure with Tony Javier. Candida confirms the news and puts the blame on herself. Paula arrives and confesses that she has destroyed the portrait, despite Tony’s attempts to convince her to sell it. The two sisters reconcile and decide to remain with their father—contra mundum (against the world).

Portrait is conceded by most Filipino critics to be the most important Filipino play in English and one of the most important pioneers of realism in Philippine theater. Proof of its significance are the many critiques published on the play, among which is The Past Revisited, 1966.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez and Cynthia San Juan, updated by Athena Angela Aquino

photos.desc: A young cast member of Komedya Don Galo’s Prinsipe Rodante, Parañaque City, 2008 (Photo courtesy of Nikki Seranilla Briones)

text:
(Prince Rodante). 1962. Komedya in Filipino. Direction, Felicidad Mendoza; script, Max Allanigue. Cast: Herminio Hernandez, Julieta Manuel, Arsenio Rodriguez, Lolita Santos, Edmundo Allanigue, Teresita Ison, Ricardo San Agustin, Ruben Bernardo Jr, Carmencita de la Paz, Florentino Reate, Erlinda Bernabe, Conrado Capistrano, Ricardo Santos, Nomer Roldan, Angel Manuel, Juan de Leon, Policarpio de Leon, Homobono Santiago, Silvestre Ferrer, Buen Cruz, Celedonio Santiago, Isidro Ison, Wilfredo Salvador, Perseverando Cruz, Arsenio Santiago, Gregorio Guerrero, Bienvenido Hernandez, Juanito Villamaria, Felino de Leon Jr, Kathy Malabanan, Germilina Santos, Erlinda Fernandez, and Abda Bunye. First staged by the Komedya ng San Dionisio (KSD) in May 1962 in San Dionisio, Parañaque. Some of its performances were at the St. Paul College Auditorium in Parañaque in Sep 1962, at the Manila Metropolitan Theater in 1979, and at the Puerta Real Gardens in Intramuros in 1988. The Philippine Educational Theater Association performed excerpts of the play in 1967. In Mar 1982, it was staged by Tony Espejo at the Little Theater, later Tanghalang Aurelio V. Tolentino, of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) with Tommy Abuel in the title role. During the first National Theater Festival held at the CCP in Feb 1992, it was presented by the KSD as one of the nine chosen regional participants. The play was once again staged by the KSD in 2008, for the University of the Philippines’s Komedya Fiesta. Komedya ng Don Galo, a troupe of child performers, also presented their own rendition of the play during the 2008 Komedya Fiesta.

The hero, Prinsipe Rodante, is a Christian, and so is the villain, his brother Prinsipe Alvaro, who offends the Moors by putting 10 of their priests to death, and then usurps his father’s throne. Against him are ranged both Christians and Moors: Rodante and Porciana, the Moro princess he loves; Floresca, Rodante’s sister, and Aladin, the Moor who won Floresca’s heart and hand at the torneo (tournament) which opens the play; Rodante’s parents Haring (King) Orestes and Reyna (Queen) Yocasta; Prinsesa (Princess) Pilita and her father Sultan Miramulin. When Alvaro, who had ordered Rodante beheaded in front of his parents, is condemned to death for his crimes, it is Porciana, the Moorish princess, who asks that Alvaro be forgiven after having met San Dionisio, patron saint of the barrio, who preached love for one’s enemies. When Miramulin, in his anger at Alvaro, lunges with his sword, it is Porciana who is killed—but she is brought to life again by a miracle of the Virgin Mary.

 

When Prinsipe Rodante was first performed, the San Dionisio community could not accept it as komedya. They had been staging komedya for generations because it was believed to be the preference of their patron saint. “Not a komedya,” they said of Prinsipe Rodante, not only because of the Christian villain and the Muslim heroine but also because it was unconventional: it is short, playable in one night; has a narrator; and has a different subtext wherein the villain was anyone of evil intent, Christian or not. Community acceptance did come later—but slowly. For the CCP’s Unang Tagpo (First Scene), 1992, the first National Theater Festival, the play was reedited by Rene O. Villanueva.

Prinsipe Rodante was an important landmark, then being one of the first and perhaps the best known “new” komedya in recent times. Although traditional in plot and verse, it challenged traditional formulae by not ranging Moors against Christians, but good against evil.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez, updated by Athena Angela Aquino

KSD (Komedya ng San Dionisio). 1962. Prinsipe Rodante. Souvenir program.

Some of its performances were at the St. Paul College Auditorium in Parañaque in Sep 1962, at the Manila Metropolitan Theater in 1979, and at the Puerta Real Gardens in Intramuros in 1988. The Philippine Educational Theater Association performed excerpts of the play in 1967. In Mar 1982, it was staged by Tony Espejo at the Little Theater, later Tanghalang Aurelio V. Tolentino, of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) with Tommy Abuel in the title role. During the first National Theater Festival held at the CCP in Feb 1992, it was presented by the KSD as one of the nine chosen regional participants. The play was once again staged by the KSD in 2008, for the University of the Philippines’s Komedya Fiesta. Komedya ng Don Galo, a troupe of child performers, also presented their own rendition of the play during the 2008 Komedya Fiesta.

The hero, Prinsipe Rodante, is a Christian, and so is the villain, his brother Prinsipe Alvaro, who offends the Moors by putting 10 of their priests to death, and then usurps his father’s throne. Against him are ranged both Christians and Moors: Rodante and Porciana, the Moro princess he loves; Floresca, Rodante’s sister, and Aladin, the Moor who won Floresca’s heart and hand at the torneo (tournament) which opens the play; Rodante’s parents Haring (King) Orestes and Reyna (Queen) Yocasta; Prinsesa (Princess) Pilita and her father Sultan Miramulin. When Alvaro, who had ordered Rodante beheaded in front of his parents, is condemned to death for his crimes, it is Porciana, the Moorish princess, who asks that Alvaro be forgiven after having met San Dionisio, patron saint of the barrio, who preached love for one’s enemies. When Miramulin, in his anger at Alvaro, lunges with his sword, it is Porciana who is killed—but she is brought to life again by a miracle of the Virgin Mary.

article.value: When Prinsipe Rodante was first performed, the San Dionisio community could not accept it as komedya. They had been staging komedya for generations because it was believed to be the preference of their patron saint. “Not a komedya,” they said of Prinsipe Rodante, not only because of the Christian villain and the Muslim heroine but also because it was unconventional: it is short, playable in one night; has a narrator; and has a different subtext wherein the villain was anyone of evil intent, Christian or not. Community acceptance did come later—but slowly. For the CCP’s Unang Tagpo (First Scene), 1992, the first National Theater Festival, the play was reedited by Rene O. Villanueva.

Prinsipe Rodante was an important landmark, then being one of the first and perhaps the best known “new” komedya in recent times. Although traditional in plot and verse, it challenged traditional formulae by not ranging Moors against Christians, but good against evil.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez, updated by Athena Angela Aquino

text:
(Rock of Aegis). 2014. Musical in two acts, in Filipino. Direction, Maribel Legarda; book and additional lyrics, Liza Magtoto; song composition, Celso Abenoja, for and popularized by the rock band Aegis; music arrangement and musical direction, Myke Salomon; set design; Mio Infante; lighting design, Jon Jon Villareal; sound design, Myke Salomon and Happy Constantino; choreography, Gio Gahol; costume design, John Pagunaling; shoe design, Marc Custodio; accessory design, Joan Pamintuan. Cast: Aicelle Santos/Joan Bugcat (Aileen), Isay Alvarez/Kalila Aguilos (Brgy Capt Mary Jane), Robert Seña/Juliene Mendoza (Kiel), Poppert Bernadas/Myke Salomon (Kenny), Jerald Napoles/Pepe Herrera (Tolits), Nor Domingo (Fernan), Ron Alfonso/Phi Palmos (Jewel), Kakai Bautista/Neomi Gonzales (Mercy), Gold Villar, Gimbey de la Cruz, Jet Barrun, Paeng Sudayan, Gie Onida, Carlon Matobato, and John Moran. First staged at the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) Theater Center on 31 Jan–9 Mar 2014.

Aileen works as a salesperson in a mall and lives with her family in Barangay Venizia, a pun on the canal city of Venice, which suffers from flooding even after two months since a typhoon hit it. Most residents have a difficult time going to and fro, resorting to riding boats; some have been getting sick from the dirty floodwater.

Brgy Capt Mary Jane is considering closing her shoemaking business due to damaged stocks from the flood, which could cost the job of Kiel, Aileen’s father. Meanwhile, her son Kenny is jobless and constantly drawing in his sketchbook; mother and son constantly argue over his future.

 

Aileen dreams of financial stability by becoming a YouTube singing sensation. Aileen’s suitor Tolits, who has been working as a boatman, posts an online video of her singing, which leads to attention from both netizens and the media for Aileen and for the flooding problem of Villa Venizia. Kiel and Mary Jane confront Fernan, the developer of nearby subdivision Villa Arkadia, for cutting down trees and causing the flooding in Villa Venizia. Fernan convinces them to let Aileen headline a concert to raise funds for the barangay. The residents capitalize on the concert by creating merchandise to sell. When the floods recede because the Department of Public Works and Highways has pumped out the waters, the residents get caught up with the frenzy that they want the floods to return. Kiel appeals to them for reason.

Aileen realizes that fame for the wrong reasons comes at a high price when her mother contracts leptospirosis from the floodwaters. Kenny reveals to his mother that his sketchbook contains new shoe designs that her business can use. It is revealed that Mary Jane and Fernan are secretly funding the concert, which gets cancelled. The community arranges with Fernan to fund the shoe industry, instead.

A pun on Broadway musical Rock of Ages, the musical offered a timely commentary on the current preoccupations of Filipinos in the first few years of the 2010s: technology such as cell phones and smartphones, Internet access and social media, unavailability of jobs and hardships of small business owners, and the overwhelming effects of intense typhoons that bring abnormally high and prolonged flooding. The musical was created some time after Typhoon Ondoy. The set design is notable for its use of actual water contained in metal troughs to create flooded “streets” for the actors to cross as well as ride a boat in.

With its more than 250 sold-out performances since its first staging, Rak of Aegis is considered one of the most successful musicals in the recent history of Philippine theater. The musical won the following awards in the 2014 Gawad Buhay! Awards: Outstanding Original Musical, Outstanding Ensemble Performance for a Musical, Outstanding Female Lead Performance in a Musical (Kim Molina), Outstanding Male Featured Performance in a Musical (Herrera), Outstanding Choreography for a Play or Musical, Outstanding Costume Design, Outstanding Sound Design, Outstanding Set Design, Outstanding Original Libretto, Outstanding Musical Direction, and Outstanding Stage Direction for a Musical.  Written by Walter Ang, with notes from Erick Dasig Aguilar

text:
1902. One-act play in Tagalog. Direction, Hermogenes Ilagan; script, Severino Reyes. Cast: Hermogenes Ilagan (Colas) and, as listed in a handwritten manuscript, Señoritas Gatchalian, Socorro B., Javier A., Señores Pepe, Lopez, Melchor, Mercado, Bautista, Espinosa, and A. Constantino. First staged by the Compañia Lirico-Dramatica Tagala de Gatchalian e Ilagan on 3 Apr 1902 at the Teatro Libertad in Manila. It was revived by the University of the Philippines (UP) Anak-Tibawan in 1980 and restaged by the same company in 1983 at the Little Theater of the Rizal Hall, UP Manila.

The play portrays a komedya troupe in rehearsal and in production. Colas, the director, worries about attacks on the komedya by the sarsuwelista (sarsuwela performers); Ichay worries about salaries and about a Spanish suitor. The rehearsal proceeds with incidents that parody the true-life situation in reverse and with comic events that make the acting, the conventions like the ditso (declamatory style), the batalla (fight scenes), the dikta (prompting), and the play itself look ridiculous. In the last scene, those sent to announce the play run in to say that they have been stoned in Divisoria; that the actors Ratia, Carvajal, and Titay Molina refuse to act in the komedya; and only fishers and market vendors watch them. They all agree to bury the komedya in a coffin which bears the letters “R.I.P.” (requiescat in paceor rest in peace).

The komedya performers protest against this play by riding past Reyes’s house in costume and on horseback, stoning it, and shouting “We cannot die!” They also stage a work by Juan Bartolome, Kailanman Ay Buhay, E.P.D. y Resurrexit (Forever Alive, E.P.D. It Rose Again), at the Teatro Nuevo Sol on Calle Diaz, which attacks Reyes and threatens the actors, causing Ilagan to desist from further appearances in the play. Although R.I.P. did not quite kill the komedya which continued to flourish in the provinces, it did mark the ascendance of the sarsuwela over the komedya in Manila, and the beginning of its reign of popularity.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

 

Source

Tiongson, Nicanor G. 1982. Kasaysayan ng Komedya sa Pilipinas: 1766-1982. Manila: De la Salle University-IRC.

text:
(Rose). 2007. One-act play in Filipino. Direction, Soxie Topacio; script, J. Dennis Teodosio. Cast: Nanding Josef (Merto) and Apolonio Bayani Chua (Anding). First staged as part of the Philippine Educational Theater Association Laboratory Festival in 2007.

It is sunset in the garden of the Home for the Aged. Anding, 65, sits on the swing, holding a photo album. Blind, he reckons memories by touching the photos, each one with a particular textural characteristic. Later he closes the album. Sensing the arrival of Merto, 72, Anding calls to him. He asks if Merto is mad at him because Anding left the institution and has just now returned. To this Merto says no, as is his answer to Anding’s inquiry on having a new roommate. Anding is glad and asks how Merto is, because the gardener and the social worker have noticed that Merto has turned into a loner of late and has often been seen musing to himself. Merto answers that he was reflecting about life. Asking about their formerly shared room, Merto shares that nothing has changed and that the vase is still there, the one from which Anding took the dried rose flower when he left. Anding recalls that it was Merto who picked that rose from the garden. Merto comments that he picked it for Anding. He asks why Anding took the already dried rose. Anding says that dried roses smell better. Merto changes the subject and asks about Nora Aunor’s photo in Anding’s album, and they reminisce about how Anding took the photo himself outside of Nora Aunor’s studio. Anding regrets having an eye cataract and asks if Merto might want to be his eyes from now on. Merto does not answer. Merto is reluctant at first, but gives in to Anding’s request for him to recite a poem. Anding narrates his experience of living with his relatives and how they impressed on him that he is still unforgiven for molesting a young man in his younger years. Merto consoles him by saying that his relatives still care for him. Anding replies that he knows who truly cares for him. After a long silence, Anding asks what kind of roses grow in the garden now. Merto answers red. Anding requests for Merto to sit beside him, confessing that Merto is the reason why he has come back. Anding asks what kind of rose Merto is going to place in their vase. Merto answers red. Anding says that red roses do not grow there. Merto apologizes. Anding says he is now giving Merto the photo album as a sign that he is not leaving anymore, and asks for him to open the last leaf of the photo album. Nora Aunor’s photo has been replaced by the dried rose which Anding took with him. Overwhelmed, Merto gives in to his emotions.

Rosas is a poignant play between two old men overcoming their repressed feelings for each other, upholding the development of gay discourse that intimacy does not have to be predatory. The play was adapted from Teodosio’s film script titled Tanso (Copper), which won second prize in the 2002 Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature. Eventually, Teodosio integrated Rosas, together with Dapo (Orchid) and Gumamela, to form a trilogy of one-act plays called Tatlong Bulaklak (Three Flowers). Upon the invitation of Barangay ni Jose Association Inc, Tatlong Bulaklak was staged under the direction of Teodosio in Santa Cruz, Putol, Laguna, in 2011. Teodosio’s poetics on the creation of the full-length play is anthologized in Writing to the Future: Poetika at Politika ng Malikhaing Pagsulat (Writing to the Future: Poetics and Politics of Creative Writing), 2008.  Written by Erick Dasig Aguilar

text:
(At the Mercy of Sharks). 1921. Sarsuwela in three acts, in Tagalog. Libretto, Julian Cruz Balmaseda; music, Leon Ignacio. It was written by Balmaseda on 15 Sep 1921. It premiered at the Manila Grand Opera House in the same year.

The play explores a theme unusual to traditional sarsuwela: the use of peaceful means or due process of law to fight the abuses of powerful landlords. It juxtaposes two families: that of the landlord, Don Juan, and that of his overseer, Ka Andoy. Their children, Nati and Mario, are sweethearts.

 

During Nati’s graduation celebration, Kabesang Andoy informs her father, Don Juan, that he is now ready to redeem the parcel of land he had mortgaged for 2,000 pesos. Don Juan informs Andoy, however, that he cannot do so because of the unpaid two-year annual interest of 1,100 pesos per year, which brings the debt to a total of 4,800 pesos. Andoy objects to the usurious interest rate but is unable to persuade Don Juan to reconsider his decision. Doña Irene proposes to lend him money, provided that he transfer the title of his land to her name.

Meanwhile, Kabesang Andoy’s son, Mario, has been elected president of the Rural Credit Union. Don Juan accuses Mario of fomenting unrest and discontent among the peasants. A court order soon comes, ejecting Ka Andoy and his family from the land. Nati intercedes.

One day, Don Juan finds his house surrounded by peasants. Not heeding Mario’s plea for nonviolence, the peasants, armed only with their bolos, gain entry into the house. At this moment, Marcelo, who had filed their petition to the Supreme Court in Manila, arrives and announces the decision of the highest tribunal, nullifying the forfeiture clause of the mortgage contract, making Ka Andoy win his case. Don Juan accepts the decision and embraces Mario in the spirit of reconciliation. Ka Andoy arrives and the two families are united.

This major work illustrates the step into social realism that the sarsuwela was beginning to take at the height of its development. Although the somewhat facile solution of the problem may not qualify as realism on the modern stage, its story deviates significantly from the traditional plot with the formulaic happy ending. Armed with a more pragmatic worldview, this sarsuwela is one of the few that commits itself to a course of action which the playwright believes will solve the problem of usury in real life.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis and Nicanor G. Tiongson

text:
(On the North Diversion Road). 1988. Play in 10 scenes, in Filipino. Direction, Felix “Nonon” Padilla Jr; script, Tony Perez; production management, Jojo Casim; set design, Salvador Bernal; light design, Dennis Marasigan; sound engineering, Milo Sarmiento; stage management, Chay Al-Matroudi; assistant stage management, Juanito Infante. Cast: Mario O’Hara (Man) and Celeste Legaspi/Madeleine Nicolas (Woman). First staged by Tanghalang Pilipino on 10 Sep 1988 at the Tanghalang Huseng Batute, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). It is the last in a trilogy of journey plays along with Bombita and Biyaheng Timog (Southern Journey), all of which were published in Tatlong Paglalakbay: The Collected Works of Tony Perez Volume 4 (Three Journeys: The Collected Works of Tony Perez Volume 4), 2007. Earlier, the play was published in English translation in Modern ASEAN Plays: Philippines, 1992, edited by Nicanor G. Tiongson. This triad was inspired by the separate adventures of the brothers Don Pedro, Don Diego, and Don Juan in capturing thei bong Adarna (Adarna bird). Their journeys paralleled the personal journey of the three protagonists in Perez’s plays (Tiongson 1992, 95). In 2005, Dennis Marasigan adapted the play to a film with the same title, starring Irma Adlawan and John Arcilla.

Sa North Diversion Road presents 10 scenes, in different cars featuring 10 different couples’ marital infidelity, as they drive along the North Diversion Road, later known as the North Luzon Expressway. The first, called “Ace of Hearts,” is about a wife confronting her husband about his cheating by divulging the extent of what she knows. He confesses to the crime, but adds that he has been cheating on her much longer than she had suspected. He then reveals that he and his mistress love each other. The wife thanks him for being honest. However, it is clear that he is unrepentant. The third, called “The Orange Light,” centers on a couple outshouting each other with exchanges of the most uninhibited expletives, even saying they regret marrying each other. The man asks the woman why she is behaving this way and she reveals having visited and warned his mistress thrice. Accused of meddling, the woman threatens to attack the mistress but is warned that he will side with his mistress if anything breaks out. The woman threatens to jump off the bridge but the husband encourages her to do so. The woman opens the door but closes it again—she cannot do it. The fourth, called “The Conversation,” is on a man and woman engaging in a silent game of dominance and submission. It ends with the woman exclaiming she knows of the man’s infidelity. The fifth, called “The Ride,” opens with the man and woman talking about their marriage. Having decided that they cannot live with infidelity, and after a final confession of love and forgiveness, they commit suicide. The sixth, called “The Steering Lesson,” is about a Momsie receiving cues from Popsie on her driving. She then starts teasing him on buying her a pink car once she improves revealing how his mistress, who has received a pink car from him, is a good friend of hers. The seventh, called “The Motorcade,” is about a woman in the middle of a nervous breakdown; her husband is calling for help through a Citizens Band (CB) radio. Narrating how his cheating sent her back to the institution, the CB radio modulator ends up giving him advice on how to repair their relationship. Following the metaphor of a journey, one car provides the setting for all the scenes, thus allowing the audience to focus on the ideas and emotions. text:
(Bet for the Red, for the White). 1939. One-act play in English. Script and translation, Francisco “Soc” Rodrigo. First staged on 10 Sep 1939 by the University of the Philippines Dramatic Club at the Manila Metropolitan Theater. During the Japanese occupation, it was directed by Narciso Pimentel Jr for Dramatic Philippines, becoming a popular piece in the group’s repertoire at the Manila Metropolitan Theater. It was originally written by Rodrigo in English for his class in dramatics under Jean Edades at the University of Santo Tomas. Later, Rodrigo revised and expanded his story and subsequently translated it into Tagalog. It was published in Short Plays of the Philippines, 1950, edited by Jean Edades.

Its principal character, Kulas, is a typical sabungero (cockfighter) addicted to the cockpit. Incidentally, he is subservient to his wife, Celing, who is against her husband’s gambling. Kulas encounters the usual problems in cockfighting, and often ends up losing both his money and his treasured cocks, which suffer defeat and death in the pit. Unknown to Kulas, however, Celing—to ensure that they do not lose money—would send Teban, the help, to bet against her husband’s cocks whenever Kulas put up any of them in a fight. One day, a friend teaches Kulas how, without crippling the cock, to hinder it from using its legs for fighting. He then suggests that Kulas bet on the other side so that he would not lose his money, as his cock would surely lose. As usual, Celing asks Teban to bet against Kulas’s cock. In a funny turn of events, both Kulas and Teban lose their bets. In the confusion that follows Kulas learns of his wife’s efforts to keep the family coffers and realizes the foolishness of gambling. Despite their loss, Celing suggests that they invite the neighbors to celebrate with them as they serve Kulas’s remaining cocks for dinner.

 

Sa Pula, Sa Puti!, a comedy, comments on people’s foibles in a situation recognizable throughout the country. Owing to this familiar theme, it has been translated and successfully presented in other Philippine languages and has been a favorite of students and amateur theater groups.  Written by Cynthia San Juan and Malou L. Maniquis
