text:
1953. One-act play in English. Direction and script, Severino Montano. Cast: Julita R. Genove, Esteban AG. Asprec, Saturnino R. Magturo, Gloria P. Alvarez, Jesusa M. Saddam, Generoso M. Bona, Ma. Socorro Dulay, Remedios C. Lotho, Florencio Miguel, and Ulrich van Holten (Tag Ellinger). First staged by the Arena Theater of the Philippines on 6 Mar 1953 at the Arena Theater of the Philippine Normal College in Manila. It was first published in Severino Montano’s Three One-Act Plays, 1953.

The play takes place in Kawakan, a small coastal barrio in northern Luzon. It opens with chant-like prayers for the dead Maria (“Death is a loneliness! Death is a sadness! … Dark is the mist that covers us, and weak indeed is the clay house! Look upon us, O God, who are living!”), and for her daughter Sabina (“She is but a frail jar against the mighty tides! … From the ravages of sin and the scorching heat of hellfire, deliver Sabina, O Lord, from evil!”).

The past comes back to life. Sabina, an innocent barrio girl, has fallen in love with George Price, a traveling American trader. In spite of everyone in the barrio being against the relationship, most especially her own family, she persists in trust and does not heed their warnings. When she tells “Mr George,” however, that she is going to have his baby and speaks happily of marriage, he reveals that he is already married. Her despair comes not only from the betrayal of her trust (“There’s an emptiness lying between us now, a wide, black, silent darkness! And no power on earth can brighten this darkness forever”), but from the fear of ridicule (“I can only hear the misers of love laughing in the darkness! … What shall I ever tell them now?”) A gunshot is heard; Sabina is brought out dead. The people begin to understand (“Ours will be the sadness now, ours … the loneliness forever!”). Soon the prayers for the dead begin again.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis

text:
(A Dozen Pair of Shoes). 2013. Musical in two acts, in Filipino. Direction and set design, Tuxqs Rutaquio; script and adaptation, Layeta Bucoy; musical direction, Jed Balsamo; lyrics, Noel Cabangon; choreography, Gerald Mercado; lights design, John Batalla; costumes, James Reyes and Leeroy New; sound, TJ Ramos. Cast: Trixie Esteban (Susie), Tessa Prieto-Valdez/Hazel Maranan (Shoe Fairy), Jonathan Tadioan (Father), May Bayot (Mother), and Regina de Vera (Sister). An adaptation of the award-winning children’s book of the same title penned by Luis Gatmaitan, the play was first staged on 13-21 Jul 2013 at the Tanghalang Huseng Batute, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), by Tanghalang Pilipino for its 27th theater season opening, as well as in celebration of the National Children’s Book Day. It was also chosen as the country’s representative to the 2014 Beijing International Theater Olympics in China. IdeaCube, an events company, organized the rerun of the musical on 28-31 Aug 2014 with a talk-back session with Gatmaitan.

 

The play starts with the actors representing shoes skating around Susie, a shoemaker’s child, born with no feet. In Susie’s dreams, assorted shoes take on humanlike forms as moving, talking, and skating beings, ruled by the Shoe Fairy. They comfort Susie and play with her. Susie’s insecurity, which causes her misery, stems from her awareness that she will not be able to live out her father’s dream for her to be a ballerina. When her family presents her with a laptop for her birthday, she smashes it out of frustration. Her father walks out. All she wants for her birthday is a single day to wear the magical shoes she has in her dreams which will allow her to walk. She wants to dance with her father as she dances with the Shoe Fairy in her dreams. Her mother and sister comfort her and tell her that it is not all her fault that her father is so stressed. Susie’s father succumbs to an illness. After his death, her mother and sister discover among his stash all the shoes that Susie saw in her dreams.

The musical is a moving ode to a father’s love for a daughter. The play also tackled domestic issues that are very familiar to Filipino families such as poverty, broken dreams, and death.  Written by Trixie Dauz

text:
(Dreamed Alliance). 1902. One-act opera in Tagalog composed by Ladislao S. Bonus.

The original Spanish libretto, titled La Alianza Soñada, was written by Pedro A. Paterno and was later translated into Tagalog by Roman G. Reyes with the title, Sangdugong Panaguinip. The opera was first translated into English by Arthur W. Fergusson, then Executive Secretary to Civil Governor William H. Taft. Another translation of the libretto in English by Col Walter H. Loving of the Philippine Constabulary Band was later published by the Imprenta de R. Mercantil de J. Loyzaga (Santiago 2009, 79). It was premiered on 2 Aug 1902 with the Orquesta Molina conducted by Ladislao Bonus assisted by Alejo Carluen at the Teatro Zorrilla to a full-house, with 1,500 seats sold in advance. Among the celebrated local singers who performed the principal roles were Juana Molina, Julian Benito, and Patricio Loyola. The opera ran for at least eight performances at the Teatro Zorrilla.

Sangdugong Panaguinip expresses a strong pro-American sentiment as it was written to legitimize America’s intrusive presence in the country. According to Rivera, the work was “regarded as a propaganda opera advocating American rule in the archipelago” (Rivera 2009, 89). At the inaugural performance, the theater was draped with numerous American flags, and it was attended by a number of high American civil officials, among whom were Taft, Fergusson, and Loving.

A short synopsis written by Raymundo Bañas (1969, 202-3) reads:

A band of Muslims invades Luzon and imposes taxes or tribute on every maiden in the towns of Pasig, Cainta and Antipolo, Rizal. Led by Lapu, the inhabitants of these towns were unified by way of a blood compact so as to repel the invaders. One night while pondering his plan to conquer the Muslims, Lapu fell asleep in a cave known as the cave of Doña Geronima. He dreamt of having seen a rainbow with rays leading to paradise and illuminated by a constellation of American stars. Lapu saw an American-Pilipino alliance, which under Bathala’s guidance could lead to prosperity and happiness of his people.

The play is an allegory using characters as symbols of political and social forces working in the Philippines to cement the relationship between the United States and the Philippines, described in the libretto as follows:

In the first scene, while Lapu is asleep, the orchestra plays the Spanish March while a woman representing Spain appears on the scene, embraces the Filipino woman and points out the road to progress... The “Star-Spangled Banner” is played afterwards as the scene changes and the Statue of Liberty looms in the background. What seemed at first to be a comet grows into a group of stars forming the Filipino flag. The orchestra then plays the Philippine national anthem to conclude the play, the Filipinos embracing the Statue of Liberty representing the United States (Fernandez and Tiongson 1994, 235).

The music of Sangdugong Panaguinip was written for orchestra and various vocal parts. There are nine vocal solo parts: one tiple, one tiple soprano, one primer baritono, two tenores, two tenor partiquino (small parts), one segundo baritono, and a bajo. There is also a chorus that plays an important role in the unfolding of the narrative. Among the orchestral instruments specified in the reduced score for piano were cornetos (horns), cornetinos (small trumpet), fagot (bassoon), bombo platillo (bass drum), trompetas (trumpets), and caja vivo (small drum) (Rivera 2009, 98). The arias and choruses are predominantly set in dance rhythms such as the balitaw, danza, and marcha, and they are mostly through-composed following the poetic flow of the verses (Rivera 2009, 99-100).

The musical score is divided into five scenes, introduced by a sinfonia (orchestral overture) in four distinct sections with differing tempi, key signatures, and character. Remarkable in the first scene is the superimposition of the “Star-Spangled Banner” on the “Marcha Nacional Filipina” in the dream sequence. The presence of the melody of the familiar “La Flor de Manila” (The Flower of Manila) in the fourth scene is also notable. The opera ends with a return of the two superimposed anthems where the American anthem is played by the orchestra while the Philippine anthem serves as an obbligato played by a corneto obligato.

Sangdugong Panaguinip is considered the first Tagalog and Philippine opera and a work that legitimized and strengthened the uneasy political relationship between the Filipino upper class and the conquering American forces.  Written by Arwin Q. Tan

Sources

Rivera Mirano, Elena, ed. 2009. “The Case of Marcelo Adonay, Musician.” In The Life and Works of Marcelo Adonay, 5-52. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

What seemed at first to be a comet grows into a group of stars forming the Filipino flag. The orchestra then plays the Philippine national anthem to conclude the play, the Filipinos embracing the Statue of Liberty representing the United States (Fernandez and Tiongson 1994, 235).

The music of Sangdugong Panaguinip was written for orchestra and various vocal parts. There are nine vocal solo parts: one tiple, one tiple soprano, one primer baritono, two tenores, two tenor partiquino (small parts), one segundo baritono, and a bajo. There is also a chorus that plays an important role in the unfolding of the narrative. Among the orchestral instruments specified in the reduced score for piano were cornetos (horns), cornetinos (small trumpet), fagot (bassoon), bombo platillo (bass drum), trompetas (trumpets), and caja vivo (small drum) (Rivera 2009, 98). The arias and choruses are predominantly set in dance rhythms such as the balitaw, danza, and marcha, and they are mostly through-composed following the poetic flow of the verses (Rivera 2009, 99-100).

The musical score is divided into five scenes, introduced by a sinfonia (orchestral overture) in four distinct sections with differing tempi, key signatures, and character. Remarkable in the first scene is the superimposition of the “Star-Spangled Banner” on the “Marcha Nacional Filipina” in the dream sequence. The presence of the melody of the familiar “La Flor de Manila” (The Flower of Manila) in the fourth scene is also notable. The opera ends with a return of the two superimposed anthems where the American anthem is played by the orchestra while the Philippine anthem serves as an obbligato played by a corneto obligato.

Sangdugong Panaguinip is considered the first Tagalog and Philippine opera and a work that legitimized and strengthened the uneasy political relationship between the Filipino upper class and the conquering American forces.  Written by Arwin Q. Tan

text:
(The Hand That Cannot Be Bitten, Must Be Kissed). 1901. Sarsuwela in Pangasinan. Libretto, Catalino Palisoc; music, Juan Aquino. First staged in 1901 in Lingayen, Pangasinan.

Forced by the Spanish friar, Carlos has agreed to marry off his daughter Filipinas to the despensero (servant of the Spanish curate). Luis Espinola, a law student and suitor of Filipinas, vows to prevent the marriage from taking place. Meanwhile, Luis’s father, who is vying for the position of capitan (municipal mayor), fails to get the approval of the friar, who has another person in mind—namely, his servant. Luis confronts the friar who, after a brief exchange of harsh words with him, orders his arrest and that of his father, who is accused of being a mason and a filibustero (subversive). Filipinas learns of the arrest and sees the friar to tell him that she is willing to marry the servant in exchange for the release of Luis and his father. In response, the lecherous priest reveals his desire for her, but she flings his hand away, leaving him with a warning. Released from prison, Luis proposes that they elope to Manila.

Considered the first Pangasinan sarsuwela, the play is said to have been written in 1897 but fear of arrest caused it to be staged only in 1901 when Palisoc was presidente municipal (mayor) of Lingayen. It was so successful—because of its portrayal of friar rule, and its difference from the komedya —that other towns in the province requested performances.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis

 

Source

Magno, Iluminada M. 1954. “A Critical Study of the Zarzuelas in Pangasinan of Catalino Palisoc.” MA thesis, College of Arts and Sciences, University of the Philippines.

text:
(Crazy Sepa). 1957. One-act play in English. Direction, John Morrow; script, Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio; musical direction, Vic Dames and Emy Layagne; choreography, Thais Robertson; production, costume, and lighting design, Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio. Cast: Bob McElya, Thais Robertson, Leigh Dean, Laura Foreman, Jaquelin Goland, Peggy Post, Elaine Sulka, Don Castelo, Leigh Dean, William Smith, Tony Roemer, Stan Samber, Dick Brooks, Sharon Hayden, and Judilee Tash. Its first performance was by the Wisconsin Players on 22 May 1957 at the Play-Circle Theater of the University of Wisconsin at Madison, Wisconsin, United States. The play was first published in the Literary Apprentice in 1958.

The play uses pantomime and dancelike movements to show flashbacks. It opens with a narration by the son, who describes the small town and the people living in it. The humble old town is a fishing village with simple, hardworking men and women whose skins are browned by the sun. The son is an engineer directing the construction of roads and bridges in his town. The town character is Sepang Loca, who wanders about and lives by herself. On the feast day of Santa Clara, when infertile women dance and chant their prayers, he remembers her dancing in abandon, while other women stood horrified. The son recalls that one night Sepang Loca and her baby were found dead.

 

The next scene is set in the whitewashed kitchen of the son’s family residence. His mother comments on the son’s drinking with his men at the end of the day. Father enters, bringing the news that the village folk are gathered in curiosity at the aplaya (seaside). It is learned that old Elena, a neighbor to Sepang Loca, had heard the whimper of a child. When she brought warm soup for Sepang Loca to start her milk, she found no one in the house, which looked as if it had been abandoned hastily. She called on the neighbors to help search for the woman and her child, and a village girl found Sepang Loca cold and dead, slumped over the mouth of the stone well, her arms dangling down its slimy inside. Her baby was not in sight, and the village speculated that she must have dropped the baby inside the deep abandoned well.

His parents eat hurriedly to join the neighbors, but the son does not budge, and would rather read. At the aplaya, the men take turns climbing down the well while the women watch and keep the coffee warm on the fire, around which they chat and wonder how Sepang Loca died. The well, deep and weed-choked, makes search difficult without drowning oneself. The son joins the crowd; the baby is fished out of the murky well—a bloated body. The women curse the unknown father. A woman notices that the child has a big black drop on his chest, which the mother recognizes as resembling her son Mauricio’s own birthmark. Her glistening eyes search the group until they fall on her son, whose back is turned to her. The last scene continues the son’s opening narration.

Sepang Loca was written by Lapeña-Bonifacio while she was studying for her master of arts degree in theater arts at the University of Wisconsin. It won third place in the 1957 National Playwriting Contest sponsored by the Wisconsin Players open to undergraduate and graduate students all over the United States.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis

 

Source

Lapena-Bonifacio, Amelia. 1981. Sepang Loca and Others. Quezon City: University of the Philippine Press.

article_title: Shadows Of The Reef/mga Anak Ng Dagat

photos.desc: Dulaang UP’s Shadows of the Reef/Mga Anak ng Dagat , UP Diliman, 2006 (Winter David)

text:
2004. Dance-drama in two acts, in English. Direction and script, Anton Juan Jr; Filipino translation, Allan Palileo; music, Francisco Feliciano’s Missa Mysterium; choreography, Myra Beltran, 2004, and Dexter Santos, 2006. First Philippine cast: Frances Makil-Ignacio/Diana Malahay (Lupe), Andoy Ranay/Peter Serrano (Padre Justo), Joseph Gabriel/Lance Reblando (Gabriel); Stella Driva, Geraldine Villamil, and Don Caesar Justiniani. It was first staged at the David Thayer Theater, University of Iowa, on 4 Nov 2004 under the university’s International Partnership in the Arts program. It made its Philippine premiere on 15 Jul 2006 at the Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero Theater of the University of the Philippines Diliman (UP) as the 31st season opener for Dulaang UP.

Shadows of the Reef, a dramatic tale told through dance, tableaux, and religious rituals and images, is about a remote and poverty-stricken fishing village whose young boys dive considerable depths to earn their living. A fishing trawler first casts its big nets over the ocean surface. The boys then dive until they reach the corals on the ocean floor where the fish hide. They beat the corals to force the fish out, sending them up to be trapped in the nets. This fishing technique, known as muro-ami, has endangered some boys, who get entangled and sometimes even drown in the net. Meanwhile, to stave off hunger, the villagers dig up wild yam, a poisonous crop; while the womenfolk climb the trawlers and prostitute themselves. Among these prostitutes is Lupe, the central character, whose son Gabriel dies due to muro-ami. Lupe reveals to the village priest, Padre Justo, her desire to be nailed to the cross on Good Friday to rid herself of the guilt caused by her son’s death. But the priest rejects her request for being a woman and, more so, for being a prostitute.

 

In the second half, the women sing the pasyon (verse narrative on the life and suffering of Jesus Christ) while the penitents flagellate themselves. These figures appear like images in a retablo (altarpiece). Soon their repentance is transformed into respite and they are transfigured. A child drowns and Lupe saves him; the crowd cheers but exalts the savior, in a surprising way, by shouting “Crucify her! Crucify her!” Lupe is nailed on the cross and her agony and ecstasy is followed by a vision where her son does not die and grows instead into a handsome young man. She becomes divine for a second. But unlike Christ, the moment she alights from the cross, she becomes a woman again.

With great success, Juan uses the very net used for muro-ami to seal the message of the play. The huge net is hung from the ceiling of the theater and is dropped on the audience at the end of the play. And to further highlight the point that there is no room for catharsis, the actors do not bow but instead freeze in a tableau, their faces contorted as if drowning, and unmoving until the audience has left the theater. The play uses the pasyon to allude to the struggle of the poor and their hopes for redemption, at the same time subverting the Christ-image via Lupe’s crucifixion. The play does not only paint a picture of a decaying society but also offers an objective and critical stance in addressing the issue of neglect and poverty.  Written by Carlo Pacolor Garcia

text:
(Bulusan and Agingay). 1990. Musical dance-drama in Bikol. Direction, Dan Razo; script, Reynaldo “Tootsie” Jamoralin; choreography, Julio Mendoza; lyrics, Glenda Razo; musical arrangement, Dan Razo and cast members; musical score, Ojee Lucero; stage manager, Rolando Habolin. Cast (alternating over several performances): Jude Frago, Rey Karlo Valladolid, Nilo Raymundo, Glenda Razo, Nestor Guardian, Cristina Digos, Tom Hagos, and Becky Razo. First staged in 1990 by the Sorsogon Community-Based Theater Group (CBTG) through a National Commission for Culture and the Arts grant, the play is the longest-running production of the Sorsogon CBTG. Since 1990, the play has been performed in Laguna, Pangasinan, Mountain Province, Benguet, at least 12 municipalities of Sorsogon, Sorsogon City, Aquinas University Legaspi in Naga, and at the Cultural Center of the Philippines.

 

The play begins with the burial of Apo Juban, the leader of the tribe. His death becomes an opportunity for his only son and successor, Casiguran, to plot against the mighty warrior Bulusan of whom he is jealous. Bulusan is Apo Juban’s beloved and trusted follower and now has been chosen by Agingay, the most beautiful woman in the village, to be her husband. Casiguran wants Agingay for himself. Casiguran connives with the soothsayer Putiao so that the latter would, through a ritual, declare Bulusan as the murderer of Apo Juban. Putiao declares that Bulusan killed Apo Juban by poisoning. This angers everyone, including the three elders Gurang Donsol, Gurang Matnog, and Gurang Bacon who then condemn Bulusan to death. Bulusan is fed to the hungry man-eating black bird Mampak. But even after Bulusan’s death, Agingay continues to refuse Casiguran’s love. In despair, Casiguran orders Agingay’s child by Bulusan to be killed at birth. This time, Putiao can no longer bear the guilt and decides to speak up, but he is killed. Before he dies, he is able to confess his guilt to Irosin, the wife of Casiguran. Irosin, unable to bear the burden of the revelation, reveals the truth. The villagers and the elders turn against Casiguran. They search for him and condemn him to the same fate as Bulusan; he is fed to the Mampak. The villagers then look for Agingay but it is too late. Agingay and her newborn child lie dead at the foot of the volcano.

Drawing from local folklore, the play utilizes pantomina, a Bikol courtship dance inspired by the movements of doves for the courtship sequence between Bulusan and Agingay. The pantomina was considered to be the play’s highlight for it expresses local culture and tradition.  Written by Rebecca Razo

 

Sources

Jamoralin, Reynaldo. 1994. Tracing from Solsogon to Sorsogon. Sorsogon City.

photos.desc: Kaliwat Theater Collective’s Siak sa Duha Ka Damgo, Davao City, 1992 (Photo courtesy of Kaliwat Theater Collective)

text:
(Crack in Two Dreams) 1991. Musical in three acts, in Cebuano. Direction, Nestor Horfilla; script, Nestor Horfilla with Arnel Mardoquio and the Kaliwat Theater Collective; musical direction, Jorge “Joji” Benitez; stage management, Richard Dian Belar; technical direction, Melvin Lamanilao. Cast: Marili Fernandez (Ye), Ranulfo “Popong” Landero (Felimon), Eden Licayan-Espejo (Syana), Geejay Bajo-Arreola (Junior), Narayan Duhaylungsod (Fernando), Arnel Mardoquio/Feblito Dinelasa (Brando), and Vicente Tringquete (Malid). The play was initially performed by the Kaliwat Theater Collective of the Mindanao Community Theater Network in several communities in Davao City in 1991. It became part of the Unang Tagpo (First Scene) Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) National Theater Festival in Manila in 1992 and was performed in an open space along the breakwater area of the CCP grounds before an audience of artists and art enthusiasts from various regions.

Siak sa Duha ka Damgo is the story of two families who have set their goal of getting gold in the mountains. The fisherfolk family—Felimon and his wife Syana and child Junior—is in search of a more sustainable livelihood so that they can settle the debts they have incurred as a result of a waning fish catch. The small-town proprietor’s family of Fernando and Brando is likewise in search of a more profitable venture as poor business returns hit their business. The two families meet Malid and Ye, members of a Blaan tribe family, who are in an intense discussion on the true meaning of progress as they themselves parry the blows of development on their ancestral lands. The families of fisherman Felimon and businessman Fernando realize that gold lies in the ancestral land of the Blaan. Malid and Ye explain the importance of making an offering to the diwata (spirit) and the ancestors so that they may be led to the path of progress.

 

At this point, one of the actors asks the audience which ending they prefer to see: a happy ending or a sad ending? In the happy ending, Junior saves her father Felimon from falling off the cliff. Felimon brings a chest, which apparently contains the key to humankind’s salvation. The audience’s attention is then requested as Malid explains the need to call on the next generation’s help in opening the chest. The chest yields a fishing net, a golden fishing line and weight, which means that nature demands care and attention in order to flourish. Felimon decides to go back to fishing while Fernando transforms into a farmer and promises to nurture the land for everybody so that nature may yield the paradise they have been longing for.

On the other hand, in the sad ending, Brando jumps off the cliff as an offering. Syana and Junior decide to jump to their death too since Felimon has also fallen off the cliff. Malid and Ye sing a sad song on the wrath of nature as floods engulf the land, and the scene ends with a prayer through Joey Ayala’s song “Bathala” (God).

The play’s distinction lies in its efforts to break the wall between the audience and the performers. At the start of the play, the actors and the musicians engage their audience in a lively banter through song and dance. As the play progresses, the audience is made to transfer to three performing areas, which tell of the condition of the three families—that of the fisherfolk, the small-town proprietor, and the Lumad family. At a certain point, the audience will be led by the actors to a center of convergence where they can take part in the meeting of the three families. In the end, the actors ask the audience which ending they prefer to see. The audience must watch the play at least twice in order to witness the two endings.

The play is a product of the Kaliwat Theater Collective’s efforts to bring community participation through theater processes. Through careful research and interactive processes with several communities in the Davao provinces, the actors brought to life the community concerns that they experienced and presented these stories to the community using theater processes as critical tools for reflection and transformation. The performance process, done in the seaside communities and Lumad communities, can be well described using Augusto Boal’s “rehearsal for change” as the audience is engaged in giving out comments in some portions of the play and choosing which ending they prefer toward the end of the performance. Likewise, the performance area is defined by setting up materials found in the community. The performance commences and ends with the musicians engaging the audience in a participatory song-and-dance number, establishing the audience’s significant role in the progress of the performance. The actors likewise are dressed in the likeness of the community characters they portray, with only the performance area as their delineation as actors in a performance. From time to time, the actors seek their audience’s participation, thus establishing the audience’s significant role in the play’s use of theater as a forum for community action.  Written by Glecy C. Atienza

article.value: (Crack in Two Dreams) 1991. Musical in three acts, in Cebuano. Direction, Nestor Horfilla; script, Nestor Horfilla with Arnel Mardoquio and the Kaliwat Theater Collective; musical direction, Jorge “Joji” Benitez; stage management, Richard Dian Belar; technical direction, Melvin Lamanilao. Cast: Marili Fernandez (Ye), Ranulfo “Popong” Landero (Felimon), Eden Licayan-Espejo (Syana), Geejay Bajo-Arreola (Junior), Narayan Duhaylungsod (Fernando), Arnel Mardoquio/Feblito Dinelasa (Brando), and Vicente Tringquete (Malid). The play was initially performed by the Kaliwat Theater Collective of the Mindanao Community Theater Network in several communities in Davao City in 1991. It became part of the Unang Tagpo (First Scene) Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) National Theater Festival in Manila in 1992 and was performed in an open space along the breakwater area of the CCP grounds before an audience of artists and art enthusiasts from various regions.

Siak sa Duha ka Damgo is the story of two families who have set their goal of getting gold in the mountains. The fisherfolk family—Felimon and his wife Syana and child Junior—is in search of a more sustainable livelihood so that they can settle the debts they have incurred as a result of a waning fish catch. The small-town proprietor’s family of Fernando and Brando is likewise in search of a more profitable venture as poor business returns hit their business. The two families meet Malid and Ye, members of a Blaan tribe family, who are in an intense discussion on the true meaning of progress as they themselves parry the blows of development on their ancestral lands. The families of fisherman Felimon and businessman Fernando realize that gold lies in the ancestral land of the Blaan. Malid and Ye explain the importance of making an offering to the diwata (spirit) and the ancestors so that they may be led to the path of progress.

article.value: At this point, one of the actors asks the audience which ending they prefer to see: a happy ending or a sad ending? In the happy ending, Junior saves her father Felimon from falling off the cliff. Felimon brings a chest, which apparently contains the key to humankind’s salvation. The audience’s attention is then requested as Malid explains the need to call on the next generation’s help in opening the chest. The chest yields a fishing net, a golden fishing line and weight, which means that nature demands care and attention in order to flourish. Felimon decides to go back to fishing while Fernando transforms into a farmer and promises to nurture the land for everybody so that nature may yield the paradise they have been longing for.

On the other hand, in the sad ending, Brando jumps off the cliff as an offering. Syana and Junior decide to jump to their death too since Felimon has also fallen off the cliff. Malid and Ye sing a sad song on the wrath of nature as floods engulf the land, and the scene ends with a prayer through Joey Ayala’s song “Bathala” (God).

The play’s distinction lies in its efforts to break the wall between the audience and the performers. At the start of the play, the actors and the musicians engage their audience in a lively banter through song and dance. As the play progresses, the audience is made to transfer to three performing areas, which tell of the condition of the three families—that of the fisherfolk, the small-town proprietor, and the Lumad family. At a certain point, the audience will be led by the actors to a center of convergence where they can take part in the meeting of the three families. In the end, the actors ask the audience which ending they prefer to see. The audience must watch the play at least twice in order to witness the two endings.

The play is a product of the Kaliwat Theater Collective’s efforts to bring community participation through theater processes. Through careful research and interactive processes with several communities in the Davao provinces, the actors brought to life the community concerns that they experienced and presented these stories to the community using theater processes as critical tools for reflection and transformation. The performance process, done in the seaside communities and Lumad communities, can be well described using Augusto Boal’s “rehearsal for change” as the audience is engaged in giving out comments in some portions of the play and choosing which ending they prefer toward the end of the performance. Likewise, the performance area is defined by setting up materials found in the community. The performance commences and ends with the musicians engaging the audience in a participatory song-and-dance number, establishing the audience’s significant role in the progress of the performance. The actors likewise are dressed in the likeness of the community characters they portray, with only the performance area as their delineation as actors in a performance. From time to time, the actors seek their audience’s participation, thus establishing the audience’s significant role in the play’s use of theater as a forum for community action.  Written by Glecy C. Atienza

text:
(Storm). 1986. Two-act play in Filipino. Direction, Nanding Josef; script, Rene O. Vilanueva; music direction, Ronnie Quesada. Cast: Manny Pambid (Del), Ellen Ongkeko (Richie), and Alan Glinoga (Mol). First staged on 30 Jan 1986 by the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) in the left wing (audience view), commonly called by PETA artists as Wanda’s wing, of the Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Fort Santiago, Intramuros, Manila. Due to the events following the snap elections in February, the show’s run was cut short by a week.

The play is set in 1982 in one of the residential houses for faculty members of a university in Diliman, Quezon City. It begins with Del and Richie entering Del’s residence after attending Nick’s burial. Nick was their close friend and was also Richie’s boyfriend in college until Nick decided to go to the mountains. Richie tells Del she won’t stay long because her family is waiting for her. Del tells her to just wait until Mol, a friend who now works in the government bureaucracy, arrives. They talk about who among their fellow activist friends from 10 years ago attended the burial. Del asks how Richie is now but she is evasive. She says she has a comfortable life now, writing celebrity gossips. Del says he misses reading Richie’s thought-provoking articles. Richie tells him a decade is too long for one not to change. Richie later reveals how she was invited and questioned for hours by the military, several years back, for an investigative report she wrote on the Chico Dam project in Kalinga. Del then asks her why she did not speak during Nick’s internment. He talks on how ambiguous the details of Nick’s death are. Reports say it was because of an encounter with the military; gossip says he was captured alive and was tortured. Richie, not wanting to hear any more of what happened, expresses her wish to just remember Nick when he was still alive. Del comments that she still loves Nick. Richie answers maybe, and adds how a decade is not enough to change them completely.

After several days, Richie, Del, and now with Mol, find themselves enjoying a few drinks at Del’s place. It is almost midnight, and Mol and Del are already tipsy. Mol explains why he wasn’t able to come to Nick’s burial. They then recollect their beginnings as four friends who dabbled in poetry; and on how, searching for new subjects for their writing, they eventually became activists during the 1970s. Their conversation always goes back to Nick, who was initially apprehensive about joining rallies but was the first and only one of them who went to the mountains to join the New People’s Army upon the declaration of martial law. Exasperated, Richie asks why they must keep bringing up memories of Nick. Tension begins when Del questions what has become of them since Nick left for the mountains. They start critiquing each other’s decision for not taking up arms as well. Del talks about his physical and emotional incapacity at that time. Richie and Mol blame Del for allowing himself to be followed by military agents that led to the arrest of some members of their group. Mol narrates his experience of torture for not squealing on other underground members’ name, as well as his three years in a Bicutan jail. Their conversation escalates to a point that they are now measuring each other’s level of commitment to their cause more than a decade ago. Realizing how emotionally difficult the situation has become, Mol leaves.

The play revolves around the changes of perspectives between activists who lay low in the 1970s and early 1980s after individually experiencing the horrors of martial law. A slide presentation on street protest was utilized during Del’s monologue. The character of Nick alludes to that of theater artist, poet, and martyred red warrior Emmanuel A. F. Lacaba. Sigwa won first prize in the full-length play category of the Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature in 1984. Its first act, titled Punla ng Dekada (Seed of the Decade), was also submitted in the one-act play category of the same year and won second prize.  Written by Erick Dasig Aguilar

text:
1995. Play in 14 scenes, in Bikol. Direction, Jazmin B. Llana and Julio Mendoza; script, Bernardo Aguay and Jazmin B. Llana, with July Mendoza, Dan Razo, and Tony Palis; project coordinator and production manager, Jocelyn A. Bisuña. Cast: Gregorio Hallare (Simeon A. Ola), Jocelyn A. Bisuña/Ma. Ira Bisuña (Daragang Magayon), Danilo Razo (Eligio), Bernardo O. Aguay Jr (Don Ramon Santos and Gurang Ente), Jazmin Llana (Doña Caridad), and Emmanuel Babilonia (Colonel Bandholtz and Garwood). First staged by Kaboronyogan Cultural Network on 17-21 Sep 1995 to represent Bikol in the Lusong Theater Festival held at the University of the Philippines Los Baños in Laguna. The play also represented Luzon in the second National Theater Festival of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) and was staged at the Aquinas University in Legazpi City on 11-18 Jan 1996. The play’s “Director’s Notes” was published in Ranga: Journal of Bikol Writing, 1997.

In the opening monologue, Daragang Magayon calls on her people to resist the oppressor. American Colonel Bandholtz entertains pro-American, wealthy abaca plantation owners Don Ramon Santos and company to tell them about America’s plans for Albay’s economy and education. Albayanos (locals of Albay), including Don Ramon’s wife Doña Caridad, support the insurgents against the Americans. Meanwhile, Simeon A. Ola, a captain in the Katipunan, transports funds amounting to 42,000 pesos to General Malvar in Cavite and continues the struggle against the Americans despite the imposition of the Sedition Law. Bandholtz, hurt fromOla’s raids, plans to bribe Olato surrender. But Olarejects Garwood’s offer of surrender.The Americans then intensify the campaign against the revolutionaries. Human rights violations by the American troops, news of General Malvar’s surrender, and the shooting of the oldest supporter Gurang Ente shatter the morale of the insurgents and their supporters.A shift to present-day incidents of burning of homes, kidnapping, and killing of farmers suspected of backing the New People’s Army, highlights the continuing suffering and struggle of the Bikol from the time of legends to the present. In the end, Don Ramon and his supporter Eligio begOlato surrender to end the great suffering of the people.Olasays he will think about it.Daragang Magayon ends the play in a tagulaylay or lament.

The play, which dramatizes the life of revolutionary Simeon A. Ola of Guinobatan, Albay, is an important contribution to Bikol drama. The production was a creative collaboration between the member organizations of the Kaboronyogan Bikol Cultural Network. The collective nature of its script and direction brought in the nuances of a variety of Bikol languages and dialects into the play.  Written by Paz Verdades M. Santos

text:
(Magic Boat). 1986/1987. Musical in Cebuano. Direction, Nestor Horfilla; script, Fe Remotigue and Don Pagusara; music, Joey Ayala, Popong Landero, Don Pagusara, and Eugene Villarino. Cast: Dabarawan, a composite dance-repertory group. First staged by DAPAT-Dabaw in Davao City.

The play focuses on the issue of ancestral land domain in Mindanao. Analyzing the problem from a historical point of view, the play traces the issue to the Spanish and American colonial periods. Mindanao, which has resisted Spanish conquest, finds itself being conquered instead by Christian Filipinos from other parts of the archipelago as a result of an American-sponsored decree declaring Mindanao, where land is rich and fertile, as open to migration and resettlement. The divide-and-rule strategy pits Filipinos against their brothers, the lumad (indigenous people), who find themselves displaced and driven deep into the forests. The Filipino Muslims, too, come into the picture, as the age-old rivals of Christianity. In one scene, the Christian peasants stand strong, claiming their newfound land, in a choral rendition. It is set against a dancing lumad maiden, who criticizes the Christians for being selfish, and swears to fight to the finish, in a melodious chanting voice. Those who come to till the land realize, however, that they have been trapped into a situation where they have to depend on institutions and government forces in order to keep their land. They also realize that they are being used as instruments for the evil intentions of a semicolonial system as personified by the giant Bakulaw.

 

The former rivals join forces to battle against evil. In one scene, the battle takes place on long bamboo poles held high up, as the warriors swing their kris. With the evil Bakulaw beaten and sent away, the lumad reclaim their rights to their land, while the Christians and Muslims learn to coexist peacefully. Though ideal, it remains the dream and vision of Mindanao.

While singing the title song “Sinalimba,” the cast calls on the audience to travel with them in their native boat, sinalimba, which is set by itself to one side of the audience, a swinging platform held a few inches above the ground.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis

text:
(Who Are You All?). 1943. One-act play in English. Direction, Narciso Pimentel Jr, script, Julian Cruz Balmaseda; translation and adaptation, Francisco “Soc” Rodrigo. Cast: Emma Benitez, Cora de Jesus, Conchita Liboro, Mitzi Ortiz, Narciso Pimentel Jr, Francisco “Soc” Rodrigo, and Oscar del Rosario. First staged on 20 Feb 1943 by Dramatic Philippines at the Metropolitan Theater in Manila.

 

This play is a farce built around sets of mistaken identities, made more confusing by characters entering and exiting at the wrong times. Doña Marcela has just been married to Crispin Sikuterat in the province, each hiding the existence of their grown-up children, her son and his daughter. Doña Marcela’s maid, Maria, and the houseboy, Juan Batugan, endeavor to conceal a secret of their own: their marriage and their baby son. Doña Marcela arrives in Manila; so does Crispin with his friend, Ubaldo, to whom he reveals that he is being threatened by a certain Maria, with whom he had been corresponding, and whom he has promised to marry. Maria, the servant, entering the sala, thinks Ubaldo is Doña Marcela’s new husband. Ubaldo thinks she is the Maria looking for Crispin. Juan, seeing Maria embrace Ubaldo, who has given her money, is jealous. Informed that the man is Doña Marcela’s new husband, he ushers him into the bedroom. Doña Marcela arrives, and finds a stranger in her room. Crispin arrives, and their counteraccusations of infidelity are complicated by the arrival of their respective children, Crispinita and Lucas, who turn out to be sweethearts. With Crispin and Marcela on the verge of separating, the identities are revealed, and the complications unraveled.

Originally written by Balmaseda as Sangkuwaltang Abaka (One Penny-Worth Abaca) and translated by Rodrigo into Tagalog, it was one of the few comedies of its period and perhaps one of the most performed comedies in Philippine theater.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

 

Source

Balmaseda, Julian Cruz. 1947. Ang Dulang Pilipino. Manila: Institute of National Language.

text:
(Professor Gecko’s Way). 1980. One-act play in Filipino. Direction, Len Santos; script, Al Santos; musical direction, Ricky Alvendia; production design, Joey Zuñiga. Cast: Manny Pambid, Spanky Manikan, Mary Joan Fajardo, Ricky Alvendia, and Apo Chua. An adaptation of a play by Alexander de Montleart, it was first staged by the Philippine Educational TheaterAssociation (PETA) on 7 Feb 1980 at the Dulaang Rajah Sulayman in Fort Santiago, Manila. In 2003, it was staged in a twin bill alongside Reijoo de la Cruz’s Tatlong Manyika (Three Dolls) by the University of the Philippines (UP) Repertory Company at the Aldaba Hall in UP Diliman. In 2012, the play was featured in Mutya (Muse), a twin bill that also featured Tomas Remigio’s Mga Santong Tao (People Saints), by Ateneo de Manila University’s ENTABLADO at the Rizal Mini Theater. It was published in the original Filipino version in the PETA-Kalinangan Ensemble Script Series 2 in 1983. The English translation by the author was published in Modern ASEAN Plays: Philippines, 1992, edited by Nicanor G. Tiongson.

Propesor Tuko is presented in his classroom on a “typical” class day, taking his students—Bodyok, an energetic basketball fan; Bondying, an overgrown baby; Kiko, a bright student on the honor list; and Ningning, an affable girl—through their lessons in literature, history, health and science, civics, and so forth.

 

The professor is often tardy, usually forgetful, and given to clichés, rote learning, punishing students (by physical blows or by being made to write phrases hundreds of times), old notes and outdated lesson plans. He collects money for activities that do not come to pass; he makes his class buy materials for such activities as making flags with which to welcome famous celebrities at the airport. His mischievous students consume class time by playing tricks on him: trapping him into their word games; bringing out information from current histories by Agoncillo and Constantino to show how outdated his lessons are; confronting him with the realities outside the classroom that they find more relevant and pressing (such as washing dishes, scrubbing floors, fetching water, and collecting pig swill); and lastly, hiding his glasses and their misdemeanors. Along the way his colonial thinking is bared: he adores Shakespeare but does not think Balagtas counts as a poet; he views history through Western eyes. His “system” brought about by 32 years of teaching is shown in all its absurdity as having been caused by low pay. This requires him to moonlight as a waiter in Cubao, which results in his being sleepy and tardy and unable to read new books or prepare his lessons. The play ends in a war, then a truce, in which students and teacher agree to help each other and to update Propesor Tuko’s absurd system.

The comedy of this farce is contained in physical stunts, wordplay, tricks and games, thus absurd to the core, and therefore so presented.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez, updated by Athena Angela Aquino

 

Source

Atienza, Glecy C. 1990. “Subersyon sa Dula sa Ilalilm ng Batas Militar: Mga Dula ng PETA 1975-1981.” MA thesis, College of Arts and Letters, University of the Philippines Diliman.

article.value: (Professor Gecko’s Way). 1980. One-act play in Filipino. Direction, Len Santos; script, Al Santos; musical direction, Ricky Alvendia; production design, Joey Zuñiga. Cast: Manny Pambid, Spanky Manikan, Mary Joan Fajardo, Ricky Alvendia, and Apo Chua. An adaptation of a play by Alexander de Montleart, it was first staged by the Philippine Educational TheaterAssociation (PETA) on 7 Feb 1980 at the Dulaang Rajah Sulayman in Fort Santiago, Manila. In 2012, the play was featured in Mutya (Muse), a twin bill that also featured Tomas Remigio’s Mga Santong Tao (People Saints), by Ateneo de Manila University’s ENTABLADO at the Rizal Mini Theater. Propesor Tuko is presented in his classroom on a “typical” class day, taking his students—Bodyok, an energetic basketball fan; Bondying, an overgrown baby; Kiko, a bright student on the honor list; and Ningning, an affable girl—through their lessons in literature, history, health and science, civics, and so forth.

text:
2008. Musical in two acts, in Filipino. Direction, Nor Domingo; script, Vincent de Jesus; music, Lucien Letaba; musical arrangement, Melvin Copin; production design, Leo Abaya; lights design, Jonjon Villareal; costume, Kalila Aguilos; choreography, Christine Crame-Santillan; photography and poster design, Jojit Lorenzo. Cast: Rem Zamora (Dr Beau Batoctol), Robert Seña (Narciso Dong-Can), Isay Alvarez (Isadora), May Bayot-de Castro (Amor de Sangre), Bituin Escalante (Marikit “Kit” Evangelista), Phil Noble (Pipay Organza), Red Anderson (Charleston “Chonggo” Go), Diana Malahay (Hapunta “Happy” Fuentes), Melvin Lee, Eric Bisa, Gail Guanlao-Billones, Mary Ann Espinosa, Al Gatmaitan, Glecy Atienza, Onyl Torres, Joseph Grantusa, Delphine Buencamino, Neomi Tabanao-Gonzales, Joan Bugcat, Eric de la Cruz, and Giu Comia. First staged from 8 Feb to 9 Mar 2008 by the Philippine Educational Theater Association as part of the company’s 40th season.

 

An internationally acclaimed cosmetic surgeon, Dr Beau Batoctol is opening the Skin-Deep Beauty Sanctuary in the Philippines, and seven distinct characters are all willing to undergo surgery for a whole range of reasons. The seven patients, known as the “Lucky Make-Over Seven,” are Marikit “Kit” Evangelista, the female call-center agent who is insecure about her obesity; Pipay Organza, a promiscuous middle-aged woman; Charleston “Chonggo” Go, the male talent who wants to achieve physical perfection to increase his demand in the flesh market; Isadora and Narciso Dong-Can, a troubled couple; Amor de Sangre, a florist and mail-order bride who desperately wants to look young for her future husband; and Hapunta “Happy” Fuentes, an abused housewife who wishes to salvage her ruined features. All seven of them approach and consult Dr Batoctol in a desperate search for solutions to their respective beauty problems. As the play progresses, each of the patients comes to a realization about what they truly seek. They come to terms with the fact that narcissism is not the path to the happiness and acceptance they are looking for.

Skin Deep is a play that makes the audience rethink its ideas of external and internal beauty and see the visible effect of narcissism on people’s lives. In a satirical vein, it successfully sheds light on the dichotomy between healing and destruction; between reality and superficiality. The play won the 2008 Philippine Legitimate Stage Artists Group Gawad Buhay! for Outstanding Musical Production.  Written by Ronald H. Biñas

 

Sources

Dimaculangan, J. 2008. “PETA’s Skin-Deep to Be Staged from February 1–March 9.” Philippine Entertainment Portal, 8 Jan. Accessed 27 Jan 2015.

Lardizabal-Dado, N. 2008. “Skin-Deep, A Review.” Touched by an Angel, 3 Mar. Accessed 27 Jan 2015.

text:
(Shadow and Solitude). 1917. One-act play in Spanish. Script, Claro M. Recto. First staged on 19 Jun 1917 at the Manila Grand Opera House. Cast: Praxedes (Yeyeng) Fernandez de Pastor, Joaquin de San Agustin, Adelina Amoros, and Francisco Zamora. It was translated into Tagalog by Francisco“Soc” Rodrigo as Nag-iisa sa Karimlan in 1954, while Nick Joaquin translated it into English as Shadow and Solitude in 1956. The play was staged in Filipino translation at the Dalubdulaan of the Manila Metropolitan Theater in 1980, and in China by Sining Silangan under the direction of Rustica Carpio in 1983. It was published in Outstanding Filipino Short Plays, 1961, edited by Alberto S. Florentino. It was again published in Early Philippine Literature: From Ancient Times to 1940, 1971, edited by Asuncion David-Maramba.

Written in Spanish when the author was in his early 20s, the play was dedicated to Chief Justice Cayetano Arellano and won first prize in a contest held by the dramatic guild Sociedad Talia. The prologue was written by poet CecilioApostol. It was acclaimed by both the public and critics.

Produced when the sarsuwela, komedya, and sinakulo were still popular, the drama is powerfully realistic. The theme of mundane love was common enough, but Recto viewed it critically from the perspective of the educational system and moral standards of the time. He vividly depicted the conflicts between two cultures: the conservative (Spanish) and the modern (American).

The play also portrays the changing role of women in Philippine society by contrasting moral and social values. Gabriela, the heroine, is conservative and religious. She is the unsuspecting and dutiful wife of Andres. When she discovers that her younger sister, Marina, is having an affair with her husband, she dies of a heart attack. Marina, who represents modern mores, repents, and leaves the unfaithful husband Andres grieving—alone in the dark.

Recto thought that by writing this play, he would encourage others to write Spanish plays, which were not faring too well vis-à-vis the play in Tagalog and other native languages.  Written by Elvira Santos-Verano

text:
2012. Musical in two acts, in Filipino. Direction, Chris Millado; script, Mario O’Hara; composition, arrangement, and musical direction, Jeffrey Hernandez; choreography, Denisa Reyes; lights design and technical direction, Katsch SJ Catoy; costume design, Brenda Fajardo; set design, Leeroy New; sound engineering, TJ Ramos; videography, King Catoy; vocal coaching, Mia Bolaños; tap dance instruction, Tony Casimiro; hair and makeup design, Yette Valenzuela. Cast: Nonie Buencamino/Roeder Camañag (Tirso), Shamaine Centenera-Buencamino/Liesl Batucan (Ester), May Bayot/Mae Paner (Magdea), Angelina Kanapi (Chabeng), Lou Veloso (beggar), Rody Vera, Jonathan Tadioan, Rayna Reyes, Gilbert Onida, Pamela Hundana, Gino Ramirez, April Iñigo, Tara Cabaero, Hazel Maranan, Kaye Garcia, Agnes Sarreal, Anthony Falcon, and Aaron Ching. First staged on 10 Oct 2012 by Tanghalang Pilipino at the Tanghalang Aurelio Tolentino, Cultural Center of the Philippines. In November of the same year, the play became part of the National Theater Festival.

Set in the 1950s, the play revolves around the love of Tres Dahlia’s lead singer Ester for her husband Tirso, a womanizing conductor of the band Tirso and the Bandits. A musical number, “Mambo Magsaysay,” is performed by the Tres Dahlias: Ester, Chabeng, and Magdea. Ester dreams about Tirso’s affairs but little does she know that another member of the Tres Dahlias is her rival in love, Chabeng. Tirso goes to his band rehearsals and performs “Tittina, My Tittina” with girls including Chabeng. Tirso goes missing after abandoning both Ester and Chabeng. Ester confronts Chabeng in the perya (carnival) where the latter plays the seductress babaeng gagamba or spider woman. Chabeng tries to help Ester find Tirso by giving her information, and asks for her forgiveness in the number “I Apologize.”

 

Ester finds out that her husband suffered a stroke and ended up on the streets of Manila as a beggar. She sets off to find her husband, going from town to town asking for her husband’s whereabouts. She suffers misfortunes, such as getting lost and robbed, and ends up with a beggar who subjects her to sexual abuse. Undaunted by her misfortunes, she manages to find Tirso, who is now very sick. With her forgiveness, Tirso expires with a bang in the number “I’m Gonna Live Till I Die.”

Stageshow is the last play written by O’Hara, honoring the forgotten artists of bodabil, the Filipino version of vaudeville. The play is staged like a bodabil performance with the narrative unfolding through skits and production numbers featuring songs and dances popular during the peak and waning years of bodabil. The play won the following awards in the 2008 Philippine Legitimate Stage Artists Group Gawad Buhay!: Outstanding Musical Production, Outstanding Stage Direction, Outstanding Book or Original Libretto, Outstanding Choreography for a Play or Musical, Female Lead Performance in a Musical (Centenera-Buencamino), Female Featured Performance in a Musical (Kanapi), and Male Featured Performance in a Musical (Vera).  Written by Trixie Dauz

text:
(Sister Clara). 2010. One-act play in Filipino. Direction and script, Floy Quintos; set and costume design, Eric Cruz; stage manager, Joseph Kevin Cardona; sound design, Janice Dee; lighting design, Dave Lim. Cast: Frances Makil-Ignacio (Suor Clara) and Ron Capinding (Bishop Salvi). First staged on 24 Jun 2010 at the Tanghalang Huseng Batute of the Cultural Center of the Philippines as part of Virgin Labfest 6. It is included in Floy Quintos: Collected Plays Volume 2, 2014.

It is midnight, 1898, and the revolution is under way. Suor Clara, more than 40 years old and Madre Superiora of the Convent of Santa Clara in Intramuros, recites sensuous passages from the Song of Solomon in her chamber. Interrupted by Bishop Salvi who is demanding to enter her room, she finishes reading and lets him in. Noticing the opened pages of the Bible, Salvi warns her of the impropriety of reading those passages, especially for a woman of her stature. Clara argues that the songs are part of the Bible, wherein the woman in the passages longs for her lover. Salvi continues that she should not say things like that to her subordinates. Clara tells him that her congregation already knows; that she encourages Sour Agatha during meal time to sing them with emotion and with Venancio in mind. Salvi begs her to lower her voice and inquires who Venancio is. She explains that he is the meat and vegetable seller who comes on Wednesdays. Clara suggests calling Agatha so that Salvi could hear her sing. Salvi, afraid of being seen in her chamber, asks her to lower her voice. Clara comforts him by saying that her congregation already knows that he visits her on occasion. He is dumbfounded. She asks about his almost one year of absence and Salvi speaks of the revolution that is happening outside the convent walls. Clara is made aware of this with propaganda pamphlets coming their way through Venancio who is part of the resistance. Salvi wants the convent to stop its communication with Venancio at once, but she counters that what happens outside the convent walls do not concern them. He vehemently asks what kind of convent it is. Clara answers that he should know as it was he who sent her there. She picks up a roll of paper and spreads it on the table, revealing the design for a new sculpture to be installed in her private sanctuary. It is a statue of the Virgin Mary dressed as a Grecian goddess sitting atop a mound of books and maps, as well as scientific, musical, and art instruments. Salvi accuses her of sacrilege and tears the paper to pieces. Clara becomes formal but says that the next time he comes, the sculpture would have been installed and cannot so easily be destroyed. Reciting the sensuous passages again, Salvi pleads for her to stop but she continues on. He wonders what might happen if the revolutionaries win, while her confidence on Venancio’s word regarding their safety is unwavering. Salvi asks what her relation to Venancio is, and Clara reveals that he visits her chamber during the early hours of the morning after the Matins. Salvi is scandalized, but Clara says that she hides nothing from her sisters. After Salvi denounces the convent as a brothel, Clara asks him to leave, exclaiming that he has no right to speak of the sisters that way since he never experienced the loss of freedom that they had. Lamenting over the “new” Clara, he apologizes for making her enter the convent. She answers that she has matured. Getting tired of his apologies, she tells him that she has gotten over her melancholy existence and has decided to devote her mind to learning, praying, and loving. She tells Salvi that he has become powerful, but she is the one who is happy. They imagine a scene where Clara is being burned at the stake. Salvi, witnessing the spectacle, strips his clothes and runs toward her and they both burn. Cradling him like a child, she tells him that she does not regret anything that she has done. Salvi finally reveals his fears of the revolution and that he has to leave the country. He persuades her to leave with him. She asks if he loves her, and he tells her that it was not just desire that sustained his visits for the past 25 years. She turns down his offer, saying she does not love him and relates that she has regained her freedom through the years of being in the convent. Clara remembers that when Ibarra asked for her forgiveness, he also left her, the way Salvi is doing now. He bids her a final goodbye and leaves the room. Finally alone, she removes her veil and reveals her gray hair while the singing of Matins begins.

 

Suor Clara is a reimagination of the characters Padre Salvi and Maria Clara created by Jose Rizal in his novels Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not) and El Filibusterismo (Subversion). Quintos transforms Maria Clara from an abiding woman in the novel into a resolute and empowered woman onstage. The play was awarded second prize in the one-act play category in Filipino in the 2010 Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature.  Written by Erick Dasig Aguilar

article.value: Suor Clara is a reimagination of the characters Padre Salvi and Maria Clara created by Jose Rizal in his novels Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not) and El Filibusterismo (Subversion). Quintos transforms Maria Clara from an abiding woman in the novel into a resolute and empowered woman onstage. The play was awarded second prize in the one-act play category in Filipino in the 2010 Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature.  Written by Erick Dasig Aguilar

text:
(Golden Chain). 1902. Drama simboliko in three acts, in Tagalog. Script, Juan Abad. First staged on 7 Jul 1902 at the Teatro Libertad. It was banned for being “seditious” on 10 May 1903 at a performance in Batangas, Batangas. Abad was sentenced to imprisonment for two years and fined 2,000 dollars. The decision of the Batangas Court of First Instance was later reversed by the Supreme Court. It was later published in 1907 after the Supreme Court acquitted him of sedition charges. Decades later, it was again published in Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio’s The “Seditious” Tagalog Playwrights: Early American Occupation, 1972, and in Arthur Riggs’s The Filipino Drama (1905), 1981.

The heroine, Liwanag (light, the Spirit of Independence), is betrothed to Kaulayaw (sweetheart, the loyal Filipino defender), but is separated from him and kept from marriage by her uncle and adoptive father Maimbot (avaricious, the American Insular Government). Maimbot has previously given consent, but now attempts to bribe her to his will with a tanikalang guinto (golden bracelet) that turns into a chain of bondage. He is aided by Liwanag’s traitorous brother Nagtapon (spendthrift, a collaborator with the Americans), whom he directs to spy on Kaulayaw. Dalita (dispossessed, the Motherland), mother of Liwanag and Nagtapon, is disowned by him, and dies in the first act. Maimbot’s gifts have no effect on Liwanag, and so he binds her to a tree, and places Nagtapon on watch. Kaulayaw, searching for her, is killed by Nagtapon. Liwanag, who wants to kill herself, is consoled by Diwa (Spirit of Struggle), who assures her that Kaulayaw is not dead. Nagtapon is tormented by souls and spirits, then taken away by the devil while Kamatayan takes Maimbot. Kaulayaw is taken by Bat (Goddess) and crowned by the Kaluluwa (Spirit) with flowers, while Liwanag and Diwa rise to the skies.

Next to Aurelio V. Tolentino’s Kahapon, Ngayon at Bukas, this is the most famous of the allegorical drama simboliko written in the early 1900s.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

 

Source

Lapeña-Bonifacio, Amelia. 1972. The “Seditious” Tagalog Playwrights: Early American Occupation. Manila: Zarzuela Foundation of the Philippines Inc.

text:
(Grease Man). 1982. One-act dramatic monologue. Script and direction, Anton Juan Jr. Cast: Lou Veloso. First staged by Dulaang UP in 1984 at the Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero Theater, University of the Philipppines Diliman. Subsequently performed in other venues all over the country, including the CAP Auditorium in Cebu City in 2007, the UP Visayas Auditorium in Iloilo City in 2014 (the latter with Alfredo B. Diaz), and in the PETA-Phinma Theater in 2014 as part of the Imaginarium: Multi-Arts Festival of the Absurd.

From the pavement where he has made a bed of empty cement sacks, the street person, called Tao or Everyman, is rudely awakened by the drunken singing of a prostitute and her old client as they enter a motel room. Under the dim street lights, the Tao looks decrepit, with sunken cheeks, rotten teeth, cracked lips, and skin burnt by the sun and covered with layers of dust and grease. He wears loose pants, fastened with abaca strings, and carries abayong(native bag) in which he keeps the scraps of food he collects from garbage cans and heaps. Despised and rejected by passersby, he has no one to talk to but his stomach which is forever growling for lack of food. He wishes his intestines were like those hanging behind glass in restaurants—clean, quiet, and quite dead. As he walks on the street, he hears an ambulance driving past, and imagines that its patient will soon die and be embalmed, its intestines taken out and replaced with cotton. To amuse himself, he crosses the street oblivious of traffic and earns a barrage of curses from motorists who almost run him over. As he reaches a particular street, he recalls a woman who lay on the pavement, all swollen and with blood running between her legs. She used to be a pretty turon (sweetened banana roll) vendor whom three policemen had raped. A firetruck careens through the night and the Tao imagines the people asleep in their beds burning with the city, and dying without ever understanding or caring why there are street persons like him. Understood or not, the Tao has a dignity of his own. He does not beg for alms; he walks the streets to scavenge for left-overs. Yet he can turn away from a bag of mooncakes as he did once, because the man who tossed it at him did not even look him in the eyes. Affirming himself, he reveals his name. He is Samuel, and like his namesake Samuel Belibet, he is cursed to live and walk forever. He is tired of watching people day in and day out going in and out of buildings, moviehouses, kabarets, restaurants, and funeral parlors. But he has no choice. As he and his growling stomach head for a cleaner street corner to sleep in, they look forward to the next day, the feast of the Nazarene in Quiapo, where thousands of people will fill the streets, stare at him—and not see him.

 

Taong Grasa won first prize in the one-act play category of the 1982 Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature. For its attempt to show poverty from the point of view of the poorest of the poor and for showing the street person as no less pathetic than the rest of humanity that despises him, it is considered one of the most successful dramatic monologues in Philippine theater.  Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

article_title: Tatarin: A Witches' Sabbath In Three Acts
text:
1978. Three-act play in English. Direction, Lamberto Avellana; script, Nick Joaquin; set design, Juvenal Sanso; special props and sculptures, Napoleon Abueva; choreography, Felicitas Layag-Radaic; costume design, Jose Hilario Lingan; lighting design, Teddy L. Hilado. Cast: Nick Agudo, Daisy Hontiveros-Avellana, Tessie Ojeda-Luz, Veronica Palileo, Ma. Rosario Revilla, Bernardo Bernardo, Nancy Araw, Edgar Sudario, Ella Puno, and Cris Vertido. Produced by the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). First staged on 20 Jun 1978 at the Main Theater, later Tanghalang Nicanor S. Abelardo, of the CCP. The play was also adapted into film in 2001, directed by Tikoy Aguiluz, starring Dina Bonnevie and Edu Manzano. In 2004, the play was staged by Dulaang Unibersidad ng Pilipinas (Dulaang UP) under the direction of Anton Juan Jr as a tribute to the National Artist for literature Nick Joaquin who passed away on 29 Apr. It was published in Joaquin’s Tropical Baroque, 1979.

Tatarin explores the pagan forces beneath Christianized society, and the woman power banked beneath macho imperiousness and women’s submission. The action takes place on the feast of San Juan on 24 Jun, around the mid-1920s. It opens on the veranda and front yard of the Moreta house in Paco, where reigns a thick old balete tree, at the foot of which flowers are strewn and a small candle burns. The whole cast is presented: Don Paeng and Doña Lupe Moreta, elegant ilustrados (educated native), and their sons; their cousin Guido, lately arrived from abroad; the visiting expatriates Micaela and Maggie, mother and daughter. On the other side of the social divide are Amada, the cook, and her husband Entoy, the driver; Kikay and Rosa, the housemaids; and the men and women who participate in the rites of the tatarin (summer solstice).

In act 1, Don Paeng, imperious male, asserts his macho thinking and supremacy over his wife, to which she assents. Entoy, on the other hand, usually a wife beater, reveals both fear and reverence for Amada, because “The spirit is in her. She is the tatarin … At such times she is not my wife. She is the wife of the river … of the crocodile … of the moon.” Act 2 is set at noon of the same day. The men, stripped to the waist, appear, dancing with the image of San Juan around the tree and throwing water at the spectators. Guido, who is with them, kisses Lupe’s feet, unsettling her with his admiration. Juanito, also unsettled after having joined the procession, grows from a boy fond of ice cream to a young man discovering woman. Act 3, set in the evening, uncovers the forces beneath the Moreta milieu. The procession of the tatarin is led by a young girl, then the mature woman Amada, and an old woman who dies and rises triumphant. Their San Juan is “a crude, primitive, grotesque image,” followed by “a female tumult.” Paeng is repelled, but Lupe is drawn to and joins the procession. Paeng chases after her and is attacked by the women. When Lupe returns, she is changed: wanton and flamboyant. When she demands that Paeng admit his fears, she is woman triumphant, and he, bereft of his macho image of self, grovels on the ground to kiss her feet.

Tatarin, which Joaquin calls A Witches’ Sabbath in Three Acts, is based on his short story “Summer Solstice” that has also yielded the ballet Amada by Alice Reyes, was written especially for the Avellanas. In addition, it is notable for the fact that four future National Artists participated in the same production: Joaquin, the author, National Artist for literature; Lamberto V. Avellana, the director, National Artist for theater and film; Daisy Hontiveros-Avellana, the actress, National Artist for theater; and Napoleon Abueva, the sculptor, National Artist for sculpture.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez, updated by Ronald H. Biñas

text:
(Three Marys). 1991. Monologues. Direction, Armand Sta. Ana; script, Noel Valencia, Nena Gajudo, and Armand Sta. Ana; stage manager, Fred De Leon; artistic director, Joonee Gamboa; music and sound, Joeprey Marian. Cast: Lita dela Cruz (Sebya), Ellen Reyes (Saling), and Percy Estrella (Sepa). First staged by the Barasoain Kalinangan Foundation Inc’s (BKFI) professional theater company Uhay at the Hiyas ng Bulacan Auditorium in Malolos, Bulacan, in Dec 1991. The original version, also directed by Sta. Ana, has been staged during Holy Week through invitation by the Living Faith Formation in various churches in Metro Manila in 1987; and by Dulaang Apo ni Lakan in seven towns of Bulacan in 1988 under Sta. Ana. For the BKFI-Uhay production, the material was revised to make it suitable for the Christmas season, adding a prologue and an epilogue.

Based on three short stories—namely, “Bakya” (Wooden Slippers) by H. R. Ocampo, “Tata Selo” by Rogelio Sicat, and “Mariang Tabak” (Maria the Bolo Wielder) by Nena Gajudo-Fernandez— Tatlong Maria tells the narratives of three women through three monologues.

 

In “Bakya,” Sebya waits for her husband Tonio to come home for supper. She laments that her husband has not been coming home lately due to his involvement in a protest for higher wages.She soon learns from the neighbors that a shooting occurred at the factory where Tonio works and that seven protesters died. Frantic and worried, she makes her way to the factory, bringing her kids with her. Her daughter stumbles upon her husband’s blood-stained shoe. Nearly brought to tears at the sight of it, she tells her family to head home, saying that Tonio might be there waiting for them. She tells her daughter to bring the shoe with her.

In “Tata Selo,” Saling, a young girl, recounts the story of how she and her father, Selo, were exploited by their landlord and ousted from the land they once owned. Selois seen trying to convince the landlord that he is still fully capable of taking care of the farm. The landlord ignores his protest, stating that he has already found someone else to till his land for him and turns him violently away. In revenge for his daughter whom the landlord impregnated, Selo stabs the landlord and is thrown into jail because of it. In jail, Selo tries to reason that he was only protecting his daughter, but the chief of police beats him up instead. Saling pleads for them to stop, but the chief grabs her and violates her right in front of her father.

In “Mariang Tabak,” Sepa, an elderly woman, confides in a girl named Elizabeth whom she realizes knows her son well. She talks about how she still clings on to hope that her son, Emmanuel, is still alive for she has yet to see the body. Elizabeth leaves and comes back with news that Emmanuel is dead—shot during a protest at a factory. As Sepa attempts to console Elizabeth, Sepa recalls how her husband died in the same manner: shot to death while tending to the fields. She then discovers that Elizabeth is pregnant and tries to comfort her, stating that crying is bad for the child. Sepa vows to be strong for her son, and to raise her grandson.

In the epilogue, the fates of the three women turn out for the better. Sebya remarries, a priest takes Saling under his wing, and Sepa fondly tells stories about her grandson.

Tatlong Maria was staged, mainly in arena style, more than 80 times in Malolos, and was the official entry of BKFI-Uhay to the National Theater Festival hosted by the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 1992.  Written by Athena Angela Aquino

 

Source

Chua, Apolonio B., ed. 1992. Unang Tagpo: Kalipunan ng mga Dulang Rehyunal sa Pambansang Pistang Pandulaan. Manila: Sentrong Pangkultura ng Pilipinas, Sentrong Tagapag-ugnay para sa Panitikan.

text:
1948. One-act play in English. Direction and script, Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero. Cast: Fernando Sison Jr, Celia Diaz, and Joe Viterbo. First staged by the University of the Philippines (UP) Dramatic Club on 10 Dec 1948 at the Assumption College Auditorium in Manila. Through the years, it has been restaged many times by the same company and later by its successor, the UP MobileTheater. Some of the actors who have acted in the play are Marce Viduya, Minda Feliciano, and Sergio Amante, in 1950; Monty Manibog, Mart Siojo, later known as Greg Martin, and Erlinda Cortes, in 1952. It was also presented over the radio with Marce Viduya, Carmen Tiongco, and Sergio Amante. It was first published in the Evening News Magazine, 1 Oct 1948, and later in Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero, 13 Plays, 1947. It was later translated as Tatlong Ulupong by Lilia F. Antonio for the UP Repertory Company.

Three Rats is a play about three people: Gonzalo and Nita, a couple, and Gonzalo’s best friend, Adrian. The story revolves around the theme of deceit and conspiracy. After figuring out that his wife and his best friend are having an affair, Gonzalo decides to destroy them. He goes away for two weeks, supposedly on a business trip to Baguio. When Adrian arrives, Gonzalo offers him a cup of coffee in which he has earlier dropped cyanide crystals. Adrian does not drink it immediately. He talks to Gonzalo to borrow money to cover a debt. The conversation between the two friends seems pleasant and innocent, recalling their friendship since grade school. Nita is nervous and jittery, for she knows that the cup Adrian holds is poisoned.

Although she tries several times to take the cup away, Gonzalo succeeds in preventing her each time. Finally, when Nita steps out of the sala, Adrian drinks his coffee and drops to the floor, as Gonzalo declares that their friendship is unto the grave. Nita hears the dreaded sound of death and screams. Gonzalo dials the number of the police station and gives an officer their address, telling him that in that house he will find three rats.

This is one of Guerrero’s most popular plays. Its exploration of human psychology, its compactness and stageability, brought a new direction for theater in the 1940s and the early 1950s.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis and Cynthia San Juan

article.value: 1948. One-act play in English. Direction and script, Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero. Cast: Fernando Sison Jr, Celia Diaz, and Joe Viterbo. First staged by the University of the Philippines (UP) Dramatic Club on 10 Dec 1948 at the Assumption College Auditorium in Manila. Through the years, it has been restaged many times by the same company and later by its successor, the UP MobileTheater. Some of the actors who have acted in the play are Marce Viduya, Minda Feliciano, and Sergio Amante, in 1950; Monty Manibog, Mart Siojo, later known as Greg Martin, and Erlinda Cortes, in 1952. It was also presented over the radio with Marce Viduya, Carmen Tiongco, and Sergio Amante. It was first published in the Evening News Magazine, 1 Oct 1948, and later in Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero, 13 Plays, 1947. It was later translated as Tatlong Ulupong by Lilia F. Antonio for the UP Repertory Company.

Three Rats is a play about three people: Gonzalo and Nita, a couple, and Gonzalo’s best friend, Adrian. The story revolves around the theme of deceit and conspiracy. After figuring out that his wife and his best friend are having an affair, Gonzalo decides to destroy them. He goes away for two weeks, supposedly on a business trip to Baguio. When Adrian arrives, Gonzalo offers him a cup of coffee in which he has earlier dropped cyanide crystals. Adrian does not drink it immediately. He talks to Gonzalo to borrow money to cover a debt. The conversation between the two friends seems pleasant and innocent, recalling their friendship since grade school. Nita is nervous and jittery, for she knows that the cup Adrian holds is poisoned.

Although she tries several times to take the cup away, Gonzalo succeeds in preventing her each time. Finally, when Nita steps out of the sala, Adrian drinks his coffee and drops to the floor, as Gonzalo declares that their friendship is unto the grave. Nita hears the dreaded sound of death and screams. Gonzalo dials the number of the police station and gives an officer their address, telling him that in that house he will find three rats.

This is one of Guerrero’s most popular plays. Its exploration of human psychology, its compactness and stageability, brought a new direction for theater in the 1940s and the early 1950s.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis and Cynthia San Juan
