text:
1905. Komedya in Filipino. Script, Fruto Cruz. Published in Manila by Libreria Martinez. It was staged by Tanghalang Pilipino in 1999 at the Tanghalang Aurelio V. Tolentino of the Cultural Center of the Philippines under the direction of Nonon Padilla; set and costume design, Salvador Bernal; lighting design, Jay Aranda. Noemi Manikan-Gomez and Julio Diaz played leading roles.

Tibag I starts with a battle between the forces of Emperatriz (Empress) Elena and her son, Emperador (Emperor) Constantino, and the pagan Romanos led by Rey Maxencio. Maxencio is struck down and the Romans defeated, while Elena watches from the palace balcony, and praises heaven for the victory.

 

In act 1, the Christians and their prisoners reach a cave with the image of Adonis, around it a flat ground with many crosses. There they find two men, 400 and 800 years old, who at first will not tell them where the true Cross is buried. Threatened with drowning, one confesses that he was with Malco, the soldier who slapped Jesus in the house of Annas, but does not have the answer. Offered the care of the emperatriz, the other speaks of the place where the cross of Jesus had stood. Elena orders the mountains demolished, and incense comes out of the earth’s core, glistening in the light, followed by a flock of doves. Three crosses are found, and the right one is identified when it cures a sick woman and brings back three dead bodies to life.

In Tibag II, the Holy Cross has fallen into the hands of the Moors, and is in the kingdom of Cosroas of Persia. The Christian soldiers promise Emperador Heraclio to defeat the Moors and return the Santa Cruz (Holy Cross) to the mountain of Calvary. The Christian Embahador Liviano tries to dissuade Cosroas from resisting their might, reminding him of the weakening of his position by the conversion of his only son, Siroes. Cosroas refuses, and a battle ensues, in which father and son meet in combat. Siroes wounds his father, who asks his son’s forgiveness before he dies. Siroes takes the Holy Cross and offers it to the emperor.

In act 2, Emperador Heraclio, dressed like the Nazarene and wearing a crown of thorns, carries the Cross of Christ and, like Jesus, falls thrice. Patriarca Zacarias observes a miracle: the emperor’s clothing and crown of thorns shine brightly.

In act 3, the Christians enter the mountainous terrain of Ciudad Hudicyaria, with the emperor carrying the Cross. When they reach the highest peak, birds come out of both sides of their path, and the Santo Ligno is placed on top of a mound, with everyone kissing the Holy Cross before proceeding. Zacarias orders the lands in Italy and Rome captured by the Moors to be seized and entrusted to France, following the teachings of Lucas, Mateo, Juan, and Marcos, and not the treaty that binds the lands to the Moors. Meanwhile, a battle ensues in Constantinople, with the Romanos capturing the papal throne and the pope surrendering the church’s relics. Later, however, the Moors are defeated by Principe Carlomagno and his army, who release Contantino and Constantinople. In the end, the pope and Italy, and Sultan Abdelmelec and his surviving men, kiss the cape of Haring Pepino (father of Carlomagno) as a sign of allegiance.

Tibag is the popular name for a komedya about the search for the Holy Cross, so called because a mountain is torn down (“tinibag”) in the search. Most tibag are unpublished manuscripts.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis

text:
(The Dead Season). 1987. Play with song and mime, in Filipino (Hiligaynon and Tagalog). Direction and script, Joel R. Arbolario. Cast: Emman, Jori, Cutie, Tiwi, Brenda, Carmela, Larry, Jean, Rommel, Samson, Dangka, Lavenia, Zaldy, Joel, Ricky, Roy, Scholars, Sakada (seasonal cane workers), Cowboy (American imperialist), and Mamumugon (peasants). First staged by the Negros Theater League in Bacolod City, Negros Occidental, in Oct 1987. In Nov 1988, it was restaged at the University Theater, University of the Philippines Diliman, and then at the Folk Arts Theater, Cultural Center of the Philippines Complex, Manila.

Tiempos Muertos is a subgenre of Philippine drama called dula-awit-kilos (play-song-mime). It was written and directed by Joel Arbolario for a Manila tour in 1988 but premiered in Bacolod City in 1987. The characters are nameless, though the actors might address their fellow actors by ad-libbing their real names during the play’s staging. Thus, the cast of characters is listed according to the actors’ nicknames, except a few, such as the “Sakada,” “Cowboy,” “Peasants,” and “Scholars.” The actors who had their own individual roles to play doubled as any of these, which were social class stereotypes following the conventions of the political allegory.

 

The cast runs from behind the audience onto the stage, wearing huge, grotesquely smiling masks, and singing a satirical song about the Maskara Festival, to the tune of “La Bamba.” The Maskara Festival is Bacolod City’s version of the Mardi Gras (Shrove Tuesday) held every year in October, when there is much drinking and carousing. Half of the cast falls to the floor in a drunken stupor, while the other half removes their masks to expose suffering faces that represent the Negros masses. In rhyming verse, they enumerate their troubles: children dying of hunger, the war between vigilantes and rebels, and the collapse of the sugar industry.

In a university library, the country scholars quote statistics, health studies, and the dictionary to display their erudite knowledge about the death of the sugar industry. Eavesdropping, the lead characters, scoff at their pedantry and explain to the audience the plight of the Negros sakada battling hunger.

In the hacienda (sugar plantation) house, the enkargado (foreman) tells the hacendero that there is a crowd of people outside looking for work. However, he replies that he is no longer hiring. The American Cowboy enters waving a contract for the hacendero’s signature and, in a singsong chant, offers a sugar quota. This brings to mind a chapter in Philippine history when the American colonial government gave a glowing promise of long-term security for the hacienda system in exchange for the Negros hacendero’s dependence on the American sugar market. The characters recall the old times when the plantation workers’ best meals were dried fish and corn meal. Now they are reduced to eating kamote (sweet potato) and field rats. The country’s economic troubles, culminating in the crisis of 1983, are traced to American machinations, including the coups d’etat beleaguering Manila at the time of the play’s staging.

The cast stages a protest rally, in which the slogans reveal the problems of Negros: the shutdown of the sugar centrals leading to widespread unemployment; low wages of those who remain employed; and the laid-off workers’ demand for a small piece of land on which to plant subsistence crops and vegetables. A series of explosions backstage herald the violent dispersal of the rallyists.

A mass burial is held after the massacre of the rallyists. Mourners enter, carrying corpses and lighted candles. This is followed by a series of reenactments of atrocities committed as a result of the new administration’s “total war policy,” aka low-intensity conflict: the brutalities of the vigilantes called alsa masa; the hamletting of mountain villages by means of bombing, strafing, razing, and military brutalities; mass evacuations and the consequent epidemics and famine suffered by the refugees with the children being the most numerous war casualties.

The grimness of the play’s content is lightened but not diluted by satirical songs, which are either adapted from folk songs or are original compositions with folksy tunes. The movements of the sakada at work or of those caught in battle scenes are defamiliarized as dance movements or enacted in slow motion. The poignancy of the vignettes is heightened by the use of bamboo curtains as backdrop, on which corresponding scenes are painted in a naif style.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero

text:
(People’s Teacher). 2014. Musical-drama in Filipino. Direction and composition, Roberto Mendoza; script, Glecy C. Atienza; production design, Hesus Bobot Lota. Cast: Glecy C. Atienza, Lou Veloso, Ruby Alcantara, Ronie Protacio, Rommel B. Rodriguez, Jane Alde, June Hebrew, Hesus Bobot Lota actors, and the Alyansa ensemble. First staged in Oct 2014 at the Tanghalang Aurelio V. Tolentino, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), by the Guro sa Sining ng Bayan as part of its program to train teachers and make them members of Ang Maging Actors. The play is a collaborative production among teachers and students from Metro Manila belonging to the theater network Alyansa. Prior to its Oct 2014 run, the play has been performed several times in various schools and communities in Metro Manila and Luzon through the support of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts and local government units.

Titser ng Bayan is a rewriting based on a play of the same title by Eric Torres. The original play was staged in 2002 at Tanghalang Hulyo Beinte Tres of Polytechnic University of the Philippines. It is about a group of students who try their best to learn from their teachers. Unfortunately, one of their best teachers leaves the profession to work abroad. In 2004, Atienza rewrote the play and changed the main characters to teachers themselves. This new version is an attempt to display how the teaching profession was reduced to commercialization and how teachers became the new face of the working class in the global age. This same material was updated several times and used as material to train teachers from Metro Manila on performance and production work. The 2014 version dealt with the implications of the K-12 program for the teachers.

 

Titser ng Bayan follows the story of Luisa and her fellow artist-teachers who created their own cultural group to produce a play that advocates the retention of Filipino in higher education. Throughout the play, the complex problems in the Philippine education system are gradually revealed and discussed. Luisa and her husband are artist-teachers who gave up their opportunities to work abroad and came home to pursue teaching in the public school system. Unfortunately, the husband dies while leading a teachers’ rally for better wages and benefits for teachers. Luisa takes on the task of raising their only child as a single parent, with the help of her parents who are teachers as well. Using creative approaches to teaching, Luisa catches the ire of the conservative school officials and eventually loses her job. Luisa’s father suffers a stroke and Luisa is forced to work abroad to support her family. But amid everything, the whole group powers through and successfully mounts their play in the end.

The collaborative work reflected the reality of struggle that the Filipino teachers are facing. The work empowers the teachers by making their own voices heard and their story told in the play.  Written by Tyron Judes de la Calsada Casumpang

text:
1997. Three-act play in English and Filipino. Direction and translation, Alexander Cortez; script, Adrian Cristobal; lights design, John Neil Ilao Batalla; set pieces, Jerry Araos; set design, Jo Marie Jose; costume design, Dante Nico Garcia; English dialogue coach, Chris Vertido; incidental music, Ada Bautista; martial arts and arnis instructors, Bot Jocano and Nathan Dominguez; devised additional movement, Paul Morales; mask design, Elmir Castillo. Cast: Joseph Pe/Kris Lacaba/Richard Quan/Joseph Lara (Bonifacio), Mario Magallona (Lt Col Pedro Giron), Mon Confiado/Noel Canlas (Fiscal Jose Elises), Lyviele Aguila/Banaue Miclat (Gregoria de Jesus), Fermin Villegas/Albert Reyes (Julian Aguila), Elmir Castillo (Maj Benito Torres), Nestor Leyson/Jacob Aragon (Procopio Bonifacio), Allan Palileo (Judge Adv Pedro Lipana), Jacques Borlaza (Elises), Fourth Lee, Dondon Subido, Raymond Firmo Narag, Jethro Joaquin, and Kenneth Lubguban. Written in 1961, the play was first staged by Dulaang Unibersidad ng Pilipinas as part of its 23rd season in 1997, in anticipation of the 1998 Philippine Centennial celebration. The play was performed in English and Filipino with over 120 performances. The play came into print, titled The Trial: A Dramatization of the Prosecution of Andres Bonifacio, 1963. It was anthologized in the Panorama of Literature for Filipinos, 1974, and The Ravens 2: An Anthology, 1996.

The play depicts the trial of Andres Bonifacio, the supremo (head or leader) of the Katipunan, until he was condemned to death. The courtrooms are the rebel headquarters in the town of Naic and Maragondon, in which the trial lasts for three days, 29 Apr and 4-5 May 1897. The trial is carried out by the Military Tribunal and the Council of War, both created under the authority of Gen Emilio Aguinaldo, the recently elected president of the dictatorial government at the Tejeros Convention where Bonifacio was defeated and shamed.

The play follows closely the conduct of real-life court litigations. Cristobal states that the work is “a dramatization, not a literal reproduction, of that historical trial.” Most of the events in the play are taken from the minutes of the trial of Andres Bonifacio kept by a general of the Philippine revolution captured by the Americans. That document became part of the Philippine Insurrection archive, which was used as a reference by the playwright. The members of the Military Tribunal and the Council of War were unnamed so the playwright inferred them from other sources.

 

In act 1, which happens on 29 Apr 1897, the rigging of the trial of Bonifacio and its results are insinuated by an ordinary citizen who thinks a sarsuwela is going to be staged in the courtroom. Majority of the scenes depict the intense interrogation and harassment of the witnesses by the fiscal Jose Elises, with some interruptions from the judge advocate Pedro Lipana. The first witness to take the stand is Maj Benito Torres, followed by Procopio Bonifacio and Julian Aguila. The trajectory of the interrogation is to make the witnesses corroborate the crimes imputed on Bonifacio—that he instigated an attack on the rebel soldiers led by Colonel Yntong in Limbon, Cavite, and killed two soldiers in the process; and that he is guilty of sedition, treason, and counterrevolution against the duly constituted government of the people. The last witness to take the stand is Lt Col Pedro Giron, an obvious turncoat, who presents lies and fabricated details to impress upon the court the categorical culpability of his former supremo. The news of an impending Spanish attack on Cavite cuts short the interrogations and forces the court to adjourn.

In act 2, which happens on 4 May 1897, Elises and Lipana continue attempts to condemn Bonifacio and his wife Gregoria de Jesus. Bonifacio argues that the accusations against him are all lies; that it is impossible to go against the revolution he himself started. He adds that Colonel Yntong’s band attacked first and without provocation. Gregoria de Jesus narrates in detail how Colonel Yntong could have hurt her seriously if not for the timely intervention of comrade Tomas Mascardo. Despite the claims of the couple, the council is not convinced and continues the trial for conspiracy, bribery, and treachery against the supremo.

In act 3, which happens on the last day, the Council of War decides that Bonifacio is guilty of the crimes, deserving nothing less than the death penalty. In the summation made by Major Makapagal, the secretary of the Military Tribunal, blind ambition is singled out as the motivation that pushed Bonifacio to carry out the crimes. Curiously, Bonifacio’s counsel, Placido Martinez, does not even attempt a lame defense for his client. When Bonifacio is given the chance to speak out his mind about the verdict, he delivers an impassioned speech—saying that he is innocent and could never go against his beloved country, and that accusations against him were all lies and fabrications.  Written by Romulo P. Baquiran Jr

 

Sources:

Cristobal, Adrian E. 1963. The Trial: A Dramatization of the Prosecution of Andres Bonifacio. Manila: P.B. Ayuda.

article.value: In act 1, which happens on 29 Apr 1897, the rigging of the trial of Bonifacio and its results are insinuated by an ordinary citizen who thinks a sarsuwela is going to be staged in the courtroom. Majority of the scenes depict the intense interrogation and harassment of the witnesses by the fiscal Jose Elises, with some interruptions from the judge advocate Pedro Lipana. The first witness to take the stand is Maj Benito Torres, followed by Procopio Bonifacio and Julian Aguila. The trajectory of the interrogation is to make the witnesses corroborate the crimes imputed on Bonifacio—that he instigated an attack on the rebel soldiers led by Colonel Yntong in Limbon, Cavite, and killed two soldiers in the process; and that he is guilty of sedition, treason, and counterrevolution against the duly constituted government of the people. The last witness to take the stand is Lt Col Pedro Giron, an obvious turncoat, who presents lies and fabricated details to impress upon the court the categorical culpability of his former supremo. The news of an impending Spanish attack on Cavite cuts short the interrogations and forces the court to adjourn.

In act 2, which happens on 4 May 1897, Elises and Lipana continue attempts to condemn Bonifacio and his wife Gregoria de Jesus. Bonifacio argues that the accusations against him are all lies; that it is impossible to go against the revolution he himself started. He adds that Colonel Yntong’s band attacked first and without provocation. Gregoria de Jesus narrates in detail how Colonel Yntong could have hurt her seriously if not for the timely intervention of comrade Tomas Mascardo. Despite the claims of the couple, the council is not convinced and continues the trial for conspiracy, bribery, and treachery against the supremo.

In act 3, which happens on the last day, the Council of War decides that Bonifacio is guilty of the crimes, deserving nothing less than the death penalty. In the summation made by Major Makapagal, the secretary of the Military Tribunal, blind ambition is singled out as the motivation that pushed Bonifacio to carry out the crimes. Curiously, Bonifacio’s counsel, Placido Martinez, does not even attempt a lame defense for his client. When Bonifacio is given the chance to speak out his mind about the verdict, he delivers an impassioned speech—saying that he is innocent and could never go against his beloved country, and that accusations against him were all lies and fabrications.  Written by Romulo P. Baquiran Jr

text:
(Sun Shining, Rain Pouring, Horse Demons Wed). 2011. Two-act play in Filipino. Direction, Josefina Estrella; script, Rodolfo Vera; set and lights design, Lex Marcos; shadow and puppetry, Don Salubayba; costume design, Leeroy New; sound design, TJ Ramos; movement, Stephen Viñas; dramaturgy/assistant direction, Bryan Viray and Jandee Chua; technical direction, Ohm David. Cast: Fitz Bitana (Jepoy Baybayin), Opaline Santos (Galis), Lucky de Mesa/Skyzx Labastilla (Aling Barang), Karenina Haniel (Aling Paqui), BJ Borja/Jeff Henson-Dee (Doña Geronima), Therese Carlos (Maria Sinukuan), Charlene Elechi (Maria Makiling), Jo Ann Teh (Maria Cacao), Bodjie Pascua/Joey Vargas (kapre), and the Dulaang Unibersidad ng Pilipinas (DUP) Ensemble. First staged in 2011 under the Dulaang UP’s 36th theater season at the Tanghalang Hermogenes Ilagan. It was restaged in 2012 under the UP Playwrights’ Theatre at the Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero Theater. The play is an adaptation of Gilda Cordero-Fernando’s short story titled “The Magic Circle.”

The play is about the journey and adventures of a young boy named Jepoy Baybayin and his pet dog Galis. Jepoy, together with Galis, leaves his mother Aling Barang at home with her laundry duties because he and Galis have been invited to a tikbalang’s (half-human half-horse creature) wedding. While it rains and shines simultaneously, they enter a balete tree amid the murky forest leading to a strange place. Jepoy discovers an underworld filled with magical creatures, elementals, nature spirits, talking animals, and other Filipino folktale characters. They meet the dwarf Aling Paqui, Doña Geronima, the three diwata (nymphs) Maria Makiling, Maria Sinukuan and Maria Cacao, tiyanak (changeling) ring bearers, aswang, santelmo (Saint Elmo’s fire), musicians of San Roque, pineapple, snakes, rat, cockroach, cat, and Kap, the kapre (tree giant). With the party ended, Jepoy goes back with Galis to their small house, cherishing the values he gathered from the underworld.

 

The children’s play adaptation raises and challenges the comprehension of children as an audience by tackling issues on humanity’s survival, class division, tolerance and peaceful coexistence of various identities, care for the environment, self-awareness, and the sense of humility to overcome the human being’s feeling of supremacy. The play highlights the richness of the Philippine folk literature that has been overshadowed by foreign popular culture.  Written by Opaline Rae B. Santos

text:
(Love Is Off Limits Too). 1945. Sarsuwela in Waray. Direction and script, Iluminado Garcia Lucente aka Dadong Lucente (1883-1960). The play was first staged during the annual feast of Tacloban City in Jun 1945 and was revised in Dec 1947. Up Limit Pati an Gugma is one of the 30 plays known to be written by Lucente.

The drama nga kinantahan (drama with occasional music), as Lucente calls it, tells the story of a couple named Duyak and Badul, and their daughter Buranday. Duyak, the breadwinner of the family, peddles local goods while her husband, Badul, tends to their small store of souvenir items and is always drunk. Buranday is flattered by the admiration of two American soldiers: a white Mr Henderson and a black George. Besotted by the language spoken by her American suitors, Buranday tries her best to learn English and stops singing the native balitaw, an antiphonal song. This fondness for America is also shared by her parents who want to barter their daughter for a supply of canned goods and American dollars. George wins Buranday’s affection but he needs to leave immediately when the soldiers are called to active service in their own country. Brokenhearted, Buranday realizes: “Up limit pati an gugma!” Her parents, on the other hand, are sorry they can no longer enjoy American goods.

In his preface, Lucente articulates that his main purpose for writing the play was to record the lives of the Leyteños (locals of Leyte) during the liberation of Tacloban City in 1945, especially their fondness for anything American after the war. Like Lucente’s other plays, Up Limit Pati an Gugma does not only depict the social milieu but also channels his critique on society, particularly, on Filipino women who “seemed to have been stunned, struck dumb by the new arrivals, and lost their sense.” Leyteños were eager to learn the English language and became fixated with American modes of dancing and fashion.  Written by Analyn C. Galvez

 

Source

Lucente, Iluminado Garcia. n.d. Up Limit Pati an Gugma. Manuscript.

text:
1919. One-act play in Tagalog. Script, Cirio H. Panganiban. First staged in Panganiban’s hometown Bocaue, Bulacan, in 1919. Because of its immense popularity, the play was restaged in the established theaters in Manila like the Teatro Zorrilla and the Manila Grand Opera House. In the 7 Oct 1927 production by the Compania Ballecer at the Teatro Zorrilla, the lead roles were played by Honorata “Atang” de la Rama and Jose Corazon de Jesus (Sebastian 1951). The script was published in Ang Dulang Tagalog (The Tagalog Drama), 1951, and Philippine Literature: Past and Present, 1981.

 

Years before, Veronidia divorced her husband Roselyo to be with her childhood sweetheart Cristino. Now, in the home of Cristino, Veronidia is driven by remorse and guilt when she learns that her former husband, Roselyo, is at his deathbed due to tuberculosis. Later, she learns of Roselyo’s death through Gorito, their only child, who adds that his father died mentioning her name. Veronidia desperately wants to be united with her former family as an act of contrition. Cristino refuses to let her go to Roselyo’s wake and points out that his own father did not like Veronidia for him. Roselyo disobeyed his father’s wishes even if it meant losing his inheritance. He has lavished her with jewelry and parties. Veronidia insists on going. Cristino, in jealous indignation, sees this as Veronidia’s way of reconciling with Roselyo—even in death. Cristino stabs Veronidia, who dies a martyr to her own repentance.

The play was one of the most famous melodramas in the first quarter of the 20th century. It tackled the topic of divorce and showed its dire consequences.  Written by Monnette E. Alfon

 

Source

Sebastian, Federico B. 1951. Ang Dulang Tagalog. Maynila: Silangan.

text:
(Let No One Blink). 2012. Two-act play in Filipino. Direction, Tuxqs Rutaquio; script, Layeta Bucoy; set design, Jerome Aytona; lighting design, Katsch SJ Catoy; sound design TJ Ramos. Cast: Suzette Ranillo/Sharmaine Suarez (Christina Medina), Mymy Davao (Melba), Doray Dayao (Doray Gutierrez), Peewee O’Hara (Panchang), Crispin Pineda/Paulo Cabanero (Molong), Ding Navasero/Nonoy Froilan (Santiago Sr), Ced Torrecarion (Alex), Nar Cabico/Gloc 9 (Gutierrez), Jonathan Tadioan (Lu), Marco Viaña (Marky Medina), Regina de Vera (Rhoda), Nicolo Magno (Santiago Jr), Ralph Mateo (Dino Perez), Remus Villanueva (Vic), Jiovanni Cadag (Pong), Lou Veloso, Sherry Lara, Delphine Buencamino, and April Joy Iñigo. First staged by Tanghalang Pilipino on 14 Sep 2012 at the Tanghalang Huseng Batute, Cultural Center of the Philippines, as part of the company’s 26th theater season.

The play opens with a game of mahjong by political party allies of the Perezes in the garage of recently widowed Christina Medina. Mayoralty candidate Molong pushes Christina to run for vice mayor. The game ends with the killing of Chinese drug lord Lu, the party’s alleged traitor. The murder serves as a threat for Christina despite the fact that the Perezes are suspects to the sudden and anomalous death of her husband. Forced to accept the task, Christina runs against her cousin Melba. The influential businessman Santiago Sr and the anti-corruption advocate Doray Gutierrez run for mayor as well. Doray dies upon falling down the stairs on her wheelchair, leaving her son, a Sangguniang Kabataan chairperson, who is slowly becoming corrupt himself.

 

At a bar, an initially happy drinking spree of the political families’ children ends in a fight between Dino Perez and Santiago Jr. The incident leads to the death of tricycle driver Pong who tries to protect Marky Medina, Christina’s son. As payback, Santiago Jr trains with his father’s friend Vic, a would-be lawyer who owes a debt to Pong’s mother Panchang. Gambling lord Alex, on the other hand, teaches Marky how to fix matters through money and guns. Marky, who gains power through violence, rapes his cousin Rhoda, his Aunt Melba’s daughter, and kills his friend Vic, turning a solemn procession of the town sponsored by the ruling families to another bloodbath. In their final statements, both the Perez and Santiago families resolve to retain their power, while the Medinas begin to wonder how they can start a life out of politics.

The play was devised from interviews and testimonials among government whistleblowers, political insiders, and bloggers. The play portrays the country’s traditional politics characterized by corruption, impunity, and nepotism. While the situations are quite familiar, the extreme violence that comes with graft and corruption and the filthy practices of political dynasties do not allow the audience to blink for even a second.   Written by Joanna Lerio

text:
(No Wounds). 1902. Sarsuwela in three acts, in Tagalog. Direction and libretto, Severino Reyes; music, Fulgencio Tolentino. Cast: Hilaria Alvarez, Adriana Nicolas, and Jose Constantino, among others. First staged on 14 Jun 1902 at the Teatro Libertad in Manila. Revived by the Zarzuela Foundation of the Philippines in 1970 at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) under the direction of Daisy Hontiveros-Avellana with additional music by Mike Velarde and with the following lead actors: Constantino Bernardez, Ruby Jose-Salazar, Aurelio Estanislao, and Minda Azarcon. In 1991, it was revived by Tanghalang Pilipino at the CCP Tanghalang Aurelio V. Tolentino, with direction by Dennis Faustino, musical direction by Chino Toledo, choreography by Agnes Locsin, set and costume design by Salvador Bernal, and lighting design by Dennis Marasigan. In 1994, as part of its sarsuwela series, the CCP published the Severino Reyes text, with additional text by Nicanor Tiongson, accompanied by cassette tapes of the performance with voices and orchestra and a minus one with orchestra for those who may want to stage the sarsuwela. It was made into a movie three times: in 1913, as a silent movie produced and directed by Albert Yearsley starring the Gran Compañia de la Zarzuela Tagala; in 1939, by Filippine Films, directed by Enrique Davila and starring Leopoldo Salcedo and Rosa del Rosario; and in 1957, by LVN Pictures, directed by Lamberto V. Avellana with music by Francisco Buencamino Jr, and starring Mario Montenegro and Charito Solis. It was published in Federico Sebastian’s Ang Dulang Tagalog, 1951.

The play is set during the last decade of the 19th century in a small Bulacan town. There, Julia lives with her widowed mother, Aling Juana. The relationship that began from childhood between Julia and her distant cousin Tenyong develops gradually into a strong love, unnoticed by Julia’s mother. One day, news reaches Tenyong that his father, Kapitang Inggo, and other men from the town have been arrested as rebel suspects by Filipino volunteers of the Spanish army and jailed at the provincial capital of Bulacan. In prison, Tenyong finds seven of the prisoners already dead, and his father dying from the physical torture ordered by the friars. When his father dies, Tenyong swears to avenge him, and leads the town’s able-bodied men to take up arms and join the revolution. Torn between his love for Julia and his love of country, and spurred by his desire for vengeance, Tenyong leaves for the front despite Julia’s objections. On the way there, Tenyong’s men attack and kill some friars and Spanish civilians who are waiting at the Guiguinto Railroad Station for a Manila-bound train. One of the friars escapes by boarding the departing train.

 

Left behind, Julia is urged by her mother to accept Miguel, a rich but stupid suitor, who is the parish priest’s nephew. Although Julia longs for Tenyong, the obedient daughter gives in. However, she sends word to Tenyong about her approaching marriage, urging him to rescue her from misfortune. Tenyong seeks the advice of his general, who assures him of help to effect his marriage to Julia. Tenyong sends back word that he would be returning home. Lucas, the message bearer and a comic character, goes home, weaving his way through a battle in which the rebels engage. Lucas, Monica, and Tadeo, Miguel’s father, and Aling Juana, play courtship scenes that serve as comic counterpoint to that of Julia and Tenyong.

The day of Julia’s marriage to Miguel dawns. In the midst of seeming gaiety, Lucas announces the arrival of Tenyong, who comes in bandaged and on a stretcher. Julia’s exaltation at the news turns into sorrow, as she cries and sings intermittently. Miguel demands that the wedding ceremony proceed but Julia ignores him and demands attention for Tenyong, who is pronounced on the brink of death. A priest called to hear his last confession announces his last request—to be married to Julia before he dies. Aling Juana finally agrees after Miguel and his father reluctantly give their consent. Julia and Tenyong are married, and immediately after the ceremony Tenyong gets up, not wounded at all—“Walang Sugat!”

One of the earliest sarsuwela in Tagalog, the play established the sarsuwela as the regnant theater form in Manila, dislodging the komedya of the Spanish period. Because of this play, Severino Reyes has been called the “Father of the Tagalog Sarsuwela.”  Written by Malou L. Maniquis

Miguel demands that the wedding ceremony proceed but Julia ignores him and demands attention for Tenyong, who is pronounced on the brink of death. A priest called to hear his last confession announces his last request—to be married to Julia before he dies. Aling Juana finally agrees after Miguel and his father reluctantly give their consent. Julia and Tenyong are married, and immediately after the ceremony Tenyong gets up, not wounded at all—“Walang Sugat!”

One of the earliest sarsuwela in Tagalog, the play established the sarsuwela as the regnant theater form in Manila, dislodging the komedya of the Spanish period. Because of this play, Severino Reyes has been called the “Father of the Tagalog Sarsuwela.”  Written by Malou L. Maniquis

text:
1940. One-act play in English. Direction and script, Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero. Cast: Raymundo Lorenzana, Fred Gonzales, Cory O. de Jesus, Jaime de la Rosa, Nati Nacu, Rosita Jose de Guerrero, Eliseo Bautista Jr, and Vic L. Escasa. First staged by the Filipino Players on 21 Nov 1940 at the St. Cecilia’s Hall of St. Scholastica’s College in Manila. It was subsequently staged by the University of the Philippines Mobile Theater from the 1960s to the 1980s. It was published in Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero, 13 Plays, 1948. It has been translated into Tagalog by Jose Villa Panganiban as Kailangan: Isang Tsaperon.

Wanted: A Chaperon, a household comedy, has Don Francisco and Doña Petra and their children, Roberting and Nena, holding opposing views on behavior and on family norms. The parents, for example, want their children chaperoned by an elder person on dates and at parties. They also feel that when a son starts to earn money, even while a student, he should pay for his own leisure. Meanwhile, Doña Petra decides to hire another servant and asks her manservant, Francisco, to hang a signboard outside carrying an announcement: Wanted: A Muchacho. A man soon applies for the job. Pablo does not look like a servant at all. Doña Petra tells Pablo to get instructions from Francisco, the servant. When she leaves the sala, Don Francisco enters, and introduces himself to the “visitor” as Francisco. Thinking that this was the servant referred to, Pablo acts the señor , and the flabbergasted Don Francisco declares himself the owner of the house. When Pablo finally meets the servant Francisco, he insists on being called mayordomo (head of househelps). The two fight over their household tasks. Doña Dolores arrives and immediately recognizes Pablo as a former servant who left without notice. She is there with her son Fred to complain about Nena’s behavior at a party she attended the night before with Fred, unchaperoned. The angry Señora claims that Don Francisco and Doña Petra have designs on her. Nena is summoned by her confused parents, and declares that nothing happened between them. When she turns an accusing glance at Fred, he admits to his mother that nothing actually happened. The embarrassed mother and shamefaced son leave the house. The mayordomo enters, smoking Don Francisco’s cigar. An irritated Don Francisco decides to kick him out of his house. Doña Petra changes her mind about getting another servant and asks Francisco to change the sign to Wanted: A Chaperon. Just then Roberting’s date, Lia, is seen outside the house with her father, who is carrying a gun. Don Francisco remarks that they would probably need to hire two chaperons.

 

A favorite piece in schools, Wanted: A Chaperon is one of Guerrero’s most popular plays. It won first prize in the University of Santo Tomas (UST) annual one-act play contest held at the UST Gym on 25 Sep 1947 in the production of the UST College of Medicine under the direction of Renato Ma. Guerrero.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

text:
(Strike! Strike!). 1972. Play in five scenes, in Filipino. Script, Bonifacio Ilagan. First staged by Panday Sining on 25 Jan 1972. In 1986 it was directed by Leo Rimando for MASA, a worker’s theater alliance at the Cultural Center of the Philippines Main Theater. It was published in Panitikan at Kritisismo (Literature and Criticism), volume 2, 1980, edited by Rosario Torres-Yu; and in Kamao: Mga Dula ng Protesta 1970-1986 (Fist: Plays of Protest 1970-1986), 1987, edited by Alfrredo Navarro Salanga et al.

Ignacio Aniscal is the leader of the first union formed and recognized by the management of American Sugar Products. On the fifth day of a strike and in the absence of other committee members, Ignacio alone negotiates for the workers’ demands with Mr Davis, company owner, and his lawyer, Atty Nubla. Ignacio turns out to be a scheming negotiator, who for a price sells out the workers’ watered-down demands to management. Upon learning the results of the negotiations, the union members question him, suspecting the possibility of a sellout.

From among the discontented emerges a new leader, Dominador “Ador” Garcia. Ador has already experienced being harassed. After the first strike, he and three others had been arrested for “resisting arrest,” and for “illegal assembly.” Once out, Ador inspires the disheartened members with his ideas on the real struggle of workers: it does not end with economic demands but in seeing their struggle as that of the whole nation and all classes against imperialism. He initiates the formation of a new union to serve as the workers’ weapon in fighting for their rights, and the drafting of a new constitution that would truly reflect their sentiments and aspirations, without the loopholes found in the previous constitution. With two unions existing, and only one to be recognized through a Certification of Election as provided by law, the management, with Ignacio’s help, tries to cheat by not including in the list some workers believed to be with the new union, and by including nonexistent workers’ names. The new union finds out and reports it to the representatives of the Department of Labor. The workers vote against Ignacio’s yellow union and for the new one, called Progresibong Kaisahan ng mga Manggagawa sa American Sugar Products (Progressive Association of Workers of the American Sugar Products or PKMASP). Gaining popularity, factory and plantation workers under the same company form their own unions based on its constitution. Management terminates Ador, and PKMASP members immediately respond by planning a strike. At the meeting, Zardo confesses to having once been a spy for Ignacio, but his conscience does not allow him to remain a traitor, nor to allow a new spy to infiltrate their ranks and sabotage the strike. He and another former spy, Dodo, identify Tomas as the new spy.

On the day of the strike, the union members receive the good news that members of their alliance in factories and plantations in the provinces have joined their strike in sympathy, and are staging strikes of their own. Afraid of even a single day’s loss in profit, the management tries to force eskirol (hired goons) into the company premises, but not enough of them get through the thickly manned line of strikers barricading the gates. Desperate, the management sends a letter requesting a conciliation meeting. Ador and his fellow union members see this as another tactic that should not blind them from the true nature of the workers’ enemy. They call on all workers to unite under the banner of national democracy, reminding themselves that it is their task as a union to educate, organize, and lead the movement that would eventually end exploitation of man against man. They end with a call: “Mga manggagawa ng buong daigdig, magkaisa at lumaban!” (Workers of all nations, unite and fight!).

A play about laborers and unionism, it was one of the important and typical plays staged by activist groups during the peak of the activist movement, months before the declaration of martial law.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis

text:
2011. Musical in two acts, in Filipino. Direction, Maribel Legarda; script and lyrics, Ron Capinding; music, Jeff Hernandez; choreography, Batche Tan; set design, Boni Juan. Cast: Timee Gorecho/Meann Espinosa (Ms Lugarda Martinez), John Emmanoel Moran (Richard), Ian Segarra (Erwin), Inno Martin (TJ), Anna Luna (Estella), J-mee Katanyag (Sophia), Julia Enriquez, Rico del Rosario, Norbs Portales III, Joan Bugcat, Nathan Nunag, Justin Mactal, Cheeno Macaraig, Carlon Matobato, Felicia Constantino, Jojo Atienza, and Elmer Cruz. First staged by the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) on 14 Aug 2011 for the company’s 44th theater season. The play was also part of the 4th National Theater Festival in Nov 2012. In late 2013, the production was close to having done 100 shows, touring schools and universities. In Jan-Feb 2014 it had a three-week run at the Star Theater in Star City.

The play starts with a rap performance introducing the difficulty students experience in reading Shakespeare’s plays. Ms Lugarda Martinez, the terror class adviser, forces her students to read Shakespeare’s texts in order to pass the final grading period and graduate from high school. The students are far from excited because they have their own concerns. Richard, an academic achiever, is gay and refuses to come out of the closet. Erwin is a stutterer and an outcast. The class bully TJ, abused by his father at home, writes Richard’s sexuality on the bathroom wall; he also pulls a prank on Erwin by nominating him for batch representative. Estella, who worries about her grades more than her classmates, is the angry daughter, left behind by her mother who is an overseas Filipino worker in London. The family of Sophia recently won the lottery, and with this came a shift in her perspective about her classmates. She becomes a social climber going to absurd lengths to prove she and her family are now better-off. As the grading period draws to a close, each student performs a monologue from Shakespeare’s tragedies. Richard faces homosexual bullying by choosing to recite Shylock’s “If you prick us do we not bleed …” speech from Merchant of Venice. TJ unravels as bully via the “To be or not to be …” soliloquy from Hamlet. Erwin finds his voice and comes out of his shell in defense of Richard through Julius Caesar ’s “Friends, Romans, countrymen …” oration. Estella forgives her mother—and herself—via Portia’s “The quality of mercy …” plea in Merchant of Venice. Sophia, seemingly petty as her crisis is, ties together a newfound love in the poor boy that is Erwin through Juliet’s “What’s in a name …” musings from Romeo and Juliet. Through the monologues the students get the chance to voice out their inner turmoil.

 

The set design of William consists of wooden armchairs piled one on top of the other, which function as both backdrop and as the shifting and changing parts of a set for the individual homes and particular spaces of each of the five characters. Alongside the forms of rap and hip-hop that William employs is the use of colloquial Filipino that is comprehensible to its target audience, the Filipino youth. The play featured compositions by Hernandez of 10 original rap songs, which are fusions of various music genres executed through various hip-hop forms. William received seven awards in the 2011 Philippine Legitimate Stage Artists Group Gawad Buhay!: Outstanding Play, Outstanding Ensemble Performance for a Play, Outstanding Original Script, Outstanding Stage Direction, Outstanding Male Lead Performance (Segarra), Outstanding Female Featured Performance (Espinosa), and Outstanding Male Featured Performance (Atienza).  Written by Katrina Stuart Santiago

text:
1955. One–act play in English. Direction, Nick Agudo; script, Alberto S. Florentino. Cast: Belle Gonzales, Jose Avellana, and Vic Silayan. First staged by the Civic Theatre Inc on 25 Jan 1955 at the Far Eastern University Auditorium in Manila. First presented on television by the Caltex Star Caravan on 24 Jul 1959 under the direction of Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero with the following cast: Rose Lara, Jose Ma. Gayoso, and Antonio Mercado. It was subsequently staged by the University of the Philippines Mobile Theater—first in English, then in its Filipino translation—from the 1960s to the 1980s. It was first published in the Sunday Times Magazine on 26 Sep 1954; in More Short Plays of the Philippines, 1957, edited by Jean Edades; and in Alberto S. Florentino’s The World Is an Apple and Other Prize Plays, 1959.

The characters of this play are Mario and Gloria, a couple with a child, Tita, and Pablo, former “partner” to Mario in crime (he has a jail record) before Mario married Gloria. The play opens with Gloria waiting for Mario, and then asking him for money to buy food for their sick daughter. Mario does not have any, and works up lies and stories (he had spent it on drink or another woman), but Gloria squeezes out the truth: he has lost his job, and has been without work for a week. He had stolen one apple that had rolled out of a crate he was carrying, wanting to take it home to Tita, and for that he was fired. He assures her that he has found a new job. Happily, Gloria prepares to send him off to meet someone who will give him a job as night watchman. Pablo comes in, and Gloria, who hates him and the past he represents, tries to drive him away, only to find out that he is the person Mario is meeting. Before Mario leaves, Gloria makes one last attempt to bring him to his senses, but Mario cannot be stopped. As he and Pablo walk away, Gloria cries out Mario’s name, knowing that she has lost him, and the baby, from inside the house, cries out with her.

 

The World Is an Apple won first prize in the one-act play category, English division, of the Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature for the year 1953-54. It pioneers in the depiction of social realities—specifically, of the problems of the urban poor—in English-language Philippine theater.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis

text:
(The Plan). 2006. Play in five scenes, in Filipino. Direction, Mae Quesada-Medina; script, Tim Dacanay. Cast: Soliman Cruz (Tatay Jessie), Gail Billones (Nanay Grace), Ian Segarra (Kuya V.I.), Julia Enriquez (Ate Mawsi), and Jason Barcial (Eman). First staged on 9 Feb to 4 Mar 2006 by the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) as part of PETA Kalinangan Ensemble production of five one-act plays titled Pinoy Wannabes during the company’s 38th theater season at the PETA-PHINMA Theater Center in Quezon City. The play’s script is anthologized in Davao Harvest 2, 2008.

The first scene opens with Eman or Emmanuel, nine, playing an X-box computer game as Ate Mawsi or Mao Zedong, 13, enters irate because their maid has left with some of her jewelry. The two are now left to themselves as their parents are both working abroad, their grandmother has been dead for two years, and their oldest brother Kuya V.I. or V.I. Lenin, 17, who has just started work as a call center agent, finds no more time to be with them. Eman mentions there is no need for her to help him on his assignment since he will just copy his classmate’s work. Their conversation leads to the issue of who will chat online with their Tatay Jessie and Nanay Grace when the schedule comes. The next scene takes them back two years. Over the phone, V.I. talks with their Tatay Jessie about Mawsi’s sudden mood swings because of her first menstruation. Eman, while playing with his toys, asks help from Kuya V.I. later with his assignments. Mawsi’s mood swings make her and V.I. cuss at each other. V.I. apologizes over the phone and comments about the pressure on him in making things work since their grandmother’s recent death. Tatay Jessie, now working as a janitor in Canada, makes V.I. reiterate the family’s plan to gradually immigrate—Nanay Grace has been abroad for six years and Tatay Jessie, four. Their conversation ends and V.I. afterward sweet-talks Mawsi into being a lady from now on and helping Eman with his assignments. The third scene is set four years further back. Canada-bound Tatay Jessie is bidding farewell to his children as he leaves for the airport and gives them instructions about how the setup is going to be. Tatay Jessie asks V.I. to teach his siblings to be independent. It is revealed that their Nanay Grace is now in hiding as an illegal alien in the United States (US). The plan includes Tatay Jessie’s task to get Nanay Grace out to Canada. He reassures them that if the plan is fulfilled, in two years they will be whole again as a family. The fourth scene is two years more into the past. Grace is about to leave the house to go to the US embassy for her visa. She talks about the prospect of working as a caregiver in New York. She repeats to Jessie their plan to prepare the future for their children, adding that with the worsening of the country’s economy, there is a need for practicality. Jessie and Grace lament how they started as activists against the United States but now are forced to leave for New York. As she calls on V.I., Mawsi, and Eman for an embrace before she leaves, she realizes how young her children are and decides not to pursue her visa application. The fifth and final scene is set during the Mendiola Massacre in 1987. Fleeing the massacre, activists Jessie and Grace find themselves hiding in an alley where they meet for the first time. Grace is frightened to leave the spot. Jessie convinces her to relax. They go out to the streets and pretend to be lovers.

The play’s structure, inspired by Harold Pinter’s Betrayal, starts at the present and in succeeding scenes goes deeper into the past. The play shows the deterioration of the Filipino family as the parents, former activists, turn into menial migrant laborers in the United States and Canada. The play was one of five one-act plays written by a new batch of playwrights under the PETA Playwrights Development Program in 2004, facilitated by Manny Pambid.  Written by Erick Dasig Aguilar

The two are now left to themselves as their parents are both working abroad, their grandmother has been dead for two years, and their oldest brother Kuya V.I. or V.I. Lenin, 17, who has just started work as a call center agent, finds no more time to be with them. Eman mentions there is no need for her to help him on his assignment since he will just copy his classmate’s work. Their conversation leads to the issue of who will chat online with their Tatay Jessie and Nanay Grace when the schedule comes. The next scene takes them back two years. Over the phone, V.I. talks with their Tatay Jessie about Mawsi’s sudden mood swings because of her first menstruation. Eman, while playing with his toys, asks help from Kuya V.I. later with his assignments. Mawsi’s mood swings make her and V.I. cuss at each other. V.I. apologizes over the phone and comments about the pressure on him in making things work since their grandmother’s recent death. Tatay Jessie, now working as a janitor in Canada, makes V.I. reiterate the family’s plan to gradually immigrate—Nanay Grace has been abroad for six years and Tatay Jessie, four. Their conversation ends and V.I. afterward sweet-talks Mawsi into being a lady from now on and helping Eman with his assignments. The third scene is set four years further back. Canada-bound Tatay Jessie is bidding farewell to his children as he leaves for the airport and gives them instructions about how the setup is going to be. Tatay Jessie asks V.I. to teach his siblings to be independent. It is revealed that their Nanay Grace is now in hiding as an illegal alien in the United States (US). The plan includes Tatay Jessie’s task to get Nanay Grace out to Canada. He reassures them that if the plan is fulfilled, in two years they will be whole again as a family. The fourth scene is two years more into the past. Grace is about to leave the house to go to the US embassy for her visa. She talks about the prospect of working as a caregiver in New York. She repeats to Jessie their plan to prepare the future for their children, adding that with the worsening of the country’s economy, there is a need for practicality. Jessie and Grace lament how they started as activists against the United States but now are forced to leave for New York. As she calls on V.I., Mawsi, and Eman for an embrace before she leaves, she realizes how young her children are and decides not to pursue her visa application. The fifth and final scene is set during the Mendiola Massacre in 1987. Fleeing the massacre, activists Jessie and Grace find themselves hiding in an alley where they meet for the first time. Grace is frightened to leave the spot. Jessie convinces her to relax. They go out to the streets and pretend to be lovers.

The play’s structure, inspired by Harold Pinter’s Betrayal, starts at the present and in succeeding scenes goes deeper into the past. The play shows the deterioration of the Filipino family as the parents, former activists, turn into menial migrant laborers in the United States and Canada. The play was one of five one-act plays written by a new batch of playwrights under the PETA Playwrights Development Program in 2004, facilitated by Manny Pambid.  Written by Erick Dasig Aguilar

text:
(Zsazsa Zaturnnah The Musical). 2005. Musical in two acts, in Filipino. Direction, Chris Millado; script, Chris Martinez; lyrics, music, and musical direction, Vincent de Jesus. First staged at the Tanghalang Aurelio Tolentino of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) by Tanghalang Pilipino (TP) in 2005. Original cast: Eula Valdez (Zsazsa Zaturnnah), Agot Isidro/Kalila Aguilos (Queen Femina), Tuxqs Rutaquio (Ada), Ricci Chan (Didi), Lauren Novero and Arnold Reyes (Dodong). Subsequent performances featured Joey Paras, Janvier Daily, Nar Cabico, K Brosas, Meliza Reyes, Red Anderson, Pinky Amador, Rocky Salumbides, Prince Stefan, Gabe Mercado, and Jonathan Tadioan. The source material’s cult following as well as the stage play’s overwhelming reception marked Zsazsa Zaturnnah Ze Muzikal as one of TP’s largest and most successful productions, enjoying seven runs that brought the performance from the CCP to the Philippine Educational Theater Association stage, the International Theater Festival, and the RCBC Plaza until 2011. Songs featured in the musical were also used in the 2006 film adaptation, Zsazsa Zaturnnah Ze Moveeh directed by Joel Lamangan. Zsazsa Zaturnnah Ze Muzikal is an adaptation of the graphic novel Ang Kagila-gilalas na Pakikipagsapalaran ni Zsazsa Zaturnnah (The Amazing Adventures of Zsazsa Zaturnnah) created by Carlo Vergara in 2002.

A clear parody of the popular Darna created by Mars Ravelo in 1950, Zaturnnah is the buxom and red-headed super heroine alter ego of gay Ada, the owner of a small-town beauty salon. Rejected by his parents for his homosexuality and stinging from failed relationships, Ada pines in silence for Dodong, the handsome straight baker next door. When Ada receives a mysterious rock from outer space, his comic relief assistant Didi recalls the popular Darna myth and urges Ada to swallow the rock and shout “Zaturnnah!” This transforms Ada into the superwoman Zsazsa Zaturnnah who becomes the town’s protector from small-time criminals, rampaging giant frog monsters, and interstellar colonizers, the Amazonistas led by Queen Femina, who are bent on enslaving mankind.

 

Staying true to its graphic novel roots, Zsazsa Zaturnnah Ze Muzikal employs campy and comic book aesthetics in stage design, costume, direction, and music. The space rock that Ada swallows—comically huge in contrast to Darna’s magic pebble—is made out of cotton candy. The thrust stage is designed to look like a large pink phallus. Didi’s near-death music piece monologue, “Nakikita Ko Na ang Nakakasilaw na Ilaw” (I Can Now See the Bright Light), is replete with half-naked, macho-dancing cherubs and ends in a wailing high note.

Zsazsa Zaturnnah anchors and updates the Darna story for the modern Filipino audience. Published and staged at a time when gender politics and identity were popular topics for literature, theater, and film, Ada’s plight as a gay man holds a mirror to how Filipino society treats and silences the experiences of this marginalized sector. But when Ada transforms and takes on the mantle of town protector, the story shifts into queer fantasy, where the previously shunned homosexual steps forward to become the hero despite the perils and thanklessness of the role. Just the same, in the fight against man-hating supervillains, the story is careful to draw a line between gender equality and acceptance versus vengeful gender supremacy and social engineering. At its core, Zsazsa Zaturnnah Ze Muzikal appeals to the audience through its witty quotable dialogue and catchy songs.

In the 19th Aliw Awards in 2006, Zsazsa Zaturnnah Ze Muzikal was nominated for Best Stage Musical, while performers Rutaquio and Valdez got nominations for Best Actor and Actress in a Musical, respectively, with Valdez winning the award. Millado was nominated for Best Stage Director.  Written by Mixkaela Z. Villalon

photos.desc: Tanghalang Pilipino’s Francisco Maniago, featuring Pio de Castro III and Pen Medina, CCP, Manila, 1988 (Tanghalang Pilipino Collection)

text:
1988. Two-act play in Filipino. Direction, Nonon Padilla; script, Paul Dumol; set and costume design, Salvador Bernal; lighting design, Jun Gomez; music, Manuel Maramba, OSB, and Herminigildo G. Ranera. Cast: Pio de Castro III, Alan Bautista, Pen Medina, Gamaliel Viray, Pocholo Montes, Dante Balois, Gigi Dueñas, Bon Vibar, Ding Navasero, Jovi Miroy, Ony de Leon, Oby Castañeda, Sonny Aragon, Joven Velasco, Joe de Castro, Dong Alegre, Melvin Lustria, Edgar Mendoza, and Joseph Dalope. First staged by Tanghalang Pilipino at the Tanghalang Aurelio V. Tolentino, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), on 5-14 Feb 1988. It was restaged at the Tanghalang Huseng Batute on 17 Jan–9 Feb 1991.

 

Francisco Maniago is composed of two acts: the first is on the Pampanga Revolt, and the second is on the fate of the revolt’s leader while in prison in Manila.

 

Act 1 opens with Kapampangan shipbuilders rising against their overseer and setting the campsite on fire. The woodcutters ask Francisco Maniago, a native of Mexico, Pampanga, and maestre de campo (brigadier-general) of troops, to head the revolt. He refuses due to his loyalty to the king of Spain, but agrees to present the grievances of his people to the Spanish governor-general Sabiniano Manrique de Lara if the people will no longer pursue their plans. The leaders agree but, without Maniago’s knowledge, they plan to use Maniago’s name to turn the protest into a war. The governor-general leads well-armed troops from Manila to Pampanga. He succeeds in pacifying the Kapampangan. The Kapampangan present their grievances and de Lara accedes to their requests. However, when de Lara sends three generals to present his reply to the Kapampangan, the three generals are captured and imprisoned by the revolt’s leaders, who had earlier removed Maniago as their leader.

 

De Lara reacts swiftly, surrounding several villages of Pampanga with his battle troops. Once again, the Kapampangan panic and they release one general. The formerly argumentative leaders ask Maniago to head them once more. Maniago orders the release of the two remaining generals and sends de Lara an apology. The latter says he will accept their apology only if all the leaders of the revolt will meet him in de Lara’s camp. During the meeting, de Lara reprimands but also pardons the leaders. He then invites the leaders to go to Manila, promising them important positions in the native army. The leaders acquiesce. Maniago prepares to go to Manila despite his wife’s protestations.

 

 

Act 2 begins two months after. De Lara receives news of a new revolt in Pangasinan led by Andres Malong who heeded Maniago’s call for revolt. De Lara then orders the house arrest of Maniago in Manila. After a few weeks, Maniago is put in prison. The revolt in Pangasinan is still raging, and news of a third revolt in the Ilocos arrives, headed by Pedro Almazan. Maniago is accused once more of treason to the Spanish king, his protestations of innocence to no avail. Once the revolts in Pangasinan and Ilocos are neutralized, Maniago is executed together with other revolt leaders.

 

The play is significant because it puts on stage the central and northern Luzon’s experience of rebellion against the Spaniards based on historical accounts of the 1660-61 Pampanga Revolt with Francisco Maniago as the hero. It also featured one of Salvador Bernal’s best designs for the stage.  Written by Ronel O. Laranjo

 

 

Source:

Tanghalang Pilipino. 1988. Francisco Maniago. Souvenir program.
